DOC.HEAD: Murdered Tourist's Family: `Police Can't Do It Alone'
DOC.TEXT: The mother of aslain Utah tourist testified Monday that civilians, not police, came to the family's rescue while her son lay fatally stabbed in a Manhattan subway station. The family of mugging victim Brian Watkins returned to New York from Provo, Utah, for the first time since the Sept. 2 murder to testify before the U.S. Senate Transportation Appropriations Subcommittee, which is exploring ways to pay for improved subway safety. Karen Watkins, her voice strong and unwavering, recalled what happened after a gang of muggers attacked the family and stabbed her son Brian, 22. ``I had asked the token booth clerk to call 911. He just ignored me. So I ran outside. There were two pay phones out there that were being used at the time by two gentlemen. And I asked them to call 911.'' A man told her there was another phone on the train platform. He ran downstairs with her, jumped the turnstile and opened an exit door so she could bypass the turnstile and get onto the platform to call 911. Mrs. Watkins said the token booth clerk ``never said a word to me at all. My son was lying not more than 5 feet from him. But he did not respond.'' The Transit Authority has disputed this account, saying the clerk used an emergency phone in his booth to summon police and paramedics. Brian's brother, Todd, testified that it took about 10 minutes for official help to arrive after the 911 call. Watkins, a former high school tennis star, was on an annual trip to the U.S. Open tennis tournament with his brother, mother, father and sister-in-law. They were attacked at a station in midtown Manhattan at around 10:30 p.m. A group of youths set upon Watkins' father, Sherwin, slashing his pants with a knife and stealing a money clip containing about $200 in cash and some credit cards. Brian and Todd interceded when Mrs. Watkins was punched in the face. Brian was stabbed in the chest. He collapsed while chasing the suspects and died 40 minutes later at a hospital. ``I don't think there was anything that really alerted us'' to the imminent danger, Mrs. Watkins said. ``Maybe, looking back, we should have been a little more careful as we watched these young boys run into the subway and not pay the toll. ... We just thought they didn't want to pay the fare and were running to catch the train.'' Eight suspects have been charged with second-degree murder in Watkins' killing. Todd Watkins read a statement on the family's behalf that said: ``The death of Brian Watkins has shocked the city of New York. It has made New Yorkers realize that there is no safe place in the city and that crime is rampant.'' The one-day hearing was held by Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., and Sen. Frank R. Lautenberg, D-N.J. Zenia Mucha, a spokeswoman for D'Amato, said the senator's office invited the Watkinses to testify. She said an airline donated airfare and a hotel donated accommodations.

DOC.HEAD: Study Throws More Dirt on Lawn Darts
DOC.TEXT: Scores of children are hurt each year by lawn darts despite a ban on the dangerous toys that have killed and maimed, a study found. ``I want people across the country to simply throw these things way,'' said Dr. Sara Sotiropoulos, who led researchers at The Children's Mercy Hospital in Kansas City, Mo. ``Even though the sale of these has been banned ... there (are) supposedly 10 million sets of these in garages'' across the country, Ms. Sotiropoulos said Monday in a telephone interview. Lawn darts were designed for use outside in a game played like horseshoes. They have heavy, pointed tips. ``They're just too dangerous,'' said Ms. Sotiropoulos, now practicing pediatrics in Bellingham, Wash. In the study, published in the September issue of the American Journal of Diseases of Children, Ms. Sotiropoulos and colleagues examined data on 76 children injured by the darts from 1973 to 1988. Three of those children were killed by the darts, and more than half suffered serious head injuries, such as skull fractures and brain lesions, she said. Congress and the Consumer Product Safety Commission banned lawn darts in the fall of 1988. Until the ban, lawn dart injuries were responsible for an estimated 675 emergency room visits a year, according to the CPSC. In 1989, after the ban, an estimated 439 such visits were blamed on the darts, department statistics show. The study examined data on children aged 19 months to 18 years, including 69 cases reported by the CPSC. Of those, 49 percent were hospitalized and 13 percent suffered lasting damage such as blindness or brain damage. The six additional children studied all suffered serious head injuries. They included a 7-year-old boy injured when a thrown dart pierced his cheek and entered his brain, Ms. Sotiropoulos said. The boy, who was admitted to the Kansas City hospital, contracted meningitis because of the injury and remains in a coma nearly two years after he was injured, she said. ``Pediatricians should educate parents about this hazard and encourage them to discard all lawn darts,'' the study said. The darts were manufactured by several companies, which are prohibited from making the devices under the 1988 ban, said CPSC spokesman Ken Giles.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Expert Sentenced To Life For Masterminding Wife's Death
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Jeoffrey in 5th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A computer entrepreneur described by a judge as ``a master manipulator'' was sentenced Monday to life in prison for persuading his teen-age daughter to kill his wife. David Arnold Brown, 38, displayed no emotion as Superior Court Judge Donald A. McCartin told the affluent businessman his sentence left no possibility of parole. Prosecutors convinced jurors that Brown plotted his wife's death so he could marry his teen-age sister-in-law, who he later tried to kill. ``The circumstances of this case are unbelievable,'' McCartin said. ``You are a scary person. For you to be able to get one of your children to kill your wife ... you make Charlie Manson look like a piker.'' In a separate matter Monday, Brown was given a six-year prison term for a jailhouse plot to kill his current wife, another man and Jeoffrey Robinson, the lead prosecutor in his case. The sentence is to run concurrently with the life sentence. ``You're just a master manipulator,'' McCartin said. ``I don't know how you could do that to another human being.'' Defense attorney Gary Pohlson said the sentences were ``exactly what I expected.'' Brown, owner of a computer company, was convicted in June of masterminding his wife Linda's death and persuading his then 14-year-old daughter, Cinnamon, to commit the slaying. Cinnamon Brown spent three years in a youth prison before she told authorities that her father planned the murder and urged her to carry it out on March 19, 1985. While the girl was jailed, Brown collected $835,000 in life insurance taken out on his wife and married Patricia Bailey, the younger sister of the slain woman. Ms. Bailey, a minor at the time her sister was killed, pleaded guilty to participating in the scheme and was imprisoned by the California Youth Authority in May 1989.

DOC.HEAD: New Teachers Idealistic But Fear They Lack Training
DOC.TEXT: A survey of more than 1,000 fledgling teachers finds them full of optimism that they can make a difference but fearful that they are unprepared for problem-plagued youngsters. The poll of teachers entering classes for the first time this fall, issued Monday by Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., found that 99 percent believe that all children can learn, and 83 percent said they were confident they can make a difference in pupils' lives. But 58 percent said they wish they had more practical training before entering the classroom. Two-thirds said they believe all teachers should be required to take a national standardized test to prove their qualifications. And 45 percent agreed that even the best teachers will have difficulty succeeding with more than two-thirds of their students. Three-fourths believe many children come to school with so many problems that it's hard for them to become good students. The survey was the eighth poll of teacher attitudes conducted by the insurance company since 1984. ``What is most striking ... is the enormous idealism with which new teachers are approaching their jobs,'' the survey concluded. ``Before getting caught up in the realities of the job, they have a very strong faith in what children, and they themselves, can achieve.'' Sharply contrasting with that optimism, a survey of more than 21,000 veteran teachers released two weeks ago by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching found that 61 percent consider morale at their schools fair or poor. It also found a majority souring on the progress of school reform. ``I can almost guarantee that unless government and other institutions start solving the out-of-school problems of kids, and unless our schools change dramatically to support teaching and learning, five years from now this idealistic and committed group of new teachers will be leaving the profession in droves,'' said Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, reacting to the latest poll. The 1,002 teachers surveyed by Met Life were selected randomly from a list of this spring's teacher college graduates compiled by the American Association of Colleges for Teacher Education. The survey was conducted by telephone in July and August by Louis Harris and Associates Inc. It had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points. Met Life said it plans to poll the same group next spring to determine their attitudes after a year of classroom experience. Keith Geiger, president of the National Education Association, the nation's largest teacher union, said the survey pointed up the need for all prospective teachers to gain classroom experience working with a mentor teacher. He also called it disturbing that one out of five new teachers surveyed felt unprepared to teach students of different ethnic backgrounds. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Copies of the survey will be available later this month for free by writing to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co., The American Teacher Survey, P.O. Box 807, Madison Square Station, ew York, N.Y. 10159-0807.

First U.S. Ground Unit Into Saudi Arabia Gets New Assignment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The first American ground forces to reach Saudi Arabia have been given a new mission that will take them away from the front lines but would put them even closer to any combat. The 82nd Airborne is ill-equipped to fight the strong Iraqi army. But because of its readiness for swift deployment, it was the first U.S. Army combat unit to hit Saudi soil under Operation Desert Shield. Now, as heavier, tank-fighting hardware arrives, the military wants the paratroopers to get ready for another job - perhaps to parachute into Iraq or Kuwait if necessary, top officers say. The 82nd - some members of which spent last Christmas in Panama - began arriving within a day of President Bush's Aug. 8 decision to send troops to help defend the Saudi kingdom from possible attack by Iraqi forces. With Vietnam-era M551 Sheridan light tanks, the 82nd would have proved no match for Iraqi forces, had they decided to continue south from Kuwait with their heavy Soviet tanks. ``In those early days we were as much a political statement about the United States position as a deterrent force,'' one 82nd officer said recently. ``For some time there were a lot fewer of us here than they were telling the folks back home.'' Another 82nd member, who like his senior officer spoke on condition of anonymity, said he was confined to base at Fort Bragg, N.C. waiting to be sent to Saudi Arabia when he read in the paper that his unit already was en route. ``Maybe we had Saddam Hussein fooled too,'' he said. ``I thought it was pretty funny.'' The 82nd was deployed in northeast Saudi Arabia to secure airstrips and port facilities for arriving U.S. forces. It also formed a thin defensive line against Iraqi aggression - about 150 miles from the Kuwaiti border. The unit's desert base was first named All-American City, then changed to Champion City because of Saudi objections. As other troops began to arrive, the 82nd conducted desert exercises to get used to the searing heat, and last week held drills with the Sheridans, which are light enough to be dropped by air into battle. Now, with heavy armored divisions from the Army and Marines taking up positions much further north, the 82nd has begun to pull back. ``Paratroopers don't fight tanks,'' a senior Army officer said this past week. ``It's time we get the 82nd into a mission that fits the unit.'' That new mission, according to sources who agreed to dicuss it on grounds that specific details and locations not be disclosed, is more in line with the 82nd's reputation as what the Army calls its premier ``forced entry'' unit. If orders come to take part in an offensive against Iraq, top officers in the 82nd believe the unit could be called on to drop into Kuwait or southern Iraq behind the occupation forces and attempt to cut off their supply lines. The unit recently ordered a parachute shipment from home. Rules prohibit saying how many members of the 82nd are in Saudi Arabia, but most of the 15,000-member division has been deployed. Over the past week, a brigade-size detachment from the 82nd was pulled back to a camp not far from a Saudi air base. The remaining units likely will receive new orders in the next two to three weeks, provided that expected heavy armor arrives. The pullback will continue unless hostilities break out. There had been talk of pulling the unit out of Saudi Arabia and stationing it elsewhere in the Persian Gulf region, but it now appears the new base camp will be within Saudi Arabia, the sources said.

DOC.HEAD: Rancher Touts Ostrich Meat as Health Food of the '90s
DOC.TEXT: Doug Stickler is sticking his neck out for ostrich meat. Stickler, who with his older brother Mike have an ostrich spread in the middle of Oklahoma Panhandle cattle country, predict meat from the bareheaded bird will be the health food of the '90s. The Sticklers have brought four of their flightless flock to the Los Angeles County Fair in Pomona. ``It won't be long until you see people eating Kentucky fried ostrich,'' Stickler said in a telephone interview Sunday. ``It's definitely the future.'' The Turpin, Okla., rancher said the meat is low in cholesterol, high in protein and tastes like steak with the texture of veal. Stickler said doctors and nutrition experts who have seen the future are investing in ostriches. Cost per pound - $10, since there are so few of the birds in the United States. But Doug figures in 20 years, he'll be giving the beef a run for its money. ``At first, we got a lot of teasing from the area ranchers. They thought we were crazy,'' he said. ``Well, those same ones that teased us have been coming down to see what we're doing.'' Stickler got into the ostrich breeding business in 1986. He bought his first birds from ostrich-farming monks in Oklahoma City. Two years later, the Sticklers moved their 10,000 head of cattle out and moved the birds in - about 175 of them now. The brothers have sold more than 300 chicks nationwide. Prices range from $500 to $3,000 per chick. ``You just feed 'em, water 'em and leave 'em alone,'' he said. ``With cattle you worked from dark to dark. Back home it takes 30 minutes to do the ostrich chores.'' Stickler said that according to the American Ostrich Association, there are more than 5,000 ostriches being bred across the country. The association predicts an ostrich population boom of 75,000 to 100,000 by mid-1990.

DOC.HEAD: To Saudi Arabia Via the Belly of a Whale
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The 265th Quartermaster Detachment of the South Carolina National Guard is one of the reserve units called up for Operation Desert Shield. National Writer Fred Bayles followed the 14 Guardsmen as they prepared for deployment and he was with them aboard the ``Sandbox Express.''

``Welcome aboard, gentlemen,'' said the Air Force loadmaster. ``You'll be flying Freedom Bird to the world's largest beach without water.'' The joke didn't register with the men of the 265th Quartermaster Detachment. After a night of delays they just wanted to get on the C-141 and sleep the expected 19 hours it would take to fly from Georgia to Saudi Arabia. But sleep would not be easy to come by this night for the South Carolina National Guard unit. The hold of the big cargo plane was packed. There was a scant two feet between the unit's four pickup trucks and the row of red web seats along the side of the plane. The 14 men couldn't stretch their legs. They couldn't lie down. They couldn't read in the dim gloom of the cargo hold. And they couldn't stay warm. As the plane climbed to 37,000 feet, the temperature in the hold dropped to the low 60s. The men rolled down the sleeves of their desert uniforms, buttoned up their collars and shivered through the long night. ``The only way you can do it is stand up for a while to get warm and then hope you can fall asleep,'' said Sgt. Hullie Cohen, who served in the Air Force before joining the Guard. The water purification unit from Allendale, S.C., deployed for Saudi Arabia late Friday after 16 days of training at Fort Stewart, Ga., boarded the plane just before midnight. Their M-16s were on their shoulders and they carried white plastic bags with water, rations, and a toiletry bag containing toothbrush, toothpaste, razors, shaving cream, sunscreen, bug spray, skin conditioner, lip balm, eye drops and deodorant. ``This is good enough for a vacation,'' said Sgt. John Williams. But the next nine hours were no vacation. The plane, the name ``Sandbox Express,'' stenciled on its side, looked huge on the floodlit runway. But once aboard, space was a premium. The web seats dug into the men as they tried to get comfortable. Some used their soft-sided canteens as pillows. Conversation was impossible. The engines' roar was hardly muted by the yellow foam plugs sticking out of each man's ears. Riding in the windowless hold was like cruising through the ocean in the belly of a whale. The plane stopped at Torrejon Air Base near Madrid for fuel and a fresh crew, giving the 265th three hours to wash up in the crowded bathroom, send postcards home and watch a Clint Eastwood movie on a big screen television set up in a hanger. Spc. Mark Rooker, 20, the youngest member of the unit, spent his time staring at the scenery. Rooker hasn't traveled much, and he was fascinated by the flat landscape. ``I'd like to come back here someday,'' he said. Back on the plane, the men ate an Air Force box lunch of ham and cheese sandwiches and packaged Spanish pastries. Some visited the cockpit crew as the plane passed from Spanish to French air controllers over the Mediterranean. Seven hours later, the plane rolled to a stop at a Saudi airport. It was 3 a.m. local time. The men scrambled down the ladder in full combat gear, carrying the South Carolina state flag. But the only one to greet them was a bored sergeant who led them past giant cargo planes and a road busy with truck traffic. They stopped at an intersection where a half dozen men were busy filling sandbags in the glare of a truck's headlights. The 265th watched, a little stupefied from their long flight. ``OK,'' said Sgt. Earnest Deloach. ``The joke's over. Let's go back home.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Driven By Radicals to Accept Capitalist Reforms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Soviet-Protest
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, driven by the radicals who control the Parliament of the largest Soviet republic, seems to have accepted their prescription for the gasping Soviet economy: capitalism. The economy's fall into depression was a major impetus. But the final push came from Russian President Boris Yeltsin, who won approval for the drastic reforms in the Russian Parliament this week and forced Gorbachev's hand. Yeltsin threatened to pursue his economic revolution in Russia - which contains half the Soviet people and three-quarters of the country's land mass - with or without Gorbachev's support. Gorbachev went along. The economic plan he distributed to the national Parliament on Friday ``95 percent coincides'' with the Russian plan, Russian Deputy Prime Minister Grigory Yavlinsky told his Parliament on Saturday. That is an exaggeration. Gorbachev rejected some key points and a parliamentary battle remains to be fought. But the comment was a good indication that the Russian radicals feel they have already won. In the five years since he came to power proclaiming the need for reform, Gorbachev has tinkered with the Communist system, trying to fill the barren shelves of Soviet stores. Now, he has thrown his support behind an economic reform plan full of ideas that warm the hearts of capitalists and horrify die-hard Communists: private land, home ownership, merit pay and profits. It also contains the thorns of capitalism: unemployment, factory closings, bankruptcies and rising prices. In the first months of switching to a market economy, the Soviet Union is likely to feel the full pain of these thorns. Gorbachev this week was defensive, thumping his fist in Parliament as he told Soviet legislators such radical change would have been impossible earlier. ``A year and a half ago, we were just talking about pluralism,'' he said, referring to the Soviet Union's dramatic switch to multicandidate elections. If he had heeded calls to change from a centrally planned to a market economy then, Gorbachev said, ``Do you think anything would have come of it? That's nonsense.'' ``We needed all that time to think about things. Otherwise, there would have been such a tragedy, such confusion in the country, that we never could have escaped it,'' he said. Now, however, the changes must come quickly, Gorbachev admitted. ``The old structures are falling apart and the new ones are not yet formed,'' he said. ``There is no system in the true sense of the word.'' His own economic reform plan says the country already has entered an economic depression, with rising foreign debt and declining ability to pay. The country's international economic position, the plan said, is ``catastrophic.'' As a result, Gorbachev's economic plan says the gradual transition to a market economy proposed by Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov would be too slow. Without urgent action, ``we would be forced to choose between hyperinflation and direct seizure of cash from the population and enterprises,'' the plan says. Ryzhkov went on national television Saturday night to argue for his moderate approach to reform and to insist on retaining, through 1991, the rigid Soviet bureaucracy that now runs the economy. In arguing against the Russian republic's plan, Ryzhkov predicted it would lead to a 30 percent drop in the country's standard of living. But Ryzhkov's plan, which calls for dramatic price increases on Jan. 1 without fundamental structural changes, is so unpopular that legislators have called for his resignation. And about 50,000 Muscovites demonstrated near Red Square in a cold rain Sunday evening, calling for Ryzhkov to step down. Still remaining, however, is the battle over sections of the Russian plan that would strip the central government of much of its power. Gorbachev has rejected that notion, including calls to transform the country into an economic association like the European Community. His plan also deletes the Russian call for republic laws to supersede national legislation. Neither Gorbachev nor any other Soviet politician has dared define the coming changes as ``capitalism.'' Instead, officials say it's time to kill off the dying authoritarian system and get on with what they call ``normal life.'' --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Ann Imse, based in Moscow, has covered the Soviet Union for The Associated Press for two years.

DOC.HEAD: 42nd Annual Primetime Emmys Presented; `Twin Peaks' Vanishes in Major Awards
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with final winners, quotes, network award totals. editing to tighten; Marg is CQ; should stand for AMs.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Emmys-List.
LaserPhotos LA9,LA11-12,14,15,16,LA20,22,23
DOC.TEXT: NBC's legal drama ``L.A. Law'' won three top honors in Sunday's 42nd Annual Primetime Emmy Awards show, while ABC's mysterious ``Twin Peaks,'' with 14 nominations, won the hole in the doughnut. ``L.A. Law'' won best drama, writing and best supporting actor for Jimmy Smits. ``Twin Peaks,'' a post-Modern tale of murder, assion and diner food in the Pacific Northwest, won only for its editing and costuming in non-televised awards Saturday. CBS' newsroom comedy ``Murphy Brown'' won for best comedy series and Candice Bergen, who plays the title role, won for best actress for a second consecutive year. Tracey Ullman, the British comedian who quit her critically acclaimed but low-rated ``Tracey Ullman Show'' last spring, won the most trophies of anybody. Her series and a special combined for six statuettes. In the network competition, ABC emerged with 22 awards, followed by NBC with 18 and CBS with 14. The Fox Broadcasting Co. won nine awards, and cable television's Home Box Office collected eight. The Academy of Television Arts and Sciences chose as best miniseries NBC's ``Drug Wars: The Camarena Story,'' an account of the torture-slaying of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena. ``This is a victory for him, too,'' said executive producer Michael Mann. Patricia Wettig, who plays the cancer-stricken young mother on ABC's ``thirtysomething,'' won the best dramatic actress trophy, and Peter Falk won the Emmy for outstanding actor in a drama series. ``I would really like to thank all the women with cancer who have shared their stories with me so wholeheartedly,'' Miss Wettig said. ``I shared their insights and their fears. I truly salute their courage.'' Falk, 63, who has played the rumpled homicide detective since 1971, told the Pasadena Civic Auditorium audience it was his birthday. ``You know, to get one of these things at any age is nice, but when you hit 41 . . ,'' he said. Marg Helgenberger, who plays the prostitute K.C. on ABC's ``China Beach'' won for best supporting actress in a dramatic series, and Smits, who plays Hispanic lawyer Victor Sifuentes on ``L.A. Law,'' won as supporting actor. ``I want to thank all of the Vietnam vets who have so graciously shared their experience with us,'' said Miss Helgenberger, who thanked ABC for its last-minute decision to renew the Vietnam series: ``You won't regret it.'' The award for best dramatic direction was shared by Thomas Carter, for ``Equal Justice'' and Scott Winant for ``thirtysomething.'' Miss Ullman was honored with a pair of Emmy awards in the music-variety category for her work as star and a writer of ``The Tracey Ullman Show.'' ``Oh, blimey, this brings it all full circle,'' she said. ``I miss the show a whole lot. Maybe I shouldn't have been so cavalier. Maybe I should have taken that ten minutes in the middle of `The Simpsons,''' she said. The hit Fox cartoon series, selected as top animated program in earlier awards, began as brief commercial ``bumpers'' on her program. ``I breast-fed those little devils,'' Miss Ullman told the black-tie audience moments after she and her show's writers shared the writing Emmy with comedian Billy Crystal and his HBO special ``Midnight Train to Moscow.'' ``In Living Color,'' the irreverent Fox sketch comedy show won the best music-variety Emmy. ``Above all, I'd like to thank my family,'' said Keenan Ivory Wayans, the show's star and executive producer. ``My mother and father are here tonight. This is for you, Ma.'' ``Cheers'' finally brought an Emmy to Ted Danson, nominated eight times for best actor in a comedy series for his role as womanizing bartender Sam Malone. It was the eighth consecutive year, every year the show has been on the air, that Danson was nominated. His other Emmy nomination was in 1984 for the TV movie ``Something About Amelia.'' Danson's award was presented by the animated family from Fox's ``The Simpsons.'' The series' obnoxious son, Bart, shredded the envelope containing the winner's name and thn jokingly announced himself as the recipient. Danson said it was ``appropriate'' to receive his trophy from cartoon characters. ``I feel a little weird. I felt like if it didn't happen this year it would be more embarrassing than ever before.'' Hume Cronyn, who starred in HBO's ``Age Old Friends,'' won for best actor in a miniseries or special. Barbara Hershey, the lead in CBS' ``A Killing in a Small Town,'' won the Emmy for best actress in a miniseries or special. Playwright Terrence McNally was voted the Emmy for writing in a miniseries or special for ``Andre's Mother,'' a drama about AIDS. Joseph Sargent was named best director in a miniseries or special for his work on CBS' ``Caroline?'' Vincent Gardenia won for supporting actor in a miniseries or special, given for Home Box Office's ``Age Old Friends.'' Eva Marie Saint took the trophy for supporting actress in a miniseries or special, co-starring in NBC's ``People Like Us.'' Alex Rocco won the Emmy as comedy's outstanding suppporting actor for his portrayal of sleazy talent agent Al Floss in ``The Famous Teddy Z.'' The supporting actress award went to Bebe Neuwirth, the self-possessed psychoanalyst on ``Cheers.'' ``The Wonder Years'' collected trophies for best directing (Michael Dinner) and writing (Bob Brush) in a comedy series. A special recognition was given to puppeteer Jim Henson, who died earlier this year. Leonard Goldenson, founder of the American Broadcasting Cos., was selected as the recipient of the annual Governor's Award. He joins such previous winners as Grant Tinker, Lucille Ball, Johnny Carson, Bob Hope and Alistair Cooke. The Emmy for outstanding achievement in casting was announced in August. It went to Randy Stone and Holly Powell for casting CBS' ``The Incident.'' The telecast was seen in more than two dozen countries. The academy estimated 150 million people would see the show outside the United States, including viewers in Bangladesh, Costa Rica, Nicaragua and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: The Comedy of Crisis: `Take My Mullah-in-Law ... Please!'
DOC.TEXT: ``A human shield? Take my mullah-in-law ... please!'' Barrump-bump! From the Top 10 lists of ``Late Night'' to the political humor of Will Durst and Harry Shearer, humorists are finding comedy in the Gulf crisis. On Aug. 2, Iraq invaded Kuwait and erased its Kuwaitibank Visa card's $10 billion tab. That same night, ``Late Night with David Letterman'' offered ``Saddam Hussein's Top Ten Reasons for Invading Kuwait.'' Reason No. 6: ``To impress Jodie Foster;'' No. 3: ``Didn't have enough fuel and supplies to invade the moon;'' and No. 1 ... (drum roll) ... ``Because the sand is always grainier on the other side of the border.'' Nobody said it's easy being a jester in the court of public opinion. ``It's hard coming up with the lighter side of Armageddon,'' said Will Durst, a comic who specializes in politics and writes a weekly column for the San Francisco Examiner. Saddam is funny, the invasion wasn't. ``When he invaded, it was tough,'' Durst said. ``I turned it on him and made him the focus: `You know Saddam is a bad guy because Switzerland is (angry) at him. Imagine: Switzerland, the Aunt Bea of the U.N.' '' `Saddam Hussein is such a bad guy that if he were an American, John Sununu would still be governor of New Hampshire.''' ``I call Saddam Hussein a yuppie. His motives are something we can all understand: Greed. I mean, this is a corporate raider with tanks.'' ``At least this guy has a motive we can relate to - because (as Americans) we never got past the suicide-terrorist thing. I mean, how do those people get paid? Is it a union thing?'' Durst gets serious, too: ``It's obvious that America would rather sacrifice its boys than carpool.'' Saddam, he said, ``is the symptom, not the problem. Taking out Hussein would be like whiting out a tumor on an X-ray.'' Political impressionist Jim Morris made his name portraying Ronald Reagan as an amiable dimwit, but these days his focus is George Bush and his handling of the Gulf crisis. Morris says it's a sensitive topic and he's very careful. ``I am a lot kinder to the president in this situation than I am when he wants to cut funding for school lunch programs,'' Morris said. Then, in the voice he calls ``a cross between Liberace, Jack Nicholson and Mister Rogers,'' Morris drawls, ``I don't hafta defend the way I been handlin' the crisis. M' door's always open. 'M never there, but m' door's always open.' '' Some top comedians aren't doing the Gulf crisis. ``Robert Klein has nothing on the Middle East,'' said his publicist Glen Schwartz. Richard Belzer said he's too worried about the situation to find it funny. ``My problem is that Americans have such a short attention span that they're going to get bored and almost will something to happen,'' Belzer said. ``I'd rather be bored for the rest of my life than have one 18-year-old get his head blown off because we're not prudent enough to conserve oil.'' Harry Shearer, a comedian, writer, star and co-author of the pseudo-documentary ``This Is Spinal Tap'' and occasional voice on ``The Simpsons,'' uses the Gulf crisis in ``Le Show,'' his eekly National Public Radio program. ```Le Show' is basically a topically oriented show,'' Shearer said. ``I'm almost obliged to do material about the crisis. For the last four weeks it has pretty much been the only subject.'' Saddam's appearing on TV with hostages prompted Shearer to imagine him savvier about Western media and getting Robin Leach to gush breathlessly over his lifestyle and ``pleasure palaces that rival the pashas of Persia!'' Then there was Shearer's sketch on the last woman hostage leaving blockaded Iraq when the Iraqis detain her, suspicious of her 5 o'clock shadow. It turns out she's a transsexual who has been cut off, as it were, from her supplies of hormones and depilatories. The Iraqis don't know what to make of her. Should she stay or should she go? A war without fighting is funny. Shearer acknowledges that Gulf crisis humor risks offending people when a good joke is suddenly made tasteless by events, but he's also quite careful about his timing. ``I do stuff so close to when it airs that I'm not going to get caught by surprise if something happens,'' Shearer said. ``I think it doesn't start to get risky, really, until body bags start coming back. Then all the equations start changing.''

DOC.HEAD: National Service Bills Stray from Sponsors' Idea
DOC.TEXT: The House and Senate have passed multimillion-dollar bills establishing a civilian ``national service'' corps for young people. But originators of the idea say the differing bills bear little resemblance to what they had in mind. ``The committee picked up the ball but forgot to run,'' Rep. Dave McCurdy, D-Okla., one of the sponsors of national service, said after the House passed its bill last Thursday. ``This bill is not national service.'' Nonetheless, the $193 million bill the House approved on a voice vote after long debate bears the title National Service Act. It now goes to a conference committee to work out differences with the Senate, which passed a $125 million bill that, although less costly, is more ambitious. McCurdy and other original sponsors hope the final version will include a provision in the Senate's bill, a $35 million demonstration program that will test their idea for linking national youth service with financial aid incentives. It's a plan that the House did not include. The chairman of the House panel that wrote the bill, retiring Rep. Augustus Hawkins, D-Calif., opposed the idea and said his committee ``categorically rejects any linkage between service and student financial assistance.'' The idea of a national service corps to encourage young people to do social works the nation otherwise couldn't afford has been bound up in political differences that go beyond pride of authorship. President Bush uttered the phrase ``a thousand points of light'' in his nominating speech and later refined it into a modest $25 million plan to establish a clearinghouse for community service - publicizing successful projects and encouraging new ones. Critics of that idea, however, concluded it would do little to actually support an organized effort harnessing the energy and time of young people to do constructive social or environmental work benefiting their communities. Moderate and conservative Democrats who lead the Democratic Leadership Council, a group formed to counterbalance what they see as the more liberal national party organization, proposed a more sweeping plan in January 1989. Their bill would have made student financial aid contingent on a full-time stint in the military or in low-wage community service. Their bill would have phased out current forms of student aid in five years. It would amount to a ``civilian GI bill,'' a civilian program comparable to the benefits that encourage military service, according to its sponsors, led by McCurdy in the House and Sens. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., and Charles Robb, D-Va. Their plan met stiff resistance, however, and in the Senate they settled for the scaled-back pilot program. Participants could receive vouchers for use toward college, a first home purchase or establishment of a small business - worth $5,000 for one yea's service. ``I haven't dropped my original thinking on the subject, but I do think we ought to go slowly and determine what works,'' Nunn said. Critics, who include liberal Democrats as well as Republicans, said tying aid to service would penalize low-income students while allowing the affluent to escape service obligations. Supporters, however, said low-income students already have to work to supplement the meager support they get from existing student aid programs. The House's bill provides grants to states and local school systems to encourage volunteer activity by young people, and establishes youth conservation and service corps to do environmental and social projects. Sponsors of the Democratic Leadership Council's plan say volunteerism is different and more limited in scope than what they have in mind. They say Hawkins' committee, with its ties to the establishment education and labor lobbies, basically added money to existing programs and came up with little more than a traditional youth jobs program. ``From our point of view, the House really missed the point of national service,'' said Will Marshall, head of the Progressive Policy Institute, a Democratic think tank that has pushed the idea. ``The committee missed an opportunity for a dynamic, fresh approach because members did not want to touch previously created, sacred student aid programs,'' McCurdy said. But Hawkins contends his bill will encourage volunteer work and ``responds to the same concerns that the president noted when he proposed his points of light initiative in his inaugural address.'' ``This bill,'' Hawkins said, ``is an attempt to make the concept of service more central to Americans' life and work.''

DOC.HEAD: Despite Deep Grievances, Saudi Shiites Don't Heed Iran
DOC.TEXT: Al-QATIF, Saudi Arabia (AP) - Shiite Moslems in Saudi Arabia, long considered a potential fifth column, say they ignore calls from fundamentalist leaders of their sect in Iran to fight the Americans in the Middle East. But many in the estimated 1 million-strong Shiite community complain that discrimination by the Saudi government has left them with a wrenching sense of their minority status. The subject is so sensitive that most Shiites don't want to talk at all about their treatment. ``It's such a difficult question,'' said one student. ``It's like punching us in the heart.'' Shiites interviewed at random over two weeks said they can't find jobs, no matter how educated they are. They also say their freedom to practice their religious rituals is sharply curtailed and they live under a cloud of suspicion as Iranian sympathizers. ``Nobody feels free,'' said the student, who spoke on condition he not be identified. The Shiites are concentrated in the Eastern Province which contains most of Saudi Arabia's massive oil deposits, font of the kingdom's wealth. Saudi Arabia's estimated 10 million people are overwhelmingly members of the mainstream Sunni Moslem sect. It has for centuries been at odds with the breakaway Shiites, who form the majority of Iran's 55 million people. The split goes back to a 7th century battle over who would succeed the Prophet Mohammed as leader of all Moslems. Ali, the prophet's son-in-law, was defeated and killed in a battle in what is today Iraq. His defeat produced the Shiite faction. Distrust of Shiites in Saudi Arabia is widespread, especially since many Saudis adhere to a puritanical Sunni sect, the Wahhabis. Last week, Iranian spiritual leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei called on Moslems in the region to fight a holy war to drive the Americans and their Western allies from the Persian Gulf. But like all Saudis, most Shiites say the threat from Iraq's Saddam Hussein justifies deploying U.S. troops in the region. ``The true believer, whether Shiite or Sunni, is against an American presence,'' conceded a Shiite gold seller. ``But they'd rather have the United States here for a while than Saddam.'' One of their main concerns is that the Americans might start fighting Iran and bring a resumption of the large-scale arrests carried out by Saudi Arabia during the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. The 1979 revolution in Iran that propelled Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini to power alarmed conservative Saudi Arabia. Khomeini wanted to export his Islamic revolution and called for the ousting of the Saudi monarchy. Radical Moslems took over the holy mosque in Mecca in 1979 and Shiites inspired by Iran plotted to topple the governments in neighboring Bahrain and Kuwait. Saudi diplomats overseas were shot, and there was a rash of bombings in the kingdom. More than 400 pilgrims, mostly Iranians, were killed in Mecca in 1987 in what the Saudis said was Iranian-inspired riots. Saudi Arabia clamped a quota on the number of pilgrims, citing renovation work in the Mecca. Iran claimed it was a deliberate move to cut its usual contingent of 150,000 pilgrims by two-thirds. In April 1988, Riyadh broke off relations with Tehran, citing its support for terrorism and subversion. A year ago, the Saudis executed 16 Kuwaiti Shiites for a bombing in Mecca that renewed suspicions they were still ``a potential nest of conspirators,'' a diplomat said. The 20-year-old brother of a teacher in this predominantly Shiite city was among those arrested at the time. Jailed for eight months, his treatment included beatings, cigarette burns and solitary confinement, the teacher claimed. ``They asked him over and over again: Do you have any connection with Iran?'' said the teacher, who spoke on condition he not be identified. ``The main thing here is that they're afraid of the revolution in Iran. If they were suspicious of anybody, they took him,'' he said. That suspicion abated with Khomeini's death last year and the more moderate policies of President Hashemi Rafsanjani that followed. But the pilgrimage dispute still sours relations. Diplomats note the Eastern Province's new governor, King Fahd's son, Mohammed, has worked hard to improve services in Shiite areas and been markedly less sweeping with arrests. ``The Saudi policy has been to win them over with kindness while dealing very firmly with any incidents that occur,'' said one Western diplomat. ``Dissidents are still put in jail to cool off.'' But Shiites said the lingering effect is an inability to get any government jobs in a country where most of the people depend on the state payroll. For decades, Shiites had formed the majority of workers at Aramco, the state-owned oil company. That's now seen as a security risk. Shiites say note of them have been hired by the government since the Iranian revolution. ``The main problem is discrimination,'' one man complained. ``If anyone from Qatif applies for a job, they take the papers, give him an interview appointment and then forget him. How can he live?'' Government officials deny there is any active dicrimination policy. The other big sore point is the ban on certain Shiite religious traditions, such as self-flagellation during the Ashoura holiday or mentioning the name Ali, a Shiite saint, in prayer calls. Sermons are banned in most mosques and it's impossible to get permission to build new mosques, Shiites said. Any violation is considered a political act and leads to imprisonment, the Shiites said. ``All Saudis are part of society and have to respect the feelings of the majority,'' said a Saudi prince, speaking on condition he not be named.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Allies Feel Sting of Congressional Frustration on Iraq
DOC.TEXT: One by one, lawmakers grappling with a U.S. economy in decline stood on the House floor venting their anger at American allies unwilling to reach into their deep pockets and help the campaign against Iraq. The rhetoric was fierce. And the main target was Japan. ``There is a toll-free number that our friends and allies call whenever they run into trouble: 800-USA-Free,'' said Rep. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D. ``Japan, more than any other nation, has rung up the biggest tab on this toll-free line.'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney had told Congress the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf region could cost as much as $15 billion. Budget negotiators, meanwhile, were locked in a struggle to trim $50 billion from the federal deficit. Suddenly, Japan's $1 billion offer of assistance in the gulf crisis began to look miserly, and the House responded. On a 370-53 vote, it approved an amendment last week forcing Japan to foot the entire bill for stationing 50,000 U.S. troops in the Asian nation, or begin losing them at a rate of 5,000 a year. Rep. Pat Schroeder, D-Colo., said the House was giving Japan ``a good swift kick.'' Two days later, Japan said it would contribute an additional $3 billion for international forces in the gulf region and for nations suffering from the U.N. embargo on Iraq. ``When you're tough, you get respect - and you get a response,'' said Rep. David Bonior, D-Mich., sponsor of the House measure. But some lawmakers saw it differently. Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Europe and the Middle East, said the House had hit the Japanese ``across the snout with a two-by-four'' - a move that was counterproductive to U.S. efforts to obtain more allied help against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Hamilton, who voted against the measure, said he had spoken to officials in Japan and they were offended by the House vote. ``It complicates our task even if it does not become law,'' Hamilton said. Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., shared similar concerns as the Senate last week approved, 97-2, a resolution saying the United States should prosecute Saddam and other Iraqi leaders as ``war criminals'' if hostilities break out in the gulf. He said he feared that other nations would mistake the non-binding resolution as something much more serious than just an expression of the Senate's anger and frustration. ``I appreciate this is a sort of an amendment that looks relatively harmless,'' Kerrey said. But noting that Iraq was holding Americans hostage, he added ``What happens if this, in fact, sends precisely the opposite message. I'm not skilled in the psychology of somebody who takes hostages and holds them.'' Similar consternation was evident in April when the Arab world was affronted when Congress approved a resolution declaring Jerusalem to be Israel's capital. Senate Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas supported the resolution but after meetings with leaders of four Arab nations - Egypt, Jordan, Syria and Iraq - realized the repercussions from the congressional action. ``These kinds of resolutions, hastily prepared and even more hastily passed, are nonsense - dangerous nonsense, and we ought to do something about it,'' Dole said.

DOC.HEAD: Feather Detective Always Gets Her Bird
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Ace feather detective Roxie Laybourne always gets her bird. Even when the evidence is a mere wisp of fluffy down. From her cluttered aerie on the top floor of the National Museum of Natural History, amid storage bins containing more than 600,000 specimens of stuffed birds, the hawk-eyed Mrs. Laybourne reigns as the nation's foremost authority on feathers. Give her a tuft of tail feathers and Roxie (nobody calls her Mrs. Laybourne) can tell whether they were plucked from an Australian palm cockatoo, a South African crowned plover or a Caribbean coot. Criminal investigators once tapped her 46 years of expertise in a murder case involving a wife who shot her sleeping husband with a pistol wrapped in a feather pillow as a silencer. Roxie informed authorities that microscopic traces of down taken from the bullet lodged in the victim's skull matched the feathers from the bullet-punctured pillow. The New York Times dubbed her ``Miss Marple of Eiderdown.'' Roxie squints knowingly from behind her gold-rimmed spectacles and whispers in a Carolina drawl as thick as grits with ham gravy. ``The fingerprint says you are it,'' she confides. ``Feather evidence says you might be it. The feather puts you at the scene of the crime.'' Roxie's knack for unraveling the puzzles of plumage was discovered in 1960, when an Eastern Airlines turboprop hit a flock of starlings and crashed shortly after takeoff from Boston, killing 62 people. Roxie's identification of the mangled feathers scraped from the Lockheed Electra's engines led to studies for the Federal Aviation Administration and major aircraft engine manufacturers on designing safer, bird-proof planes. A Smithsonian research associate, she roams the country testifying as an expert witness for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service against poachers, smugglers of endangered birds and traders who sell contraband Indian headdresses containing eagle feathers. Roxie also trained Doug Deedrick to become the FBI crime laboratory's expert on feather identification. ``We met when he was specializing in hairs and fibers,'' she said. ``I asked him, `Would you like to learn about feathers? Give me a call and come to my skinning class.''' Roxie's admirers include James Parrish, a research ornithologist at Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah, who once sent Roxie the bits and pieces of prey remains from a sharp-shinned hawk's nest in Alabama. ``She identified every one of them - yellow-billed cuckoo, Northern mockingbird, downy woodpecker and mourning dove,'' Parrish said. ``She's the best. She's irreplaceable. I don't know anyone else in the world who can identify feather remains like she can.'' Kenneth Goddard, chief of the Fish and Wildlife Service's forensic laboratory in Oregon, says Roxie's abilities are amazing. ``She can identify birds and feathers like they were her own children,'' he said. ``She can give their height, weight, sex, even eye color. It's fascinating.'' As a child in rural Farmville, N.C., Roxie spent hours exploring the outdoors. ``Growing up in a small town, I was always interested in anything that creeped and crawled,'' she said. She landed her first job after college at the North Carolina State Museum of Natural History in Raleigh in 1937. Her curiosity remains undimmed. She is enthralled by the delicate lacework of the feathers under her microscope, the pronged nodules on the quills, the pigment cells that sometimes resemble tiny Vienna sausages. ``I'm learning new things every day - that's what makes it exciting,'' she said. ``The more I delve into my feather stuff, the more I see that needs explaining. I'll never be finished.'' Roxie recently got her first glimpse of a ruby-throated hummingbird's feather magnified 1,500 times under the lens of her scanning electron microscope. ``It was so exciting,'' she said. ``It was like finding mysef in the middle of a great tropical forest I'd never seen before. It's as much excitement as I'd ever need.''

DOC.HEAD: Arts Could Win Trial But Lose War on Expression, Director Says
LaserPhoto CS4 of Sept. 15
DOC.TEXT: A gallery director who goes on trial for exhibiting sexually explicit photos by Robert Mapplethorpe fears artistic expression will lose even if he and his museum are cleared of obscenity. ``Other arts institutions see what the Contemporary Arts Center had to go through to prove itself innocent of the charges,'' said director Dennis Barrie. ``I honestly do believe a lot of people won't do what they believe in, as a result of this.'' Art authorities and experts in constitutional law have said they expect the gallery ultimately to be cleared, even if it loses the trial set to begin Sept. 24 in Hamilton County Municipal Court. The real impact will come if a prosecutor elsewhere follows Cincinnati's lead, said Floyd Abrams, a New York City lawyer who defends First Amendment cases. ``One more indictment by one more prosecutor, let alone two convictions, would change the entire picture for museums nationwide,'' he said. ``I think a lot rides on the result of the Cincinnati prosecution.'' The gallery is the first ever indicted on obscenity charges. They stem from a six-week, 175-item of Mapplethorpe's photos, seven of which led to the charges. The photos, which include homosexual and sadomasochistic images, stirred debate last year over federal funding of art. The National Endowment for the Arts, which had supported Mapplethorpe's works, adopted a requirement that grant recipients pledge not to use money for works that might be considered obscene. Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., had pressed for the policy. Barrie faces up to a year in jail and $2,000 in fines. The gallery faces $10,000 in fines. The Hamilton County prosecutor's office said it is duty-bound to enforce Ohio's obscenity laws. ``If there's a criminal violation, we have to look into it. It's that simple,'' said spokesman Chip Gerhardt. ``To say nothing about it would be a form of acceptance. We don't want that. The people don't want that,'' said Monty Lobb Jr., president of Citizens Concerned for Community Values in Cincinnati. It has denounced Mapplethorpe's photos. The case against Barrie and the gallery is just one of a series of challenges this year to art works: -In April, federal agents in San Francisco seized photographer Jock Sturges' pictures of ``naturists.'' The man who processed the film faces child pornography charges, and a federal grand jury is investigating Sturges. -In July, a federal prosecutor in Maine dropped a court fight to destroy a 1962 photograph of a nude father and son by photographer Walter Chappell. The picture was seized from a traveler crossing the Canadian border. -In August, a Los Angeles lawyer who calls himself a devout Christian filed a lawsuit over a government grant to a photo exhibit by David Wojnarowicz. The lawyer said the exhibit depicted Jesus Christ as an intravenous drug user. -On Sept. 5, a Boston court rejected a request by the conservative American Family Association to file obscenity charges against the Institute for Contemporary Art, where the Mapplethorpe exhibit opened Aug. 1. The Contemporary Arts Center has spent $95,000 on legal bills and budgeted $100,000 more for legal costs in the fiscal year that began Sept. 7. The gallery's legal defense fund has received grants from the J. Roderick MacArthur Foundation and the Nathan Cummings Foundation. The Rockefeller Foundation has given $50,000 to replace money that was spent on legal costs.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Seeks More U.S. Defense Aid to Balance U.S. Aid to Saudis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top prospects uncertain. Meeting with Cheney set for 3 p.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: Israel wants more money and weapons from the United States so it can keep up with the massive arms sales to Saudi Arabia planned by the Bush administration. Israeli Defense Minister Moshe Arens planned to deliver that message to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and congressional leaders today. The administration is preparing to ask Congress to approve the sale of $18 billion worth of planes, tanks and other weapons to Saudi Arabia over the next few years, sources say. Israel has not been consulted about the deal, Arens said in a speech Sunday to a conference of the Washington Institute for Near East Studies. ``I hope there will be discussions with us because I'm sure that there cannot be anybody in Washington that does not feel that that kind of an arms deal would have an effect on Israel that couldn't be positive,'' Arens told the gathering at Wye Plantation, Md. ``And we would have to have discussions to see what could be done ... that will provide the necessary equilibrium,'' he added. Technically, Israel and Saudi Arabia are in a state of war although the two sides have not fought directly since 1948. The Saudis fund the Palestine Liberation Organization and others among Israel's enemies. The United States has for years supplied Israel with sufficient weapons to maintain a qualitative edge over the far larger armies of its hostile Arab neighbors. But in recent years the United States has eroded Israel's advantage by selling the Arabs everything it sells Israel, Arens said. As a result, Israel relies increasingly on its home-grown defense industry. Israeli sources say Israel will ask for an increase in the $1.8 billion the United States gives Israel annually in defense aid. The increase would be used to help Israel develop and produce new weapons. Arens also wants answers on a shopping list Israel gave the administration several weeks ago, including F-15 and F-16 fighter jets and a leasing arrangement for U.S.-made Patriot anti-missile missiles, said the sources. One of the thorniest issues on Arens' agenda is Israel's desire for direct access to U.S. spy satellites orbiting over the Arab world, the sources say. The United States has balked at giving Israel raw satellite photos so Israel may ask instead for processed pictures or any other intelligence information the United States is willing to provide, the sources said. Arens warned that the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the resulting arms sales to the Saudis and other U.S. allies were escalating the arms race in the Mideast and destabilizing the region. He said Israel would be willing to discuss a halt of the arms flow into the area, if its Arab enemies did the same. ``We don't have the resources to compete'' with Saudi arms acquisitions and those of other oil-rich Arab states, Arens said.

DOC.HEAD: Emmy Show Dull Again But Efficent
With PM-Emmys, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Knocking the annual Emmy Awards show has become sort of like drop-kicking a wounded butterfly. So let us be charitable this time and say that Sunday's edition of network television's annual back-pat festival was tolerable, efficient and ran only 14 minutes beyond its allotted three hours on the Fox network. It offered one funny animated guest-presenting bit by Fox's ``The Simpsons;'' a lovely but too short tribute to the late Jim Henson, and speeches that generally were brief and to the point. There also was one surprise. It was that David Lynch's quirky ``Twin Peaks,'' so loudly hailed by those who can spell postmodern, got no Emmy in the major categories. It must be that Hollywood looked at ratings of the ABC series and decided it's time to be derriere garde. With three hosts - Candice Bergen of ``Murphy Brown, who won a best-actress Emmy, Jay Leno and NBC News' Jane Pauley - Sunday's ceremonies from the tiny republic of Pasadena were akin to last year's effort - dull but painless. The specially made ``Simpsons'' clip in the show's first hour was nifty, though. The goggle-eyed clan was on hand to present, through the magic of animation, the award for best actor in a comedy series. Little Bart Simpson, who wanted the honor that Ted Danson of ``Cheers'' finally won, tore up the envelope and scattered the pieces. Lisa, his good little sister, tried to make the best of things. ``Members of the creative community,'' she said, ``this could be a blessing in disguise - a chance to do away with winner and loser.'' If members of the black-tie audience felt that competition should be a thing of the past and all the other winning envelopes torn up, she said, ``then stand up and applaud.'' Everyone remained seated. Nobody applauded. And you wonder why television gives you shows like ``thirtysomething.'' Sunday's here's-your-statue festival was put together by some TV veterans, including executive producer Martin Starger andco-writer Buz Kohan. Their labors yielded an evening that was professional and crisp enough. But it was oddly short on show-biz flash. Jay Leno, normally sharp, recycled a few Saddam Hussein jokes and seemed to be saving the good stuff for Christmas. Jane Pauley, resplendent in a reddish satin jacket, seemed out of place. She just smiled, introduced presenters, then withdrew. There were no lavish production numbers, no impassioned pleas to save the Brazilian rain forest, the whales, or even 2 Live Crew. Although double-winner Tracey Ullman was merry and showed welcome signs of life, the proceedings generally were so sedate that MTV's Downtown Julie Brown wore a black derby. Oh well. Things could have been worse. They could have broadcast the awards for all 78 categories, including ``outstanding achievement in hairstyling for a miniseries or a special.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Walter Cronkite has begun writing his memoirs at last. He signed a contract for his autobiography 20 years ago. ``I have probably the longest existing book contract in the history of publishing,'' the former CBS anchorman said in the Sept. 24 issue of People magazine. The 73-year-old Cronkite, who signed a contract with publisher Alfred A. Knopf Inc., finally got around to working on the book this summer. It won't be a tell-all about CBS News. ``It seems to me there have been enough books about all that,'' he said. And the title? ``I'm going to have to fight the publishers to keep them from calling it `And That's the Way It Is.' I think we might come up with something more imaginative.'' --- MONTGOMERY, Ala. (AP) - Charlton Heston, who has been stumping for two Republican congressmen, will relinquish the podium soon to take on the role of Sherlock Holmes. Heston said Sunday he's traveling to London this month to begin work on ``Crucifer of Blood,'' a film based on Paul Giovanni's play about the Arthur Conan Doyle sleuth. The movie will be directed by his son, Fraser Heston. Heston starred in a 1980 stage production of ``Crucifer of Blood.'' Earlier Sunday, Heston spoke at a rally for Rep. Bill Dickinson of Montgomery, seeking his 14th term. On Saturday, he spoke in support of Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., at a news conference in Atlanta. The Oscar-winning actor, who has long been active in politics, praised Dickinson and Gingrich for their ``energy, wisdom and influence.'' --- NEW YORK (AP) - Hotel queen Leona M. Helmsley took out a full-page ad in today's The New York Times to chastise Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein for referring to hostages as ``guests.'' ``I know something about how one is supposed to treat guests, Mr. Hussein,'' she said. ``I have been inviting guests from around the world into my hotels for 18 years. The people held in your grasp are not guests.'' Helmsley appealed to Saddam to release foreigners who have been prevented from leaving Iraq or Kuwait since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``I can make one recommendation that I have never made in all the years I have been welcoming people: Mr. Hussein, it is time to check out,'' she said. Mrs. Helmsley, 70, who is president of Helmsley Hotels, was convicted in 1989 of federal tax fraud charges and was sentenced to four years in prison and fined $7.1 million. She is free on appeal. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Ed McMahon and his wife, Victoria, have cleared a final obstacle delaying their divorce. A statement issued by the McMahons said they had ``reached an amicable agreement to our mutual satisfaction.'' The obstacle was not described and there was no elaboration. McMahon, the 67-year-old ``Tonight Show'' sidekick to Johnny Carson and host of the ``Star Search'' talent show, filed for divorce in 1989 after 13 years of marriage. The couple have an adopted daughter, Katherine. After a hearing a year ago, Mrs. McMahon's attorney said McMahon had agreed to child and spousal support of $50,000 a month and shared custody of Katherine. The lawyer said the divorce would not become final until at least January 1991 for tax reasons. --- WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. (AP) - The business manager for New Kids on the Block says his briefcase containing $100,000 in cash was stolen as he checked out of a hotel with the pop group, police said. James Rossi reported to police that the briefcase vanished Saturday at the Bel Age Hotel, where the group spent the night after performing to a sold-out crowd Friday at Dodger Stadium. Rossi said he put the briefcase on the floor beside him to sign out and when he turned moments later it was gone, said sheriff's Deputy George Ducoulombier. Authorities said they were uncertain why Rossi had so much cash. Calls to the group's management agency, Dick Scott Entertainment in New York, went unanswered Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Twenty-Six Children, Seven Adults Drown In Honduras Bus Accident
DOC.TEXT: Rescue workers searched today for four children lost when a bus carrying preschoolers home from a party overturned in a flash flood as it forded a river, killing at least 43 people. The dead - 26 children and all seven adults aboard - included an American missionary who was driving the bus across the rain-swollen Rio Grande on Sunday when it was hit by the flood wave and pushed downstream, authorities said. National Fire Department spokesman Lt. Frank Medina said three children were rescued after the midafternoon accident, which occurred between the villages of El Naranjal and Cantarranas 80 miles southeast of Tegucigalpa. The vehicle was carrying 33 children between the ages of 3 and 6 and seven adults, said Red Cross spokesman Jordan Peralta. Among the victims was American missionary Dorothy Saunder Hood, 52, wife of the Rev. George B. Hood, Medina said by telephone. The children were on their way back to El Naranjal from a party at Cantarranas, a few miles away, and the bus was crossing the usually shallow Rio Grande when the flash flood hit, he said. There is no bridge over the river on that road. ``The accident occurred when the vehicle was in the middle of the river ... and it was dragged along with all the passengers,'' Peralta said.

DOC.HEAD: Three Indian Slayings Bring Charges of Prejudice
DOC.TEXT: The mysterious deaths of three young American Indians in 18 months have produced no arrests, and some Indians think they know why. ``If three young, white college students, two of whose parents were professors, had been killed or died in similar circumstances, do you think they'd have taken the same attitude?'' asked Don Bread, father of one victim and law instructor at Haskell Indian Junior College here. ``From my side of the fence, I'd say no.'' When Christopher Bread became the third young Indian to be found dead recently, Indians wondered if a killer wasn't targeting them. There are about 3,000 Indians in this fast-growing city of 56,000. The fear has waned, but the city's Indians still contend police were too quick to discount foul play because two of the three victims had blood-alcohol levels above the legal limit, evoking the stereotype of the drunken Indian. Police and sheriff's officials dispute the charge. They say they investigated the deaths fully and found no connections but continue to chase leads. The body of John Sandoval, a 19-year-old Navajo from Canoncito, N.M., was found in April 1989 in the Kansas River. He had been missing since November 1988 and his body was so decomposed the coroner couldn't pinpoint a cause of death. Cecil Dawes Jr., 21, a former West Point cadet whose father teaches at Haskell, was found in October 1989 floating in river weeds. He had been missing for 10 days. Dawes had left a bar and got his car stuck on railroad tracks. His young companion told investigators he told her to hide and she then heard voices. But she has changed her story, investigators say. The coroner's report said Dawes was presumed drowned. His blood-alcohol level was .18, above the legal limit of .10. Although he won't rule out the possibility, Sheriff Loren Anderson said he'd be surprised if a link between the deaths ever appeared. He said there is no evidence the victims were murdered or died the same way. Indian leaders say their complaint was never with Anderson. Most of their anger is directed at the town's police chief, who they say scoffed at their fears during a meeting after Dawes died. Police Chief Ron Olin has said in the past that he thinks Indians overreacted to the deaths. He no longer gives interviews because of what his spokesman calls inaccurate information in newspaper stories. The spokesman, Chris Mulvenon, attributed the Indians' anger to a personality conflict. Bread and others disputed that. ``He made a strong case that Cecil Dawes was a bad person, that all we have here is a drunken Indian who went and fell in the river,'' Bread said. ``He tried to condemn him more than anything else.'' Christopher Bread was found with a fractured skull along a rural road outside of town in early March. He had spent the night at a building where two heavy metal bands were playing. Investigators originally suspected the 19-year-old had been hit with a blunt instrument, then dragged to the site where he was found by a motorist, Anderson said. But two of three autopsies ordered in the case concluded Bread died in a hit-and-run accident as he walked along the road late at night. His blood-alcohol level was nearly .13. ``I'm still not totally convinced that our first impression was wrong,'' Anderson said. Bread's shirt was rolled up under his arms, as if he'd been dragged by the feet, Anderson said. The autopsy said he had scrapes on his back, plus a gruesome wound on one leg where the skin had been stripped. There were no skid marks or shattered glass, the sheriff said. ``There had to be someone else around there at the time, and that person might eventually come forward,'' he said. ``But in the other two cases, well, the river doesn't talk.''

DOC.HEAD: Interest Rates Pinch Homeowners, Businesses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A young roofer says he and his wife haven't gone on vacation in three years and rarely go out. A civil engineer says he can't save money, and a jeweler says his business is just ``making a living.'' They all blame high interest rates, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's chosen tool for squeezing inflation out of the economy. Mrs. Thatcher's policy has yet to pay off. On Friday, the government announced that retail prices were up 10.6 percent in August compared with a year ago, the highest rate of inflation since 1982. Maidstone, a town of 140,000 residents about 40 miles southeast of London, is in the heart of Kent County's prosperous commuter country. Unemployment is below 4 percent, and a 647-acre business park at Kings Hill in Maidstone is one of the largest economic development projects in the county. However, the region has not been spared the economic pressures squeezing the rest of the country. The Kent Economic Development Board says inquiries from businesses have dropped 13 percent since last year. For some individuals, the economic trends add up to a crisis. ``A lot of people who had stretched themselves (before) can no longer cope,'' said Mavis Firth, project leader at Maidstone's Money Advice Center. ``We can't see all the people who ask for our help.'' The center's load of new cases has increased more than 50 percent, and there's a six-week waiting list, she said. ``It can take people years to get back on the straight-and-narrow again,'' Mrs. Firth said. Nick Kember, 28, a self-employed roofer, and his 26-year-old wife Joanne bought a home in 1987 when the mortgage rate was 9.85 percent. Now the rates are 15 percent, and he says it doesn't help that construction and business in general are slowing down. ``It's so tight, really,'' he said. Geoffrey Pettitt, a 49-year-old civil engineer, said his monthly mortgage payment of about $510 is a third higher than it was a year ago, and has more than offset the increase in his salary. At least they still have their homes. More than 14,000 homes were repossessed in Britain in the first half of this year, double the number in the last half of 1989, according to the Council of Mortgage lenders. Mrs. Thatcher has been especially proud of the increasing rate of home ownership in Britain under her leadership, and newspaper pictures of evicted families are bad news for a government facing an election by mid-1992. Not only are interest rates high, said council spokesman Adrian Coles, but unemployment is creeping up, from 5.7 percent in July to 5.8 percent in August. Retail sales were down 1.6 percent in the same period. The Institute of Directors said nearly three-quarters of the 200 members surveyed in August said they were less optimistic about the economy and company prospects than six months ago, an increase of 27 percentage points since June. The accounting firm Touche Ross and Co. says 2,365 businesses failed in Britain between January and August, compared with 866 over the same period a year ago. Manufacturing, retailing and construction businesses were the most frequent casualties, it said. Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major said Friday that the government is committed to its policy of high interest rates. The rates will remain high until it's safe to lower them, he said. Economic growth is expected to shrink to 1.2 percent this year, from 2.1 percent in 1989 and 4.7 percent in 1988, says the London investment firm James Capel and Co. John Banham, director general of the employers group, the Confederation of British Industry, said: ``Businessmen do not question the need to tackle the inflationary malaise. But a full-scale recession ... is not the answer.'' Lawrence Curtis, a partner in the Anthony W. Peake jewelry store in Maidstone, said sales have been good but profits have been pared by rising mortgage costs on the shop premises. ``It's a difference between making a living and making a profit,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bumper Corn Crop May Boost Livestock Industry
DOC.TEXT: The big 1990 corn crop may provide a strong boost to the nation's livestock industry - the ranchers, farmers and feedlot operators who turn out beef and pork for consumers. According to Agriculture Department economists, the price of corn is going to be substantially less than they had forecast a month ago. That will mean some easing of feed costs from what had been expected. But lower corn prices will mean lower profits for farmers who produce grain for sale on the market. ``A lot of it may be whose ox is getting gored,'' said Leland Southard of the department's Economic Research Service. ``It's going to be positive, I think, for livestock.'' Last week USDA estimated this fall's corn harvest at 8.12 billion bushels, up 3 percent from prospects a month earlier and 8 percent more than last year's crop. Projections on supply and demand for corn during the 1990-91 marketing year that began Sept. 1 point to total use - including domestic and export demand - of about 4.7 billion bushels, up from 4.5 billion in 1989-90. It is also 100 million bushels more than the agency forecast in August that would be used in the coming year. As a result of the bumper harvest - corn yields per acre were estimated at a record high of 121.7 bushels - prices at the farm are expected to decline to a range of $2.10 to $2.50 per bushel in 1990-91. That would be down 25 cents a bushel from the August forecast and probably below the average 1989-90 price of $2.38 per bushel. Southard, in a telephone interview a day after the Sept. 12 crop report, said he had previously forecast a 3 percent increase in pork production next year but that uncertainty still clouded the plans of producers. ``I would certainly expect a little more expansion now'' that the 1990 corn crop is shaping up so large, he said. Farmers and ranchers who have cow-calf operations, which form the foundation of the nation's beef industry, may settle on ``a more active herd expansion'' because of the general outlook and, particularly, the prospect of moderating feed costs, Southard said. ``In the short run, that tends to take away from beef production, but then increases it in the longer run,'' he said. That is because beef cattle have a much longer biological cycle than hogs and poultry. Thus, when heifers are retained for breeding herds, it means fewer animals for the slaughter market - and less beef. Eventually, the calves produced by the heifers will grow up and be added to the nation's beef output.

Rising food costs, lower rebates for infant formula and more poor people mean Congress will have to provide more money than originally anticipated to fully fund the women and infant feeding program, says the Congressional Budget Office. The WIC program never has been funded sufficiently to cover all the eligible women and babies, but it was generally believed that to do so would cost about $150 million more each year. The House has appropriated a total of $2.32 billion for fiscal 1991. The CBO estimates that $285 million more would be needed to get participation to 85 percent, which is considered full funding. For many years participation has been about 50 percent of those eligible. The budget office estimates the following increments would be needed for future years: $319 million for 1992; $358 million, 1993; $400 million, 1994; $446 million, 1995. The WIC program provides monthly food packages or food vouchers to low-income women, infants and children whose health is at risk because of poor nutrition. Pregnant women, breast feeding mothers, babies and children under five whose family income is less than specific poverty guidelines are eligible. CBO estimates that there will 8.7 million eligible people in 1991. WIC is an Agriculture Department program administered by the states.

The Agriculture Department says the tiny island Republic of Malta offers an opportunity for enterprising food exporters. Nothing huge, mind you, Malta is less than twice the size of the District of Columbia. But the Mediterranean island produces only 40 percent of the food needs for its 350,000 inhabitants and thriving tourist trade. Only about $9 million worth of U.S. products were imported last year, says a report in the October issue of AgExporter magazine. Still, Maltese importers have ``expressed a keen interest'' in buying a wide variety of U.S. agricultural products. These include packaged rice, popcorn, peanut butter, dried fruits, walnuts, in-shell peanuts, breakfast cereals, soybean meal and alfalfa. However, according to U.S. agricultural officer Stan M. Cohen, who is stationed in Milan, Italy, ``taking advantage of this interest may require some flexibility'' on the part of exporters. For example, many of the Maltese orders are for such small quantities that they will not fill up a standard 20-foot shipping container, thus requiring the shipment of mixed containers, the report said. Also, since there is no direct shipping service between the United Sates and Malta, cargoes must be routed through North European ports, meaning a transit time of six to eight week.
