DOC.HEAD: Israelis Generally Pleased at Growing Ties to Moscow
DOC.TEXT: Many Israelis are praising the weekend meeting of two Cabinet ministers with Mikhail S. Gorbachev as opening new horizons of diplomacy and trade, but some question Moscow's motives. ``It changes our international map,'' said Gideon Raphael, a veteran Israeli diplomat. He witnessed the departure from Israel of the Soviets and their East bloc satellites 23 years ago, and he's now happily watching them trickle back. The Soviet leader met for 2{ hours Saturday in Moscow with Israeli Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai and Science Minister Yuval Neeman. It was the highest-level encounter ever between Soviets and Israelis, and the most significant since Moscow severed diplomatic ties with Jerusalem in June 1967. At an airport news conference in Tel Aviv on Sunday, the two ministers said they were carrying a personal message from the Soviet president to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. They did not describe its contents. They disclosed little of their talks with Gorbachev but said they focused on the Persian Gulf crisis and possible trade deals, including agriculture and oil. The meeting was hailed by some Israeli foreign policy analysts. Raphael said the Soviets had over the years plunged Israel into a diplomatic no man's land that stretched ``from the Berlin Wall to the Chinese Wall.'' They had armed the Arabs, equated Zionism with Nazism, and persecuted Soviet Jews who wished to emigrate. ``Now this no man's land has become smaller,'' he said in an interview. Commented the daily newspaper Haaretz: ``Had anyone dared a year ago to prophesy what would happen this weekend in Moscow, he would have brought nothing but mockery upon himself. ... It shows that no political situation, however unchangeable it looks, exists forever.'' Saturday's meeting was unannounced beforehand. Modai and Neeman left without fanfare, sidestepping protocol. Their visit was arranged by a Soviet Jewish immigrant, Ilya Zemtsov, an aide to eeman. Modai said Sunday that the talks with Gorbachev ``covered wide possibilities of imports and exports,'' including the idea of building a Soviet-U.S.-Israeli passenger plane. Asked about a possible exchange of Soviet oil for Israeli agricultural products, Modai said it was ``a successful guess, but at this stage only a guess.'' Modai said that Israel, faced with the prospect of absorbing 1 million Soviet Jews over the next few years, needed ``a breakthrough in agricultural exports.'' The talks, which also covered diplomatic issues, came as Moscow and Jerusalem find themselves in the same camp for the first time since the 1950s by dint of their opposition to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The meeting in Moscow happened to coincide with Secretary of State James A Baker III's talks with President Hafez Assad of Syria. The Soviets used to be Syria's main military backer; indeed, it was that alliance that helped trigger the 1967 Middle East War and, in turn, the Soviets' diplomatic rupture with Israel. Now that Soviet arms are no longer guaranteed to Syria, Israeli attitudes are changing, too. However, not everyone was euphoric about Saturday's meeting. Sovietologist Mikhail Agursky of Hebrew University said in an interview that he believes Gorbachev won't last and that ``to bet on Gorbachev is to bet on a dead horse.'' The daily newspaper Davar argued that Soviet overtures to Israel are motivated by the old anti-Semitic canard about Jews bent on world domination. ``They are convinced that Jewish control of world, and above all American capital, can channel enterprise and investments their way,'' it editorialized. Unlike East European countries, the Soviet Union has yet to take what in Israel's view is the ultimate step - re-establishing full diplomatic ties.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats See Gulf Crisis Stealing The Spotlight In 1990 Elections
DOC.TEXT: Jim Ruvolo feels the frustration of Democrats who thought the party had the best of the issues going into the 1990 campaign. And then Saddam Hussein decided to overrun Kuwait. ``There's this big screen between the voters and information and that screen is Iraq,'' said Ruvolo, chairman of the Ohio Democratic Party. For two days, Democrats met in Washington this weekend and tried to define a campaign that so far has been overshadowed by public interest in the Persian Gulf. Like their Republican counterparts, the Democrats profess to lack a clear signal of what impact the Middle East crisis will have on individual contests this fall. The odds are that very few of the races will be decided by what voters are thinking about Iraq. But the Persian Gulf is making it far more difficult for candidates to get the attention of voters. The savings and loan industry scandal was an issue the Democrats thought would work for them in 1990. ``People are angry,'' said Ruvolo. ``And they blame Republicans more than Democrats'' for a crisis that leaves them uneasy about their personal savings and that appears certain to boost the federal deficit. ``But now that's faded into the background,'' he said. Ronald H. Brown, the national party chairman, tried to set a campaign tone for his party with a speech that expressed unwavering support for the U.S. commitment in the Persian Gulf while sharply criticizing Republican domestic policies. Brown referred to a ``Republican recession'' and said Bush wanted to push through another tax cut for the wealthiest Americans. He castigated the president for failing to develop an energy policy that would make the nation less dependent on Middle East oil and said the S&L crisis was the result of ``see-nothing Republican justice.'' But Brown steered clear of other domestic issues he apparently felt would not work to the advantage of his party's candidates. The Democrats refused to act on a proposal to put them on record as flatly opposing any tax increase to help balance the budget. It was only months ago that Bush was forced to abandon that ground, much to the distress of many Republicans, and Brown had no desire to occupy it. ``We'll accept the president's call for tax increases,'' said Brown, ``but we'll not go gently when he tries to cut taxes for the richest Americans yet again.'' Not a word was uttered on the nomination of David Souter to the Supreme Court. After two days of testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee, in which he refused to say whether he might vote to overturn the decision legalizing most abortions, Souter appears certain to win confirmation from the Senate. ``I have great confidence in the Senate Judiciary Committee,'' was as far as Brown would go when asked about the nomination. When pressed as to hw he would vote on the nomination, Brown gave a lawyerly answer: ``I think I'd like to see the full hearing and make a judgment on what he said in response to questions.'' No one was willing to guess what might happen in the Persian Gulf between now and Election Day. The most anyone would speculate was that the situation would remain pretty much the same with American forces in Saudi Arabia and Iraq hanging tough in Kuwait. ``I think he (Bush) has six or eight months of goodwill on this thing,'' said Ruvolo. Beyond that, he said, the president might face growing questions as to why U.S. troops were remaining in the Saudi desert.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of President Bush's address to the people of Iraq, as released by the White House: I'm here today to explain to the people of Iraq why the United States and the world community has responded the way it has to Iraq's occupation of Kuwait. My purpose is not to trade accusations, not to escalate the war of words, but to speak with candor about what has caused this crisis that confronts us. Let there be no misunderstanding. We have no quarrel with the people of Iraq. I've said many times, and I will repeat right now, our only object is to oppose the invasion ordered by Saddam Hussein. On August 2nd, your leadership made its decision to invade, an unprovoked attack on a small nation that posed no threat to your own. Kuwait was the victim; Iraq, the aggressor. And the world met Iraq's invasion with a chorus of condemnation, unanimous resolutions in the United Nations. Twenty-seven states, rich and poor, Arab, Muslim, Asian and African, have answered the call of Saudi Arabia and free Kuwait and sent forces to the Gulf region to defend against Iraq. For the first time in history, 13 states of the Arab League, representing 80 percent of the Arab Nation, have condemned a brother Arab state. Today, opposed by world opinion, Iraq stands isolated and alone. I do not believe that you, the people of Iraq, want war. You've borne untold suffering and hardship during eight long years of war with Iran. A war that touched the life of every single Iraqi citizen. A war that took the lives of hundreds of thousands of young men, the bright promise of an entire generation. No one knows better than you the incalculable costs of war, the ultimate cost when a nation's vast potential and vital energies are consumed by conflict. No one knows what Iaq might be today, what prosperity and peace you might enjoy had your leaders not plunged you into war. Now, once again, Iraq finds itself on the brink of war. Once again, the same Iraqi leadership has miscalculated. Once again, the Iraqi people face tragedy. Saddam Hussein has told you that Iraqi troops were invited into Kuwait. That's not true. In fact, in the face of far superior force, the people of Kuwait are bravely resisting this occupation. Your own returning soldiers will tell you the Kuwaitis are fighting valiantly in any way they can. Saddam Hussein tells you that this crisis is a struggle between Iraq and America. In fact, it is Iraq against the world. When President Gorbachev and I met at Helsinki we agreed that no peaceful international order is possible if larger states can devour their neighbors. Never before has world opinion been so solidly united against aggression. Nor, until the invasion of Kuwait, has the United States been opposed to Iraq. In the past, the United States has helped Iraq import billions of dollars worth of food and other commodities. And the war with Iran would not have ended two years ago without U.S. support and sponsorship in the United Nations. Saddam Hussein tells you the occupation of Kuwait will benefit the poorer nations of the world. In fact, the occupation of Kuwait is helping no one and is now hurting you, the Iraqi people, and countless others of the world's poor. Instead of acquiring new oil wells by annexing Kuwait, this misguided act of aggression will cost Iraq over $20 billion a year in lost oil revenues. Because of Iraq's aggression, hundreds of thousands of innocent foreign workers are fleeing Kuwait and Iraq. They are stranded on Iraq's borders, without shelter, without food, without medicine, with no way home. These refugees are suffering, and this is shameful. But even worse, others are being held hostage in Iraq and Kuwait. Hostage taking punishes the innocent and separates families. It is barbaric. It will not work. And it will not affect my ability to make tough decisions. I do not want to add to the suffering of the people of Iraq. The United Nations has put binding sanctions in place, not to punish the Iraqi people, but as a peaceful means to convince your leadership to withdraw from Kuwait. That decision is in the hands of Saddam Hussein. The pain you now experience is a direct result of the path your leadership has chosen. When Iraq returns to the path of peace, when Iraqi troops withdraw from Kuwait, when that country's rightful government is restored, when all foreigners held against their will are released, then, and then alone will the world end the sanctions. Perhaps your leaders do not appreciate the strength of the forces united against them. Let me say clearly, there is no way Iraq can win. Ultimately, Iraq must withdraw from Kuwait. No one - not the American people, not this president - wants war. But there are times when a country, when all countries who value the principles of sovereignty and independence, must stand against aggression. As Americans, we're slow to raise our hand in anger and eager to explore every peaceful means of settling our disputes. But when we have exhausted every alternative, when conflict is thrust upon us, there is no nation on Earth with greater resolve or stronger steadiness of purpose. The actions of your leadership have put Iraq at odds with the world community. But while those actions have brought us to the brink of conflict, war is not inevitable. It is still possible to bring this crisis to a peaceful end. When we stand with Kuwait against aggression, we stand for a principle well understood in the Arab world. Let me quote the words of one Arab leader - Saddam Hussein himself: ``An Arab country does not have the right to occupy another Arab country. God forbid, if Iraq should deviate from the right path, we would want Arabs to send their armies to put things right. If Iraq should become intoxicated by its power and move to overwhelm another Arab state, the Arabs would be right to deploy their armies to check it.'' Those are the words of your leader, Saddam Hussein, spoken on Nov. 28, 1988, in a speech to Arab lawyers. Today, two years later, Saddam has invaded and occupied a member of the United Nations and the Arab League. The world will not allow this aggression to stand. Iraq must get out of Kuwait for ,the sake of principle, for the sake of peace, and for the sake of the Iraqi people.

DOC.HEAD: What Makes a Parent? Judge to Hear Complex Case
DOC.TEXT: The childless couple and the young woman struck a bargain: Mark and Crispina Calvert would give Anna Johnson $10,000, and she would bear a child created from their egg and sperm. The deal went wrong. Now, just weeks before the birth, the Calverts and Ms. Johnson are locked in a bitter custody dispute that is moving from the TV talk show arena into the courtroom. Lawyers for the three sides - the fetus has a court-appointed attorney - are preparing their strategies in a case called unprecedented even in the cutting-edge realm of surrogate pregnancies. The issues: What makes a parent - the genetic link or the act of bearing a child? And what is the legality of the surrogate contract? The outcome, experts say, could be a groundbreaking ruling or a narrow decision that doesn't go beyond that of any other custody case. A pre-trial hearing is set for Thursday in Superior Court. Harold LaFlamme, the fetus' attorney, said his goal is to avoid protracted litigation and an unstable life for the child. A narrow ruling based on the child's best interests is possible, he said. California courts ``try to avoid constitutional disputes, try to fit cases into the family law scheme of things,'' he said. H. Joseph Gitlin, head of the surrogacy committee of the American Bar Association's family law section, agreed that the child's interests may outweigh other issues. But if Ms. Johnson is found to lack a genetic link to the child, ``that surely gives the (Calverts) a leg up,'' he said. California's liberal track record in family law - giving the nation such concepts as no-fault divorce - makes it more likely that the surrogate contract will be upheld, Gitlin said. But even if the contract is ruled invalid, ``I see the court deciding the case on the same basis as the Baby M case: That is, in the best interests of the child,'' he said. In that landmark New Jersey case, the child was conceived by a surrogate mother, Mary Beth Whitehead, with the sperm of a man whose wife couldn't have a baby. Whitehead reneged on the arrangement, prompting a bitter custody fight that was won in 1988 by the father, William Stern, and his wife, Elizabeth. The judge ruled the contract invalid and awarded them the baby. However, in that case, Ms. Whitehead was genetically the child's mother because she provided the egg. In the California case, the Calverts agreed to provide both sperm and egg for a so-called test-tube baby. Complicating the California case is a claim from Ms. Johnson's attorneys that the fetus might be her natural child. And because one of Ms. Johnson's grandparents is American Indian, the child's adoption could involve federal tribal-protection laws that give preference to Indians. Calvert, 34, is white and his wife Filipino. Mrs. Calvert, 36, and Ms. Johnson, 29, met at the Santa Ana hospital where both worked as nurses. Ms. Johnson agreed to undergo an embryo transplant for the Calverts for $10,000. Mrs. Calvert was unable to conceive a child naturally because of a hysterectomy. A single parent with a 3-year-old daughter, Ms. Johnson said she had seen the contract as a way to put herself through graduate nursing school. But Ms. Johnson claims the couple's enthusiasm for the pregnancy turned to indifference, they were late with payments and showed no concern when she suffered complications. She is seeking custody, child support and emotional damages. The Calverts deny the allegations, accusing Ms. Johnson of greed and publicity-seeking. The dispute has been aired by both sides on such TV shows as ``Geraldo'' and ``Donahue.'' The couple's attorney, Christian Van Deusen, said he will ask the court to enforce the custody rights detailed in the contract and to recognize the genetic relationship in determining parenthood. Ms. Johnson's attorneys, Richard Gilbert and Diane Marlowe, say they will seek to have the contract declared illegal and invalid because it constitutes baby-selling. California has no law on the issue. They maintain that Ms. Johnson is the biological parent because she is carrying the child to term, and that the transplant may not have even succeeded. State law recognizes the birth mother as the legal mother, they say.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Budget Talks
DOC.TEXT: Here at a glance is what has occurred so far at the budget summit between Bush administration and congressional negotiators. The talks at Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland entered their ninth day Sunday:
DOC.HEAD: THE PACKAGE:
DOC.TEXT: Both sides want to reduce next year's deficit by $50 billion and shrink the budget gap by $500 billion over five years. They agree that about half the first-year savings should come from new taxes and fees, the rest from spending cuts.
DOC.HEAD: DEFENSE CUTS:
DOC.TEXT: Democrats want $11 billion next year, $200 billion over five years. Republicans want about $10 billion next year, $170 billion over five years. Not considered a major problem.
DOC.HEAD: DOMESTIC PROGRAMS:
DOC.TEXT: Democrats willing to reduce them by about $103 billion over five years, Republicans want to go to at least $120 billion. Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, is said to be stubbornly resisting further cuts. A sticking point. On Sunday, Democrats moved away from $30 billion in reductions to benefits programs the two sides had discussed, making the problem more serious.
DOC.HEAD: TAXES AND FEES:
DOC.TEXT: Both sides want about $25 billion for next year, but they disagree on components. Republicans want to cut the capital gains tax rate. Democrats say they won't agree unless income taxes on the wealthy are increased as compensation. This is a major problem. Democrats have proposed boosting gasoline taxes 11 cents per gallon, putting a 4 percent tax on other energy and increasing taxes the well-to-do pay to support Medicare. Republicans want to tax almost all petroleum products a penny a gallon, limit the deductibility of state and local income taxes, and let many excise taxes increase with inflation. Both sides have proposed increasing taxes on cigarettes; on luxury items such as expensive automobiles, yachts and jewelry; and on chemicals that remove ozone from the atmosphere. Other problems: Republicans want to limit Congress' ability to increase spending in future years. Democrats are resisting. This is also a major hurdle.

DOC.HEAD: The Border Opened, Kuwaitis Stream Out With Grim Tales
DOC.TEXT: Kuwaitis fleeing through a suddenly opened border crossing say food is becoming scarcer in their homeland and Iraqi soldiers are trying to quell resistance by blowing up blocks of houses. Their government-in-exile called the unannounced weekend exodus of several thousand Kuwaitis - the first allowed by Iraq in about a month - evidence that Iraq's Saddam Hussein intends to depopulate Kuwait and move in his own people. One refugee, the 45-year-old owner of an investment company, said ``people are not obeying them (the Iraqis) so they want to get rid of us.'' Iraqi soldiers confiscated all identity documents, including car registrations, from those leaving the oil-rich emirate, refugees said. They said the Iraqis apparently wanted to make it difficult for anyone to return. No precise tally was available on the number of refugees who had crossed into Saudi Arabia at Khafji since word spread in Kuwait on Friday that Iraq was lifting restrictions on departure through the border post, the only official crossing between the countries. In addition to the several thousand Kuwaitis who apparently made the journey, refugees included a Yugoslav woman maried to a Kuwaiti and about 20 Asians, Saudi officials said. They said they were too overwhelmed with paperwork to give exact figures. The Iraqis had not announced the border opening. The refugees learned of it by word of mouth and could only speculate on the reasoning behind it. The Kuwaiti Cabinet discussed the development in an emergency meeting Sunday in the southwestern resort of Taif, where the government-in-exile has established its headquarters. Afterward, it issued a statement saying the border opening reflected a new Iraqi policy of ``getting the Kuwaitis out after stripping them of their identity papers, and bringing in Iraqis to settle in Kuwait.'' Kuwaiti leaders have previously accused Saddam of intending to eventually repopulate Kuwait with Iraqis. On Sunday, Mercedes, Chevrolet Suburban jeeps and scores of other expensive cars stretched 500 yards from the checkpoint as Saudi border police checked vehicles and demanded some identification. ``There's just too many of them to handle. It's a very slow procedure getting them through because they have no documents,'' said a Western diplomat stationed at the border to monitor the traffic. A committee of Kuwaitis at the border screened refugees, asking questions about such things as membership in local organizations. Saudi officials have expressed concern the Iraqis opened the border to sneak in spies and terrorists. Some refugees said they had received news of the border opening in anonymous telephone calls. A 33-year-old journalist said a friend got a call saying: ``Why do you always talk badly about Saddam Hussein? The border's open, why don't you leave?'' Like many fleeing, he was afraid to give his name for fear that the Iraqis might harm relatives left behind. ``It's a rough life now,'' the journalist said. ``They're blowing up houses, killing people for any suspicion.'' Kuwaitis said the Iraqis have blown up or burned up to 20 houses at a time in neighborhoods where Iraqi soldiers were killed by resistance fighters. The Iraqis also were sealing off whole neighborhoods to conduct house-to-house searches, looking for resistance material and the several hundred Westerners still reported in hiding, the refugees said. They said the sound of gunfire could be heard during the curfew hours of 11 p.m. to 7 a.m. Saddam's troops have plundered most public property - carting off everything from hospital machinery to street lights - but have generally stayed out of Kuwaiti homes. ``Now they want to make a super robbery in Kuwait - take everything,'' said 35-year-old Salam Matouk, another refugee. An estimated 300,000 of Kuwait's native population of 570,000 have fled since Iraq invaded on Aug. 2. Most are in Saudi Arabia, where the government pays for their housing and food. Only Kuwaitis working in essential services like electricity and water plants are at their jobs, refugees reported. Kuwait's police officers have ignored an order to return to work, and no one has registered for the announced Oct. 1 opening of schools. Stocks of food are getting low and cash short, the refugees said. But staples are still available, and small quantities of vegetables are brought in by Palestinian traders allowed to go to Iraq's southern port city of Basra, they said. The refugees bitterly criticized the Palestinians - thousands of whom work as professionals or merchants in Kuwait - for collaborating with Iraqi authorities to root out former soldiers and policemen. Many Palestinians in Jordan and elsewhere have supported Iraq in its occupation of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Diplomats Say Anti-Iraq Sanctions Likely To Be Extended To Air
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Angered by Iraqi raids on the French and other diplomatic compounds in Kuwait, U.N. representatives say they're considering extending to air corridors the international embargo on trade with Iraq. On Sunday, the Security Council unanimously passed a resolution condemning Iraq for violating diplomatic territory with Friday's raids and warning that further sanctions were likely if Baghdad continued to ignore U.N. resolutions. The U.S. ambassador, Thomas R. Pickering, said another resolution would be drafted to impose an air embargo, a step the United Nations has never taken against a nation. An air blockade would involve the interception of planes approaching Iraq and would pose a far greater danger of triggering hostilities than the boarding ships in the Persian Gulf, which has been done under the U.N. naval embargo. ``By singling out diplomatic missions for attack, Iraq confirms its preference for instruments of force to instruments of diplomacy and negotiation,'' Pickering said. Western diplomats say sanctions are also planned against nations that break the embargo the U.N. imposed on trade with Iraq after Saddam Hussein's forces invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The ambassadors of the Security Council's five permanent members - the United States, Britain, France, China and the Soviet Union - met at the French Mission on Sunday to begin laying the groundwork for further resolutions. Pickering and other diplomats said they expected a vote by the end of the week. ``If Iraq persists, there will be other resolutions,'' Soviet Ambassador Yuliy Vorontsov said. ``The cumulative effect will produce the necessary result, a political solution, a solution without any kind of military activity.'' President Francois Mittrrand of France said Saturday that his country wants the United Nations to widen the embargo on Iraq to include air traffic and punishment of countries or companies violating the sanctions. The swift move on the air embargo indicated how seriously the Western world views Iraq's storming of the French, Belgian, Dutch and Canadian compounds, the detention of diplomats and seizing of three Frenchmen. Iraq attacked the resolution as part of a ``vicious hostile campaign led by the United States and its allies.'' ``Iraq categorically rejects that it had kidnapped foreigners from former diplomatic premises or is holding them as hostages,'' a Foreign Ministry spokesman said in a report by the Iraqi News Agency. Work on the new resolutions began hours after the council, in an emergency session sought by France, voted 15-0 early Sunday to condemn Iraq for its storming of embassy compounds. The resolution was the seventh adopted overwhelmingly by the council to deal with the crisis sparked by Iraq's lightning invasion and annexation of the oil-rich emirate. The four embassies raided were among some 17 that have remained open in Kuwait in defiance of an Iraqi order to close. Iraq cut utilities to many embassies and surrounded missions with troops to force diplomats to leave. The Iraqi government considers Kuwait a province of Iraq and says the 1961 Vienna Conventions on Diplomatic and Consular relations do not apply. Those treaties set forth the inviolability of diplomatic compounds. In its latest resolution, the council said it ``strongly condemns aggressive acts perpetrated by Iraq against diplomatic premises and personnel in Kuwait as well as the abduction of foreign nationals who were present in those premises.'' It demanded the immediate release of all foreign nationals. Although Iraq has allowed Western women and children to leave, many men have been sent to strategic sites to serve as shields against potential attack by U.S.-led forces. An air embargo would require cooperation from Iraq's neighbors. They would have to close their air space to Iraq-bound flights, refuse refueling to planes headed for Iraq and report suspicious flights to the Security Council's sanctions committee. State Department officials say privately that the few flights now going into Baghdad are not considered a threat to the integrity of the embargo, and that it would be impossible for Iraq to effectively break the sanctions with airlifts.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Nikkei Declines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with Nikkei, dollar closings
DOC.TEXT: The dollar edged up against the Japanese yen Monday, while share prices fell sharply on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which lost 177.62 points Friday, shed another 531.865 points, or 2.13 percent, to close at 24,365.60. In bond dealings, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds continued to rise. They were quoted at 8.570 percent at 3:00 p.m. after Friday's 8.460-percent close, the highest yield the bond has ever reached. The price was lower at 81.17 points from 81.62. The dollar closed at 137.00 yen, up 0.45 yen from Friday's close of 136.55 yen. After opening lower at 136.45 yen, the currency ranged between 136.43 yen and 137.10 yen. The yen fell against the U.S. and European currencies as investors sold the yen in an attempt to correct overbought positions, said Toru Kanai, a currency analyst with New Japan Securities Co. The dollar started lower following its downtrend in the Sydney market, which opens earlier than Tokyo. ``Institutional investors had bought the yen and sold substantial amounts of European and U.S. currencies before their settling their accounts for the first half of fiscal 1990,'' he said. On Monday, such investors bought the dollar at around 136.40 to 136.50 yen to make up their short, or oversold, positions, he said. ``Weakness in the bond and the stock market also contributed to the yen's weakness,'' Kanai said. But he said the Japanese currency's weakness Monday is just a brief correction. On the stock exchange, traders said the index fell as soon as the market opened because investors discouraged by the weakening government bond market and began index-linked large-scale selling. They also said announcement of a price increase by major oil wholesalers also discouraged investors.

DOC.HEAD: Since Aug. 2 Invasion, Seven Security Council Resolutions Target Iraq
With PM-Gulf-UN
DOC.TEXT: Since Iraq invaded and occupied Kuwait on Aug. 2, the Security Council has passed seven resolutions condemning Baghdad and ordering action intended to force the Iraqis into withdrawing. Aug. 3: The Security Council votes 14-0 to condemn the invasion and demand the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi troops. Yemen, the only Arab member of the council, abstains. Aug. 6: The Council votes 13-0 to order an embargo on trade with Iraq and occupied Kuwait. Cuba and Yemen abstain. Aug. 9: The Council votes 15-0 to declare Iraq's annexation of Kuwait null and void in international law. Aug. 18: The Council votes 15-0 to demand that Iraq free all detained foreigners. Aug. 25: The Council votes 13-0 to give the United States and other naval powers the right to enforce the economic embargo by halting shipping to those countries. Cuba and Yemen abstain. Sept. 13: The Council votes 13-2 to allow humanitarian food aid into Iraq or Kuwait only ``to relieve human suffering,'' and says only the council can decide when those circumstances exist. Cuba and Yemen vote against it. Sept. 16: The Council votes 15-0 to condemn Iraq's aggressive acts against diplomatic missions in Kuwait, including the abduction of foreigners who were in the buildings.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Rescued After 14 Hours in Hole
DOC.TEXT: A toddler who was trapped for 14 hours in a 12-foot shaft at his parents' new home popped out ``like Superman'' after a firefighter crawling on his belly through a rescue tunnel grasped the boy's hand. Twenty-month-old Kevin Davis was released from a hospital with little more than a scraped elbow Sunday after being treated for dehydration. Kevin listened to his mother sing nursery songs and busied himself rolling mud balls as rescuers dug a parallel hole to the shaft and then tunneled over to the boy, who had fallen in on Saturday afternoon. ``I could hear him crying, but I couldn't touch him and I couldn't help him,'' said his mother, Lisa Davis, fighting back tears at a news conference at Denver General Hospital. ``It was really difficult.'' Kevin fell to the bottom of the shaft dug for a remodeling project at the home. The family was not living there at the time. ``He managed to slip under a piece of wood and fell into the hole. I heard him bouncing around,'' Mrs. Davis said. Lying on their stomachs, firefighters Kevin Duncan and Joe Cipri used their hands to dig the last few feet of the second tunnel before reaching the boy shortly after 6 a.m. Sunday. Cipri said when he placed his hands near Kevin, the toddler's ``little hands just grabbed my fingers. He just kind of flew out of there like Superman.'' Firefighters worked through the night to keep Kevin warm and dry, pumping oxygen into the hole and shining halogen lights to keep the temperature at about 70 degrees. Workers dug a vertical rescue shaft using a huge truck-mounted pipeline excavator that uses a stream of compressed air to chisel away dirt and clay and then vacuums out the loose dirt. ``He was in a daze, his diaper hanging off, just kind of looking at us like `What's happening here?' '' Duncan said. ``When he clinched my fingers, I felt a tingle in my heart. It's still there.'' After Kevin was safe, Cipri said, ``I just laid there for awhile in that tunnel enjoying the roar outside. It was just great. This is what you get on the fire department for.'' Hospital spokeswoman Mary Lee Chin said Kevin had only a scrape on his elbow. The boy's father, Tom Davis, admitted he had not obtained the necessary building permits for work being done at the home. No charges were immediately filed.

DOC.HEAD: Historic Post Faces Live-Or-Die Vote
DOC.TEXT: News and advertising employees at the New York Post vote tonight on whether the nation' oldest daily will live or die. Owner Peter Kalikow says if members of The Newspaper Guild don't agree to a four-day week - less one day's pay - he will close immediately, putting 960 people out of work. The 505,000-circulation paper is losing $27 million a year. On Friday, 10 unions at the paper known for its screaming headlines agreed to $19 million in concessions. Guild negotiators rejected Kalikow's offer 7-3, but the guild president endorsed it and decided to let the members decide. The union's 352 editorial and advertising workers vote on whether to accept a 20 percent pay cut and the elimination of 43 jobs. Punctuated by a big question mark and a picture of the presses, the front page headline today was possibly the 189-year-old newspaper's last: ``WILL THE POST PRESSES EVER RUN AGAIN?'' Editor Jerry Nachman in today's edition was asked how he would feel if the Post folded. ``How did the captain of the Titanic feel?'' he asked. ``I think we will get through this tonight because the alternative is unthinkable,'' Nachman said. ``It's more than a job,'' said a 23{-year composing room veteran who declined to give his name as he arrived at work Sunday. ``It's part of your life. It's part of the life of the city.'' If the Post lives, workers will get 20 percent of company stock and a representative on the board of directors, union leaders said. Kalikow bought the money-losing tabloid from media baron Rupert Murdoch two years ago after wringing $24 million in concesssions from the unions. As Kalikow's Friday evening deadline for reaching agreement on still more concessions approached, the Post braced for the worst and reportedly readied the headline: ``BANG, WE'RE DEAD.'' ``AIN'T OVER YET!'' the Post trumpeted Saturday. Alexander Hamilton founded the newspaper in 1801. His was the first of many famous names associated with the Post. In the 1820s, New England poet William Cullen Bryant began a 50-year tenure as editor. Walt Whitman covered the Civil War for the Post. Franklin D. Roosevelt was briefly a co-owner in the 1920s. Heiress Dorothy Schiff bought the Post in 1939. While other New York papers withered and died the Post profited under Schiff's politically liberal format and tight budgeting. But its fortunes dimmed in the 1970s as much of its audience moved to the suburbs and it lost $500,000 annually. Schiff sold it in 1976 to Murdoch for $31 million. Murdoch turned the Post politically conservative and into a steamy tabloid with sexy pictures, racy headlines - ``HEADLESS BODY IN TOPLESS BAR'' - and a steady diet of crime stories. Murdoch said he lost $150 million on the Post before selling it for $37 million in 1988 to Kalikow.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Names New Ambassador to the United Nations
DOC.TEXT: Israel has appointed Yoram Aridor, a former finance minister who has never held a diplomatic post, as its ambassador to the United Nations. Aridor, 57, a member of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc, received the necessary Cabinet approval on Sunday, a spokesman for Shamir's office said. The Foreign Ministry said Aridor will assume his post later this month after the opening of the General Assembly in New York. He will replace acting Ambassador Yochanan Bein, who will remain part of Israel's U.N. delegation. The Israeli-born Aridor was named finance minister in 1981 during triple-digit inlation. He was forced to resign in 1983 after he backed an unpopular plan to tie the Israeli shekel to the dollar. A supporter of Foreign Minister David Levy, Aridor rose with Levy through Likud ranks after joining the party in the 1960s. He was educated at Hebrew University of Jerusalem where he studied economics and political science. He also has a law degree. He is married and has three children.

Later, in London, the dollar fell to 136.82 yen. DOC.HEAD: Cosby Named the World's Highest-Paid Entertainer
With PM-Richest Entertainers-List
DOC.TEXT: TV's top-rated dad is also its highest-paid one, as Bill Cosby knocked Michael Jackson out of first place on Forbes' list of the world's 40 richest entertainers with two-year earnings projected at $115 million. Jackson, who had been No. 1 for two years straight, hasn't put out an album or gone on tour this year but still made more money than any other singer or musical group - a two-year estimate of $100 million. He was ranked No. 2. Jackson's singing sister Janet was a newcomer to Forbes' list. She ranked 26th with estimated two-year earnings of $30 million, the magazine said in its Oct. 1 issue, released today. Cosby made $60 million last year, and Forbes projected he would earn $55 million this year. The Rolling Stones - with $88 million - rose to third place from eighth last year thanks largely to a big concert tour. Movie producer-director Steven Spielberg, whose ``Arachnophobia'' was a box-office success this summer, made $87 million. He slipped to fourth place from second. New entrants on the list were the teeny-bopper sensation New Kids on the Block in fifth place. Forbes said the group would make $78 million in the two years, $61 million of it in 1990. Forbes said the estimated gross incomes were based on talks with industry executives, lawyers, agents and managers. It said earnings figures for recording artists are based on royalty payments from record and video sales and estimated pretax gross for concert tours. Rounding out the top 10 were Oprah Winfrey, $68 million; Sylvester Stallone, $63 million; Madonna, $62 million; Arnold Schwarzenegger, $55 million, and ``Peanuts'' cartoonist Charles M. Schulz, $54 million. Newcomers to the list included Paul McCartney, with an estimated income of $45 million; Bruce Willis, star of the two ``Die Hard'' movies and of the December release ``Bonfire of the Vanities,'' based on the Tom Wolfe novel, at $36 million, and Sean Connery, who starred in ``The Hunt for Red October,'' at $35 million.

DOC.HEAD: Hurricane Dissipates, Now Tropical Storm
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Marie weakened to a tropical depression but kicked up the surf at Hawaii today. The approaching storm prompted the Navy to suspend efforts to raise from the Pacific a door that blew off a jumbo jet. The storm was downgraded late Sunday after it winds fell from 80 mph to 70 mph, below the 75 mph hurricane threshold. Marie was 320 miles east-southeast of Hilo, heading for Hawaii at 10 mph, said forecaster Tim Craig. Waves generated by Marie began hitting Hawaii, known as the Big Island, Sunday evening and were expected to rise up to 10 feet by early today. Authorities issued a high surf advisory Sunday and said all ocean and beach activities should be halted. Gale force winds, which range from 39 mph to 54 mph, extended 75 miles from the center of the storm, Craig said. If the storm continued on its track, its center would pass about 40 miles south of the island at midday Tuesday, when its winds were expected to be about 35 mph, Craig said. Because of the storm, the Navy suspended efforts to recover the door that tore off a United Airlines flight last year, hurling nine people to their deaths. The minisub Sea Cliff returned to Pearl Harbor on Sunday after Navy officials decided seas 90 miles south-southwest of Honolulu were too rough to make a second 2{-mile dive to the ocean floor, Lt. Cmdr. Sandy Stairs said. The cargo door and part of the fuselage ripped off the Boeing 747 as it cruised at 22,000 feet in 1989. The Navy hoped to return to the site later this week, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in Boston, Fog in New Orleans
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell in Boston early today and there was fog in New Orleans. Elsewhere, skies were mostly clear. Gusty winds from the northwest were expected to bring showers to New England today, with highs only in the 50s and 60s. A mixture of sun and clouds was predicted for the remainder of the East, with thundershowers possible in Florida. Sunshine was expected in the South and Midwest, while a storm system was forming from Oklahoma to South Dakota, thanks to a stretch of humid coming in from the Gulf. The West looked sunny skies, with a large high pressure system covering the region, except for some showers in Idaho, Montana and western Colorado. Temperatures were expected to be in the 70s for the Middle Atlantic states, the Pacific Northwest and the Great Lakes, in the 80s for the Plains and the Rockies, the 90s for the South and the 100s for the Southwest. Tonight, the thermometer could dip into the 30s in the Midwest, Northeast and the central Appalachians. The high temperature for the nation Sunday was 107 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: More Evacuees from Kuwait Arrive In U.S.
DOC.TEXT: A plane arrived with 160 Westerners and other foreigners aboard who had been trapped in Kuwait by the Iraqi invasion, and some described deteriorating conditions in the annexed country. ``I feel very happy. I'm glad I came to this country,'' said an Indian pediatrician who arrived Sunday on the plane with his wife and six children. The man, who declined to be identified because of fear he would endanger people left behind in Kuwait, said he heard reports of atrocities, but had not witnessed any. The charter flight brought a group of 54 Americans and 106 non-U.S. citizens. Sixty-six were children or infants, 50 were women and 44 were men, said Helen Szablya, a spokeswoman with the state Department of Human Resources. It was the third charter to fly evacuees from Kuwait to Baltimore via Bagdad and London. A flight carrying 285 people arrived Saturday. An American evacuee said military action should be taken to oust Iraqi forces from Kuwait. ``The Kuwaiti people want military action, we can't wait for the sanctions to work,'' said the woman. She described random killings, deserted streets and nights punctuated by gunfire. Many of the evacuees left behind husbands and fathers who have been barred from leaving after the Aug. 2 invasion. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has used some Western men as a human shield at key installations to deter possible military force.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down, Dollar Rises
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to CORRECT direction of bond prices. Pickup 5th pvs, `The market...'
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices dropped today in Tokyo as the dollar rose against the Japanese yen. The Tokyo Stock Exchange's Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which lost 177.62 points on Friday, fell another 531.865 points, or 2.13 percent, closing at 24,365.60. Dealers said falling Japanese government bond prices and rising interest rates led to the third consecutive decline in the exchange's most widely followed barometer. The yield of benchmark No. 119 10-year government bonds rose to 8.565 percent, up from Friday's 8.460 percent close. Their price fell to 81.19 points from 81.62. ``The market expects that earnings of many companies for the current fiscal year will be considerably lower because of high bond prices and depressed stock prices,'' said a dealer with a major brokerage, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``It makes it hard for both institutional and private investors to find shares which appear worth buying.'' The dealers said announcements today of price hikes by major oil wholesalers also discouraged investors from buying. Volume traded on the first section of the exchange was estimated at 300 million shares. In currency trading, the dollar closed at 137.00 yen, up 0.45 yen from last Friday's close. After opening lower at 136.45 yen, the currency ranged between 136.43 yen and 137.10 yen. Spot volume was estimated at about $6 billion. The yen fell against the U.S. and European currencies as investors sold the Japanese currency in an attempt to correct overbought yen positions, said Toru Kanai, a currency analyst with New Japan Securities Co. ``Institutional investors had bought the yen and sold substantial amounts of European and U.S. currencies before settling their accounts for the first half of fiscal 1990,'' he said. The middle of the standard Japanese fiscal year comes at the end of September. Today, such investors bought the dollar at about 136.40-136.50 yen to make up their short, or oversold, positions, Kanai said. ``Weakness in the bond and the stock market also contributed to the yen's weakness,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Announces He Will Run For President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads throughout to UPDATE with Jaruzelski reaction, Walesa saying a president must win with 80 percent of the vote. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa, who a decade ago led Polish workers in forming the East bloc's first free trade union, announced today that he will run for president of Poland. ``Today I made up my mind. I am putting forward for society's approval my readiness to be a candidate for the post of president of the Polish Republic in popular elections,'' the Solidarity chairman said in a statement from the union's headquarters in the Baltic port of Gdansk. ``For me, it is a fulfillment of the pledge I made in August 1980,'' said Walesa. He was catapulted to fame that month by a leading role in strikes that spurred the government to recognize the Solidarity labor federation. Walesa, a skilled negotiatior, also played a key role in the spring of 1989 in the talks that led Communist authorities to eventually hand over power to pro-Solidarity forces. The 46-year-old electrician at the Gdansk shipyard where Solidarity was born is at odds with his former allies now running Poland's government. He has suggested for nearly a year that he might run. Post-Communist Poland's first fully democratic presidential and parliament elections are expected as early as this fall and no later than spring. Supporters of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, the former close adviser Walesa picked to be the East bloc's first non-Communist government leader, want Mazowiecki to run for president. Mazowiecki has not said whether he would run, and his office said today there would be no immediate response to Walesa's decision. The country's current president, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, is Poland's former Communist leader and ordered a 1981 military crackdown that attempted to crush Solidarity. Jaruzelski said through a spokesman today that Walesa's presidential bid ``reflects the process of democratic changes in Poland.'' Jaruzelski was elected by parliament last year as part of the political compromise that gave pro-Solidarity forces control of the government. Walesa has charged that too many supporters of the old Communist administration remain in key posts and that the government is losing touch with the problems of Poland. Two camps - the beginning of a multiparty system after four decades of Communist control - have emerged in the political feud. One, the Center Alliance, supports Walesa for president and is identified with workers and the Solidarity union in Gdansk. The other, known by the acronym ROAD, backs Mazowiecki and is associated with intellectuals and the government in Warsaw. ROAD organizers have called on Mazowiecki to make his decision by the end of September. Walesa predicted last week that he would win. He said that Mazowiecki would receive 35 percent of the vote if he ran. ``I am not worried about victory, but about its scale,'' Walesa said. ``The situation is hard, and if the president is elected with only 50 percent of the vote, he will have to work 48 hours a day ... Thus he must win with 80 percent.'' Jaruzelski has said he will resign early from his six-year term as president. He was elected in July 1989 largely to smooth relations with the Soviet Union after historic accords between Solidarity and then-Communist authorities paved the way for the democratic transformation of Poland and other Eastern European states. Poland's powerful Roman Catholic primate. Cardinal Jozef Glemp, has called together the leaders of the country's political factions for a meeting Tuesday to discuss the next stage of the nation's democratic development. Parliament is scheduled to begin debate Thursday on a schedule for elections.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Newspapers Dismiss Bush Speech
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 9,12-14,21 to CORRECT spelling of Iraqi newspapers Al-Jumhuriya, Al-Qadissiyah. ^By SALAH NASRAWI
DOC.TEXT: Newspapers today derided President Bush for warning in a broadcast message to Iraqis that Saddam Hussein was steering them toward war. One declared: ``Mr. Bush, we listened to your message, but please shut up.'' Bush's speech to the Iraqi people touched off street protests Sunday in Baghdad, Iraq's capital. Thousands of Iraqis marched and shouted, ``Death to Bush! Death to America!'' In a move consolidating control of Kuwait, authorities announced today that Iraq has ordered the dissolution of Kuwait Airways, that country's flagship air carrier. Iraqi authorities allowed Bush's eight-minute speech to be broadcast, apparently in its entirety, on Sunday evening. Iraq had offered Bush television time after U.S. officials complained of the air time given Saddam, the Iraqi leader, by Western media. In the message with an Arabic voice-over and subtitles from the U.S. government, Bush warned that Iraq was internationally isolated and ``on the brink of war.'' He said Saddam had miscalculated and should withdraw from Kuwait, which Iraq invaded Aug. 2. ``Saddam Hussein tells you that this crisis is a struggle between Iraq and America. In fact, it is Iraq against the world,'' said Bush, standing in front of his White House desk with the American flag behind him. In a 25-minute rebuttal Sunday after Bush's message, Iraqi authorities responded with a statement on Iraqi TV saying his speech was ``full of lies and contradictions.'' ``Should war be imposed on us, the Iraqi people will not hesitate in joining to teach the aggressor an important lesson,'' the announcer said. Today, the government-owned newspaper Al-Jumhuriya, or The Republic, published a front-page commentary headlined, ``The Illusions of Mr. Bush.'' ``Once again the president of the United States fails to understand the mentality and psychology of the Iraqi people,'' it said. ``Instead of correcting his previous mistakes, Bush wants to push the area to the abyss of untold catastrophes.'' The Arab-language newspaper said Bush is the victim of his own hatred for Iraq and its leaders. It defended Saddam, saying,``If other people see the sun shining from the eastern horizon, Iraqis see it shining in the face of Saddam Hussein.'' Another commentary in Al-Jumhuriya headlined ``Shut up, Mr. Bush'' said, ``America today is a bastion of oppression and we have this to say: `Mr. Bush, we listened to your message, but please shut up.''' The Iraqi army newspaper Al-Qadissiyah also taunted Bush, saying his message was ``empty'' and avoided the issues. ``It is evident that Bush, who is the president of a state which claims the leadership of the world, has failed in his first test with the Iraqi people,'' Al-Qadissiyah said. It also questioned Bush's claim to represent world opinion. The paper declared that ``Bush wants to say that he has a mandate to carry out his aggression against Iraq, but we know that the decision to go to war with Iraq is purely American.'' The semi-independent newspaper Iraq ran a page-one headline: ``Bush Tricks.'' It said Bush's message was evidence of how the United States is moving toward confrontation with Iraq and the Arab and Islamic nations. ``It reveals the arrogance of the United States, which wants to impose itself as regent on the international community,'' the paper said. ``President Bush's message was full of lies, forgery and contradictions.'' Sunday's demonstration began with a few hundred men who gathered in the streets of Baghad. As they marched through residential neighborhoods, thousands of others, including women and children, joined them. In addition to denouncing Bush, they called Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and King Fahd of Saudi Arabia ``traitors of the Arab world'' for backing the U.S.-led multinational troop buildup that began in response to Iraq's seizure of oil-rich Kuwait. The dissolution of Kuwait Airlines was announced today in a presidential decree published in Al-Qadissiyah. It said all assets were transferred to the government-run Iraqi Airways.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Says It Shot Police Officer
DOC.TEXT: The outlawed Irish Republican Army has claimed it executed a police officer who was seized earlier by armed men. The IRA statement, relayed anonymously to the media Sunday night, said the officer, 42-year-old Louis Robinson, had been shot to death after questioning. The Royal Ulster Constabulary, the police force, said it was investigating a report that a body had been found. Police normally are cautious about approaching bodies for fear of booby traps. Robinson's wife, Ann, 39, had earlier made a television plea for her husband to be released unharmed. He had been on sick leave for three years and was being treated for depression. ``He is a human being, he is my husband and the fact that he is not well makes it even more horrific. Please let him go. Let him go home,'' she said. If Robinson is dead, he is the eighth police officer slain this year and the 274th to be killed since the IRA launched its violent campaign in 1969 to end British rule in the province. His death brings the total of civilians, police and soldiers killed in the past 21 years to 2,813. A search for Robinson had gone on all through Saturday night and Sunday on both sides of the border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic. Police said Robinson had been on a fishing trip to the republic in Dingle, County Kerry, with five friends in the Northern Ireland prison service. On the way home Saturday night, their van was stopped by about a dozen armed men after crossing the border on the Dublin-Belfast road in south Armagh. Police said Robinson and two of his friends were bundled into the trunks of cars and driven off while the other three in the party fled in the darkness into surrounding fields. Two of the men abducted were badly beaten but released later near Belleek village, seven miles away. They were treated in a hospital and one was detained with rib injuries. Police said the gunmen asked for Robinson by name when they stopped the van. The south Armagh area is known as ``bandit country'' by the British army because of the high level of support there for the IRA and the large number of IRA attacks.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev: Referendum is Needed on Privatizing Land
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with new Gorbachev, Shatalin quotes, Abalkin questioning whether parliament has authority to call referendum, edits to tighten. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, assailed for indecision on overhauling the economy, called today for a national referendum on whether to end the collectivization of farmland and return it to individuals. It apparently would be the first national referendum ever conducted in the Soviet Union, and Gorbachev's proposal reflects the deep split in opinion about how to rescue the economy. He spoke a day after 50,000 protesters marched to the Kremlin and demanded the resignation of Gorbachev and his prime minister over the state of the economy, which is plagued by underproductivity and worsening consumer shortages that have included bread lines in Moscow this month. The demonstrators carried banners reading ``The Economy is a Disaster.'' In a 30-minute address to the national parliament today, Gorbachev said the fate of farmland ``is too big a decision, comrades, to be made in offices, auditoriums or meeting halls - even as important as the one in which we are working today.'' The parliament, or Supreme Soviet, was opening debate on competing economic reform plans. Last week, Gorbachev endorsed a plan that would move the Soviet Union toward a market economy in 500 days. It would include allowing farmers and other private citizens the right to own and sell land and pass it to their heirs. So far, Soviet reforms have stopped short of full privatization of land, in part because of staunch opposition from traditional Communists. Land was collectivized in a bloody 1929-32 campaign under Josef Stalin, leaving a legacy of fear and distrust among farmers. Several competing reform plans have been proposed, including a radical version backed by Russian republic President Boris Yeltsin and approved by the republic's legislature. Russia is the largest of the 15 Soviet republics with half the country's people and three-fourths of its land mass. The national prime minister, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, last week proposed a more moderate plan that would only partially dismantle the state planning bureaucracy. In his address today, Gorbachev stopped short of advocating any specific proposals. It was not immediately clear how strongly he supports the proposal to decollectivize land. ``The question of whether there should be private ownership of land or not is the sovereign right of the people to decide, and it can be decided only by a referendum - that's my point of view,'' he said. Gorbachev called privatization of land ``the most difficult issue'' in devising plans for reform. He also emphasized the need for political stability, a tack he has taken in the past to counter calls for the resignation of Ryzhkov and other national leaders. Reshuffling ``the top echelons of power ... would draw us into grim political battles, (and) would heighten confrontation in society at a time when we most badly need consolidation to carry out the market economy program and to draft a new federal treaty,'' Gorbachev said. His remarks appeared designed in part to calm fears among Communist Party members and other elements of Soviet society opposed to moving to a market economy. He said that no matter which proposal is adopted, the government should protect the population from the negative aspects of a market economy, such as inflation, unemployment and possible sharp rises in the costs of basics like health services and housing. ``We need to guarantee Soviet citizens a basic wage, pensions, housing and free medical care,'' he said. Ryzhkov, in a television interview Saturday, said he feared that a 500-day transition to a market economy would cause widespread suffering. His more conservative reform program would keep central planning through 1991. After Gorbachev addressed parliament, economist Stanislav Shatalin told lawmakers he opposed the proposed referendum, saying it would take at least six months and delay the reforms. ``If all our lives we make the heavy decisions by referendum ... then we're not truly taking responsibility. It's not the way politicians should talk,'' he said. Shatalin helped draft the economic plan backed by Yeltsin. Gorbachev interrupted Shatalin's remarks to stress that he was not in favor of referenda on a wide range of subjects, but ``only on the matter of land, the land on which we live.'' The situation was clouded further when Deputy Prime Minister Leonid Abalkin told lawmakers that the 542-member Supreme Soviet lacked the legal authority to schedule a referendum on decollectivization, as implied by Gorbachev. Abalkin said the only body with the constitutional power to order a referendum was the Congress of People's Deputies, the 2,250-member body that elects the legislature and the president. Gorbachev sat expressionless during Abalkin's remarks.

DOC.HEAD: Army Won't Automatically Retaliate For Iraqi Attack on Jordan
DOC.TEXT: The army chief of staff says Israel will not automatically respond in kind to an Iraqi invasion of Jordan, signaling an easing of Israel's stand on the gulf crisis. The comment by Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, reported today by Israeli newspapers, followed suggestions that an Iraqi invasion of Jordan could be aimed at drawing Israel into the gulf conflict as a way of uniting Arab nations behind Iraq. Shomron's statements appeared to back away from Defense Minister Moshe Arens' warnings that Israel would act immediately if Iraq invaded Jordan. Arens has made the statement repeatedly since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Shomron said that by placing such a ``red line,'' Israel did not mean ``that it's an automatic system, that if an Iraqi soldier steps on it an electric circuit will close and an entire military system will be put into action,'' newspapers said. Shomron was quoted as saying that if Iraqi troops entered Jordan, Israel would first examine which troops went in and would study the possible impact of any Israeli response. However, Shomron also said Israel's air force, military intelligence and civil defense units were on heightened alert, because of Jordan's closeness to Iraq and to radical Palestinian guerrilla groups that support Sadam Hussein. The Haaretz daily said Shomron also disclosed, in a briefing with Israeli military reporters, that Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has secretly agreed to increase the defense budget to confront the new Middle East buildup. An unidentified military source was quoted as estimating the increase as an additional $205 million. The present budget allots about $5 billion to defense. Reports on Shomron's briefing said the chief of staff was concerned by the protracted U.S. standoff with Iraq and repeated warnings by Iraqi leaders that Israel could come under attack if war breaks out. Israel is also worried by Jordan King Hussein's fence-mending last weekend with radical Palestinian guerrilla leaders George Habash and Nayef Hawatmeh, Shomron reportedly said. The two leaders are visiting Jordan's capital, Amman, ending a 20-year rupture in ties with Jordan's King Hussein. According to the Post, the army feared Hussein could become incapable of preventing the guerrillas from launching cross-border raids from Jordan into Israel. In a related development, the Haaretz military correspondent quoted American army experts as saying Iraq has recently developed new nerve gas warheads for ground-to-ground missiles. The same experts reportedly questioned the potential accuracy of such missiles. They also noted Iraq has developed this capability as part of a new technological push since its invasion of Kuwait, Haaretz said. Israel is particularly nervous about Iraq's chemical arms capability since Saddam has threatened to use such weapons against the Jewish state if his country is attacked.

DOC.HEAD: Miami Mayor Pulls Gun, Scares Wife's Muggers From Home
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Xavier Suarez pulled a gun and scared off two men who robbed his wife at their home, police said. Both suspects remained at large early today. Rita Suarez had just escorted relatives to their car outside the Suarezes' private residence just south of Miami's downtown Sunday evening when the robbers ordered her inside, said police spokesman Robert Navarro. ``One puts a gun to her head and demands her money and jewelry,'' Navarro said. ``She yells and the mayor hears it upstairs.'' The mayor armed himself and yelled out the window, ``Let her go!'' and the robbers fled, Navarro said. No shots were fired and nobody was injured in the incident, but the thieves did make off with some of Mrs. Suarez's possessions, he said. He wouldn't specify what was stolen or say what type of guns were involved. While Suarez was loading his weapon, he ordered his 12-year-old son, Francis, to call for help on a direct line to the police department, Navarro said. Officers arrived in minutes and surrounded the two-story pink stucco home on Miami Avenue, but the robbers had fled. It's not the first time crime has hit the home where the Suarezes and their four children have lived since 1985. Last year, the house was robbed while the family was away on a summer vacation, and in 1987, a car was stolen from the driveway, said Odalys Mon, the mayor's chief of staff. The mayor has police protection only occasionally, Mon said, and police were not at the Suarez residence when the robbers appeared.

DOC.HEAD: Iran, Iraq Halt Prisoner Exchange
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iran and Iraq have halted a monthlong prisoner of war exchange during which some 75,000 POWs were repatriated, but both sides still hold many prisoners, a Red Cross official said today. There was no explanation from either side. The prisoners had been seized during the 1980-88 Persian Gulf war and their release had been a sign of the warming relations between the two nations. An official of the International Committee of the Red Cross said in a telephone interview from Geneva that it was not immediately known how many prisoners had yet to be repatriated. But the Red Cross, which is coordinating the exchange, has estimated that some 100,000 prisoners were held by both sides before the exchange began. The move came as an Iranian delegation headed by Deputy Foreign Minister Manouchehr Mottaki met in Baghdad with an Iraqi team led by foreign undersecretary Wisam Al-Zahawi to discuss normalization of ties between the former gulf war foes. Tehran Radio, monitored in Nicosia, reported Sunday that repatriation of the prisoners, which began Aug. 17 after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein gave in to Iranian territorial demands over their shared border, was abruptly halted Sunday without any explanation from Baghdad. Reports from Iraq confirmed that no Iraqi prisoners had been repatriated since Sunday, either. The prisoners who still have to be exchanged are those whom the Red Cross had been unable to register. Internationally isolated after his Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, Saddam last month made peace with Iran. He initiated the prisoner exchange, agreed to shared sovereignty over the Shatt-Al-Arab waterway, which forms the southern border between the two countries, and removed troops from Iranian territory captured during the war.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi, Soviet Reach Tentative Agreement on Diplomatic Ties
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia and the Soviet Union reached a preliminary agreement today to restore diplomatic relations after a break of more than 50 years, the official Tass news agency reported. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and his Saudi counterpart, Prince Saud Al-Faisal Al Saud, also called for the immediate withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait, Tass said. Shevardnadze said the two nations reached a preliminary agreement to restore diplomatic relations, and he hoped the question would be settled fully after the Saudi minister met with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Tass said. ``The issue of establishing official contacts between the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and Saudi Arabia has long been ripe,'' a Foreign Ministry official, Sergei Kirpichenko, was quoted by Tass as saying. Saudi Arabia's new rapport with Moscow comes after the Soviet Union -despite its long alliance with Iraq - broke with Baghdad and condemned the invasion of Kuwait. Saudi Arabia and Moscow had full diplomatic relations until 1938, when dictator Josef Stalin closed his embassy in Jiddah in a cost-cutting move. Several attempts to re-establish ties during the 1980s faltered over what Saudi Arabia called the Soviet Union's ``belligerent attitude'' toward its 50 million Moslems. In their discussions of the Persian Gulf crisis, the Saudi and Soviet foreign ministers were quoted as saying both wanted a peaceful settlement. ``We hope that faced with the world community's unanimity, Iraq will agree to the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of its troops from Kuwait and will restore legality,'' Tass quoted the Saudi official as saying. On Sunday, the Saudi Arabian minister of pilgrimage and endowments arrived in Moscow to attend a three-day Islamic conference and meet with Soviet Moslems, Tass said. The visit is the first ever to be made by a religious affairs minister to the Soviet Union. As part of the improving atmosphere between the two countries, King Fahd, the Saudi monarch, recently donated about 1.6 million copies of the Moslem holy book, the Koran, to Soviet Moslems. The Soviet Union allowed more than 1,000 Soviet Moslems to make the annual pilgrimage, or hajj, to Mecca this summer.

DOC.HEAD: First Cambodian Council Session Ends Without Progress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads thruout to UPDATE with fight over Sihanouk's role, details on meeting. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Cambodia's warring factions today held the first session of a council formed to try to end 11 years of civil war and argued over the future role of guerrilla leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk. The Supreme National Council, created last week during talks in Indonesia's capital, Jakarta, met for three hours at the Cambodian Embassy. The embassy had been abandoned since 1975, but 100 Thai workers cleared it of overgrown foliage and repainted it over the weekend. ``There were some problems, and we will have to resume discussions tomorrow,'' said Premier Hun Sen of the Vietnamese-installed government. He would not elaborate. The council has six seats for the Vietnam-installed Phnom Penh government and two spots for each of the rebel factions. The plan also allows for a 13th seat for a chairman, but the post remains in dispute. The guerrillas want Sihanouk to hold the chairman seat. A Thai Foreign Ministry official said Hun Sen replied that Sihanouk could only be chairman if he also takes the spot of one of the dozen regular members. Sihanouk officials accused Hun Sen of ``intransigence.'' The council now includes six representatives of Hun Sen's government and two representatives from each of the three allied guerrilla groups. Not discussed were other items Hun Sen placed on the agenda: choosing a delegation to this week's U.N. General Assembly, and arranging a ``voluntary cease-fire'' and an end to outside military aid. The rebel coalition includes the non-Communist forces of Sihanouk and former Cambodian premier Son Sann, who have been backed by Washington, and the Chinese-backed Communist Khmer Rouge, ousted by the Vietamese in 1978. During nearly four years in power, the Khmer Rouge tried to transform Cambodia into a radical agrarian society, resulting in the deaths of nearly 1 million people. The Supreme National Council would cede much of its authority to the United Nations, which would administer the country until free elections. U.N. officials have said up to 20,000 troops and civilian personnel could be sent to Cambodia to oversee the plan. The U.N. plan, which also calls for disarming the four armies, was adopted Aug. 28 by the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council: the United States, Soviet Union, China, Britain and France. Hun Sen met in the session with Khieu Samphan of the Khmer Rouge, Son Sann of the Khmer People's National Liberation Front and Prince Norodom Ranariddh, who commands forces loyal to Sihanouk, his father. The sparsely furnished meeting room was decorated with fresh flowers and photographs of Cambodia, including one of Angkor Wat, ancient capital of its greatest civilization.

DOC.HEAD: Inmates at Oakdale, La., Federal Deportation Center Set Fire to Dormitory
DOC.TEXT: Rampaging inmates at the Federal Deportation Center set fire to a housing wing, but authorities brought the situation under control after about two hours, authorities said. ``All the inmates are accounted for,'' Oakdale Mayor George Mowad said Sunday night. No one was seriously injured and no hostages were taken, Mowad said. One Bureau of Prisons employee was treated for smoke inhalation. The Deportation Center holds aliens awaiting deportation after serving time for crimes committed in the United States. It is near the Federal Detention Center, which was rebuilt after it was destroyed by fire during an eight-day siege by Cuban detainees in November 1987. Inmates at the deportation center, which holds about 300 people, set fire to one wing of one dormitory during a disturbance at about 9 p.m. Sunday, Mowad said. The fire was extinguished about 11 p.m. At least five state police patrol cars were dispatched to the prison, and the Calcasieu Parish Sheriff's Office also sent about 10 deputies to the prison. A roadblock was set up about a half mile from the center to keep people away. Edwin Strother, who lives near the federal complex, said Sunday's incident didn't compare with the November 1987 riot at the Detention Center. ``The other time it worried me. This time it didn't,'' Strother said. ``The last time they burned that thing plumb to the ground.'' The Deportation Center, which opened in April, was built by the Bureau of Prisons and is operated in conjunction with the INS and the Executive Office for Immigration Review. Hearings are held at the center to determine whether aliens are to be deported.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet-US Mistrust Given Way To Cautious Friendship, Reagan Says
LaserPhoto MOSB3
DOC.TEXT: Mistrust between the Soviet Union and the United States has given way to ``cautious friendship,'' former President Ronald Reagan told a Soviet parliamentary committee today. He later met with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Reagan, addressing the international committee of the Supreme Soviet legislature, predicted gradual arms reductions by both superpowers in the next five years ``as we find new ways to work together on matters where our goals are similar.'' ``We both have powerful tools of war,'' he said. ``Neither of us wants to use them. However, we can use the knowledge about hem to help blunt or head off regional conflicts or reckless acts of renegades.'' ``Together, our great size can be used in the service of all humankind to persuade those whose passions have reached the danger point to cool down again,'' he said, speaking from a podium beneath a portrait of Karl Marx. Reagan singled out Soviet cooperation in countering Iraq's invasion of Kuwait as an example of ``our mutual understanding for the need to prevent the spread of conflict in a volatile region of the world.'' Reagan and his wife, Nancy, arrived in Moscow on Sunday, the second day of a five-day visit. Reagan's talks with Gorbachev today were closed to the media. Reagan is scheduled to meet Tuesday with students at Moscow State University. Referring to efforts by the Soviet government to hammer out a new federal structure with its 15 ethnically diverse republics, Reagan appealed for reason to prevail over passion. ``As you find a reformulation of the relationships in your union, you will find there is a period of uncertainty and tension,'' he said. ``Differences can be resolved in ways that are fair to all, but reason must prevail over passion if there is to be a climate conducive to the settlement of disagreements. Thirteen republics have declared independence or sovereignty, defined as republican laws having precedence over national laws. ``When men and women are free to express themselves, and do so in large numbers, as is happening in your land today, a consensus will emerge over time on major issues,'' Reagan told about 50 lawmakers gathered around a long conference table. The Reagans, on a 10-day European tour, spent Sunday in Leningrad touring the city's cathedrals and the Hermitage Museum.

DOC.HEAD: West Africans Bomb Liberian Rebels
DOC.TEXT: Ghanaian warplanes bombed rebels in the Liberian capital of Monrovia in retaliation for a mortar attack that killed five members of a West African peacekeeping force, reports from the city said. Liberian rebels under Charles Taylor shelled the headquarters of the 3,000-member task force Saturday, killing three Nigerian medical workers. Another shell hit a Ghanaian warship docked in the port, killing two sailors. In response, two Ghanaian fighter bombers went into action Sunday ``looking for and neutralizing artillery emplacements,'' the British Broadcasting Corp. quoted a West African task force spokesman as saying. Nigeria, meanwhile, sent 650 more soldiers to join its 1,000-member contingent in the force. The soldiers were flown Sunday from Lagos to Freetown, Sierra Leone, where they were to board ships for Monrovia, a Nigerian government statement said. A rebel radio broadcast said three aircraft bombed Robertsfield International Airport, and charged that the United States was involved. A spokesman for the U.S. Embassy in Monrovia denied any American planes took part in the alleged raid. The airport, 30 miles east of Monrovia, has not been used by international airlines since it fell behind Taylor's lines in May. Monrovia has been cut off from the outside world since June, without running water, electricity or telephone communications. Little food has gotten through, and many people are dying of starvation. The war began when Taylor invaded from Ivory Coast in last December. President Samuel Doe was slain Sept. 10 by a breakaway rebel group led by Prince Johnson. Now the rebel factions headed by Johnson and Taylor are fighting for control. Rebels from both groups also have been hunting down members of Doe's Krahn tribe and remnants of his army. The West African task force has been criticized as ineffectual in halting the fighting, which has killed more than 5,000 civilians this year. The 3,000 troops from Nigeria, Ghana, Guinea, Sierra Leone and Gambia arrived in Monrovia early in August. Taylor has accused the West African force of wanting to impose a puppet government.
