He is holding more than 2,000 West African civilians hostage.

DOC.HEAD: Nearly 5,000 Teachers Strike In New Orleans; First Walkout Since '78
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to UPDATE with teachers reinstating original demands; and to add detail, including district enrollment, role of teachers' aides and secretaries, administration position on spending. No pickup. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 5,000 public school teachers went on strike today over $400,000 worth of health benefits - the first walkout in New Orleans schools since 1978. Union president Nat Lacour said the Orleans Parish School Board's refusal to bend on health benefits that demand triggered the strike. He reinstated earlier demands that had been dropped during bargaining, for a $45 million package that includes pay raises for the system's teachers plus 1,100 teachers' aides and school secretaries. The school board insisted that classes would continue almost as usual for more than 84,000 pupils, with substitute teachers and administrators replacing teachers who refused to cross picket lines. Parents of some emotionally disturbed or educationally handicapped children were told that classes for their children would be canceled. Pickets were out before dawn, their signs bearing messages such as: ``No raise, No work.'' School buses rolled past the chanting pickets half empty. Parents walked with their children to the schools, then stood about in small knots, talking quietly. ``We're not striking just for money. ... We're looking for professional respect,'' said Katy Hall, a sixth-grade teacher at Lafayette Elementary School, where the picket line went up more than two hours before classes were to open. Lacour, president of the United Teachers of New Orleans, gave strike orders Sunday in a blistering speech that laid the blame on what he called the school board's poor spending habits and inflexibility. ``It's a strike over economic justice,'' Lacour said. The teachers scaled back over the weekend to demanding $1 million in additional health benefits. The school board turned them down and stuck to the $600,000 it had on the table. ``We cannot give what we do not have,'' said Frank Fudesco, the board's chief negotiator. He appealed to teachers ``to weigh loyalty to union against loyalty to students.'' The teachers, who receive pay from both the school system and the state, have already received a 7 percent wage increase from the state this year. Salaries range from $19,455 for a starting teacher to $35,111 for someone with a doctorate and 25 years of experience. About 650 teachers' aides, who make about $10,000 a year, would get raises of 4 percent to 5 percent under union demands, as would 450 clerical workers, who make about $17,000. In his speech, Lacour complained that school administrators drive new cars while schools go without soap and toilet paper. He also criticized Superintendent Everett Williams' $102,700 a year salary, which Lacour said is comparable to the pay in larger cities. Administrators have dismissed the union's complaints and say their spending has been appropriate. With the board's refusal to agree to the union demands, teachers said they will circulate recall petitions against all school board members. In addition, after the strike broke out, the union reverted to its original demands for 10 percent raises each year of a three-year contract. The board has raised teachers' salaries twice since 1983, but Lacour said the increases have been eroded by rising health insurance and retirement costs. The union also is seeking collective bargaining rights for about 100 psychologists and other employees who evaluate students for special education services.

DOC.HEAD: Besieged Policemen And Soldiers Removed From Fort
DOC.TEXT: The army today evacuated nearly 200 policemen and soldiers who defended the Jaffna Fort during a three-month siege by Tamil rebels, military officials said. The rescued security men were airlifted by helicopter from the fort to an airstrip at Palali, also in Jaffna peninsula, officials said. ``Some of them could hardly walk and had to be carried,'' said one official who cannot be identified under briefing rules. ``They will receive initial medical treatment and then be sent to Colombo to their familes for a rest.'' Troops broke through the siege last week to reach the fort at the edge of Jaffna city, a predominately Tamil city 187 miles north of Colombo. Jaffna is the stronghold of the Liberation Tigers for Tamil Eelam, which has been fighting for an independent homeland for Tamils in the Sinhalese-dominated country. The officials said the army has consolidated positions around the fort and was slowly expanding its perimeters to reach the closed government hospital in Jaffna. Twelve policemen and soldiers were killed during the siege and were buried inside the fort, built by Dutch colonialists in the 17th century. The star-shaped fortress was cut off since Tamil rebels broke a 13-month cease-fire in June. Tamils form 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, while Sinhalese make up 75 percent of the populations. At least 14,000 people have been killed since the ethnic war erupted in 1983.

DOC.HEAD: `L.A. Law' Big Winner at Emmy Awards
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Despite 14...', to CORRECT that `Twin Peaks' on ABC sted CBS.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos
With PM-Emmys-List
DOC.TEXT: ``L.A. Law'' won the Emmy for best drama series for the third time in four years, ``Murphy Brown'' was named best comedy and the acclaimed ``Twin Peaks,'' nominated 14 times, managed only two technical trophies. Ted Danson, the skirt-chasing bartender Sam Malone on ``Cheers,'' finally won as best comedy series actor Sunday night after being nominated eight times - every year the NBC show has been on the air. And Candice Bergen of CBS' ``Murpy Brown'' won best actress as the acid-tongued newswoman for a second consecutive year. In a big signoff for ``The Tracey Ullman Show,'' the British comedian's program grabbed the most awards at the 42nd annual Emmys with six. Ullman, who pulled the plug on the little-watched show last spring, won Fox Broadcasting Co. its first Emmys last year. ``Oh, blimey, this brings it all full circle,'' said Miss Ullman, honored with a pair of Emmys in the music-variety category for her work as star and a writer. ``I miss the show a whole lot.'' Peter Falk's rumpled but brilliant ``Columbo'' earned him the dramatic actor award - his fourth Emmy for the role of the trenchcoat-wearing detective he created during the '70s. Patricia Wettig, who plays a cancer-stricken young mother on ABC's ``thirtysomething,'' won the best dramatic actress trophy. ``I would really like to thank all the women with cancer who have shared their stories with me so wholeheartedly,'' a teary Miss Wettig said. ``I shared their insights and their fears. I truly salute their courage.'' Despite 14 nominations, ABC's ``Twin Peaks,'' the strange new series about murder in a Northwest logging town, captured only two technical trophies - for editing and costuming. Both were given in a non-televised ceremony Saturday. Instead, NBC's ``L.A. Law'' went home with the best drama Emmy - an honor it also received in 1987 and 1989 - and won a writing award plus a best supporting actor Emmy for Jimmy Smits, who plays lawyer Victor Sifuentes. In a reversal of the order last year, ABC finished first with 22 awards, NBC won 18 and CBS, which topped the Big Three networks with 27 Emmys in 1989, managed only 14 this year. Fox won nine Emmys, the most in its four-year history. Cable's Home Box Office collected eight. Best miniseries went to NBC's ``Drug Wars: The Camarena Story,'' an account of the torture-slaying of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena. ``This is a victory for him, too,'' said executive producer Michael Mann. Keenen Ivory Wayans, whose irreverent Fox comedy sketch series ``In Living Color'' won the variety, music or comedy category, welled up. ``Oh, forget it,'' said the show's executive producer and host. ``This is for you, Mom.'' Scott Winant of ``thirtysomething,'' who tied with Thomas Carter of ``Equal Justice'' for best drama series director, got choked up, too. ``I'm afraid I'm not really going to be able to express myself,'' he said. Danson's award was presented by the animated family from Fox's ``The Simpsons.'' Obnoxious 10-year-old son Bart Simpson shredded the envelope containing Danson's name and pronounced himself the winner. Asked how it felt to receive his trophy from cartoon characters, Danson replied, ``I think it is appropriate after nine years. I feel a little weird. I felt like if it didn't happen this year it would be more embarrassing than ever before.'' Joseph Sargent was named best director in a miniseries or special for his work on CBS' ``Caroline?'' Vincent Gardenia won for supporting actor in a miniseries or special, given for HBO's ``Age-Old Friends.'' Eva Marie Saint took the trophy for supporting actress in a miniseries or special, co-starring in NBC's ``People Like Us.'' A special recognition was given to puppeteer Jim Henson, who died earlier this year. To the strains of Kermit the Frog's song ``The Rainbow Connection,'' Miss Bergen, daughter of puppeteer Edgar Bergen, movingly recounted Henson's career. Alex Rocco won outstanding supporting actor in a comedy for his portrayal of sleazy talent agent Al Floss in ``The Famous Teddy Z,'' which was canceled this year. The supporting actress award went to Bebe Neuwirth, the cold-as-ice psychoanalyst on ``Cheers.'' ABC's ``The Wonder Years'' collected trophies for best directing (Michael Dinner) and writing (Bob Brush) in a comedy series. Miss Bergen, Jay Leno and Jane Pauley were the program's hosts. During Saturday's technical awards, Fox's ``The Simpsons'' was selected top animated program. Hume Cronyn, who starred in HBO's ``Age Old Friends,'' took the prize for best actor in a miniseries or special. Barbara Hershey, who played the lead in CBS' ``A Killing in A Small Town,'' won for best actress in a miniseries or special.

DOC.HEAD: Loggers Rally As Lobbying Blitz Begins
DOC.TEXT: About 200 Northwest loggers and community leaders rallied on Capitol Hill today, asking for compassion for mill workers and families who may be hurt by environmentalist-backed plans to slow timber harvests. ``The social havoc and human suffering being caused in the Northwest is a concern for everyone,'' said Valerie Johnson, leader of the Oregon Lands Coalition. The push for protection of the region's old-growth forests has intensified since the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service declared in June that one of its inhabitants, the northern spotted owl, is a threatened species. ``The preservationist agenda has become more clear to us as we learn what is happening in other parts of the nation. Farmers, fishermen, miners - we are all being told that Americans don't need us any more,'' Ms. Johnson said. The coalition is one of the groups making up the Northwest Citizen's Lobby, which plans to lobby each member of Congress this week in an effort to stir up opposition to proposals that would ban logging across millions of acres of Northwest forests. Environmentalists planned their own lobbying blitz this week after about 500 demonstrators rallied at the Capitol on Sunday to protest a series of bills they say would further reduce the shrinking supply of the nation's old-growth forests. ``The timber industry lobby has a national agenda as they grab the wealth of public lands, operating from a national power base in Congress,'' said Mark Winstein of Save America's Forests, an organization that sponsored the demonstration. ``We didn't come to Washington to ask Congress for a handout. We came to ask for the opportunity to continue working,'' said Doug Robertson, a county commissioner from Roseburg, Ore., participating in the Oregon Lands Coalition rally. ``All patriotic Americans must join forces to create a new power base that will represent our desire for a healthy environment,'' said Winstein, whose coalition speaks for more than 30 organizations representing nearly 150,000 members in 18 states. At today's rally, Evelyn Badger presented Rep. Denny Smith, R-Ore., with 40,000 petition signatures from Northwest families. The petition asks Congress to consider the social and economic impacts on families and communities as it weighs scientific evidence concerning preservation plans for the Northwest's forests. ``There's a war waging across this nation and resource-dependent people are losing,'' Ms. Badger said. ``The challenge now is to convince federal lawmakers to weigh both the scientific evidence and the social price tag.'' Smith, who is seeking re-election and has been targeted by environmentalists as an enemy, said the Northwest residents face an uphill battle.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Air Force Chief of Staff Dismissed
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force chief of staff, Gen. Mike Dugan, was relieved of his duties today, the Pentagon said. The action came one day after Dugan was quoted in published reports as saying U.S. military authorities had concluded that massive air strikes are the only effective way of forcing Iraq out of Kuwait if war erupted. Dugan was on a tour of U.S. military instillations in Saudi Arabia when he made his comments. Lt. Col. Rick Oborn, a Pentagon spokesman, said he could not immediately comment on the reason for Dugan's dismissal. He said a formal announcement was being prepared. Dugan commanded the U.S. Air Force in Europe before his appointment as chief of staff three months ago. On Sunday, National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft distanced the adminstration from Dugan's comments, which appeared in the Los Angeles Times and The Washington Post. ``I would just point out that Gen. Dugan is not in the chain of command, and he does not speak for the administration,'' Scowcroft said.

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Ship Explodes, Continues Burning Into Morning
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with last compartment blowing up, no cargo spilled, plans to spray with foam; pick up 6th graf pvs, `Ronald Stopyak ...; SUBS grafs 9-10, `Henry said ..., with 3 grafs to UPDATE with governor declaring emergency, details on missing crewman; pick up penultimate graf, `Bay Medical ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BAY1 of Sept. 16
DOC.TEXT: The sixth and final fuel compartment on a burning gasoline tanker exploded this morning, the day after the first in a series of blasts and fire injured 17 crew members, authorities said. One crewman who apparently tried to swim for shore was missing. The blazing, 392-foot hulk burned through the night, casting an orange glow across the Saginaw River. None of the cargo of 1 million gallons of gasoline had spilled into the river from the double-hulled tanker, but Coast Guard officials feared the hull might melt or break because of the intense heat, spreading flaming fuel into the water. Officials decided this morning to use a Coast Guard cutter, along with oil rig fire specialists from Texas, to spray the tanker from bow to stern with fire-retarding foam. Then they would wait 24 hours before trying to move the ship. The M.V. Jupiter, a tanker owned by Cleveland Tankers Inc., erupted in flames Sunday morning while moored at a pier. It had pumped about 30,000 barrels of its 54,000-barrel cargo into a pipeline leading to storage tanks ashore, said Dan Lacey, spokesman for Ashland Oil Inc., parent company of Cleveland Tankers. Ronald Stopyak, who had returned home 15 minutes before the blast from working at a chemical plant across the river from the tanker, said he raced back to work after hearing the explosion. ``I thought the plant exploded and when I got out there I saw black smoke everywhere,'' he said. ``I saw the employees on the ship go overboard. It was really hot. I could feel the heat from across the river.'' State environmental officials undertook water and air pollution tests, said spokeswoman Susan Henry. A gasoline spill is less damaging than an oil spill because gasoline evaporates easily. Gov. James Blanchard visited the site and declared an emergency to free up state aid and assistance. Henry said Ashland had set up booms to contain any spill. Coast Guard crews secured the tanker with cables to prevent it from drifting into a bridge. The missing crewman was identified as Tom Sexton, 46, of Cedar Falls, Iowa. Other crewmen said Sexton tried to swim for shore after the explosion but apparently didn't make it. Bay Medical Center spokesman Curt Miller said 17 crew members were treated there and three were admitted. Two had head injuries, and a third suffered chest pains, he said. Bay City is a town of 40,000 on Lake Huron's Saginaw Bay, about 100 miles northwest of Detroit.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors: Barry Will Not Be Tried Again
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 8th graf pvs, The decision, with four grafs of additional comments from Stephens, picks up 9th graf pvs, The prosecutor.
DOC.TEXT: Federal prosecutors said today they will not retry Mayor Marion Barry on a dozen drug and perjury charges a jury could not resolve. ``I'm obviously relieved,'' the mayor said. The government's decision came five weeks after Barry was convicted of one misdemeanor charge of cocaine possession and acquitted on another. Jurors deadlocked on the 12 remaining perjury and drug charges, and U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson declared a mistrial on those counts. Jackson set Oct. 26 as the sentencing date for the possession charge. The mayor faces a maximum penalty of one year in prison and a $100,000 fine. At the sentencing hearing, prosecutors will make a formal motion for dismissal of the unsettled charges. Jackson is expected to grant the request. Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin told the judge today, ``The government has made a determination not to seek retrial on the pending counts.'' Barry smiled broadly when Retchin announced the government's decision. ``I'm obviously relieved at this phase of the legal proceedings,'' Barry said afterward. He declined further comment. U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens told reporters that even if Barry were convicted on some of the remaining charges, the potential sentence would not be significantly longer than what he already faces. ``A retrial would achieve little more than what has already been accomplished,'' Stephens said. ``When all the dust has settled, in the final analysis, the ultimate truth remains: that the chief executive of this city charged with leading the fight against illegal drugs and violence has himself been convicted of contributing to that human devastation,'' Stephens said. ``What has been achieved here really is substantial, and a retrial would not contribute substantially more to that result, in terms of the public record of the evidence,'' Stephens said. The prosecutor denied that political considerations, including Barry's pre-trial decision not to run for re-election, entered into his choice. ``Mr. Barry's political status and political future are not factors we considered when making decisions about this prosecution,'' Stephens said. A week after the jury's Aug. 10 verdict, Barry announced he would run as an independent for a seat on the city council. He had ruled out seeking a fourth four-year term as mayor before his trial began. After the jury's verdict, Barry urged federal prosecutors to abandon any thought of retrying him, saying: ``Now is the time for healing. Let their judgment be our last judgment.'' The jury's decision followed a dramatic eight-week trial in which the jurors - and the world - watched videotape of Barry smoking crack cocaine the night he was arrested in an FBI sting operation at a downtown hotel room. Earlier this month, the U.S. attorney for the Virgin Islands, Terry Halperin, announced that she would not bring charges against the mayor there. One of the felony perjury charges and the conspiracy charge Barry faced involved alleged drug activity in the Virgin Islands during 1986 and 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Decides Not To Request Further Injunction
DOC.TEXT: The Israeli government decided today not to seek an extension of a court injunction that banned publication of a book by a former intelligence agent. The decision means the book, ``By Way of Deception'' by Victor Ostrovsky, could be on Canadian bookstore shelves by the end of the month, a spokesman for Stoddart Publishing of Toronto said. The Israeli government won the 10-day injunction Sept. 7. It argued that release of the book would endanger the lives of its agents. ``The harm we were seeking to prevent has already occurred,'' Joel Goldenberg, a lawyer for the Israeli government, told the general division of Ontario Court. He was referring to a New York appellate court decision Thursday allowing the book - by Ostrovsky, a former Mossad agent, and Canadian journalist Claire Hoy - to be published by St. Martin's Press. ``Without the American decision, it would have been a tough battle, but I think it's one we would have won,'' said Gordon Wood, lawyer for Stoddart, Ostrovsky and Hoy. A day after the New York decision, bookstores were swamped with requests for the book. Those that had copies sold out almost immediately. St. Martin's had already shipped 17,000 copies of the book to 1,500 stores and reviewers before Israel obtained a temporary order from a state Supreme Court justice barring sales.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Team Arrives for Asian Games
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Forty-two Kuwaiti athletes accompanied by a single coach arrived today from Saudi Arabia to take part in this week's Asian Games, their entourage diminished by Iraq's invasion of their homeland. Games officials did not say how large a delegation Kuwait originally planned, but more coaches were to have come. Kuwait's National Olympic Committee, now based in exile in Saudi Arabia, said athletes who were out of the country during the Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion would come to the games. The chairman of Kuwait's National Olympic Committee, Sheikh Fahad Al-Ahmad Al-Sabah, was killed during the invasion. The sheik also was president of the Olympic Council of Asia and was to have presided over the Asian Games, which start Saturday. The Asian Games press center said 42 athletes arrived from Saudi Arabia, including 23 soccer players, four swimmers, six table tennis players, six track and field contestants and three judo contenders. They were accompanied by a swimming coach. Kais Al-Yacoubi, a liaison officer for Iraq's National Olympic Committee, said in Beijing last week that any Kuwait athletes caught inside their country during the invasion would have to apply to Iraqi authorities for exit permits to attend the games. He refused to comment on the chances they would be allowed to leave. All 38 members of the Olympic Council of Asia are scheduled to meet Thursday to decide whether Iraq should be banned from the games. The council's 11-member executive bureau recommended a ban, but the final decision will be made by a two-thirds majority of the full council. China has said it welcomes participation by all council members but also hopes all will comply with the council's decision. If Iraq takes part, a boycott is feared by other Persian Gulf states. An Iraqi soccer team is in China for non-Asian Games competition against Chinese teams, but Iraq's Asian Games team has yet to arrive.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Investigating Arson As Cause Of California Forest Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 2 grafs at the end to update with cost of fighting fire, small fire in Yosemite.
DOC.TEXT: Officials are investigating arson as the cause of a fire that charred 2,500 acres in the Stanislaus National Forest and forced 400 people to spend a night away from their homes. ``It's definitely arson,'' U.S. Forest Service spokeswoman Joan Leidenthal said Sunday. Investigators had a few leads about a possible culprit but were releasing no further information, she said. The fire began Thursday in a campground on the north fork of the Tuolumne River about 130 miles east of San Francisco. Aided by fairly cool temperatures in the low 80s, light wind under 10 mph and normal humidity, about 2,700 firefighters contained the blaze by 6 p.m. Sunday and expected to have it under control later today. No buildings have been damaged, but the blaze forced the evacuation of about 400 residents when flames came within a half mile of their homes Friday. Residents were allowed to return to their homes on Saturday, and the Forest Service said the threat to residents of the resort towns of Mi-Wuk, Sierra Village and Sugarpine had passed. ``There was the potential to really burn a lot of structures, but we protected quite a few. We just got lucky. The weather cooperated,'' fire information officer Mike Brown said. Five firefighters were injured. The cost of fighting the fire climbed to $3.5 million. To the southeast, in fire-scarred Yosemite National Park, a small fire charred about 120 acres near Mount Starr King, about 3 miles south of Half Dome. It was contained Sunday evening and full control was expected later today, fire officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Libyan Delegate Calls For Suicide Attacks Against Americans
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with PLO official quoted as saying Iraq must leave Kuwait. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `Sauddi said...'
DOC.TEXT: A Libyan delegate at a conference of Arab radicals called today for suicide attacks on U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf and Saudi Arabia. Ibrahim Al-Kharraz, a member of the Libyan People's Congress, said Arabs should follow the example of the suicide bombers who blew up the Marine barracks in Beirut in 1983, killing 241 Marines. ``We have the striking examples of heroes who turned their bodies into bombs that horrified the aggressors and forced them to flee in darkness as happened to the American Marines in Beirut,'' said Al-Kharraz. The cheers and enthusiastic applause from delegates to the conference of Arab leftists, Islamic party members and Palestinian guerrilla factions underscored the depth of anti-American feeling among Arab radicals. The Palestine Liberation Organization has come out on the side of Iraq during the crisis. But in Stockholm today, a senior PLO official was quoted as saying Iraq must leave Kuwait and a solution to the crisis should not be delayed by the Israeli-Palestinian issue. The PLO has called for an international conference to settle the gulf crisis and deal with Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. ``But the first step must be that Iraq leaves Kuwait. We do not demand that the two issues be linked,'' Nabil Shaath, an aide to PLO chief Yasser Arafat, was quoted as telling the Swedish national news agency TT. ``We have been hurt by the saying that PLO is on the side of Iraq. But this is not true. We demand that Iraq leave Kuwait,'' Shaath said. The delegates at the Jordan conference also cheered when Adnan Saududdin, a member of the Jordanian Islamic Front and the fundamentalist Moslem Brotherhood, called for an Islamic uprising to topple Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. Saududdin said Moslems should rise up against Mubarak and free Egypt from ``the shackles of the treasonous CampDavid accords.'' The three-day conference also got a lift when the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine said in a statement that King Hussein met today with its leader, Nayef Hawatmeh. There was no one immediately available at the king's press office or the Information Minstry to confirm the report. Hawatmeh had been banned from Jordan for 20 years after the ``Black September'' war in 1970 between Palestinian guerrillas and the king's forces. However, Hawatmeh and George Habash, the leader of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine who also was banned for 20 years, returned to Jordan last week for the conference. Hawatmeh's Palestinian guerrilla faction said that the king and Hawatmeh talked at length about the gulf crisis and Middle East problems.

DOC.HEAD: Prominent Vietnamese Editor Dies
DOC.TEXT: Dao Tung, the editor in chief of the official Vietnam News Agency, has died at a hospital in Hanoi, the agency announced Monday. He was 65. It said he died Saturday at the Vietnam-USSR Friendship Hospital but did not specify the illness. He is to be buried Tuesday. The agency said Dao Tung was a member of the National Assembly and vice president and secretary-general of the Vietnam Journalists Association. The Vietnam News Agency and the state radio are the two prime daily sources of official news on Vietnam for foreign news organizations based outside that country.

DOC.HEAD: Police Disperse Refugee Demonstration
DOC.TEXT: Riot police dispersed an estimated 25,000 Mozambican refugees who were protesting food at their refugee camp, police said Monday. Four people were arrested during the protest Friday at a camp near Petauke, 235 miles east of Lusaka. Police said the refugees, who allege the camp's Zairean fugitives receive better food, tried to ransack a food depot. A police spokesman, who by custom is not identified, said camp authorities were investigating the complaints. This southern African nation of 7.5 million people gives refuge to more than 30,000 Mozambicans who have fled the 13-year-old civil war in their homeland. In addition, an unspecified number of Zaireans sought refuge here after government troops in their homeland allegedly massacred at least 50 student protesters in May.

DOC.HEAD: American, International Publishers Train Hungarians
DOC.TEXT: American and European publishers on Monday opened a weeklong seminar in Budapest designed to train dozens of Hungarian publishers, editors and executives in management, distribution, advertising, promotion and marketing. Lloyd G. Schermer, chairman of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, and ANPA board members on a tour of central Europe were among those attending the seminar organized by the Paris-based International Federation of Newspaper Publishers. Western publishers have bought heavily into the Hungarian press since it was freed of Communist control last year. Rival publishers Rupert Murdoch and Robert Maxwell have bought part shares in the national dailies Magyar Hirlap and Esti Hirlap respectively. The West German publishing house founded by Axel Springer and Oskar Bronner, publisher of Austria's Der Standard daily, are among those who have purchased outright various local publications outside Budapest.

DOC.HEAD: Mountain Accidents Kill Ten Germans and Swiss
DOC.TEXT: Mountaineering accidents killed seven West Germans and three Swiss over the weekend in the Swiss Alps, police said Monday. Six of the Germans, grouped in two rope parties, died when they fell at a height of 13,200 feet on Mount Aletschorn, near Zermatt in the southern canton of Valais. Police said the victims apparently slipped on ice. Icy conditions were also responsible for the deaths of two Swiss climbers in another part of Valais, police reported. It did not give details of the other accidents.

DOC.HEAD: General Says Military Seeking R&R Sites for U.S. Troops
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: American troops sweltering in Saudi Arabia might be allowed to take their rest and recreation in foreign cities, on private beaches or on cruise ships, U.S. officials say. The need for some kind of holiday system has become apparent with the realization that U.S. military forces are likely to be in the desert at least until early 1991 and probably longer. At the same time, officials concede there are special problems in finding ways to let American soldiers relax in Saudi Arabia, a strictly conservative Moslem society where they cannot mix casually with the local population or the opposite sex. Moreover, the sheer size of the American force - likely to reach 200,000-plus within a few weeks - could have a severe impact on nearby smaller Persian Gulf states, such as Bahrain and Dubai, where alcohol is available and the lifestyle is somewhat more Westernized. Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of U.S. forces in Operation Desert Shield, said in an interview that he envisioned an R&R system similar to that provided for American troops in Vietnam two decades ago. Those soldiers were allowed one week's leave a year, with the round-trip air fare paid to any one of several places, including Hong Kong, Australia, Singapore, Taiwan, Bangkok and Hawaii. ``I'd hope we could have the same sort of platter of selection available here,'' Schwarzkopf said. But, he added, ``we're still in the process of brainstorming this whole routine. ... We're a long way from having any firm plan for R&R.'' One obstacle is that Defense Department regulations permit government-paid leaves only for soldiers in areas where there is hostile fire, he said. ``I know they're looking at that and a lot of other things,'' he said, noting that another Pentagon regulation already has been changed to give Saudi Arabia-based troops free mail privileges, usually permitted only in combat zones. A key concern in finding suitable recreation centers was the threat of Iraqi-inspired terrorist attacks, Schwarzkopf said. ``I'm not going to set up another Beirut barracks to get blown up,'' he said, referring to the 1983 bombing of a U.S. Marine barracks in Beirut in which 241 servicemen were killed. ``We're certainly factoring that into it.'' If a Vietnam-style R&R is approved, possible sites might include Cairo and vacation spots in Europe, such as the U.S.-owned military ski resort and recreation center in Garmisch, West Germany. Schwarzkopf said another proposal was for ``a couple of cruise ships, where they can relax and dance and have music and air conditioning and swimming pools, and just sort of live it up.'' Schwarzkopf said, however, that this was ``an idea only,'' as was another suggestion for a private beach somewhere that could serve American troops without their numbers having too much impact on the local population. The two most logical R&R sites in the region are Bahrain, just across a 12-mile causeway from Saudi Arabia, and Dubai, the major port of the United Arab Emirates near the southeastern end of the Persian Gulf. Both are accustomed to U.S. Navy personnel, in relatively small numbers and civilian clothes. But they could have difficulty coping with an influx of military people looking for fun. Schwarzkopf said there had been ``no agreements ... no formal contacts'' with those countries. But he said he could imagine ``some entrepreneurial Bahrainis who wouldn't mind setting up a hotel at some location that wouldn't interfere with Bahraini life.'' In addition to planning for out-of-country R&R, officers are setting up centers with air-conditioned tents, showers and television, where troops can gain a few days' respite from the desert. Schwarzkopf acknowledged that while the military faced a ``shortage of videotapes,'' it also had to deal with the Saudis' ban on any sexually oriented materials. ``It's their law, just as we have customs regulations that don't allow outsiders to bring certain things into the United States,'' he said, ``So if they deem it objectionable and confiscate it, that's OK. I'm sure there are plenty of other videotapes out there that will not be deemed objectionable.''

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Holds Records for Most Launch Delays
With AM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Columbia, NASA's oldest and most delayed shuttle, has been grounded twice in four months by hydrogen leaks and once by payload problems. Columbia set the record for the most launch delays in January 1986, when it was delayed seven times before a satellite delivery mission. So far this year, only three shuttles have flown. NASA originally planned nine missions for 1990, but now is hoping for six. The following is a chronology of this year's shuttle flights and Columbia's delays since May: Jan. 9 - Columbia lifts off on a mission to retrieve a scientific satellite. The flight had been scheduled for Dec. 18, but its launch pad was being refurbished and not ready. Bad weather delayed a Jan. 8 launch attempt. Feb. 28 - Atlantis is sent on a secret military mission following five delays due to bad weather and the commander's cold. It was one delay short of tying the record for launch postponements. April 24 - Discovery is launched with the Hubble Space Telescope. An April 10 launch attempt had been halted with four minutes to go because of a faulty valve in a hydraulic power unit. May 29 - NASA called off Columbia's May 30 launch attempt after hydrogen leaked during fueling. It was the first countdown for the astronomy mission. Aug. 30 - NASA halted Columbia's second countdown, canceling a Sept. 1 launch attempt, because of a failed electronic part on one of four telescopes inside the shuttle. Sept. 5 - NASA called off Columbia's Sept. 6 launch attempt after hydrogen flooded the aft compartment during fueling. Launch was rescheduled for Sept. 18.

DOC.HEAD: Teen-ager Arrested in Brutal Murders of Four Family Members
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager described as troubled and rebellious faces four counts of murder in connection with a weekend shooting rampage that left his grandparents and two other relatives dead. John Morrell Frierson, 17, was arrested without incident Sunday morning, said Pearl River County Sheriff Lorance Lumpkin. He was scheduled to face charges as an adult today on four counts of capital murder, two counts of rape and two counts of armed robbery, Lumpkin said. The sheriff identified the murder victims as Frierson's grandparents, Ray Merle Frierson, 61, and Molly M. Frierson, 57; his brother, Josh Morrell, 13; and his aunt, Pam Howard, 38. His grandparents had adopted him and raised him, authorities said. The sheriff said all four were killed by multiple gunshot wounds to the upper body and that both women were raped. One victim was severely beaten, Lumpkin said. Two guns believed used in the attack were recovered at the Frierson home. Lumpkin said the bodies were found at the house about 9 p.m. Saturday by relatives who became concerned when they couldn't reach anybody by phone. ``They feared something like this ... had happened,'' Lumpkin said. He said the shooting appeared to result from a ``buildup of frustration and rebellion of the boy.'' The youth was arrested at a friend's house about 1 a.m. Sunday and was held at the Pearl River County Jail. Lumpkin said the Sheriff's Department was also holding another 17-year-old in connection with the case, but so far that individual had not been charged. The second person's name was not released.

DOC.HEAD: Police Clash With Demonstrators on Eve of Bases Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmiting to correct cycle designator.
DOC.TEXT: Police clashed today with hundreds of people protesting U.S. military bases on the eve of talks on their future. At least 17 people were arrested and seven injured when police broke up rallies in front of the U.S. Embassy. The demonstrators urged the government to close Clark Air Base, the Subic Bay naval base and four smaller U.S. installations when their lease expires in September 1991. In a nationwide address, President Corazon Aquino said the U.S-Philippine talks beginning Tuesday will focus not only on the bases but also on the relationship between the United States and this former American territory. ``In a world where the Cold War has ended, and events in eastern Europe and the Middle East have altered the traditional geopolitical order, the decades-old parameters of the relationship no longer hold,'' Mrs. Aquino said. ``The old cannot continue; the new must now be born,'' she added. ``This new relationship shall be the subject of the talks that begin tomorrow.'' During the first round of talks in May, the two sides agreed to continue negotiations on a new bases agreement. Former Assistant Secretary of Defense Richard Armitage arrived today to lead the American panel. Early today, about 350 protesters marched to the U.S. Embassy but were driven away by police after some in the crowd hurled small homemade bombs. A bigger group of about 1,000 returned late in the afternoon but police again blocked their march about 600 feet from the embassy. Anti-bases activists plan to stage a series of demonstrations during the bases talks. Any new agreement would have to be approved by the 23-member Senate, where opposition to the facilities is strong. The 40,000 U.S. troops, military dependents and civilian employees have been restricted to their bases to avoid incidents during the talks.

DOC.HEAD: Derailment Results in Evacuation Of Small Arkanas Town
DOC.TEXT: The entire population of Chidester - about 345 people - was evacuated this morning when a Union Pacific train derailed and a car containing nitric acid began to leak, authorities said. Ten cars of the 51-car train went off the tracks near downtown Chidester, in Ouachita County in southern Arkansas, about 4:45 a.m., said Mark Davis, a spokesman for the railroad. Chidester is 84 miles southwest of Little Rock. Gary Talley of the state Office of Emergency Services said leaking cars contained nitric acid and ammonium nitrate. The evacuation was a precautionary measure, and no injuries were reported, Talley said. Nitric acid is corrosive to metals and tissue, according to a hazardous materials book at the OES. Prolonged exposure to low concentrations or short-term exposure to high concentrations may be harmful to health, it said. Talley said the substance is non-combustible, but will accelerate the burning of combustible materials. The ammonium nitrate is a fertilizer, Talley said. A State Police Hazardous Materials Team was dispatched to the site along with local and regional OES officials, and members of the Chidester and Camden fire departments, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Expelling Eight Diplomats, Other Iraqis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with two more expulsions announced, EC action. Pick up 3rd graf pvs, `The Home...'
DOC.TEXT: Britain expelled eight staff members from the Iraqi Embassy and ordered the deportation of 23 other Iraqi citizens today in what Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd called a gesture of solidarity with European allies. The action came as the 12 European Community nations decided to expel military attaches and restrict the movements of other diplomats to protest Iraqi raids last week on European embassy compounds in Kuwait. The Foreign Office said that two military attaches and six support staff were being expelled from the Iraqi Embassy in retaliation for the Iraqi intrusions. The Home Office later announced that 23 Iraqi nationals were being deported for reasons of national security. The names and occupations of those people were not disclosed. Hurd announced the action against the diplomatic staff in Brussels, Belgium, where he was attending a meeting of European Community foreign ministers. ``This all arises because I feel, the government feels, that we've got to act in solidarity with the French and the other countries whose embassies have been invaded and people taken out during the last few days,'' Hurd said in an interview relayed to London by the government's information office. A reporter asked Hurd if there was a danger that new sanctions could worsen the crisis. ``There is always a danger,'' Hurd said. ``But there is also a danger of letting these things happen and accepting them as if they were tolerable. They are not tolerable. ``Just as we have taken action against the Iraqis over their treatment of hostages in general, so we have taken action in this respect,'' Hurd said. On Friday, Iraqi troops stormed the residence of the French ambassador in Kuwait City, seizing four French citizens, including a military attache. The attache was later released, but the whereabouts of the other three remained unknown. Dutch, Belgian and Canadian diplomatic compounds in Kuwait also were raided last week by Iraqi troops. The embassy raids were unanimously condemned Sunday by the U.N. Security Council. France announced the ispatch of 4,000 additional troops to the Persian Gulf region and expelled 29 Iraqis in retaliation. Italy announced it was ousting all officials at the Iraqi military attache's office in Rome. In Paris, Iraq's ambassador today accused French authorities of maltreating military trainees who were expelled from France over the weekend. Pressed to give examples, Ambassador Abdul Razzak al-Hashimi told a news conference that some of the Iraqis were shoved. France and Britain are among more than a dozen nations, including the United States, which have refused Iraqi orders to remove their diplomats from Kuwait. Hurd complained about the treatment of diplomats in the besieged country. ``They are surrounded by soldiers, they can't get food or drink in, they can't get oil in. Their position is gradually getting worse. They've been blockaded since the end of August. ``So all the Western embassies are in the same boat. The Iraqis have taken one step further, and we have to react accordingly,'' he said. Hurd said there was support among the EC ministers for an air blockade of Iraq. But he said it was important to obtain backing from the U.N. Security Council for such a move, as was done for the naval blockade.

DOC.HEAD: Tank Gunners Gunning To Go To Saudi Arabia
Desk: Subs graf 2, I love, to CORRECT title from Pvt. to Spec. 5.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: AP Military Writer Susanne Schafer recently traveled with General Carl Vuono, the Army's chief of staff, to Fort Hood, where elements of the 1st Cavalry and 2nd Armored Divisions are preparing to ship out to Saudi Arabia. This is the third of three reports.
DOC.TEXT: Two young gunners stood in front of the twin beige behemoths that will be their metallic camels of the desert - M1A1 battle tanks dubbed ``Hound Dog'' and ``Hollywood'' being inspected for duty in Saudi Arabia. ``I love tanks,'' confesses Spec. 5 Joseph Barajas of Modesto, Calif. ``I can't wait to get there - start gettin' those T-72s in my sights.'' Barajas and his sergeant, Michael Duda of Glendale, Calif., were as eager to show off their tanks as if they were their shiny new sports cars. ``Right now, we're focusing all our attention on getting maintenance of the vehicles, to make sure they're ready,'' Duda said. There was a flurry of activity around the two tanks as Duda's unit prepared to leave this capital of tankdom, the largest center of armored weaponry in the free world. ``We just got back from Calfax training - that's the best. We're really ready to go,'' Duda said of a training exercise his unit had just undergone. Duda and Barajas' armored machines are designed to ferret out and destroy their Soviet counterpart - the T-72 - in use by President Saddam Hussein's heavily mechanized Iraqi divisions. The 67-ton tanks are revered by their crews because they can keep a target in sight while the 1,500 horsepower turbine engine moves flat out at 42 mph. With the tank's laser range finders, ballistic computer, thermal-imaging night site and wind sensors, the gunners can see through darkness, fog and dust to blast the insides out of any armored opponent. Such a love of tanks inspired Barajas to volunteer for duty in Saudi Arabia and turn down a transfer to the lush green hills of Bamberg, West Germany. ``I couldn't go to Germany and leave these guys go off without me,'' Barajas explained. ``This is what I've been training all my time in the Army for.'' The 25-year-old soldier said he'd sent his wife and three children back home to be with family while he was away. But goodbyes weren't easy. ``My oldest son, he's five, he said to me, `Daddy, don't worry. You won't die,''' he said. ``Can you believe that?'' Asked whether any of the soldiers in the unit were afraid of what they might encounter, Barajas said a few had admitted to such qualms over some barbecue and beers the night before. ``But you'd be crazy if you didn't feel a little bit of that,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Media Mock Bush Message
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The official press mocked President Bush's broadcast message to the Iraqi people, saying Monday that he ``failed in his first test'' to convince them that Saddam Hussein was to blame for the Persian Gulf crisis. One Baghdad newspaper, commenting on Bush's eight-minute message broadcast nationally Sunday evening, said: ``Mr. Bush ... please shut up.'' Al-Thawra, the official newspaper of the ruling Baath Party, said: ``Iraq, its leader and the Arab nation are but one state with one will, a will having a firm determination to score victory and purge the land of Arabs from any presence offending their sovereignty and dignity.'' In his videotaped message, recorded at the White House and with Arab subtitles and and an Arab voice-over, Bush said: ``Saddam Hussein tells you that this crisis is a struggle between Iraq and America. In fact, it is Iraq against the world.'' The Iraqi army newspaper Al-Qadissiyah replied Monday that ``it is evident that Bush, who is the president of a state which claims the leadership of the world, has failed in his first test with the Iraqi people.'' Al-Thawra said the speech was ``an attempt to distort facts and reverse the true nature of the conflict under cover of international legitimacy.'' ``If Washington prepares for a military action against Iraq, the Iraqis, backed by all Arabs, Moslems and honorable citizens all around the world, are quite ready to defend their land, sovereignty and rights,'' Al-Thawra said. Bush is ``the direct enemy whose forces were desecrating Mecca and the tomb of the prophet in a futile effort to threaten Iraq,'' it said. Other newspapers joined the chorus ridiculing Bush for saying President Saddam Hussein was pushing the country toward a war. One also printed a presidential decree formally dissolving the Kuwait Airways Corp., the flagship air carrier of the emirate Saddam invaded Aug. 2 and then annexed. Bush's speech triggered anti-American demonstrations in the streets of Baghdad, with thousands marching and chanting, ``Death to Bush! Death to America!'' In a front-page commentary headlined ``The Illusions of Mr. Bush,'' the state daily Al-Jumhuriya said: ``Once again the president of the United States fails to understand the mentality and psychology of the Iraqi people. ``Instead of correcting his previous mistakes, Bush wants to push the (conflict) to the abyss of untold catastrophes.'' Another article in the newspaper, headlined ``Shut up, Mr. Bush'' said: ``America today is a bastion of oppression and we have this to say: `Mr. Bush, we listened to your message, but please shut up.''' Al-Qadissiyah said Bush was ``playing a new game'' of CIA-inspired psychological warfare. It challenged Bush's claim that he spoke on behalf of the international community. ``By that we understand that Bush wants to say that he has a mandate to carry out his aggression against Iraq,'' the paper said. ``But we know that the decision to go to war with Iraq is purely American.'' Al-Qadissiyah published a decree by Saddam that formally dissolved Kuwait Airways and transferred all its assets to the government-run Iraqi Airways. The decree also dissolved all Kuwait Airways offices abroad and dismissed its personnel. Several Kuwait Airways planes have already been moved to Baghdad and repainted in the green and white colors of Iraqi Airways. Kuwaiti authorities in exile managed to salvage some of Kuwait Airways' 22 aircraft and have set up a new headquarters for the airline in Cairo.

DOC.HEAD: `Who Needs $106 Million?' Says Lottery Winner Happy To Claim $17.75 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from two winners, jackpot calculated at $106.5 million. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `I just...'.
DOC.TEXT: A woman who says she ``fussed at my husband every time he bought some tickets'' was among the winners to step forward today and claim their share of a record $106.5 million jackpot. Six Florida Lottery tickets matched the winning numbers drawn Saturday night after a week of feverish buying, some of it by people who drove or flew in from out of state or plunked down thousands of dollars trying to improve their odds from 1 in 14 million. Two of the winners appeared at a news conference this morning. Jeanne Piasecki of New Smyrna Beach said her family was splitting the winnings. She added smilingly: ``I still don't believe in gambling. I fussed at my husband every time he bought some tickets.'' Another winning ticket holder, Pat Landry of Sorrento in Lake County, said her winning entry, bought by her daughter in Longwood, was divided among a dozen family members and friends. She said she was glad their were six grand prize winners because it helped keep the attention on her family to a minimum. ``Who needs $106 million?'' she commented. Both ticket winners said the numbers were picked at random. The jackpot, estimated at $105 million Sunday, was calculated today at $106.5 million - a state record and second largest in U.S. history. Each of the six tickets is thus worth $17.75 million over 20 years, or about $887,500 a year before taxes. The other four winners didn't immediately step forward. Lottery computers show the other winning tickets were bought in Miami, Coconut Creek, Venice and Winter Haven. The winners matched all six numbers drawn: 05-06-21-34-35-45. Some of the umpteen million losers had plenty to say, too. ``I just lost miserably,'' said Victor Morgan, who bought two tickets. ``But I've wasted my money on worse things.'' Jennifer Kram, who matched just three numbers on one of her 20 tickets, said, ``I'm very depressed. Three isn't good enough for me. I wanted at least $500,000.'' The three-number match will bring her a grand total of $5.50. The prize had snowballed for four weeks, growing with each week's drawing every time no one won the jackpot. Only a $115 million jackpot in Pennsylvania last year has been higher. But in that drawing, 14 winning tickets were sold. More than 100 million $1 tickets were sold, at up to 44,500 a minute. Lottery Secretary Rebecca Paul hinted at the exhaustion the week had brought. ``I think we're glad it's over,'' she said. ``But it's been fun and exciting.'' State economists planned to meet today to calculate how much extra money education will reap. Education, like the rest of state government, is facing a 5 percent spending cutback because of a shortfall in revenue. By law, half of every dollar spent on a Florida lottery ticket is paid out in prizes. At least 38.5 percent goes to education, and the rest to retailers and administration. The U.S. record for a lottery prize to a single winner is held by Florida, which awarded a woman almost $55.2 million after a drawing two years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Endowment Chairman Says Senate Bill May End `Obscene Art' Crisis
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts expressed hope Monday that ``the crisis will soon pass'' over federal support for controversial art with a Senate proposal to let the courts decide whether works are obscene. But chairman John E. Frohnmayer held fast, at least for a while longer, to his much-criticized requirement that NEA grant recipients sign a pledge not to use federal funds to produce art that might be considered obscene. Even though the pledge was prompted by a congressional obscenity ban that will expire Sept. 30, Frohnmayer said he will keep the pledge until a federal court in New York issues a ruling on its constitutionality and Congress decides whether to impose new anti-obscenity restrictions on the endowment. In any case, the embattled NEA chairman said there was ``zero truth'' to rumors that he may resign in the heat of battle over past endowment support for works that conservative critics have denounced as obscene and sacrilegious. At a news conference at the National Press Club, Frohnmayer said he was ``heartened'' by two events last week. One was a report by a bipartisan study commission that backed the endowment, opposed anti-obscenity curbs and called for reforms in the NEA's grant procedures. The other was the emergence of a Senate compromise that shifts the burden of deciding cases of ``obscene art'' from the NEA to the courts. Both developments, Frohnmayer said, ``give us hope that the crisis will soon pass.'' The Senate bill, approved 15-1 last week by the Labor and Human Resources Committee, provides ``a wise solution to a very thorny problem,'' Frohnmayer said. The measure, now headed for Senate floor action, would allow the endowment to get its money back if a grant recipient is convicted of creating works that violate obscenity or child pornography laws. The guilty artist would be forbidden to receive further NEA grants for at least three years. ``We await the action of Congress with the hope that clear thinking and cool heads prevail,'' Frohnmayer said. Frohnmayer outlines several internal reforms at the federal arts agency to make its grant procedures more responsive to the desires of the tax-paying public. But he conceded that his reforms ``won't satisfy those who don't want an arts endowment.'' Both the study commission and the National Council on the Arts, the presidentially appointed advisory body to the endowment, have urged that Frohnmayer eliminate his anti-obscenity pledge, which has stirred widespread protests in the arts community. The Senate committee also is expected to suggest that the pledge be dropped when it issues its formal report on the bill, which would extend the NEA's life for five years beyond Sept. 30, when its statutory authority expires. Also expiring that day will be a ban on NEA support for works that ``may be considered obscene,'' specifically including depictions of homoeroticism, sadomasochism and the sexual exploitation of children. Congress attached the ban to the endowment's current $171 million budget last October at the urging of conservative lawmakers led by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., who had protested NEA grants for exhibitions of works by photographer Robert Mapplethorpe and artist Andres Serrano. Since Frohnmayer instituted the anti-obscenity pledge in November, a dozen artists and arts organizations have forfeited NEA grants rather than sign the pledge. Three lawsuits filed against the endowment in federal courts in New York and Los Angeles charge that the pledge violates First Amendment guarantees of freedom of expression. Frohnmayer said Monday he won't decide whether to eliminate the pledge until he knows what Congress and the courts have to say about the ``obscene art'' issue in the next few weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Murder Trial Begins 17 Months After Rampage Left Seven Dead
DOC.TEXT: Ramon Salcido went on trial for his life today, 17 months after his wife, two daughters and four others were shot or stabbed to death in a murderous rampage through California's wine country. Salcido admits the slayings, but a jury will decide if the 29-year-old winery worker is guilty of first-degree murder or, as his lawyer argues, was not mentally capable of such an intentional act. Salcido could face the gas chamber if convicted. The prosecution argues that Salcido planned and willfully carried out seven killings - including three in-laws and a co-worker - and tried to kill three other people, and therefore should be convicted of first-degree murder and attempted murder. ``These were coldly calculated crimes,'' says Peter Bumerts, chief deputy district attorney in Sonoma County, where the slayings occurred on April 14, 1989. He planned to rely principally on Salcido's tape-recorded confession to detectives. Salcido's lawyer, Marteen Miller, planned to concede that Salcido killed the victims and tried to kill the three survivors. ``That puts at issue his state of mind,'' he said. Miller, the Sonoma County public defender, will argue that Salcido was in a ``psychotic depression'' and high on cocaine and champagne, and mentally incapable of the planning or intent required for a conviction of first-degree murder. The trial, moved to San Mateo County Superior Court because of intensive news coverage in Sonoma, is expected to last about a month. Salcido is charged with fatally shooting his wife, Angela, 24, in the couple's Boyes Hot Springs duplex, and cutting the throats of their three young daughters and leaving them for dead at a dump. Carmina, then 2, survived and told detectives: ``Dad hurt me.'' He also is accused of fatally stabbing his mother-in-law, Marian Richards, 47, and killing two of her daughters, and with shooting to death a co-worker at the Grand Cru winery in Glen Ellen. Salcido was charged with attempted murder in the attack on Carmina, the shooting of a co-worker and an attempt to shoot the man's wife. If the jury convicts Salcido of first-degree murder and finds true the special-circumstance allegation of multiple murder, a second phase of the trial would be held to determine if he should be executed or be sentenced to life in prison without possibility of parole.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Chief of Staff Dismissed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; Will be led with 2:30 p.m. EDT Cheney news conference
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Mike Dugan was fired as Air Force chief of staff today following the four-star general's blunt comments about U.S. contingency plans for massive air strikes against Baghdad. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney relieved Dugan of his duties after consulting with President Bush, and then delivered a harsh critique of the 53-year-old decorated flier. ``There are certain things we never talk about. We never discuss operational matters, such as the selection of specific targets for potential air strikes,'' Cheney told reporters. ``We never talk about the targeting of specific individuals, who are officials in other governments. That is an violation of the executive order,'' the secretary said. ``We never underestimate the strength of opposing forces or reveal previously classified information about the size or disposition of U.S. forces. Nor do we ever demean the contributions of the other services,'' he said. ``Gen. Dugan's statements as reported in the press and as confirmed by him to me - failed all of those tests,'' Cheney said. The Pentagon's rare disciplinary action of a top officer came one day after published reports quoted Dugan as saying U.S. military authorities had concluded that massive air strikes are the only effective way of forcing Iraq out of Kuwait if war erupted. Dugan was on a tour of U.S. military installations in Saudi Arabia when he made his comments in an interview with the Los Angeles Times and The Washington Post. Atop the Dugan interview in the Los Angeles Times, the paper quoted unnamed ``senior U.S. military planners'' as saying that such an air campaign would be designed in part to ``decapitate'' the Iraqi leadership by targeting Saddam Hussein, his family, his senior commanders and his palace guard. The paper quoted Dugan as saying that ``a better list'' of high-value Iraqi targets had been drawn up by military planners. The paper said, ``the list stressed the importance of attacking Hussein and his inner circle, but beyond that Dugan would not detail'' any target points. Dugan still retains his four-star rank, but he is expected to retire. ``Protocol demands that he retire,'' a Pentagon source said. ``There's no job in the Air Force he could really hold now.'' Dugan flew combat missions during the Vietnam War, and later taught cadet military training courses at the Air Force Academy. He was named assistant deputy chief of staff at Air Force headquarters in January 1987, and six months later he became Air Force deputy chief of staff for programs and resources. Dugan was promoted to the joint position of commander of U.S. Air Forces in Europe and commander of Allied Air Forces Central Europe, headquartered at Ramstein Air Base, West Germany, in April 1989. His military decorations include the Distinguished Service Medal, the Silver Star, the Legion of Merit, the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Purple Heart. Pending the choice of Gen. Dugan's successor, the vice chief of staff, Gen. John Michael Loh, will act as the top commander of the Air Force. Cheney told reporters, ``Mike Dugan is a fine officer with an outstanding record of service in the United States Air Force and to the nation. Relieving him is not a pleasant task but I felt it was a necessary one.'' Cheney said there are 150,000 U.S. combat troops in the Persian Gulf. ``They may be engaged in hostilities in the very near future. A very fragile, very important international coalition has been put together to halt Saddam Hussein's aggression,'' Cheney said. ``Under those circumstances,'' he added, ``the conduct of U.S. national security policy is an extremely delicate task.'' He said Dugan's statement ``did not, in my mind, reveal an understanding of the situation or of what is expected of him as a member of the joint chiefs.'' Dugan's office said he was not at work today and was unavailable for comment. Dugan's attempts at openness - a major change for top Air Force generals - appeared to contribute to his undoing. Shortly after taking over from Gen. Larry Welch in July, Dugan began an aggressive campaign to meet with reporters and deal openly with some of the service's sore points on Capitol Hill. The service had been battered by congressional budget battles over the B-2 Stealth aircraft and problems with the performance of the F-117A Stealth bomber during the Panama invasion. Dugan raised a few eyebrows inside the Pentagon last week when he traveled to Saudi Arabia before the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff - Gen. Colin Powell - had a chance to visit with the troops. Commanders on the ground in Saudi Arabia have been critical of Dugan for several weeks because of his open assessment of U.S. military capabilities. Powell's aides said last week Dugan was one of several people who have been talking too much. ``Saddam already has you guys giving away the store, we don't need to help him any more,'' one Powell aide said privately. Pentagon officials said Dugan appeared to be the second member of the Joint Chiefs of Staff to be relieved of his duties. In 1949, President Truman relieved the Chief of Naval Operations, Adm. Louis E. Denfeld. Truman took the action upon the recommendation of the Secretary of the Navy, who'd asserted that the admiral had lost control of his command. Denfeld's dismissal, according to a New York Times account printed the day after the president's action, came two weeks after the admiral had complained to Congress that the Navy was being ``starved'' in order to support the Air Force's bombing mission.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Warns Iraqis of War, Iraq's Papers Scornful
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Cheney confirming Dugan firing, tying it to Dugan's remarks to press. Pickup 4th, `In Iraq...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA1,2
DOC.TEXT: Young Kuwaiti men trying to flee their occupied homeland were seized today by Iraqi troops, refugees reported, and their sobbing wives and daughters were forced to cross into Saudi Arabia without them. The Air Force chief of staff, Gen. Mike Dugan, was fired today because of his frank comments about U.S. contingency plans for air strikes on Baghdad. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Dugan violated Pentagon rules barring discussion of the selection of targets for possible military strikes and revealed classified information about the strength of U.S. forces in the gulf. While touring U.S. military sites in Saudi Arabia on Sunday, Dugan said massive air strikes would be the only effective way to force Iraq out of Kuwait in a war. He was quoted by The Washington Post and the Los Angeles Times. In Iraq, state-run newspapers today heaped scorn on President Bush for his broadcast warning to the Iraqis that their president, Saddam Hussein, is leading them to war. One newspaper's headline read: ``Shut up, Mr. Bush.'' ``Saddam Hussein tells you that this crisis is a struggle between Iraq and America. In fact, it is Iraq against the world,'' Bush said in his speech, aired Sunday on Iraqi television. Standing in front of his Oval Office desk with the American flag behind him, Bush urged Iraq to withdraw its troops from Kuwait, which it overran on Aug. 2. Iraqi authorities responded that Bush's statement was full of ``lies and contradictions.'' They said the U.S. president aimed to be ``dictator of the world.'' Thousands of protesters gathered in the streets of Baghdad's capital after Bush's broadcast, chanting ``Death to Bush! Death to America!'' International opposition to Iraq, however, picked up strength. Britain said today it would expel the Iraqi military attache and three aides from the embassy in London. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd indicated the Home Office would be annoucing further sanctions against Iraq later in the day. Belgium restricted the mobility of Iraq's diplomatic personnel. The Dutch Foreign Ministry said it was summoning Iraq's ambassador today, and Dutch television reported a cutback in the Iraqi mission and restrictions of its diplomats' freedom of movement were imminent. The moves came after Dutch, French, Belgian and Canadian embassies or diplomatic residences were raided last week by Iraqi troops. The embassy raids were unanimously condemned Sunday by the U.N. Security Council. France on Sunday expelled 29 Iraqis in retaliation, and Italy announced it was ousting all officials at the Iraqi military attache's office in Rome. Twelve member nations of the European Community, meeting today in Brussels, Belgium, were also weighing a possible air blockade of Iraq to enforce a U.N. trade embargo. ``Everybody was arguing for an air blockade,'' said the Belgian foreign affairs minister, Mark Eyskens. The ministers were also considering new economic steps against Iraq and more aid for countries hurt by the U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with that counry. U.N. diplomats on Sunday began drafting a new resolution to close off Iraq's air routes and punish nations flouting the U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with Iraq, U.S. officials said. An Egyptian military source said Egypt will send 250 soldiers to Saudi Arabia today and more will follow in a few days, joining the estimated 4,000 Egyptian troops already in the region. The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Egypt would also send Egytian tanks, armored personel carriers and air defense systems to Saudi Arabia by ship across the Red Sea. Meanwhile, Japan's first mission of doctors, nurses and support staff was preparing today to leave for Saudi Arabia Tuesday to lay groundwork for a planned 100-member Japanese medical team, officials said. Japan has pledged a total of $4 billion to the U.S.-led multinational effort against Iraq, but recruitment of medical personnel has been slow. Moscow announced today it would restore diplomatic ties with Saudi Arabia, cut in 1938. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and his Saudi counterpart, Prince Saud Al-Faisal Al Saud, also called for the immediate withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait, the official Tass news agency said. Tass quoted Shevardnadze as saying the formalities of re-establishing ties would be finalized after the Saudi minister met with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The Soviets had been longtime allies of Baghdad, but became cool to Iraq after Saddam seized Kuwait. At the lone border crossing between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, about 6,000 Kuwaitis streamed out of their homeland over the weekend after Iraq troops suddenly and without explanation opened the crossing. It had been shut for a month. But refugees arriving today said Iraqi troops manning the border crossing were seizing all Kuwaiti males between the ages of 17 and 36, apparently because they were of age to serve in the military. And all non-Kuwaitis, except for a few Western women married to Kuwaitis, were turned back by the Iraqis and told to leave Kuwait through Baghdad. The Kuwaiti government-in-exile called the unannounced weekend exodus evidence that Saddam intends to depopulate Kuwait and move in his own people. In a move consolidating their control of Kuwait, Iraqi authorities announced today that they ordered the dissolution of Kuwait Airways, that country's flagship air carrier. There was concern that the Iraqis might be trying to send spies or terrorists into Saudi Arabia, where 100,000 U.S. troops have deployed since the invasion of Kuwait, leading a multinational force. Refugees without proper identity documents were being questioned carefully by Saudi authorities. The Kuwaiti refugees told tales of terror and anarchy at home, of dwindling food supplies and Iraqi troops blowing up the homes of suspected resistance fighters in Kuwait City. Meanwhile, the flow of Arab and Asian refugees from the Persian Gulf region continued unabated. Air India's top executive said the airline is ferrying 3,000 Indians a day from the region, making it one of the world's largest-ever civil evacuations. Subhas R. Gupte, the chairman of the state-owned airline, said 45,000 Indians have been flown home. About 190,000 Indians were in Kuwait and Iraq at the time of the invasion. Bush's address to the Iraqi people, with an Arabic voice-over and captions provided by the State Department, was apparently broadcast in its entirety Sunday evening. It was the first direct message from Bush to the Iraqi. In a commentary today headlined ``Shut up, Mr. Bush,'' the Iraqi government-owned Al-Jumhuriya, or The Republic, declared, ``America today is a bastion of oppression and we have this to say: `Mr. Bush, we listened to your message, but please shut up.''' The speech was followed immediately by a 25-minute response from an Iraqi TV announcer, who said a ``thundering rage'' is building against the United States in the Arab world, and a showdown in the Persian Gulf would end ``in a catastrophe'' for U.S. forces. A few hundred men later took to the streets of Baghdad, the Iraqi capital. As they passed through residential neighborhoods, thousands of men, women and children joined them. Raising clenched fists, the demonstrators denounced Bush. They also called President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and King Fahd of Saudi Arabia ``traitors of the Arab world'' for siding with the United States in the confrontation.

DOC.HEAD: Baby Begins Life in the Fast Lane
DOC.TEXT: Some people live life in the fast lane. Tiffany Paula Brickner began her's there. The 4-pound, 2-ounce girl was born Sunday in the front seat of a Chevrolet traveling about 85 mph, according to Pauline Hollencamp, the newborn's aunt. ``I thought I had plenty of time to get to the hospital,'' said mother Hilda Freed of Beaver Falls. The two women were at church when Ms. Freed, 25, realized she was in labor. The hospital was about 15 miles away and the baby's father, Robert Brickner, was at work. Mrs. Hollencamp, a 24-year-old mother of two who has training in natural childbirth, served as driver and coach for her sister. ``I just kept telling her to breathe. That's the best thing for the unborn baby is to breathe,'' Mrs. Hollencamp said. ``She coached me the whole way,'' said Ms. Freed. ``She told me not to push, but I couldn't avoid that. I knew the baby was on its way and there's nothing I could do.'' Just after Tiffany's birth, Mrs. Hollencamp pulled into a state police barracks parking lot and ran inside for help. Troopers covered the baby and mother with blankets and called an ambulance. Despite being underweight, Tiffany was reported in good condition at Medical Center of Beaver.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Aide: Plans Won't Fully Transform System
With AM-Soviet-Gorbachev, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A senior aide to Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Monday that competing reform programs now under debate are designed to ``give momentum'' to the transition to a market economy but will not fully transform the system. Nikolai Petrakov, meeting with The Associated Press board of directors and executives, also acknowledged that Soviet politics were in a state of crisis as old-line communists and bureaucrats battle reform. President Gorbachev further confused the political scene Monday by telling parliament he wanted a referendum on one of the fundamental tenets of economic reform - legalizing the private ownership of farm land and other real estate. The parliament of the Russian Federation, the largest republic in the country with more than half its people and two-thirds of its territory, already has passed a reform plan that would decollectivize agriculture. ``The situation we have now is the situation of a government in crisis. I really don't know how this crisis is going to be resolved,'' Petrakov said. Petrakov said he hoped for a compromise that would ``have as a starting point a really severe blow against monopolies.'' ``We want to give this process momentum. We certainly do not expect it to be completed in 500 days. ... We need to create conditions for competition ... one of the most important conditions for a market economy.'' But he said the reform package favored by Gorbachev would not make the ruble convertible against Western currencies. ``I do not think we will be able to attain full convertibility within 500 days,'' he said. But he said that the package would include ``guarantees'' that foreign investors would be able to take their Soviet profits outside the Soviet Union in the form of hard currencies - a major incentive for attracting capital. Efforts to reform the national economy, he said, had been complicated by declarations of independence or sovereignty by 13 of the 15 Soviet republics since March. ``The process of sovereignty looks like a joke or more like a musical comedy,'' he said. Most of the Soviet republics have declared control over major state enterprises and natural resources on their territory, plus the right to create their own central banks and issue their own currency. ``Many of the republics want to erect customs control on the borders between the two republics,'' he complained. He said economic union among the republics should be based on four fundamentals: a single central bank, a single currency, the ability of the central government to levy taxes and maintenance of a single customs agency. Maintaining the economic union was crucial, he said. Since the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution, the relations among suppliers and industries across the nation have grown to such a degree that ``no republic can live without the others.'' Lithuania, the republic that has gone furthest in declaring its political independence from the Soviet Union, has expressed interest in a new form of economic union, he said. ``The republics are prepared to waive their right for independent currency if we are able to create a stable monetary system,'' because that is a fundamental for a sound economy, he said. ``Of course, it is true that an economic union would be voluntary. Any republic would be free to exist as an independent state'' and would maintain economic ties with the other republics ``like relations with the countries of Eastern Europe.''

DOC.HEAD: Family Wants Soldiers to Know They're Not Forgotten
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Like many parents with college-age youngsters, David and Jean Heard like to send care packages when their children are away from home. But for the Heard children, the classroom is the Persian Gulf and their instruction could mean the difference between life and death. Since President Bush ordered American troops to the Middle East following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, three of the Heards' 13 sons and daughters have been caught up in the deployment. One son is a Marine in Saudi Arabia. Another, a sailor, is aboard the carrier Independence in the Persian Gulf. A daughter and her husband, both in the military reserves, remain in the United States but believe they'll be sent to the Middle East. Mrs. Heard said she could not sit idle while she waited for news from abroad. So she and her husband, a retired Marine, started ``Operation Something From Home.''
