Their mission is to see that every serviceman and woman involved in Operation Desert Shield gets something from home. ``We have read over the years how military personnel never get a letter, never get anything,'' Mrs. Heard said. ``My God, these are our children. They're all our sons and daughters. And the least we can do is to get something to them.'' What began from humble beginnings - a few dollars and a couple of packages a week - has grown into a nationwide effort, all from the basement of the Heards' Manassas home. Boxes are everywhere, brimming with articles from chewing gum and crackers to toilet tissue and paperback novels. Nearly a dozen volunteers shuttle back and forth. Some operate the telephone, others are assigned as ``shoppers'' who buy items to ship to the armed forces. Donations are pouring in, as are letters of support. A real estate company in the Virgin Islands sent a $50 check. An envelope from an anonymous sender arrived last week with a $100 bill tucked inside. Aaron Clark, a fourth-grader from Mount Vernon, Ill., created his own care package with a small box of cigars, a roll of candy and a paperback novel. He sent it to the Heards with hopes that they would forward it to the troops. Other packages include razors, lip balm, liquid soap, playing cards, wooden dominoes and letters from school children. All items being sent have been tested and shown to be desert-proof. Mrs. Heard puts the items in the back window of her car for two days. If they don't melt, they're included. The packages aren't sent to individuals by name, but are sent to APO and FPO boxes that correspond with those of soldiers in the Persian Gulf region. The packs are getting through. David Heard, 55, got a thank you letter from a soldier of the 82nd Airborne Division, who sent a $1 contribution. ``The care package service is going to be a real morale booster,'' wrote another soldier in Saudi Arabia. ``We are all over here for our country. We will die for our country. And if I die, I'll be proud within myself that I died for my country.'' The letters they get from the recipients of the packages are reward enough for those involved in Operation Something From Home. ``That's worth 20 hours a day, seven days a week,'' Mrs. Heard said. ``When I get tired or discouraged, I read those letters and I'm no longer tired. I only wish there were 40 hours in a day.'' In a way, the effort is helping heal some old hurts left by the Vietnam War, she said. The home-spun packages are a lifeline for those deployed to the Persian Gulf and a way to show them that they are being supported back home. ``Do you remember when our people came back from Vietnam?'' Mrs. Heard asked. ``It was no longer an honor to wear a uniform. They were spit at and rotten vegetables were thrown at them. ``I am ashamed that I was one of those Americans who didn't stand up and do anything,'' she said. ``I was a coward and I did nothing. This country in 30 years has suffered so much. There just didn't seem to be any unity. And now if you read these letters... ``God Bless America - warts and all,'' Mrs. Heard said. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - The mailing address for Operation Something From Home is P.O. Box 264, Manassas, Va. 22110.

DOC.HEAD: Rising Inventories, Declining Sales, Raise Apprehensions
DOC.TEXT: Business inventories jumped 0.7 percent in July, the biggest pileup in a year, while sales slumped 0.5 percent, the government said Monday, causing some apprehension over the amount of goods held on shelves and back lots. Although the level of inventories is not recessionary, Robert Brusca, chief financial economist at Nikko Securities Co. International Inc. in New York, said surging stockpiles are a danger sign. ``When inventories rise faster than sales, particularly when sales are in a lagging mode, it's reasonable to assume you're going to see cutbacks in manufacturing output,'' he said. That could result in growing unemployment. The Commerce Department said inventories in July totaled a seasonally adjusted $801.9 billion, up from $796.5 billion in June. It was the biggest increase since a 0.8 percent gain in July 1989. The June backlog had declined a revised 0.5 percent from the previous month, rather than the 0.4 percent originally reported. Sales, meanwhile, dropped to a seasonally adjusted $539.5 billion, down from $542.4 billion a month earlier. The June sales also were revised to a weaker 0.6 percent gain, rather than the 1.0 percent advance first reported. Cynthia Latta, an economist with DRI/McGraw-Hill in Lexington, Mass., noted that sales rose only on the retail level in July but pointed out that retail sales deteriorated in August, falling 0.6 percent, according to a Commerce Department report last week. And while retail sales increased 0.4 percent in July, the gain was less than half of the 1.1 percent jump the previous month. Retail sales represent about half of all consumer spending which itself accounts for two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. The combination of falling sales and rising inventories produced a 1.49 ratio of inventories to sales, up from 1.47 in June and the same as May's 1.49. The ratio means it would take 1.49 months to exhaust the backlog of goods at the July sales pace. Neither Brusca nor Ms. Latta believe the ratio is dangerously high. ``But with evidence that retail selling is weak and that output is falling, to have inventories building is not a good sign for the economy,'' Brusca said. All major business categories experienced gains in inventories. Manufacturing backlogs were up 0.7 percent to $373.3 billion. Wholesalers posted a 0.5 percent gain to $192.2 billion. Retailers registered a 0.8 percent advance to $236.5 billion. Manufacturing sales, meanwhile, declined 0.8 percent to $237.5 billion, while wholesalers posted a 1.0 percent drop to $152.0 billion. Retail sales totaled $150.0 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Blood Sample Taken From Minister Suspected in Attack on Wife
DOC.TEXT: Authorities have taken blood and saliva samples from former minister Walker Railey and say they may seek to prosecute him in the near-fatal choking attack on his wife three years ago. Deputy Police Chief Ray Hawkins said Sunday he hopes to present the case to the district attorney's office for reconsideration on seeking a grand jury indictment later this month or early next month. Police have long considered Railey, 43, their prime suspect but have never persuaded the district attorney to charge him. Railey was found liable in a civil trial, however. At the time of the attack, Railey was the senior pastor of the First United Methodist Church of Dallas and a prominent liberal minister whose Sunday sermons were televised. Margaret ``Peggy'' Railey, now 41, was choked with a cord in her home on the night of April 21, 1987. She never regained consciousness and remains in a nursing home in what doctors call a persistent vegetative state with little chance of recovery. Although he has maintained his innocence, Railey has refused to cooperate with authorities and fully answer questions about the assault. Railey said he was away from the house at the time of the attack. Hawkins' statement came only two days after a Dallas detective and FBI agents picked Railey up in California, where he now lives, and had him give blood and saliva samples. The authorities had obtained a court order earlier Friday to obtain the samples from a judge who then sealed all documents. ``It's fair to state that Dr. Railey was surprised,'' Hawkins said. Hawkins refused to give details of the investigation. Friday's action by federal agents was the first in the case in some time. In the weeks before the attack on his wife, Railey had reported receiving several threatening typewritten letters to him at church. The letters, which complained about Railey's sermons urging racial tolerance, were traced later to a typewriter in his church. Authorities also have said that Railey failed to disclose a visit and phone call on the night of the attack to Lucy Papillon, a Dallas psychologist who later testified that the two were having an affair. Ten days after Mrs. Railey was attacked, on the day that police had planned to interview Railey extensively, he was found unconscious after attempting suicide with a drug overdose. Within the year, he was hospitalized at a psychiatric hospital, resigned his ministerial credentials, gave up custody of his two young children, and moved with Ms. Papillon to California. In 1988, a Texas district judge found Railey liable for the attack and ordered him to pay almost $18 million in damages. He has paid nothing toward the civil judgment, saying he is barely making enough to support himself.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Nears Submitting Mexican-Trade Measure to Congress
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, spurred by events in the Middle East, set forth an ambitious negotiating schedule Monday aimed at completing a comprehensive free trade agreement with oil-rich Mexico by the end of 1991. Administration officials said that President Bush would formally submit to Congress within the next few days a request for authority to negotiate an agreement dismantling barriers to the free flow of goods and investment between the two nations. The administration's formal request starts a procedure in which Congress has 60 legislative days, a period expected to last until late spring, to review the proposal. If Congress gives its assent, which is considered likely, then the administration can begin negotiations with Mexico. Deputy U.S. Trade Representative Julius Katz told members of the congressional Joint Economic Committee that if negotiations begin in late spring, he hoped to have an agreement wrapped up by the end of 1991. That timetable would be significantly faster than the 18 months required to negotiate a free-trade agreement with Canada. Katz told reporters later that U.S. negotiators had learned a great deal from the U.S.-Canada free trade talks and believed that knowledge could be applied to speeding up a similar agreement with Mexico. Administration officials have said that the Middle East crisis has focused attention on America's trade relationship with Mexico, which has the eighth largest reserve of oil in the world. The United States would like to work with Mexico in accelerating oil production in Mexico, which currently stands at about 2.5 million barrels of crude daily. Katz and other administration officials suggested Monday that a free trade agreement with Mexico would be a first step toward achieving the president's goal of a hemisphere-wide free trade zone, an achievement that Katz said could be reached before the end of this decade. Members of the Joint Economic Committee were generally supportive of the effort to remove trade barriers between the United States and other countries in Latin America although Sen. Paul Sarbanes, D-Md., questioned whether the administration had fully explored the impact on the U.S. economy. He questioned whether a free trade zone with Mexico would encourage U.S. manufacturers to move their operations to that country, where the costs of labor were lower. Treasury Under Secretary David Mulford said that while such an agreement would have a big impact on the Mexican economy, any effects on the U.S. economy would likely be small given the relative size of the two economies. Mexico's total output is nly 4 percent of America's $5 trillion annual economy. Mulford said that the administration was anxious to complete an agreement with Mexico to reward Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari for the free-market economic reforms he has instituted in his country. Mexico is America's third largest trading partner, with two-way trade totaling $51 billion last year.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Veteran comedian Steve Allen doesn't find anything funny about television's trend toward stronger language and adult-oriented themes. Allen lashed out at current television trends in an opinion piece published in Monday's Los Angeles Times. The ``flow is carrying us all along right into the sewer,'' he wrote. ``The very sort of language parents forbid their children to use is now being encouraged not only by anything-goes cable entrepreneurs but the once high-minded networks,'' said Allen, host of the 190s comedy-variety series ``The Steve Allen Show.'' Shows that depict children and others using vulgar language only point up the collapse of the American family, he said. Allen applauded NBC's censoring of some remarks by comedian Andrew Dice Clay on a recent ``Saturday Night Live'' episode. He called Clay ``the prince of filth.'' ``The best humor, when it is not simply purely playful, says something witty and wise about the issues it confronts,'' said Allen. --- CHICAGO (AP) - Perennial Mr. Olympia Lee Haney could be a hero to Weight Watchers dropouts everywhere. Haney, crowned Mr. Olympia on Saturday for the seventh consecutive time, says the secret to his muscle-bound form is eating - and eating - and eating some more. The key is eating the right food, said Haney, 30, who estimates he gobbles up 4,000 to 5,000 calories a day, 65 to 70 percent of them carbohydrates. ``But most people eat a high-fat diet, have bacon or sausage in the morning, a burger for lunch, and before they know it, they have had 5,000 calories and have a lot of body fat,'' he said. Haney's latest Mr. Olympia crown, which came with $70,000 in prize money, eclipsed the record of six consecutive titles that he shared with actor Arnold Schwarzenegger. It also left the two tied for the overall title with seven wins apiece. ``Anyone who can repeat two, three or four times is tough to defeat and is very special,'' Haney said. ``They know their body, their nutrition, their preparation. That's what made Arnold so great. It's not that easy.'' --- FLORENCE, Italy (AP) - American author Toni Morrison's novel ``Beloved,'' depicting the struggles faced by three generations of black women, has won The Chianti Ruffino Antico Fattore international literary prize. Award sponsors praised the novel for ``giving a voice to the experience of suffering, survival and life of the black population of America and in giving a voice to the feminine experience within the black population.'' Morrison, who accepted the award Sunday during ceremonies at Florence's Palazzo Vecchio, described the book as ``the story of the complex and intense love of a woman for her children.'' It is set before, during and after the Civil War. Morrison, who was selected from among winners of other national literary prizes, receives a cash award of $4,200. ``I can't think of another prize that I could win which combines these extraordinary elements: being invited to come to Florence, entering this incredible palace, being chosen from a field of international writers, and finally, being part of the philanthropy of a family supporting art, patronizing artists who are dependent on such generosity,'' she said. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Michael Jackson didn't say if it would be the one with the glove, but he promised Boy Scout officials he would do all he could to follow their edict to extend a hand to others. The pop music superstar was presented the Michael Jackson Good Scout Humanitarian Award at a banquet in Century City. ``On behalf of the millions of past, present and future Boy Scouts, I will try to abide by your motto of being prepared and always extending a hand to others,'' said Jackson. ``Michael Jackson is a good example of youth, helping us keep kids off the streets by supporting scouting,'' said Ray Martin, chairman of the Los Angeles Area Council Boy Scouts of America. ``He supports what the scouting programs are doing - giving kids an alternative to street gangs,'' Martin said. Jackson was joined at Friday night's ceremony by celebrities including Chuck Norris, Scott Baio, Telly Savalas, Fred Travalena, Stephanie Mills and Michael Eisner,chairman of the Walt Disney Co.

DOC.HEAD: European Nations Agree To Expel Iraqi Attaches
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs after 6th pvs, `Britain expelled...' to UPDATE with West Germany taking steps against Iraqi officials. Pickup 7th, `France and...'
DOC.TEXT: The 12 European Community nations decided today to expel Iraqi military attaches and restrict the mobility of other personnel to protest Iraqi raids last week of three countries' diplomatic compounds in Kuwait. EC nations were also weighing a possible air blockade of Iraq to enforce a U.N. trade embargo. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said it was important to obtain backing from the U.N. Security Council for such a move, as was done for the naval blockade. A French official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the 12 states adopted a statement saying they ``decided in common accord to expel the military personnel at Iraqi embassies and limit the freedom of movement of (Iraqi embassy) personnel within the capitals.'' Before the joint statement was adopted today, Britain and Belgium had already joined Italy and France in implementing diplomatic sanctions against Iraq. Britain expelled eight staff members from the Iraqi Embassy and ordered the deportation of 23 other Iraqi citizens. Belgium restricted the mobility of Iraq's diplomatic personnel in Brussels. Following the EC statement, the West German Foreign Ministry announced that it is expelling the Iraqi military attache staff in Bonn and restricting the movement of other Iraqi diplomatic personnel. ``The federal government has ordered the expulsion of the military attache staff of the Iraqi Embassy in Bonn. They have 48 hours in which to leave the Federal Republic (West Germany),'' a statement from the Foreign Ministry said. The statement said other Iraqi Embassy personnel would be limited in their movements in West Germany to Bonn and the city's airport shared with Cologne. France and Italy expelled several Iraqi embassy employees over the weekend for the violations of the diplomatic missions. Some Iraqi diplomatic missions in the member states do not have military attaches, so these EC nations can only restrict the movement of diplomatic personnel. ``This all arises because I feel, the government feels, that we've got to act in solidarity with the French and the other countries whose embassies have been invaded and people taken out during the last few days,'' Hurd said. On Sunday, the U.N. Security Council unanimously condemned the embassy incursions. The foreign ministers were also discussing economic aid for to Turkey, Egypt and Jordan to compensate for loss of income suffered because of the gulf crisis. The EC Commission proposed that the foreign ministers approve $1.95 billion in economic aid to be disbursed through the end of 1991. ``There is not full agreement that a decision on figures should be taken today,'' the British official said. Some officials said the talks were delayed because France and Britain wanted to take their military efforts in the Persian Gulf into account when deciding on the overall EC contribution. EC foreign ministers first proposed sending about $2 billion to the three states during an informal meeting 10 days ago. Italy, which holds the rotating EC presidency, has said it will also propose setting up an EC panel to track the compliance with the U.N. embargo against Iraq. The sanctions were imposed after the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Says He Wouldn't Rule Out Death Penalty as Unconstitutional
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 6 grafs new, recasting to clarify. Picks up 5th graf pvs, During his tenure.
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court nominee David Souter said today that he opposes a flat ban on the death penalty and that the Constitution does not bar its use. It was Souter's 51st birthday and his third day of testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee. Asked if the Constitution's ban on cruel and unusual punishment barred use of the death penalty, Souter replied, ``I think that would be an insupportable constitutional conclusion.'' He said he ``could not join'' any opinion that banned all capital punishment. If confirmed, Souter's view would be in line with the current majority of the high court. His response underscored his reputation as a law-and-order judge. Souter explained his approach to a range of criminal law cases, including one in which he supported police use of sobriety checkpoints. During his tenure on the New Hampshire Supreme Court, it ruled against the checkpoints as extending police action too far in violation of people's rights. But Souter alone dissented. In his testimony today, Souter said the checkpoints differed from other searches because driving a car is ``a highly dangerous and regulated activity.'' He said if the checkpoints were properly conducted, police were correct in using them to try to prevent tragedy. The use of police sobriety checks was upheld by the U.S. Supreme Court earlier this year. The court, acting on a Michigan case, ruled 6-3 that such checkpoints do not violate the Constitution. On another issue, Souter was quizzed about his tough prosecution of anti-nuclear protesters when he was New Hampshire's attorney general - and whether there was an appearance of impropriety because the builder of the Seabrook nuclear plant was helping defray the law enforcement costs. Souter said he wasn't aware of the donations at the time and had not solicited them. But in retrospect he said he should have insisted the money be returned. ``I think that would have been an appropriate position to take and I wish I had taken it,'' he said. Today's hearing started with birthday greetings for the New Hampshire judge, now 51. ``Happy Birthday. We didn't bake a cake, but perhaps we'll let you go home after today,'' said Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, who complimented Souter for his handling of the committee's questioning so far. At the opening of the televised hearings last Thursday, Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said, ``the burden of proof rests with those who support a nomination.'' But the conduct of the hearings made clear the opposite was true - the burden was on potential opponents to find some chink in Souter's Yankee armor. In two days of sparring with the committee last week, Souter skillfully ducked making specific responses on politically difficult issues, especially abortion. On that one, he said he hadn't made up his mind and had made no promises to anyone. Key committee members, including Chairman Joseph Biden, D-Del., said they planned to take another run at the privacy issue, which is at the heart of the abortion debate, and at others to see if there is a reason for opposing the nomination. Outside of the committee room, feminist groups on Friday announced their opposition because Souter would not state he would support abortion rights on the court. But so far no committee members have committed themselves to voting against him. Kennedy said Friday he was troubled by some of Souter's responses to questions, including one where the nominee offered what sounded like a callous explanation. Kennedy asked about a statement attributed to Souter that said it ``dilutes the votes of those people who can read'' if illiterates are allowed to vote. Souter said the remark was ``kind of a statement of math.'' Souter's response stood out in part because the bookish bachelor has taken great pains in the hearings to portray himself as compassionate and aware of a broad range of human concerns. After it completes it hearings, the committee will make its recommendation to the full Senate. Souter's supporters have expressed great confidence he will join the court this fall. Souter himself has been cautious, however. Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., a longtime friend of Souter's who is playing host to him in Washington during the nomination process, said the judge won't even let people discuss possible places to live if he moves to the capital. ``Maybe he's superstitious,'' Rudman said.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Again Seizes the Moment
With AM-Poland-Walesa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa's astonishing mix of political instinct and personal charisma turned the stout peasant's son into a candidate for Poland's presidency. Walesa has known the moment: when to leap the shipyard fence and take charge of the 1980 strike that made the Communists legalize Solidarity; when to say Solidarity would take over the government in August 1989, as even close aides shook their heads dubiously. If this is the time for him to become president - he announced his candidacy Monday - it will be because of his uncanny ability to grip Poles with his vision and persuade them to follow. Walesa was not born to political power. He is the product of an impoverished farm in a remote north-central hamlet of Poland, and his education came at a technical school. He has never learned to speak Polish smoothly or any other language at all. He is unpredictable, and at times maddeningly ambiguous. He has been photographed fishing in his underwear. His suit collection was recently expanded by three but is still single digit. In fact, there have been suggestions among Poles that Walesa, 46, is not learned or cultivated enough to be president. ``Criticism that I do not know how to talk with presidents?'' Walesa once scoffed. ``I have talked to them and they want to talk with me.'' When Walesa drifted to Gdansk and took a job at the Lenin Shipyard in 1967, no one would imagined that a little more than two decades later, one foreign leader after another would be making the pilgrimage to the Baltic port to see him. NATO General Secretary Manfred Woerner and former President Reagan came on Saturday alone. Walesa's anti-Communist activism can be traced to 1970 food price riots in which police killed some of his fellow workers. He translated his growing furor into unquestioned authenticity. He lost one job after another as his labor activism increased and was outside the strikebound shipyard when he made the famous leap that merged his destiny with Poland's future. In his subsequent 10 years as Solidarity's leader, he has maneuvered through martial law, imprisonment, repression and, finally, the Communist regime's overtures and its eventual downfall. Along the way, there were eight children, a Nobel Peace Prize in 1983 and enormous prestige at home and abroad, his mustachioed face on countless magazine covers, a noticeable paunch and graying hair but no dimming of his twinkling eyes. And there was the incalculable satisfaction of seeing Poland's revolution sweep the East bloc. Yet the new Solidarity-led government Walesa organized included no official role for himself. Pushing aside accusations he was a jealous demagogue, Walesa started to foment against his former allies now leading the country. Many inside and out of Poland did not want to believe his message - that Solidarity's unified days were over and political parties had to develop - but most have come to agree and elections are imminent. Now Walesa must wait for democracy's decision on whether he will add the presidency to his biography.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela: Police Crackdown Gives `License To Kill'
DOC.TEXT: A new police crackdown on black faction fighting amounts to a ``license to kill'' for security forces, Africn National Congress leader Nelson Mandela said Monday. President F.W. de Klerk said he would announce further measures this week intended to halt street clashes in black townships near Johannesburg that have killed almost 800 blacks since Aug. 12. Also Monday, police in Pretoria arrested a right-wing extremist who claimed responsibility for bombing two offices of the governing National Party. Boers State Party deputy leader Piet Rudolph had been in hiding since a weapons theft at an air force base in April. The party opposes efforts to end apartheid in South Africa. No major township violence was reported over the weekend or Monday, police said. The new police measures, codenamed Operation Iron Fist, were announced Saturday in response to calls for the government to halt the township carnage. They include more police and soldiers in the townships; roadblocks; searches for weapons; use of dye dropped from helicopters to identify participants in clashes; equipping police vehicles with mounted machine guns; isolating workers hostels and squatter camps with razor wire; and a dusk-to-dawn curfew. Police spokesman Col. Frans Malherbe said all the measures except the curfew would be implemented this week. The government previously declared the Johannesburg-area townships unrest areas and poured in additional police and soldiers in a bid to halt the fighting. But the street clashes continued. De Klerk said in Pretoria that additional measures would be announced later this week. He did not elaborate but said those participating in the violence would be prosecuted. He also said the violence had shifted from attacks against the white-led government to a power struggle among black factions. ``The violence we have now is violence ... of various black political factions trying to get the upper hand within the black society so that they can play a leading role in the negotiation process,'' the president said. De Klerk has pledged to eliminate the apartheid system of racial segregation and white dominance. He also has called for negotiations on sharing power with the black majority. Mandela, on a one-day tour of four small towns near Cape Town, said the new police measures would be ineffective. He was most upset by the mounting of machine guns on armored patrol vehicles. Police Maj. Gen. Gerrit Erasmus said the machines guns were for protection from attackers with assault rifles. Several policemen have been killed recently in such attacks. ``From now on we can expect indiscriminate shootings whenever there are demonstrations, no matter how peaceful,'' Mandela said. ``In my view, this is a license to kill.'' The ANC leader said police only need tear gas and water cannons to control demonstrations. Mandela also said he believes the security forces have helped orchestrate the violence. In addition, he reiterated charges that a ``sinister task force'' had participated in recent attacks on blacks intended to destabilize the situation. Witnesses have reported seeing white men with blackened faces participating in the attacks. The government has said it would investigate such charges. Mandela said the government's failure to halt the unrest could upset planned negotiations on power sharing. But he added: ``To abandon the talks now would be to play into the hands of this task force.'' ``But we will not stand by and see our people mowed down like dogs,'' Mandela said, reiterating a threat to arm ANC supporters. The ANC, however, is not believed to possess a large arsenal of weapons. Most of the fighting has been between Zulus loyal to the conservative Inkatha movement and Xhosas and other blacks who support the ANC. The ANC and Inkatha, the two largest black political movements, both oppose apartheid but differ on tactics and plans for a future South Africa. Under apartheid, the 5 million whites dominate politics and the economy and the 30 million blacks have no voice in national affairs.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Orders Salvation Army to Pay Workers
DOC.TEXT: The Salvation Army gives its clients ``soup, soap and salvation,'' but the federal government says that isn't enough - they should get the minimum wage, too. For 110 years, the non-sectarian Christian group, based five miles northwest here in Verona, has fed, sheltered and offered spiritual counsel to the people it has taken in at its adult rehabilitation centers. In exchange for room, board and up to about $20 a week in pocket money, the beneficiaries, as the Salvation Army calls them, assist in the organization's kitchens or unload the discarded furniture and clothes the Army collects, said William J. Moss, the attorney for the Salvation Army's national headquarters. One Salvation Army official in Newark who spoke on condition of anonymity described the program as ``soup, soap and salvation in the name of Jesus.'' The federal government, however, sees the situation differently. The U.S. Department of Labor claims the people to whom the Salvation Army ministers are employees - exploited ones at that - and should be entitled to a minimum wage under the Fair Labor Standards Act, Moss said. The Salvation Army contends that payment of a wage could doom the social service centers, which are kept financially afloat by a network of thrift shops they run across the country. ``The Salvation Army is convinced that the beneficiaries are not employees entitled to the benefits of the Fair Labor Standards Act, for the same reason that volunteers and students and trainees are not employees,'' Moss said Sunday. ``They are not there to exchange their services for compensation. They are there for their own benefit, to be rehabilitated.'' According to the organization, the work assignments teach the discipline of work to the emotionally and financially destitute and prepare them to become productive members of society. Labor Department officials argue that other rehabilitation organizations, such as Goodwill Industries Inc., do meet minimum wage standards. The government's action stemmed from a complaint filed by a Salvation Army client in Pittsburgh several years ago. On Sept. 7, the department concluded that the clients of the Salvation Army - which maintains more than 11,000 beds in 117 centers nationwide - are entitled to protection under the Fair Labor Standards Act. Moss said the organization was given 10 days to respond to the letter. On Friday, Salvation Army officials sent a letter to Samuel D. Walker, acting administrator of the Labor Department's wage and hour division, advising him they would not comply with the minimum wage demand. The Army said it would do everything in its power to defend against threatened enforcement. A department spokesman in Washington did not immediately return a telephone call Monday for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Arabs Cheer Anti-U.S. Stance at Conference
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with communique issued; Picks up 8th graf pvs, `The 150 ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Arab radicals meeting in Amman on Monday cheered calls for suicide attacks against American forces and for an Islamic uprising to topple Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. ``We have striking examples of heroes who turned their bodies into bombs that horrified the aggressors and forced them to flee in darkness as happened to the American Marines in Beirut in 1983,'' said Ibrahim Al-Kharraz of the Libyan Peoples Congress. The three-day conference of Arab leftists, Islamic party members and Palestinian guerrilla factions ended with an endorsement for a peaceful, negotiated Arab settlement of the Persian Gulf crisis. But it also urged Arabs ``to strike against the American interests everywhere and by all means at the same moment an American attack is launched agaist Iraq.'' The conference communique also said regular appeals would be made to Arab troops in Saudi Arabia and some gulf states to rebel against their leaders and reject American orders. Al-Kharraz drew rapturous applause by exhorting Arabs to swiftly move against U.S. forces and Saudi oil pipelines. He urged them to follow the example of Jaul Jamal, a Syrian gunboat commander who died in 1956 when he deliberately rammed his vessel into a French warship during fighting over the Suez Canal. He also hailed the suicide bombers who killed 241 U.S. Marines in an attack on their Beirut barracks in 1983. ``We have to move swiftly and with all means against the American military presence on the peninsula and in the gulf and follow the examples of the Arab struggles in the '50s and the '60s,'' Al-Kharraz said. The call for Mubarak's ouster came from Adnan Saududdin, a member of the Jordanian Islamic Front and the fundamentalist Moslem Brotherhood. He made an impassioned plea for an Islamic uprising to ``free Egypt from the shackles of the treasonous Camp David accords.'' The 150 delegates from 11 Arab countries officially represent only their individual organizations, so the communique did not necessarily reflect the positions of their governments. Jordan, for example, agreed to act as host for the conference although King Hussein has called for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait and allow the ousted emir to return. However, the king has resisted Western pressure to publicly condemn Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Saddam has won support in the Arab world by insisting that any Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait must be tied to a similar Israeli withdrawal from the occupied territories and a solution to the Palestinian problem. The United States objects to linking the Iraqi and Israeli issues. ``The Arab triumph had already started when an Arab leader said `No' to America and slapped its face. We will slap the face of Bush with the shoes of Iraqi soldiers,'' Saududdin told the conference. ``Being leftists, Communists, Baathist or Islamist is not important. What is important is for us all to stand in the same trench with Iraq against Israel, the United States and their allies,'' Saududdin said. Groups from Morocco, Tunisia, Algeria, Libya, Sudan, Mauritania, Yemen, Lebanon, Syria, Jordan, Iraq and the Palestine Liberation Organization were invited to the conference. It was organized by the Jordanian Arab National Democratic Alliance.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Urges Soviet Republics to Let Reason Prevail Over Passion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th pvs, ``I'm sure...' to UPDATE with Tass report of meeting. Pickup 8th pvs, `Parliamentary committee...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Soviet-Gorbachev, Bjt
LaserPhoto MOSB3
DOC.TEXT: Ronald Reagan, visiting the Soviet Union for the first time since leaving the White House, on Monday cautioned the 15 fractious republics against letting their passion for independence boil over. The former president, speaking to lawmakers in the Supreme Soviet parliament, recalled the ``wrenching and terrible'' Civil War fought by American states over their division of powers with Washington. ``As you find a reformulation of the relationships in your union you will find there is a period of uncertainty and tension,'' he told the parliament's international committee. ``Differences can be resolved in ways that are fair to all, but reason must prevail over passion if there is to be a climate conducive to the settlement of disagreements.'' President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is trying to negotiate a new treaty giving more autonomy to the Soviet Union's ethnically and geographically diverse republics. But 13 of them have already have declared some form of independence or sovereignty, in which their laws would take precedence over national laws. Reagan and his wife, Nancy, arrived in the Soviet Union in Leningrad on Sunday, the start of a five-day visit proposed by Gorbachev when they last met in San Francisco in June. The two men greeted one another Monday with a warm embrace, and Gorbachev praised Reagan's contribution toward better superpower relations. ``I'm sure you must have sense by now during your stay here in this country that we and people in Soviet society hold you in tremendous esteem and respect,'' Gorbachev said before talks in his Kremlin office. The official Tass news agency said Gorbachev and Reagan had a ``substantial and sincere'' talk, discussing the Persian Gulf crisis, the prospects for continued cooperation between the Soviet Union and the United States, and the outlook for cutting strategic nuclear weapons. Parliamentary committee chairman Alexander Dzasokhov said Reagan's presidency began in 1981 ``with a vision of our country as one that was covered with thunderclouds, a country that was the source of trouble to the whole world.'' By the time he left office in 1989, Reagan had formed a ``different and fair image,'' Dzasokhov told about 50 lawmakers. In his speech, Reagan marveled at the reforms that have swept Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union since his fourth presidential summit with Gorbachev in Moscow in May 1988. ``These are yeasty times, times of ferment,'' he said. ``Freedom can bring out passions between groups of people that may boil over. When they do, cool and calm decisions are called for by leaders, so as to lower temperatures all around.'' Reagan said political changes might come easier than economic changes as the Soviet Union struggles to replace its centrally planned command economy with a market economy. ``There will be disappointment and discouragement at times,'' he said. ``There will be trials and errors, but if you have the courage to persist, you will create an economy within which all can prosper.'' Reagan also said mistrust between the Soviet Union and the United States has given way to ``cautious friendship.'' He predicted gradual arms reductions by both superpowers in the next five years ``as we find new ways to work together on matters where our goals are similar.'' ``Together, our great size can be used in the service of all humankind to persuade those whose passions have reached the danger point to cool down again.''

DOC.HEAD: Hoover-Ball Returns to Nation's Capital
DOC.TEXT: Hoover-ball, a game invented to help President Herbert Hoover stay in shape, is returning to the nation's capital after a 57-year absence. Sen. Mark O. Hatfield, R-Ore., is sponsoring the first Hoover-ball Capital Classic on Sept. 29. The tournament, staged by the Hoover Presidential Library Association, will be held on volleyball courts on The Mall in Washington. The game, likened by one participant to ``throwing a frozen turkey over your garage,'' blends elements of tennis and volleyball. It pits two three-player teams against each other as they heave a 6-pound medicine ball over an 8-foot volleyball net. The game was devised in 1929 by Hoover's physician to help the 31st president stay in shape and was played daily on the lawn of the White House while Hoover was in office. ``President Hoover was a Hoover-ball fanatic,'' said Tom Walsh, the library association's executive director. ``He and a group of other Washington VIPs - who were dubbed by The New York Times as Hoover's `medicine ball cabinet' - played six mornings a week, rain or shine, beginning at 7 a.m. He even played the morning of March 4, 1933, the day Franklin D. Roosevelt was inaugurated.'' The game was forgotten until revived in 1988 for a national tournament at the Hoover library and museum in West Branch, Hoover's birthplace. The 1990 tournament last month attracted 50 teams. ``We're expecting at least a dozen teams in Washington,'' Walsh said. He said teams were being organized by Hatfield's staff and by the staffs of Iowa's Sens. Tom Harkin and Charles Grassley and Rep. Tom Tauke.

DOC.HEAD: Hazardous Trash Stored in Boat Stalls
DOC.TEXT: A hauler stored medical waste, human tissue and dangerous solvents at a boat marina and near a grocery store because he could not afford to dispose of the waste properly. Former ball-bearing salesman Richard Kirkham said it was easy to become licensed to dispose of hazardous waste but more difficult to find places to store the refuse. Kirkham's Hazardous Waste Management Inc. stored 95 barrels of hazardous solvents, fuels and toxic chemicals at Scott's Marina No. 2 on Lake Grapevine, authorities said. They also found said they 75 drums of chemical solvents and several cartons filled with used syringes, soiled dressings, surgical gloves and human tissue at Kirkham's office and at a warehouse near a Fort Worth grocery store. Kirkham was caught removing water-soaked cartons of medical debris from shoreline boat stalls last November, after the lake northeast of Fort Worth receded following a flood. Dallas Water Utilities officials shut down a water treatment plant for two days last November before determining there was no evidence of contamination from the wastes. The discovery triggered a three-state criminal investigation of Kirkham's one-truck operation. Kirkham has been fined $260, while it has cost $125,000 so far to clean up the boxes and barrels he stashed at the marina, the Fort Worth Star-Telegram reported Sunday. No evidence has been found that Kirkham's illegal inventory polluted the environment, federal officials said. A simple registration form made Kirkham one of the state's 2,034 hazardous-waste transporters in 1986. His company went unwatched by state and federal regulators. He wasn't affected by the stringent rules imposed on licensed disposal sites that would have guaranteed that he had the money to destroy what he collected. Instead, he started the firm with a pickup and four weeks of training at Texas A&M University. Kirkham said he never intended to run the business illegally. But his struggling operation was derailed when the sand-hauling truck he used to subsidize the fledgling waste-hauling business was wrecked. He used the money paid by waste producers to repair the sand truck instead of properly disposing of the waste. ``And the reason that we did it is that hope springs eternal in the breast of man,'' Kirkham told the Star-Telegram. ``We kept thinking things would get better.'' Kirkham said that when he could no longer afford to pay disposal fees, he forged records to convince his customers that their waste was reaching its destination. In June, the Environmental Protection Agency notified 214 of Kirkham's clients that they were potentially liable for his actions and billed each of them the full cost of storing and disposing of the waste found at the boat dock. Among those notified were Texas A&M University, Parkland Memorial Hospital in Dallas, the Navy, the Army Corps of Engineers and the First Baptist Church of Dallas. Officials with the U.S. attorney's office in Fort Worth confirmed in July they are continuing a criminal investigation of Kirkham and Waste Management that was started by the EPA in January. The investigation has spread to Oklahoma and Louisiana, where records at licensed disposal sites conflict with manifests Kirkham supplied to customers showing waste had been delivered, investigators told the Star-Telegram.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Offers Assurances on Who's In Charge of US Troops
DOC.TEXT: President Bush offered assurances today that the command structure in Saudi Arabia will work well and U.S. forces won't ``stand around waiting for someone else'' to give the order to fight. ``The command structure will function very, very smoothly,'' Bush told a news conference. The president also said he believes the American public is ``magnificently united'' behind the international effort to end Saddam Hussein's occupation of Kuwait. But he cautioned, ``I'm not clear in my own mind on how long this kind of support holds up.'' Bush was asked who would give the orders to U.S. forces to shoot. The question apparently was in reference to directions earlier this month to American fighter pilots to wait for a go-ahead from Saudi commanders before firing at Iraqi jets. ``I have no hesitancy at all to say to the parents of the kids over there ... should something happen that required combat, the command structure will function very, very smoothly,'' Bush said. ``We're not going to have to stand around waiting for someone else to decide if there is some provocation, either,'' he said. Bush also appeared to support extending the naval embargo to an air blockade of Iraq. ``I would be prepared to work with anybody to tie that additional knot in the sanctions,'' he said. The U.S. ambassador, Thomas R. Pickering, said Sunday a resolution would be drafted to impose an air embargo, a step the United Nations has never taken against a nation. Pickering briefed Bush today. Bush said he wants to bring the 150,000-strong U.S. forces home ``as soon as possible,'' but he said he did not know when that would be. ``What we are trying is this all-out, full-court international press on the diplomatic side. I want to see that work,'' said Bush. He said he is hearing varying assessments from world leaders on how well the sanctions are working. What if the crisis erupts into war, with thousands of American casualties? ``I don't know, but I am inclined to feel that we are off to a very good start,'' Bush said at a news conference with regional reporters. ``I'm old enough to remember a clear-cut case, different circumstances, different times, World War II,'' he said. ``There was a lot of sorrow, there was a lot of regret, everyone identified with the families who lost loved ones. But the country stayed fairly well together. ``Now, at this juncture I think the American people are magnificently united in terms of standing up against this aggression,'' Bush said. He declined comment on Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's decision to fire Air Force Chief of Staff Gen. Mike Dugan for his blunt remarks identifying targets in a possible massive air strike against Iraq. ``I'll have nothing to say about that except I strongly support our secretary of defense,'' the president said. Cheney said he relieved Dugan of his office because he violated Pentagon policy in discussing ``specific targets for air strikes,'' revealed classified information and demeaned the contribution of other services. ``Relieving him is not a pleasant task, but I felt it was a necessary one,'' Cheney told reporters at the White House. On other matters, Bush said: - He does not plan to draw down the strategic petroleum reserve at this time, claiming ``I have not felt there is a shortage.'' But he said a case could be made that tapping the reserve would help stabilize gasoline prices. - The Mideast crisis should lay rest to talk about a ``peace dividend'' in the defense budget. ``I've always thought that was a phantom. How can you declare a dividend when you're operating at a loss?'' he asked. - Iran has provided indirect assurances that it wants to see the sanctions against Iraq work, despite deep differences that remain between the U.S. and Iran. But ``some factions within Iran will continue to resist improvement in relations with the United States,'' he said about an ayatollah's call for a holy war. Bush said an air embargo against Baghdad would be hard to enforce. Earlier, the White House said the hostile reaction in Baghdad to Bush's televised appeal to the Iraqi people demonstrates how effective his message was. Bush got his chance Sunday to make his case directly to the Iraqi people, saying the only way for Iraq to avoid a war it cannot win is to end its occupation of Kuwait. ``That decision is in the hands of Saddam Hussein,'' Bush said in a taped address broadcast over Iraqi television Sunday. Bush's eight-minute message was followed immediately by a lengthy criticism by Saddam's spokesman, charging that Bush's words were ``full of lies and contradictions.'' It set off demonstrations in the streets of Baghdad, with Iraqis chanting ``Death to Bush!'' and ``Death to America!'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the angry response shows that Bush's ``speech was very effective.'' ``The most telling aspect was the lengthy and extraordinarily personal attack against the president immediately following it,'' Fitzwater said, as well as ``the organized demonstrations.'' ``They obviously felt it was necessary to try to discredit the United States as much as possible,'' the White House spokesman said. ``We think it's important to be able to get the word through to the people of Iraq about the world''s unanimity against (Iraq) and to be able to speak forthrightly about what the U.S. role is,'' said Fitzwater. ``We're glad they gave us the opportunity,'' he said. Dugan will no longer serve as the Air Force's top commander, but he retains his rank as a four-star general, the Pentagon said. The Pentagon's rare disciplinary action of a top officer came one day after published reports quoted Dugan as saying U.S. military authorities had concluded that massive air strikes are the only effective way of forcing Iraq out of Kuwait if war erupted. Dugan was on a tour of U.S. military installations in Saudi Arabia when he made his comments in an interview with The Los Angeles Times and The Washington Post. Bush and the Cabinet also heard firsthand from Secretary of State James A. Baker III about the $14 billion pledged by America's allies for the gulf effort. Baker returned early Sunday from an 11-day mission to Europe and the Middle East during which he solicited help for the costly stand in the Saudi desert. ``Saddam Hussein tells you that this crisis is a struggle between Iraq and America. In fact, it is Iraq against the world,'' Bush said in his televised message to Iraqis. ``Iraq finds itself on the brink of war,'' Bush said. ``Let me say clearly, there is no way Iraq can win. Ultimately, Iraq must withdraw from Kuwait,'' he said. ``War is not inevitable. It is still possible to bring this crisis to a peaceful end,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Honduras Laments Drownings; Search Resumes For Children Missing in Accident
DOC.TEXT: Families held funerals Monday for 25 Honduran children and their American bus driver who drowned while their vehicle was trying to cross a flooding river. Rescue crews searched for eight other people missing after the accident Sunday. ``It is a national tragedy,'' said Nora de Melgar, mayor of Tegucigalpa, where the bodies were brought to the morgue. One child and two adults were rescued from the bus, which was sucked underwater as it was crossing the usually shallow Rio Grande between the villages of El Naranjal and Cantarranas, about 80 miles southeast of Tegucigalpa, authorities said. The bus was carrying children ranging in age from 10 months to 16 years on an outing for a missionary preschool, authorities said. The driver, Dorothy Landers Hood, 52, of East Petersburg, Pa., died in the accident. She and her husband, George B. Hood, had operated the school in El Naranjal for more than 10 years. At least 40 people were on the bus when it was caught in the flooding river, said a firefighters spokesman, Lt. Frank Medina. Heavy rains had been falling during the day in the area. President Rafael Callejas appealed for authorities to help the victims' families. Tegucigalpa authorities donated coffins for burials in Cofradia and El Zarzal, near the victims' hometown of Cantarranas. Funerals for several of the victims were held in a Protestant church in Cofradia and in several private homes. More than 200 firefighters, police and Red Cross rescue workers, with help from the army, searched the banks of the river near Cantarranas on Sunday and Monday looking for survivors or bodies.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi, Soviet Agree to Restore Diplomatic Ties
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia and the Soviet Union agreed Monday to restore diplomatic relations and exchange ambassadors after a break of more than 50 years, the official Tass news agency reported. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met the Saudi foreign minister, Prince Saud Al-Faisal Al Saud, and expressed the hope that bilateral relations between the Soviet Union and Saudi Arabia would help settle the Persian Gulf crisis, Tass reported. ``The restoration of diplomatic relations amid an acute crisis in the Arab East emphasized the resolve of both states to insistently seek the implementation of U.N. Security Council resolutions on the Persian Gulf in cooperation with other members of the international community,'' Tass said. It said Gorbachev and Prince Saud ``assessed the possible conduct of the aggressor'' - meaning Iraq - in their Kremlin meeting. Prince Saud handed Gorbachev a message from King Fahd, the Saudi monarch, the news agency added, without disclosing its contents. Earlier, the prince met with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, and they urged the immediate withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait, Tass said. In their discussions of the Persian Gulf crisis, Saud and Shevardnadze noted the similar positions of their nations and that both sides wanted a peaceful settlement. ``We hope that faced with the world community's unanimity, Iraq will agree to the immediate and unconditional withrdrawal of its troops from Kuwait and will restore legality,'' Tass quoted Prince Saud as saying. Saudi Arabia and Moscow had full diplomatic relations until 1938, when dictator Josef Stalin closed his embassy in Saudi Arabia to save money. Several attempts to re-establish ties during the 1980s faltered over what Saudi Arabia called the Soviet Union's ``belligerent attitude'' toward its 50 million Moslems. A Soviet-Saudi communique said the two nations decided to restore ties after indicating a ``desire to develop friendly relations,'' according to Tass. ``The sides agreed that their bilateral relations will be built in accordance with the U.N. Charter on the basis of principles of peaceful coexistence, equality and mutual respect for each other's sovereignty, territorial integrity and non-interference in internal affairs,'' the communique said. Tass did not give a timetable when the two nations would exchange ambassadors, although it announced that the prince would hold a news conference Tuesday. A full report on the prince's meetings with Gorbachev and Shevardnadze also was carried on the evening news program ``Vremya.'' Gorbachev asked Prince Saud to convey his best wishes to King Faud and the Saudi people, Tass said. The Soviet leader expressed hope that relations between the two nations would develop on a large scale, Tass said. Soviet Foreign Ministry official Sergei Kirpichenko has been quoted as saying the establishment of official contacts between the Soviet Union and Saudi Arabia ``has long been ripe.'' On Sunday, Abdul-Wahab Abdul-Wasie, the Saudi Arabian Minister of Pilgrimage and Endowments, arrived in Moscow to attend a three-day Islamic conference and meet with Soviet Moslems, Tass said. The visit is the first ever to be made by a religious affairs minister to the Soviet Union. Before leaving Saudi Arabia, Abdul-Wasie said he was seeking to consolidate cooperation between Soviet Moslems and religious circles in Saudi Arabia. As part of the improving atmosphere between the two countries, King Fahd recently donated about 1.6 million copies of the Moslem holy book, the Koran, to Soviet Moslems. The Soviet Union allowed more than 1,000 Soviet Moslems to make the annual pilgrimage, or hajj, to Mecca this summer.

DOC.HEAD: 2 Bomb Blasts in Puerto Rico; Group Says One Was Gulf Protest
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Small pipe bombs exploded simultaneously early Monday at a Citibank branch and a factory, causing minor damage but no injuries, police said. A pro-independence group said it set the bomb at the Citibank to protest a planned 1991 plebiscite on Puerto Rico's relationship with the United States and the use of Puerto Rican soldiers in the Persian Gulf crisis. Police said the bomb destroyed the front door of the bank branch in Arecibo, 45 miles of San Juan. No group claimed responsibility for a blast at an electrical switch factory in Vega Baja, about 20 miles west of the capital. The pipe bomb had been placed in an air-conditioning unit and caused minor damage. Both explosions took place at 1:05 a.m. but it was not immediately known if they were related, said police spokesman Edwin Burgos. The pro-independence group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces-Albizu Campos, claimed the Citibank bombing in a statement to a San Juan radio station. The group, which carried out two similar bombings last year, takes its name from independence leader Albizu Campos, who died in 1965. Congress is considering legislation that would allow Puerto Ricans to vote in a plebiscite in June 1991 on whether to remain a U.S. commonwealth, become the 51st state, or form an independent nation. Polls indicate less than 10 percent of the population favors independence. The Caribbean island of 3.6 million people has been a commonwealth since 1952. The status gives Puerto Ricans most rights of U.S. citizenship, but they cannot vote for president. They pay no federal taxes.

DOC.HEAD: Initial Ratings for Emmy Telecast Lower than 1989
With AM-Emmys-List
DOC.TEXT: Preliminary ratings for the 42nd Annual Primetime Emmy Awards indicated the stolid ceremony was less popular than 1989's awards show. Highlighted by the surprising shutout of ABC's spooky ``Twin Peaks,'' the Fox Broadcasting Co. Emmy telecast finished behind ABC's and CBS' programming Sunday night, according to viewer figures released Monday. Fox spokesman Steve Ross said that in 24 television markets, the Emmys finished first in Los Angeles, New York, San Francisco and Phoenix. In other cities, the ceremony lost to such shows as ABC's ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' and CBS' ``Murder, She Wrote.'' Fox said the telecast generated overnight A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings of 11.5. Last year's broadcast had a rating of 15.4. Each rating represent the percentage of television sets tuned to the show. Final national ratings, which usually are lower than the overnight figures, are to be released Tuesday. It wasn't a complete wash for the upstart Fox network. Its ``The Simpsons'' was honored as best animated series and network star Tracey Ullman won a combined six trophies, the most of any show. The broadcast, whose hosts were Jane Pauley, Jay Leno and Candice Bergen, ran 14 minutes past its allotted three hours. There were few surprises during the show, as veterans and favorites captured most of the top prizes. ``Twin Peaks,'' the critically acclaimed ABC series from director David Lynch, was blanked at Sunday's gala despite a leading 14 nominations. The show collected two technical awards, for editing and costuming, on Saturday. Lynch was not immediately available for comment. A publicist said he was filming a new episode. ``L.A. Law'' won as best drama series for the third time in four years and ``Murphy Brown'' was named best comedy. Peter Falk's rumpled but brilliant ``Columbo'' earned him the dramatic actor award - his fourth Emmy for the role of the trenchcoat-wearing detective he created during the '70s. Backstage, Falk said the occasional series and its title character work for audiences because the story-telling isn't sloppy. ``We don't cheat as much as some other shows,'' he said of the show's mysteries. There are ``genuine twists'' in the dramas and they are credible, said Falk, who turned 63 the day of the award show. Best miniseries went to NBC's ``Drug Wars: The Camarena Story,'' an account of the torture-slaying of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena and the subsequent cover-up by Mexican officials. The miniseries generated outrage in Mexico as a misrepresentation of the current drug-fighting situation and led to Mexico's creating a $950,000 advertising campaign in the United States extolling Mexico's successes in fighting drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Europeans Expelling Iraqi Diplomats, Air Embargo Considered
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Bush comment, detail on expulsions of Iraqi diplomats, State Department comment on refugees, four French hostages freed, other details. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA1, AMM1
DOC.TEXT: International pressure on Saddam Hussein intensified Monday as European nations expelled Iraqi diplomats to retaliate for raids on embassies in occupied Kuwait, and support appeared to grow for an air embargo against Iraq. Oil prices jumped Monday, pointing to pessimism about prospects for a settlement of the 6{-week-old Persian Gulf standoff. Oil futures soared to record levels, above $33 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. In a sign of Iraq's growing isolation, the Soviet Union, Baghdad's longtime patron, said Monday it would re-establish diplomatic ties with Saudi Arabia. The Saudis infuriated Iraq by agreeing to become the main staging ground for the deployment of a U.S.-led multinational force after the Aug. 2 Iraqi takeover of Kuwait. Sensitivities about the role of the U.S. force were underscored when a top U.S. military man was sacked after discussing contingency plans to launch massive air strikes against Baghdad and target Saddam personally. The fired official, Air Force chief of staff Gen. Mike Dugan, made the remarks while touring U.S. military installations in Saudi Arabia, and they were published Sunday in The Washington Post and the Los Angeles Times. ``There are certain things we never talk about. We never discuss operational matters, such as the selection of specific targets for potential air strikes,'' an angry Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told reporters in Washington. He dismissed Dugan after consulting President Bush. Bush, meanwhile, said he considered Americans to be ``magnificently united'' behind the U.S. military effort in the gulf, but he cautioned, ``I'm not clear in my own mind on how long this kind of support holds up.'' At a news conference Monday, the president said he wanted to bring home the 150,000 U.S. troops in the region ``as soon as possible'' but did not know when that would be. Arab radical groups, meanwhile, ended a three-day conference in Amman, Jordan on Monday with calls for suicide attacks on the U.S. forces. ``We have the striking examples of heroes who turned their bodies into bombs that horrified the aggressors and forced them to flee in darkness,'' Libyan Ibrahim Al-Kharraz told delegates, referring to the 1983 bombing of the Marine barracks in Beirut that killed 241 U.S. servicemen. In Iraq, there was an outburst of anti-American sentiment in the state-run newspapers Monday, a day after Iraqi television broadcast an eight-minute message from Bush to the Iraqi people. ``Shut Up, Mr. Bush,'' one headline said. Bush's videotaped message, in which he warned that Saddam was leading Iraq into war, was followed immediately by an Iraqi commentary blasting the speech as ``full of lies and contradictions.'' Hundreds of demonstrators then took to the streets of Baghdad, chanting ``Death to Bush!'' and ``Death to America!'' The Bush administration said the hostile reaction demonstrated the effectiveness of Bush's message. ``They obviously felt it was necessary to try to discredit the United States as much as possible,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. At the Kuwait-Saudi border, Iraqi troops unexpectedly opened the only border crossing over the weekend, and about 6,000 Kuwaitis fled their homeland. The flow slowed to a trickle Monday. Refugees said Iraqi troops were seizing draft-age Kuwaiti men and forcing their wives and daughters to travel to Saudi Arabia without them. U.S. officials expressed concern over Kuwaitis being forced to leave their identity papers with Iraqi border guards. ``The confiscation of identity papers is an ominous sign that these citizens of Kuwait may not be allowed to return to their homes,'' State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said. ``If this is part of an Iraqi effort to drive Kuwaitis from their homes, it is unacceptable.'' In Brussels, Belgium, the 12 European Community nations announced they would expel Iraqi military attaches and their staffs and restrict travel by other embassy personnel to protest break-ins by Iraqi troops at diplomatic premises in occupied Kuwait last week. The Iraqi raids on Dutch, French, Belgian and Canadian embassies or diplomatic residences were unanimously condemned Sunday by the U.N. Security Council. Britain said Monday it was deporting eight diplomats and 23 Iraqi nationals deemed a danger to national security, and West Germany gave walking papers to the Iraqi military attache's staff. Italy said Monday it was expelling 11 Iraqi Embassy employees who worked in the military attache's office. The EC ministers were also weighing a possible air blockade of Iraq to enforce the U.N. trade embargo against Iraq. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said there was strong support among the EC ministers for such a blockade. The Belgian foreign affairs minister, Mark Eyskens, concurred. ``Everybody was arguing for an air blockade,'' he said. Hurd said, however, that it was important to obtain backing from the U.N. Security Council for such a step. U.N. diplomats on Sunday began drafting a new resolution to close Iraq's air routes and punish nations flouting the embargo, U.S. officials said. An air blockade would involve the interception of planes approaching Iraq and would pose a far greater danger of triggering hostilities than the boarding of ships in the Persian Gulf. Hurd also renewed complaints about Iraq's treatment of diplomats in Kuwait, where about a dozen nations, including the United States, are defying Baghdad's orders to close their embassies. ``They are surrounded by soldiers, they can't get food or drink in,'' Hurd said. In other developments: -Four French nationals - a married couple and two men - arrived in Amman, Jordan on Monday after being freed from Iraq. They said they were held in a site about an hour from Baghdad with about 10 other hostages, including an American. Iraq is using trapped Westerners as human shields against attack on key Iraqi installations. -Ireland's Department of Foreign Affairs said three Irishmen had been jailed in Iraq on charges of attempting to escape the country. Also, West Germany said Iraqi troops seized another West German in Kuwait, raising to 44 the number of West Germans held by Baghdad. -An Egyptian military source said Egypt was sending 250 soldiers to Saudi Arabia Monday and more would follow in a few days, joining the estimated 4,000 Egyptian troops in the region. -A senior Iranian delegation met in Baghdad with an Iraqi team to discuss normalization of ties between the two nations, which fought a war from 1980 to 1988. Saddam last month initiated a prisoner exchange, agreed to shared sovereignty over a key waterway that forms the southern border between the two countries, and removed troops from Iranian territory captured during the war. But the Red Cross says the month-long prisoner exchange has stopped. -In Beijing, 42 Kuwaiti athletes and a coach arrived Monday to take part in the Asian Games, which begin Saturday. Kuwait's National Olympic Committee, now based in exile in Saudi Arabia, said athletes who were out of the country during the Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion would participate.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf at a Glance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads throughout to UPDATE with new detail
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, are Monday's developments in the Persian Gulf crisis:

--- U.S. Air Force chief of staff, Gen. Mike Dugan, was fired for his public comments about contingency plans to unleash massive air raids on Iraq and target Saddam Hussein personally. The remarks, made while touring military installations in Saudi Arabia, were published Sunday in The Washington Post and the Los Angeles Times. ``There are certain things we never talk about. We never discuss operational matters, such as the selection of specific targets for potential air strikes,'' an angry Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told reporters in Washington. --- The 12 European Community nations decided to expel Iraqi military attaches and restrict the mobility of other personnel to protest Iraqi raids last week on three countries' diplomatic compounds in Kuwait. EC nations were also weighing a possible air blockade of Iraq to enforce a U.N. trade embargo. --- Arab radical groups ended a three-day conference in Amman, Jordan with calls for suicide attacks against the U.S. forces. Ibrahim Al-Kharraz, a member of the Libyan Peoples Congress, pointed to the 1983 suicide attack on the Marine barracks in Beirut that killed 241 U.S. servicemen. --- Britain said it would expel the Iraqi military attache and three aides from the embassy in London. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd indicated the Home Office would soon be annoucing further sanctions against Iraq. --- An Egyptian military source said Egypt will send 250 soldiers to Saudi Arabia and more will follow in a few days, joining the estimated 4,000 Egyptian troops already in the region. The source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Egypt would also send Egytian tanks, armored personel carriers and air defense systems to Saudi Arabia by ship across the Red Sea. --- Israeli Army chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, says Israel will not automatically respond in kind to an Iraqi invasion of Jordan, signaling an easing of Israel's stand on the gulf crisis. The comment, reported by Israeli newspapers, followed suggestions that an Iraqi invasion of Jordan could be aimed at drawing Israel into the gulf conflict as a way of uniting Arab nations behind Iraq. --- In a sign of Iraq's growing isolation, the Soviet Union, Baghdad's longtime patron, said it would re-establish diplomatic ties with Saudi Arabia. --- Iraqi troops randomly seized young men among the thousands of refugees fleeing Kuwait but let their sobbing wives, mothers and other women go. Refugees said busloads of men between the ages of 17 and 40 were seen being shipped north, toward Iraq. No explanation was given. Other young men were allowed to pass through. --- Oil prices jumped, pointing to pessimism about prospects for a settlement of the 6{-week-old Persian Gulf standoff. Oil futures soared to record levels, above $33 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Denied Honor in Home Town, Former Hostage Salutes Townspeople
DOC.TEXT: Though denied an honor from his native city, former hostage Brian Keenan said Monday he was moved by the welcome of ``my home, my town.'' Keenan was honored at a reception arranged by Lord Mayor Fred Cobain after a proposal to make him a ``freeman'' - an ancient distinction for prominent residents or benefactors - became entangled in Northern Ireland's political divisions. Despite the controversy that preceded him, Keenan told a news conference that he had felt ``the capacity of the people of this town to love, to love passionately.'' ``Division, confrontation, even the immediate history of this land, have not and cannot ever obliterate this love in all the people.'' In a province where Protestants generally support union with Britain and Roman Catholics identify with Ireland, Keenan is an unusual figure - a Protestant who carries passports of both countries and advocates a united Ireland. Some Unionist members of the city council were offended by Keenan's identification with Ireland and by the Irish government's prominent efforts to secure his release after 4{ years as a hostage in Lebanon. ``I don't see why we should stand on our heads to do special events for him - let Dublin give him the freedom of that city,'' council member Frank Millar said following Keenan's release Aug. 25. Dr. Brian Feeney, a Catholic member of the Belfast council who had suggested awarding the freedom of the city to Keenan, said the Unionist opponents had ``made fools of themselves in front of the rest of the world.'' Council member Sammy Wilson, a member of the Rev. Ian Paisley's Democratic Unionist Party, said he was staying away from the reception and complained that the Irish government had ``milked the affair dry.'' ``Ordinary people are suffering from terrorism daily in Belfast and I cannot forget that Sinn Fein representatives had been involved in earlier attempts to free Brian Keenan,'' Wilson said. In December 1987, Sinn Fein spokesman Joe Austin said that he and another party member had met with various groups in Beirut seeking Keenan's release. Keenan's sister Elaine Spence said at the time that the family did not know in advance of the Sinn Fein overture, did not request help and had no connection with the party, which is the legal political wing of the outlawed Irish Republican Army. Wilson's party finally decided not to boycott Monday's reception, and Sinn Fein council members - who were not invited to the event - also eased tensions by dropping plans to stage a demonstration. Keenan returned to Belfast in time to celebrate his 40th birthday on Tuesday at the home of his 69-year-old mother, Minnie. It also put Keenan within reach of his frequently expressed desire - a hearty, home-cooked ``Ulster fry'' breakfast of eggs, sausage, bacon and fried bread.

DOC.HEAD: Two Moderate Quakes Felt in Caribbean Islands
DOC.TEXT: Two moderate earthquakes struck the Caribbean within minutes of each other Monday, the U.S. Geological Survey said, but there were no reports on injuries or damage. The first earthquake at 9:05 a.m. EST measured 4.6 on the Richter Scale and was centered in the Mona Passage, a 90-mile-long channel between the Dominican Republic and Puerto Rico, said the U.S.G.S. in Golden, Colo. This tremor was felt over most parts of Puerto Rico. It said a second quake at 9:24 a.m. EST was just north of the island of Anguilla, a British territory 70 miles northwest of St. Kitts and Nevis in the Leeward Islands. Its intensity on the Richter scale was not immediately available, though it was considered minor.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Throws Out Lawsuit Against Contras in Aid Worker's Death
DOC.TEXT: A judge Monday dismisssed a $50 million damage suit accusing the U.S.-backed Contras of torturing and executing Benjamin Linder, an American volunteer killed during the Nicaraguan civil war. U.S. District Judge Stanley Marcus said the case intruded too far into the diplomatic arena. ``Political branches could be hampered in their ability to conduct sensitive foreign policy initiatives with foreign groups involved in civil war if the conduct later becomes subject to suits by private citizens challenging the nature of war-making on foreign soil,'' the judge wrote. Linder, 27, of Portland, Ore., was shot to death in Nicaragua in April 1987 when U.S.-backed rebels attacked the rural hydroelectric project he was helping to build. A year later his family, with the backing of the New York-based Center for Constitutional Rights, sued Miami-based Contra leaders Enrique Bermudez, Adolfo Calero and Aristides Sanchez. The Contra war against Nicaragua's leftist government formally ended after free elections put President Violeta Chamorro in power in February. Defense attorney John Kirkpatrick said Monday he was delighted by the judge's ruling. ``This was a political lawsuit filed by a political group for political reasons, and the judge understood that,'' Kirkpatrick said. He said Center for Constitutional Rights had filed five lawsuits against the U.S.-backed Contra effort, and all five had been dismissed. The Linders' lawyer, Michael Ratner, said he was disappointed. ``I think the execution and torture of an American citizen is something that should be seen as a violation of international law,'' he said. ``I am sure we will appeal, and eventually we will win.'' Benjamin's father, David Linder, has accused the Contras of torturing and killing his son to intimidate other foreign volunteers who were aiding the Sandinistas. The suit said the decision was made by the Miami-based Contra leadership. The Linders said an independent autopsy showed their son was stuck with needles in his face before he was finally shot to death. The Contras said Linder was in a Sandinista uniform at the time of his death and carried a weapon. They called him a casualty of war.

DOC.HEAD: Report Calls for Streamlining Federal Meat Inspections
DOC.TEXT: A controversial proposal to streamline beef inspections should be adopted by the Agriculture Department, including a feature putting greater reliance on packing companies, the National Academy of Sciences said Monday. But a report from the academy said that the department, if it relies more heavily on private industry to maintain meat quality, should ``concentrate its resources on safety'' to guard consumers against microbial and chemical contamination. ``The federal government should design its inspection programs to focus on contemporary health issues,'' the report said. ``It should insist that industry comply with policies and procedures required to protect public health and foster public confidence in the safety of the food supply.''
