For example, although supporting the speeded-up inspection system for cattle, the report said the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service, or FSIS, should develop methods for quickly testing carcasses for microbial and chemical contamination. The Streamlined Inspection Service for cattle slaughter, or SIS-C, was studied by a panel of the academy's Institute of Medicine under a $154,000 grant from the department. ``From a food safety viewpoint, SIS-C alone is probably no better, and in some situations can be less effective, than traditional inspection because the reduced oversight by government inspectors is not compensated by a total commitment to product quality on the part of the industry,'' the report said. But the report also called the streamlined system ``the most important change in bovine meat inspection'' since federal supervision was begun in 1906. ``For this system to work in practice, both FSIS and industry must fully endorse the philosophy of shifting responsibility for meat quality from FSIS to industry so that the government can concentrate on safety,'' the report said. The plan was officially proposed in November 1988. USDA spokesman Jim Greene said an amended proposal would probably be made based on the new study. Greene said the department plans to begin using the revised system within two years, but only in plants that slaughter ``fed'' cattle for the slaughter market. These cattle are mostly grain-fattened steers and heifers from feedlots. The report said about 80 of the nation's more than 1,300 USDA-inspected cattle slaughter plants would be eligible to use the system. Those account for an estimated 80 percent of the fed cattle slaughtered for the consumer market. Lester M. Crawford, FSIS administrator, said the 11-month study by the scientific panel ``confirms our ongoing commitment to modernize inspection at cattle slaughter plants is on solid footing.'' Under traditional inspections, federal inspectors check bile ducts, heart, cheek muscles and numerous lymph nodes for disease and other abnormalities. They also are responsible for condemnation and disposition of diseased carcasses, as well as supervising the trimming undesirable parts. But under SIS-C, plant employees would incise heart and cheek muscles, position parts for inspectors and assume responsibility for some trimming. Inspectors still would be responsible for condemnation and disposition of diseased carcasses, and still would examine every head, viscera and carcass. The streamlined inspection system is currently used experimentally in five meat plants using high-speed techniques to slaughter steers and heifers for the beef market. Agency officials said those include two Montfort plants, in Greeley, Colo., and Grand Island, Neb.; two Excel plants, in Friona and Plainview, Texas; and a National Beef plant in Liberal, Kan. The industry's American Meat Institute called the report ``an objective assessment'' of the new inspection program and that it may help to end the controversy over the merits of SIS-C. Tom Devine of the consumer-oriented Government Accountability Project, which has helped federal whistleblowers to criticize USDA inspection operations, said he was ``delighted'' by the report. ``It's a gratifying vindication for the concerns raised by whistleblowers'' who as USDA inspectors alleged there have been many slipshod, unsanitary practices in plants where the new system has been used, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Grandmother Says Slaying Suspect Mistreated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 9-16, ``He's afraid ...' with 8 grafs to CORRECT spelling to `Hlavaty'
DOC.TEXT: The jailed college freshman who is the most publicized suspect in the serial killings of five college students is confused about why he's jailed and is being treated inhumanely, his grandmother says. ``I know he's getting very upset and he doesn't know why,'' Elna Hlavaty said of her grandson, Edward Lewis Humphrey, in an interview published Monday. ``They're treating him like he's ready for the gallows and he hasn't even been charged,'' said Ms. Hlavaty, who visited him last weekend in the Brevard County Jail, more than 100 miles from Gainesville. Also Monday, a 17-year-old Montana girl was quoted as saying she spurned Humphrey's marriage proposals about a month before the slayings. Meanwhile, life has been returning to normal in this bustling college town. Police spokeswoman Lt. Sadie Darnell on Monday canceled daily news briefings, saying no major breaks were imminent. The city's chamber of commerce dedicated this week to paying tribute to the slain students, asking residents to display white ribbons on mailboxes, fly flags at half-staff and attend a tree-planting ceremony Friday. Humphrey, an 18-year-old University of Florida freshman, has been identified as one of eight suspects in the stabbing deaths of the five students, three of whom were mutilated. He's been held in lieu of $1 million bond for nearly three weeks on unrelated charges, including one that he beat his 79-year-old grandmother on Aug. 30, two days after the last of the bodies were found. Humphrey is being kept in a medical isolation cell with only a mattress and a blanket and is reportedly given daily doses of Lithium to control his manic depression. His grandmother says that's not fair. ``He's afraid and I'm afraid,'' Ms. Hlavaty told The Gainesville Sun. ``They have no evidence against him in those murders, yet they make no effort to be humane or decent to him.'' She said one of his legs, injured in a car accident and scheduled for surgery in December, has given him much pain because he can sit only on the floor of his cell. Ms. Hlavaty, who denies Humphrey beat her and says she was injured in a fall, said he was pressured into making wild statements after hours of grueling interrogation. Published reports have said he gave investigators specific information about crime scenes and attributed two deaths to ``John.'' Authorities say ``John'' is one of several personalities Humphrey has displayed in jail. ``If someone bullied you for hours and hours and abused you while you were wearing handcuffs, you wouldn't be able to take it anymore,'' Ms. Hlavaty said. ``You wouldn't know if uou were John, Sue or Jane. My grandson is a victim and he's vulnerable because of his mental illness.'' Brevard County Public Defender J.R. Russo played down a report that investigators had found bloodstained gloves in the Indialantic home where Humphrey lived with his grandmother and mother. ``It could have been from a fishing trip or anything else,'' Russo said. Ms. Hlavaty said the gloves belong to her and that they were stained with her blood when she fell and cut her head. In Montana, a high school senior named Rachel, who asked that her last name be withheld, told the Tampa Tribune she met Humphrey in 1985 while he was visiting an aunt and uncle. She said she didn't see him again until July 18 when he traveled more than 1,000 miles to Hamilton, Mont., to propose to her, the Tribune reported Monday. ``He really became possessed with the idea of marrying me,'' she said. The girl's mother, who spoke on condition that her name not be used, told The Associated Press the teen-ager locked herself in her room and cried last week when reports of her friendship with Humphrey surfaced. ``She's upset at the implication that something she did may have led to these deaths,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Kemp Won't Answer Rinfret Charge He's Cuomo `Lackey,' Spokeswoman Says
DOC.TEXT: Housing Secretary Jack Kemp responded to an angry blast from New York Republican gubernatorial candidate Pierre Rinfret by saying Monday that it might not be possible to attend a Rinfret fund-raiser. Kemp is a ``lackey'' for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo because the Cabinet secretary pulled out of hosting a fund-raiser, Rinfret complained late Friday night in a call to The Associated Press. Rinfret had announced earlier that Kemp had agreed to host an event. ``He has lied about me. He has misrepresented me. He has broken his word to me and while he promised us support, he pulled the rug out from under us,'' Rinfret said of Kemp. Rinfret called Kemp ``a traitor to the Republican Party, ... a lackey for Governor Cuomo, and a man who is carrying on a personal vendetta on behalf of the Conservative Party.'' Rinfret's aides have invited Kemp to appear and ``no decision has been made at this point,'' said Kemp spokeswoman Mary Brunette. ``He's got dozens of requests from candidates and already has about 60 events on his schedule between now and the election so I don't know if it will be possible to schedule something or not,'' she said. One of those events was an appearance Monday night in Lloyd Harbor, N.Y., on behalf of GOP candidates for the New York State Senate. Kemp had no public reaction to Rinfret's complaint that he is Cuomo's ``lackey,'' according to Brunette. Kemp, a former Buffalo Bills quarterback and ex-congressman from the Buffalo suburbs, was among a host of prominent Republicans who declined to challenge Cuomo. Cuomo, a Democrat, is running for a third term.
DOC.HEAD: Preston Asks for Recount; Grandmaison Continues Campaign Against Gregg
DOC.TEXT: State Senate Minority Leader Robert Preston asked for a recount Monday in New Hampshire's Democratic gubernatorial primary. Former party chairman Joe Grandmaison came out of Tuesday's primary 1,134 votes ahead, but two addition mistakes in Preston's favor and one benefiting Grandmaison cut the lead by Friday to 593 votes. Preston said he was asking the secretary of state's office for a recount ``without rancor or bitterness.'' Grandmaison said the likelihood of change is ``remote.'' The winner faces Republican Gov. Judd Gregg. Preston said he would pay for the recount and asked that it be done as quickly as possible ``because I don't want to take away from the campaign.'' Preston said he will not campaign while the recount is being made. Gregg and Grandmaison are to square off Wednesday morning at a forum in Manchester.
DOC.HEAD: Mickelson Says he Won't Use Student Discussion as a Campaign Ad
DOC.TEXT: Gov. George Mickelson said a videotaped discussion he had with Brookings High School seniors will not be used in political advertising because of objections from students and teachers. Mickelson spoke to about 100 seniors in his hometown last Wednesday at the invitation of Principal Don Kolsrud. Parts of his speech were professionally videotaped, along with a question-and-answer session that followed. Superintendent Stephen Doerr said the school administration knew Mickelson was filming the session for television, but thought the discussion took a back stage to the filming. ``I think there were times when the producer more so than the governor made it a commercial venture,'' Doerr said. Democratic governor candidate Bob Samuelson said the governor shouldn't have tried to film a commercial during school hours, regardless if students knew he was taping a political advertisement. The governor said he and his campaign staff explained their plans ahead of time to the school administration and school board, and that students were told over the intercom that he would be filming his conversation with them.

DOC.HEAD: Gubernatorial Candidate's Appearance Canceled After Liquor Raid
DOC.TEXT: State Attorney General Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr. abruptly canceled an appearance at a picnic after learning it had been raided by state liquor agents. Aides said the Democratic candidate for governor was stumping on Sunday toward a picnic at the Strossmayer Croation Center when he got word of a raid staged by Akron agents of the state Liquor Control Board. Celebrezze spokeswoman Natalie Wymer said the candidate learned about the problem from his advance staff just before the time for his appearance. ``He obviously did not think it was appropriate for him to attend an event that hadn't gotten a permit,'' Ms. Wymer said. The agents went undercover into the center, where liquor was being sold without a license, and announced they were breaking up the party. About 50 people were there, said Liquor Control Board spokeswoman Patty Haskins. Two people were charged and agents confiscated 50 cases of beer, 100 loose cans of beer and 10 bottles of liquor, Ms. Haskins said. She said the club had no license to sell alcohol, and the LCB had received tips that sales were taking place. One of those charged, 72-year-old Joseph Tisler of Campbell, said he believed the raid came about because of Celebrezze's visit. Tisler said the club has existed for 30 years. Charged with Tisler, 72, of Campbell, was his daughter Ann L. Korhan, 33, of Austintown. They are to be arraigned Sept. 27 in Girard Municipal Court.

DOC.HEAD: Ol' Blue Eyes Offers View of Fame to George Michael
DOC.TEXT: Entertainer Frank Sinatra couldn't believe what he was reading: the ``reluctant pop star'' George Michael was withdrawing from public view to reduce the strain of his celebrity status. ``Come on, George. Loosen up. Swing, man,'' Sinatra wrote in a letter to the Los Angeles Times, which was published one week after the newspaper's Calendar magazine cover story featuring a complaining Michael. ``Here's a kid who `wanted to be a pop star since I was about 7 years old.' And now that he's a smash performer and songwriter at 27, he wants to quit doing what tons of gifted youngsters all over the world would shoot Grandma for - just one crack at what he's complaining about,'' said Sinatra, who will be 75 on Dec. 12. In an interview, Michael said he was releasing his new CBS album without promotional videos or a concert tour. He was also granting only a few print interviews and planned to keep out of public view. A receptionist at CBS Records said Monday afternoon that no one was available to comment on the Sinatra letter. Sinatra, who said Michael ``should thank the good Lord every morning when he wakes up to have all that he has,'' continued with sage advice. ``Dust off those gossamer wings and fly yourself to the moon of your choice and be grateful to carry the baggage we've all had to carry since those lean nights of sleeping on buses and helping the driver unload the instruments. ``And no more of that talk about `the tragedy of fame.' The tragedy of fame is when no one shows up and you're singing to the cleaning lady in some empty joint that hasn't seen a paying customer since Saint Swithin's day. And you're nowhere near that; you're top dog on the top rung of a tall ladder called Stardom, which in Latin means thanks-o-the-fans who were there when it was lonely. ``Talent must not be wasted. Those who have it - and you obviously do or Calendar's cover article would have been about Rudy Vallee - those who have talent must hug it, embrace it, nurture it and share it lest it be taken away from you as fast as it was loaned to you. ``Trust me. I've been there.'' It was signed: Frank Sinatra.

DOC.HEAD: Forecasters: Isidore Is No More
DOC.TEXT: After a 10-day sail across the ocean, the system that once was Hurricane Isidore reached the cold waters of the north Atlantic and lost its tropical characteristics, forecasters said Monday. Isidore, which formed Sept. 7, was downgraded from a hurricane early Sunday. It continued to weaken Monday and was expected to be absorbed by a north Atlantic storm by Tuesday, said forecasters at the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. Isidore remained no threat to land, hurricane specialist Miles Lawrence said. At noon EDT, Isidore's center was near 51.5 degrees north latitude and 37.0 west longitude, or about 625 miles southeast of the southern tip of Greenland. The system was heading northeast at 25 to 30 mph with winds of 45 mph. Isidore was the ninth named storm of the 1990 Atlantic hurricane season, which ends Nov. 30. Weather systems are named after when their sustained winds reach 39 mph. Tropical storms become hurricanes when their top winds reach 74 mph.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Pulls Gun, Scares Wife's Muggers From Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Olga Suarez is cq in 8th graf; mayor's wife's maiden name was also Suarez
DOC.TEXT: A shaken Mayor Xavier Suarez recounted Monday how robbers held guns to the heads of his wife and mother-in-law, but downplayed his role in frightening the men off with a gun of his own. Police searched Monday for the two men who accosted the women just outside the mayor's home Sunday night and forced them inside while Suarez and his children were upstairs, said police spokesman David Rivero. ``My kids and I ... very quickly converged in the upstairs room, and we basically hid until I was able to come out and do my best to convince (the robbers) to leave,'' Suarez said. He said he yelled down the staircase at the men and pointed his gun. ``I was ready to use it,'' Suarez added. The two men escaped with the women's purses, some jewelry and a portable telephone, police said. The mayor, who at one point choked up with emotion while discussing the robbery, said his wife, Rita Suarez, was ``deeply affected'' and one of his four children would need counseling. He did not name the child. Mrs. Suarez and her mother, Olga Suarez, had just escorted relatives to their car outside the family's private home south of downtown at about 10:45 p.m. when the robbers ordered them inside, said another police spokesman, Robert Navarro. The robbers' yelling alerted Suarez and his children, who were upstairs. While Suarez was loading his weapon, he ordered his 12-year-old son, Francis, to call for help on the ``blue phone,'' a direct line to the police department, Navarro said. Officers arrived in minutes and surrounded the two-story pink stucco home, but the gunmen got away. Police didn't say what kind of guns the robbers had, and Suarez didn't describe his weapon. The incident wasn't the first crime at the home where Suarez and his family have lived since 1985. The house was burglarized last year while the family was on vacation. In 1987, a car containing a gun registered to the mayor was stolen from the driveway. The mayor has police protection only occasionally, and the home wasn't guarded by any officer when the gunmen arrived, said Suarez's chief of staff, Odalys Mon. Beginning Monday an officer would be at the house all the time, police said.

DOC.HEAD: US Reaction To Aquino: We Want To Stay
DOC.TEXT: The State Department responded to Philippine President Corazon Aquino's announcement Monday that she wants an orderly withdrawal of U.S. bases from her country by saying the United States wants to stay. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher declined to discuss the U.S. position in bases talks or to even confirm that the negotiations are opening on Tuesday in Manila. But Boucher repeated that the United States wants to retain its military presence in the Philippines, which includes two of America's largest foreign bases: Clark Air Base and Subic Naval Base. ``We hope that any new agreement will include provisions for a continuing defense relationship, including U.S. access to Philippine military facilities,'' Boucher said. He said the talks would ``define a new relationship with the Philippines that includes a security dimension.'' Asked if he had any specific response to Mrs. Aquino's statement, Boucher said, ``I'm afraid that's my comment on Cory Aquino's speech as well.'' U.S. officials have repeatedly said that they will give up the bases if the Philippines decides it doesn't want them. Alternative sites for various installations have been explored throughout the region. Under the current agreement, which expires in one year, the U.S. military has unlimited access to Clark, Subic and four smaller facilities, making them de facto U.S. bases although they technically belong to the Philippines. Mrs. Aquino, in a nationally televised speech, said the bases talks would redefine U.S.-Philippine relations and added that her government would work with the United States ``for arrangements regarding the orderly withdrawal of their forces from our country.'' More than 40,000 American troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents now live in the Philippines. U.S. officials tally the economic benefits to the Philippines in hundreds of millions of dollars a year and thousands of jobs. Congressman Stephen Solarz of New York said last week, after meeting with U.S. negotiating team leader Richard Armitage, that he expects the U.S. side to propose a 10-year phase out of the bases. Solarz, a Democrat, heads the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Asian and Pacific affairs. Boucher declined both last week and on Monday to discuss any position the U.S. negotiators might take in Manila.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Teachers Strike in New Orleans; City's First Walkout Since '78
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of teachers struck New Orleans public schools Monday in a contract dispute over working conditions and $400,000 worth of health benefits - the city's first teachers' strike since 1978. ``We're not striking just for money. . . . We're looking for professional respect,'' said sixth-grade teacher Katy Hall, one of a half-dozen teachers picketing Lafayette Elementary School before dawn. ``I think the public looks upon us only as professional baby sitters.'' ``Maybe one in 10 toilets work. There's no toilet paper. No teaching supplies. No ditto paper. There's always a shortage of textbooks,'' said Joseph ``Wally'' Johnson, who teaches computer science at Lafayette. Frank Fudesco, the board's chief negotiator, denied that there was any shortage of toilet tissue. Union and school board officials said they did not know how many of the 84,000 students were in class or how many of the 5,000 teachers crossed picket lines. Principals who were called for spot checks said 75 to 90 percent of their students were in. Parents of some emotionally disturbed or educationally disabled children were told that classes for their children were canceled. Otherwise, the school board said classes would continue as usual. No contract talks were scheduled. Also starting strikes Monday were two districts in Pennsylvania: Cumberland Valley in Cumberland County, with 6,457 students at 10 schools and 425 teachers, and Penn-Delco in Delaware County, with 3,000 students at six schools and 187 teachers. New Orleans union president Nat Lacour said the Orleans Parish School Board's refusal to pay $400,000 in health insurance premiums triggered the strike. The teachers scaled back their request over the weekend to $1 million in additional health benefits. The school board turned them down and stuck to the $600,000 it had offered. ``We cannot give what we do not have,'' said Fudesco. Sharon Delahoussaye, picket captain at Lusher Elementary, said premiums went up from $500 to $800 a person this year. The union wants the board to cover half the $300 difference, she said. ``The board's first proposal was for $50 a person. The second was for $100. We're asking $150 a person,'' said Delahoussaye. Lacour reinstated demands, dropped during earlier bargaining, for a $45 million package that includes 10 percent annual pay raises for the teachers plus 1,100 teachers' aides and school secretaries. Louisiana teachers get much of their pay from the state, which increased its share 7 percent this year. The state now pays $14,472 for a starting teacher with a bachelors degree and $25,737 for someone with a doctorate and 25 years experience, said W.J. Cleveland, of the fiscal office for the state Education Department. Some poor rural poarishes don't add anything to that. Cleveland estimated that the average parish supplement is $3,500. New Orleans adds $4,983 to a starting salary and $9,374 at the top of the scale, so that starting teachers get $19,455 and someone at top gets $35,111. The city is offering no raise. The board has raised teachers' salaries twice since 1983, but Lacour said the increases have been eroded by rising health insurance and retirement costs.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Supports Air Blockade, Mulls Length of Americans' Patience
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Monday endorsed expanding the Iraqi trade embargo to include air traffic as a way of increasing pressure on Saddam Hussein. He expressed concern ove whether Americans will stand united if the showdown drags on too long. ``I'm not clear in my own mind at how long this kind of support holds up,'' Bush said. Still, he said the country is ``magnificently united'' at this point and recalled that the nation ``stayed fairly well together'' during World War II. Bush, at a news conference, also said that in retrospect he regrets the U.S. policy of patient diplomacy toward Iraq before it invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. At the time, the administration was resisting congressional attempts to impose sanctions against Iraq. ``If everybody had the benefit of total hindsight, why, you'd go back and say, `This doesn't make much sense,''' Bush said of the policy he pursued. ``I'm not sure, having said that, that that would have changed Saddam Hussein's intention to take over Kuwait.'' Bush met with regional reporters after the firing of Gen. Mike Dugan by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney as Air Force chief of staff for discussing contingency plans for the bombing of Iraq and the targeting of Saddam personally. Bush endorsed the firing but refused to comment on the subject further. The president offered clear support for stiffening the U.N. sanctions against Iraq by imposing an embargo on air traffic, in addition to the existing naval blockade. If approved, it would be the first time the U.N. had ever authorized an air blockade. ``What we want to do is tighten up the United Nations sanctions so nothing is going in,'' Bush said. ``And that's hard to do in terms of overflights, and some countries that seem to be more willing than others to avoid the sanctions.'' Nevertheless, he said, ``I would be prepared to work with anybody to tie that additional knot in the sanctions.'' Bush offered no predictions about how long American troops will be stationed in the Persian Gulf. More than 150,000 U.S. forces already have been deployed and the buildup shows no sign of ending. ``I want those soldiers out as soon as possible,'' he said. ``I want them all out - all out, period. And yet, I can't say when that will be.'' On Sunday, a taped address from Bush was broadcast in Iraq, warning the Iraqi people they were ``on the brink of war'' because of the invasion of Kuwait. Bush said the effort was worthwhile, even if only two Iraqis heard it. If nothing else, Bush said laughingly, ``It got a good exercise for the demonstrators who had been notified to demonstrate (against the United States) before they even heard what I had to say, so it kept them hustling around, jumping up and down, screaming about the United States.'' Bush was asked who would give the orders to U.S. forces to shoot if fighting breaks out. The question apparently was in reference to directions earlier this month to American fighter pilots to wait for a go-ahead from Saudi commanders before firing at Iraqi jets. ``I have no hesitancy at all to say to the parents of the kids over there ... should something happen that required combat, the command structure will function very, very smoothly,'' Bush said. ``We're not going to have to stand around waiting for someone else to decide if there is some provocation, either,'' he said. Asked how the nation would react to thousands of American casualties, Bush replied, ``I don't know, but I am inclined to feel that we are off to a very good start,'' Bush said. ``I'm old enough to remember a clearcut case, different circumstances, different times, World War II,'' he said. ``There was a lot of sorrow, there was a lot of regret, everyone identified with the families who lost loved ones. But the country stayed fairly well together.'' Bush defended his decision not to tap into the huge strategic petroleum reserve for fuel to offset any shortages due to the embargo and help keep gas prices low. ``It is my judgment that there isn't such a shortage at this time,'' the president said. He said gas prices were being driven not by shortages but by speculation about what will happen. The president said the Persian Gulf crisis has not prompted him to reconsider his decision to ban new offshore oil drilling in California. However, he said he was determined ``to more vigorously go forward with incentives for domestic drilling'' - including in Alaska. ``The bottom line,'' he said: ``It's going to have to be conservation; it's going to have to be alternative sources; it's going to have to be more hydrocarbon drilling.'' He said the Mideast crisis should lay rest to talk about a ``peace dividend'' in the defense budget. ``I've always thought that was a phantom. How can you declare a dividend when you're operating at a loss?'' he asked. He also said Iran has provided indirect assurances that it wants to see the sanctions against Iraq work, despite deep differences that remain between the U.S. and Iran. ``I'm not going to buy into the argument that they've (Iran) made some secret deal to violate the sanctions,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: US, Soviets Seek Role in Promoting Angola Peace
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union offered to send technical experts to peace talks between Angola's leftist government and U.S.-backed rebels, the State Department said Monday. U.S. officials said the proposed assistance would be limited to the mechanics of enforcing a cease-fire once negotiators for the government and the rebels agree to take that step. The proposal represents another marked departure for the two superpowers from their one-time bitter rivalry over Angola. The Soviets have contributed military aid to the Angolan government over the years while the United States has been arming the UNITA rebels since 1986. Both are continuing to provide arms to their respective clients but also seem eager to promote a settlement. The Angola war has raged since 1976. Washington and Moscow ``have offered to provide experts at the technical level for the next round of talks between UNITA and the Luanda authorities, to be held under Portuguese auspices, and we continue to urge both sides to move forward on the peace process,'' State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said. The last round of talks between the two sides, held in Portugal, broke down. Portuguese officials have been suggesting that a more active U.S. and Soviet role might improve the chances for a peaceful settlement. One example of the deep mistrust which has built up over the years has been Angola's refusal to allow humanitarian food shipments to be delivered to hungry Angolans in the southern part of the country. Some are in UNITA-held territory while others are in areas under government control. Angolan officials are worried that the United States might try to slip weapons to its UNITA allies, using the food shipments as a cover. The director of the U.S. Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance, Andrew Natsios, visited Angola last week to try to work out an agreement but reportedly made no progress. U.S. officials believe tens of thousands of Angolans face starvation unless food deliveries begin soon. U.S. officials said food deliveries would be in the hands of the International Committee for the Red Cross. They reject any suggestion that food shipments would be used as a means of arming the rebels. Mistrust also has been evident in the peace talks between the two countries. UNITA wants recognition as a political entity before a cease fire but Angola wants the sequence reversed. Each side blamed the other for the breakdown of the Lisbon talks.

DOC.HEAD: History Professor Wins Opposition Candidacy for Presidency
DOC.TEXT: The opposition Ivorian Popular Front on Monday chose a history professor as its presidential candidate in this West African nation's first multiparty elections in 30 years. Laurent Gbagbo, 45, has been the chief rival of President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, since the nation won independence from France in 1960. The university professor won the candidacy with 98 percent of votes at his party's first congress, which began Sunday and ended early Monday, a party statement said. He is the first candidate to declare for October's balloting, the first multiparty vote since Houphouet-Boigny became president four decades ago and named his party the sole legal political organization in Ivory Coast. Twenty-five mostly left-leaning organizations have sprung up since the Western-oriented Ivorian leader was forced to legalize other political movements on April 30. That move came after unprecedented unrest and riots demanding democracy and an end to the corruption that has helped impoverish this once-wealthy state. Authorities, however, often have refused to allow government opponents to hold rallies. Security forces twice this month used tear gas and truncheons to break up peaceful marches by opposition parties. Ivory Coast's problems began with tumbling world prices for cocoa and coffee, its main exports. The government has been unable to pay its foreign debt for two years, despite tax rates among the highest in the world. Attempts to raise taxes even higher and cut the salaries of government workers earlier this year fueled the worst unrest since independence, forcing Houphouet-Boigny to back down on some austerity measures.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Discuss Ways To Cut Medicaid Drug Costs
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers looking for ways to stretch the Medicaid dollar further considered proposals designed to cut spiraling growth in the price of prescription drugs. Over the past decade, prescription drug prices have risen 152 percent while consumer prices have gone up 58 percent, Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., sponsor of the proposals, told a Senate Finance health subcommittee Monday. These ``unyielding and unfair'' prices have forced states to cut back on Medicaid benefits, reimbursement rates for physicians and the number of poor Americans who can participate in the program, he said. ``In essence, the drug manufacturers are holding our states hostage to their price increases,'' Pryor testified. Pryor's legislation would require drug companies to give the Medicaid program the same discounts it gives other volume buyers, like the Department of Veterans Affairs, the Defense Department, hospitals and HMOs (Health Management Organizations). They get discounts of as much as 60 percent. Medicaid drug costs for the current fiscal year are expected to be $4.4 billion. Two years ago, the program paid $3.3 billion for prescription drugs. Medicaid drug reimbursement proposals have been raised in the current budget talks as a way to cut spending to meet Gramm-Rudman targets. Gerald Mossinghoff, president of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, said Pryor's legislation is unnecessary. Currently, 42 states representing more than 90 percent of the Medicaid drug market are negotiating with drug companies for discounts and rebates, he said. The proposals also could be harmful to Medicaid patients, he said. ``Drug therapy in Medicaid would be chosen by low-bid, not by the medical judgment of the patient's physician,'' he said in testimony submitted to the panel. ``The bill would thus result in second-class medical care for Medicaid recipients.'' He also said the legislation amounted to price controls, an idea he called ``inimical to this country's free-market economy.'' Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., said he was troubled by price controls as well as the possibility that restraints on the drug industry would be a disincentive to continued research and development of new drugs. ``We should not treat that lightly,'' Bradley said. Gail Wilensky, head of the federal agency that administers Medicaid, also cautioned that ``we must use care to protect the thriving (research and development) associated with prescription drugs. And we must be concerned for what is one of our most internationally cometitive industries.''

DOC.HEAD: Recall Trucks to Fix Shift Levers, Consumer Group Demands
DOC.TEXT: A consumer group on Monday demanded that Ford Motor Co. recall 240,000 Ranger pickup trucks and Bronco II utility vehicles to fix gear shift levers that in some cases have broken off in the driver's hand. Ford's offer of free repair of any broken shift lever if the truck is still under warranty is ``woefully inadequate,'' said Samuel Cole, vehicle safety staffer for the Center for Auto Safety. ``Ford has designed a defect into these vehicles for which it must now take proper action and conduct a recall,'' Cole said. ``With such a high failure rate, it will only be a matter of time before we begin seeing accidents attributed to the gear shift defect.'' Ford spokeswoman Joy Stinson said the company did not consider the problem a safety hazard. Even if the lever breaks, the vehicle remains in gear and the driver is able to pull off the road without losing control, she said. ``Whatever gear it breaks in, it's driveable,'' she said. ``For that reason ... a safety recall is not warranted.'' The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration launched an investigation of the gear lever problem last June. Ford provided the agency with a September 1988 internal report that disclosed 6,473 gear shift lever failures on 1986 and 1987 Ranger pickups with manual transmissions made by Mazda. That translates into a failure rate of one in every 37 vehicles, the Center for Auto Safety said. The Bronco II has the same transmission as the Ranger, Ms. Stinson said. Ford began using an improved lever assembly with 1988 models. The company informed the government July 16 it would provide an ``extended warranty service program'' in which owners would receive free repairs. But the offer covered only trucks whose levers had actually broken and that were still covered by the company's six-year, 60,000-mile warranty. The Center for Auto Safety, in a letter to the government agency, said the company should do more. An inability to shift gears can result in loss of vehicle control and endanger lives, it said. ``We believe a defect is a defect and ... Ford ought to own up to it and recall the vehicles,'' Cole said. The center, a private consumer advocacy organization founded by Ralph Nader, urged the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to order a recall of the Ford trucks and investigate gear lever failures on Mazda vehicles using the same transmission.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Opposition Groups Claims 86 Killed in Rioting
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's Communist Party, part of the Iraqi opposition based in Syria, said Monday that 58 people had been killed in riots against the Baghdad government as of Sept. 7. The party said the rioters were shouting in demand for bread and that violent measures taken by authorities to quell the disturbances had caused the deaths. A party statement said 28 people had been killed in similar riots in Bassora, where demonstrators demanded more bread and also called for the Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, which Iraq invaded on Aug. 2. Food has been reported in short supply in Iraq and occupied Kuwait since the invasion. There was no way to immediately confirm the report, which was received in Nicosia, Cyprus.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Names 250th Point Of Light
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's galaxy of a ``thousand points of light'' is now a quarter full. Bush named his 250th daily point of light on Monday: Linda Warsaw, a 17-year-old San Bernardino, Calif., girl who founded ``Kids Against Crime.'' Normally the honorees just get a letter signed by the president, but Ms. Warsaw also got a phone call from the president from the Oval Office. She founded ``Kids Against Crime'' in 1985 when she was 12 to teach children how to protect themselves. She got the idea while volunteering with the Victim Witness Assistance Program in the San Bernardino County district attorney's office, the White House said. Teenage volunteers operate a hot line for youths to call when they need advice and support. Bush first spoke of the thousand points of light in his acceptance speech at the 1988 Republican convention, using it as a metaphor for all the things Americans do, individually and in groups, to help fellow citizens. Last year he began naming daily points of light six days a week to encourage all Americans to perform community service. He plans eventually to name 1,000.

DOC.HEAD: House Passes Bill To Bolster Deposit Insurance Fund
DOC.TEXT: A bill letting regulators tap banks and savings institutions to shore up the dwindling government deposit insurance funds passed the House on Monday. By a voice vote, the House favored removing the legal ceiling on insurance premiums levied by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. The Senate is scheduled to consider the measure later this month. Congressional leaders, the Bush administration and the FDIC are supporting passage before Congress adjourns early next month. FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman said the agency did not plan to use the new power immediately but wanted it to meet any unforeseen emergency. ``We don't see at this time we are going to change the premiums again. However, it's an uncertain world and we thought we'd be better equipped to handle things if we had the flexibility,'' he said in a telephone interview. The House action comes a week after the General Accounting Office, Congress' auditing agency, warned that bank failures produced by a recession could wipe out the fund protecting bank deposits, requiring a taxpayer bailout. The fund protecting savings and loans has already been bankrupted. As part of negotiations on the 1991 budget, Congress and the administration are considering financing a second installment of the rescue begun last year. The insurance premium bill is aimed at avoiding a similar bailout for banks. According to its sponsor, Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the House Banking Committee, it gives the FDIC discretion to raise insurance premiums to whatever level it considers appropriate. Seidman has warned that the bank fund is under ``considerable stress'' and will probably experience its third consecutive loss this year as bank failures remain near a post-Depression record. That would bring fund reseves down to near $11 billion, or between 50 cents and 60 cents for every $100 of insured deposits. That is less than half the $1.25 reserve ratio considered safe. ``The FDIC insurance fund is teetering on the brink of insolvency,'' warned Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., chairman of the House Banking financial institutions subcommittee. In an attempt to bolster the fund, the FDIC later this month is expected to raise its 1991 bank premium from 12 cents per $100 of deposits to 19.5 cents. It is the biggest increase allowed under current law. Gonzalez' bill would scrap the 7.5 cent limit on annual increases and the 32.5 upper ceiling on the premium. It would also remove provisions restricting the agency to raising the premium only once a year, requiring instead that the FDIC give 60 days notice of increases as needed. Rep. Chalmers Wylie of Ohio, the senior Republican on the banking committee, said premiums may not have to be raised more than planned, but said it would be irresponsible to taxpayers for Congress not to give the FDIC power to take swift action. ``We are practicing an ounce of prevention before a pound of cure is needed,'' he said. Kenneth Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association of America, said industry groups were not lobbying against Gonzalez' bill. But he said bankers worried that the fast-track procedure Congress is using to adopt the measure is creating a false impression that there is an emergency in the banking system. With the premium increase already planned, the FDIC will have an additional $6 billion next year to pay for bank failures, he said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Hopes International Lending Agencies Will Aid Mideast Nations
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said Monday it would look to international lending agencies to help alleviate Mideast nations' economic hardships stemming from the Persian Gulf crisis. Treasury Deputy Secretary David Mulford said the question of financial assistance to support the trade embargo against Iraq would be a primary topic at meetings which begin in Washington over the weekend of the 151-nation International Monetary Fund and its sister organization, the World Bank. Mulford earlier this month accompanied Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady on a world trip to pass the hat among the allies for financial aid to support the trade embargo and to help defray the $1 billion-a-month costs of the U.S. military buildup. Japan, West Germany, Saudi Arabia and the exiled government of Kuwait have made significant contributions to the $28 billion pool of money the administration is trying to gather. Mulford did not provide any specifics about what amounts of money the administration would be seeking from the international lending agencies. But he said there were numerous needs that had to be addressed for the so-called front-line states of Egypt, Jordan and Turkey. He said financial assistance was needed to cushion the shock from the loss of export markets because of the trade embargo, higher oil prices and a tide of refugees from Iraq and Kuwait. ``There is a very real crisis situation with immediate problems that need to be addressed,'' Mulford told reporters during a briefing. Mulford said Egypt, Turkey and Jordan needed an emergency transfusion of money without strings attached. The administration previously has talked of the need for $3.5 billion for those countries before the end of the year with another $7 billion needed next year. In addition to aid to the front-line states, the IMF and World Bank were expected to address providing assistance to other poor nations hurt by such things as the rise in oil prices. Mulford said the issue of economic assistance would be taken up by finance ministers and central bankers of the world's seven richest countries when they meet Saturday in advance of the IMF and World Bank meetings. The other countries - Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada - have been at the top of the list of nations to participate in Bush's burden-sharing campaign among allies. In addition to the Persian Gulf, the finance meetings will address the problem of economic difficulties facing the Soviet Union. For the first time in history, the Soviets will be attending the annual meeting of the IMF and World Bank as ``special invitees,'' a designation that will allow them to attend the full sessions of the two organizations but not the policy-making meetings of the IMF Interim Committee and the joint IMF-World Bank Development Committee. The Soviet Union has expressed an interest in joining the World Bank and the IMF and has been appealing for direct aid from the West to prop up the faltering Soviet economy. The administration has opposed direct aid until the Soviets make bigger strides in developing a free-market economy and Mulford said that position had not changed.

DOC.HEAD: Middle East Crisis, Global Warming Give Nuclear Energy a Boost
DOC.TEXT: Higher oil prices since the Persian Gulf crisis and global warming could give nuclear energy a boost, according to delgates to an international conference on the atomic energy. Also at the opening session of the five-day International Atomic Energy Agency conference, delegates chose a Kuwaiti as one of the meeting's vice presidents, in essence rejecting Iraq's claim over the oil-wealthy emirate. Abdul Hamid Abdullah al-Hawadih was chosen to represent the Middle East. His nomination was endorsed by all delegations but Iraq's, which argued Kuwait ceased to exist following Baghdad's Aug. 2 invasion and annexation of the emirate. The International Atomic Energy Agency, the U.N. group hosting the conference, suspended cooperation with Iraq in the wake of its attack on Kuwait. The conference is being attended by more than 300 delegates from most of the agency's 113 member-nations. During the opening session at Vienna's Austria Cente, delegates and officials suggested the gulf crisis and global warming could give atomic energy a new lease on life, if public confidence can be restored. Agency Director General Hans Blix told delegates the crisis had reminded the world ``once again of the need to diversify energy sources.'' Outgoing Conference President Kunmo Chung of South Korea said: ``Nuclear power is being taken out of the closet like an old but usable suit.'' In addition to rising oil prices, Blix said fears of global warming - caused by generating energy from fossil fuels such as coal, oil and gas - has turned many countries to nuclear power. Currently, 17 percent of the world's electricity needs are met by nuclear power. To match that output, he said, fossil fuel power stations would have to churn an extra 1.8 billion tons of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. Partly because of nuclear power, reliance on oil to generate electricity in industrialized nations fell from 24 percent in 1974 to 9 percent in 1986, Blix said. U.S. Deputy Energy Secretary W. Henson Moore told the conference that prospects for restoring the nuclear option worldwide are ``good, if we can restore public confidence in the operational safety of nuclear facilities.'' However, he acknowledged that was unlikely in the near future. The United States, which runs one-quarter of the world's nuclear stations, will not increase nuclear electricity production over the next decade, he said. ``Nuclear power is not growing in the United States for a very basic reason: many people are afraid ... of accidents like Chernobyl,'' he said. The 1986 Chernobyl nuclear disaster, which spread radioactive waste across Europe, focused international attention on the safety of Soviet-built East European reactors. Thirty-one people died in the accident, and some reports say hundreds more who worked to clean up the site have died in the ensuing four years. According to Blix, former Communist governments across Eastern Europe expanded nuclear programs ``without much public discussion.'' But he said the advent of democracy in the East has now also put nuclear power there under just as much scrutiny and criticism as in the West. The Soviet Union and the United States were expected to sign an agreement Tuesday on nuclear waste disposal. The Soviets were to submit plans for a nuclear research center on the effects of radioactive contamination at Chernobyl, said spokesman Hans Friedrich Meyer.

DOC.HEAD: Jordan Shuts Down Last of Infamous Ruweishid Camps
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jordan's government on Monday shut the last of three makeshift refugee camps and moved the remaining residents into two clean, efficient tent villages. Flaps on the empty tents at Shaalan II snapped in the hot desert wind, and garbage blew across the scorpion-infested sand near Ruweishid along the Iraqi border. Hans Everts, a coordinator with the French humanitarian group Medicins Sans Frontieres, looked relaxed as he sipped a soda after his first good night's sleep since the flood of refugees began following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``We don't expect another big influx,'' he said about two hours after the official midday closing of the camp. ``There will continue to be another 2,000 or so people crossing each day for the foreseeable future. But Jordan has it all magnificently organized. It's time for us to go home.'' Shaalan I, which once contained about 45,000 people fleeing Kuwait and Iraq, closed on Thursday. Mercy Camp tents emptied Sunday. The government has said it will set up a small border receiving station for new refugees. The fortunate refugees from the border camps headed directly for planes or ferries home. About 18,000 mostly Asian refugees transferred to Azraq I and II, a sweep of thousands of olive drab or white tents on the desert steppes near a ancient fort where T.E. Lawrence planned the Arab revolt against the Ottomans. The tents stand in precise rows, divided into sectors by national groups, each served by a water line. The desperation in the makeshift border camps, which only two weeks ago led to fights over water and food, has given way to camaraderie at Azraq, 120 miles to the west. Cooler weather has calmed flaring tempers as well. Temperatures rose to 120 degrees at Shaalan in August, but range from 90 during the day to about 60 at night at Azraq. Monday morning at Azraq II, Sri Lankans exchanged greetings with Filipinos, and a Bangladeshi helped an Indian woman carry a plastic bucket of water. In the cool morning wind, people strolled the sandy hills near the camp wrapped in blankets. In tent no. 92, Ernesto Callejo thanked God he didn't panic and flee Kuwait in the first wave. After Iraqi troops stormed into Kuwait City on Aug. 2, Callejo gathered the other 250 Fillipino members of the local Church of Christ and began calmly planning to leave. ``We didn't want to leave anybody behind,'' he said, surrounded by a dozen of his compatriots and friends. For three weeks, the group gathered drums to fill with water, collected food and avoided occupation troops, finally renting a truck for the drive to Baghdad. If they had left earlier, they might have spent weeks at the border camps. Instead, they went directly from Baghdad to Azraq. Callejo said that during their three-day stay in Baghdad, they had money but still had trouble finding anything to eat. ``Now our money is gone but they are feeding us. God and the Jordanian government provide,'' he said. Styrofoam cartons filled with apples, cucumbers, grapes and tomatoes were stacked in the shade of a storage tent next to a camp clinic. A half-dozen doctors with the Jordanian Red Crescent supervised nurses from the Order of the Sacred Heart, bustling about in snow-white habits and Nike sneakers. Khaled Abu-Halimeh, medical director at the camp, said 500 Sri Lankans would be leaving the camp Monday along with Bangladeshis and Indians. But 3,000 more refugees arrived Monday from Iraq and Kuwait. Dozens of evacuation flights leave daily from Amman. By official count Sunday, 14,850 people arrived Saturday in Jordan while 19,768 departed. For Priscilla Ponsece, a member of Collejo's group, things weren't moving fast enough. ``We pray every day to go home,'' she said. ``And this morning we made a Philippine flag and raised it over our tent while we sang the national anthem. ``This camp is very nice, but we're not home yet,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Claims Providing Clear Sense Of Direction In Education
DOC.TEXT: President Bush claimed credit Monday for helping give Americans for the first time ``a clear sense of direction'' about the nation's schools. He made the boast at a ceremony on the White House lawn honoring 221 public and private elementary schools that won the Department of Education's excellence awards. He also used the occasion to salute Polly Williams, a Wisconsin state representative from Milwaukee who has championed educational choice for inner-city youths. Bush called the Democratic lawmaker ``a courageous leader who brought choice to Milwaukee'' and asked her to take a bow. She sponsored a plan against opposition from local public educators and civil rights leaders that is providing 1,000 Milwaukee students with vouchers to help pay tuition at private schools. Bush called educational choice ``one of the most important reforms sweeping our great country.'' Bush told the more than 500 educators at the ceremony that, ``For the first time, Americans now have a clear sense of direction toward national education.'' He said his educational summit with the nation's governors in Charlottesville, Va., last September had helped produce that consensus. Four governors - Carroll Campbell Jr. of South Carolina, Robert Casey of Pennsylvania, Rudy Perpich of Minnesota and William Schaefer of Maryland - also attended the event. Bush recited the goals for the schools that he and the governors have endorsed, including making American youth tops in the world in math and science and raising the high school graduation rate to 90 percent by the year 2000.

DOC.HEAD: Chilly Weather Moves With Hint Of Frost In Northast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to update with snow in upstate New York, picking up at the 3rd graf previous, ``Overnight.''
DOC.TEXT: Cool weather asserted itself over much of the nation Monday, with midday snow flurries in upstate New York, record lows in Michigan, and frost advisories extending into the central Appalachians. Afternoon temperatures were generally only in the 50s and 60s from the northern and central high Plains to the middle and northern Atlantic Coast. Readings also were in the 60s in the Northwest. In the Finger Lakes wine country of upstate New York, snow flurries were reported between around midday at Naples, about 40 miles south of Rochester. ``There was no accumulation. Too warm on the ground,'' said meteorologist Eric Schwibs of the National Weather Service in Rochester. He said the area's altitude of about 2,000 feet combined with 40-degree temperatures to make it cold enough for snow. The brief flurries even caught forecasters off guard. ``It's still summer - technically,'' Schwibs said. Overnight temperatures dipped into the 30s across parts of the upper Mississippi Valley, the Great Lakes region and northern New England, with freezing temperatures reported in the upper Great Lakes region. Sault Ste. Marie, Mich., on Lake Superior, was the cold spot in the Lower 48 states Monday morning with a record low of 27, the coldest reading on record for so early in the season there. Elsewhere in Michigan, Muskegon tied its record low of 36. A freeze warning was posted overnight into Tuesday morning for extreme western Maryland and the northern mountains of western Pennsylvania. Frost warnings issued for the rest of western Maryland and the southern and central mountains of northwestern Pennsylvania. Frost and freeze warnings were issued for Vermont and for parts of eastern New York state north of the Mohawk Valley. Frost advisories were issued for extreme western Virginia, much of western New York state and for much of the mountains of West Virginia. In the West, Ely, Nev., reported a low of 35 and Truckee, Calif., reported a low of 31. Temperatures in the 90s were primarily confined to Florida and the rest of the Gulf Coast, and to the desert Southwest. Showers and a few thunderstorms were scattered from Arkansas to the central high Plains. Showers and thunderstorms also were scattered over the western Gulf Coast and southern and central Florida. A few showers dotted the Northeast. The heaviest rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT was 0.78 of an inch at Dyess Air Force Base at Abilene, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: UMW Convention Begins with AFL-CIO Leader's Address
DOC.TEXT: Health insurance and the right to strike without jeopardizing jobs are basic privileges worth fighting for, AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland said Monday at the United Mine Workers union convention. The AFL-CIO will push for a bill before Congress that would bar employers from permanently replacing striking workers, Kirkland said as the UMW began its 100th anniversary convention. ``The right to strike without losing your job - that's a basic right recognized in all but the most backward or repressive nations,'' he told the coal miners' delegates. ``We enter the 1990s a stronger and, I believe, wiser and more determined labor movement after enduring the frustrations of the 1980s - a decade of excess, avarice and illusions in which the rich got richer while multitudes struggled to hold on to the very bottom rung of the social ladder,'' Kirkland said. Kirkland said the UMW's 10-month strike against The Pittston Co. at mines and coal processing plants in West Virginia, Virginia and Kentucky illustrates the power of a unified labor movement. The UMW rejoined the AFL-CIO last year, four decades after withdrawing, and the two groups worked together on the Pittston strike. ``Your struggle and your victory brought the entire labor movement together, and for that the whole labor movement owes you a debt of gratitude,'' Kirkland told the miners. The union declared victory in the bitter Pittston strike, but it was a costly win. A financial disclosure form shows the union's net worth fell by $45 million in 1989, down to $126 million. The UMW is struggling to overturn $52 million in fines levied by a Virginia judge because of the strike. The union also faces more than $1 billion in lawsuits filed by companies idled by a five-week wildcat strike that began in sympathy with the Pittston strikers. Kirkland also called health care a basic right but said ``we know that the collective bargaining process alone cannot solve the colossal health care crisis that is bankrupting workers and denying basic medical coverage to nearly one-third of our fellow Americans.'' ``Health care is a chief issue in nearly every contract negotiation, and now it's the key factor for nearly four-fifths of all striking workers,'' he said. Also Monday, UMW President Richard Trumka blamed the Persian Gulf crisis on the lack of a federal energy policy, which he said holds the United States hostage to an ``oil-soaked Middle East dictator.'' ``The only reason that characters like Saddam Hussein have any power at all is because of the oil they have - oil we could have replaced years ago with coal mined in the United States and Canada,'' Trumka said, referring to the Iraqi president. The celebration of the once-powerful union's centennial is dogged by financial and legal concerns. During the nine-day meeting, delegates will be asked to give the International Executive Board, the UMW's governing body, authority to close or merge the 21 districts to help the union save money. Several of the largely autonomous districts are insolvent because of layoffs. They also will decide whether to allow the governing body use of interest earnings from the $60 million strike fund to pay legal expenses and other costs associated with strikes. Currently, the fund can be used only to pay benefits to strikers. And the delegates will be asked to approve changes UMW leaders say they need to deal with multinational corporations in the world coal market.

DOC.HEAD: For the Saudis, a Lesson in Media Relations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 9 `The Saudis' to CORRECT to `alone' sted along. Picks up 10th pvs, `But they...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Saudi prince stopped himself as soon as he realized his lunch guest was taking notes. ``Can we do this, how do you say, off the record, or on background?'' the prince asked. ``I do not want to be quoted by name.'' The prince then launched into a series of questions about reporting ground rules, ultimately deciding his conversation was on background - he could not be identified by name but agreed to be cited as a Saudi prince or senior Saudi official. By the time lunch was over, the prince had approached several other reporters, beginning each conversation with the greeting: ``Let us talk on background.'' As his guests left, the prince boasted to one: ``I am a quick learner, don't you think?'' Indeed, many Saudi officials, in the government and military, have proved fast learners in media relations, although they have not always satisfied the more than 500 journalists who have visited Saudi Arabia in the past six weeks to cover the Persian Gulf crisis. ``We wanted to please everybody and we are trying to please everybody,'' a Saudi diplomatic official said recently. ``We are not perfect but I think we should get appreciation, not complaints.'' The most frequent complaints are that the Saudis are slow to respond to requests. Saudis traditionally are not in as much of a rush as Americans and other Westerners. ``We are dealing with two cultures here and you have to understand that,'' the Saudi official said. ``We have nothing against you.'' The Saudis also are highly sensitive to unapproved photography and often insist that reporters accustomed to working alone travel with a government escort. But they have improved their handling of media affairs. A vast public affairs office has been established alongside the U.S. military's information bureau. Taking tips from the military, the Saudis now have a number of regular trips they organize fo reporters, including one to see Saudi and other Arab troops near the Kuwaiti border. They are showing signs of trying to respond to requests more rapidly. The latest example of this came late Saturday night, when word surfaced that Iraqi troops had opened the Kuwaiti border with Saudi Arabia and were letting Kuwaitis leave their occupied homeland. Reporters wanted to go to the border right away, but Saudi officials refused to provide escorts until a government-sponsored trip the following morning. After several objections were raised, the Saudis called in a bus and headed north to the border, reporters in tow, at 2:40 a.m. As they get used to their new role, the Saudis also are borrowing some tricks from U.S. politicians. Saudi officials rarely speak for the record on any substantive matter. When asked sensitive questions, few Saudis will give direct answers, preferring instead to talk off the record or in sweeping generalities, not unlike many policy-makers in Washington. The current media crush in Saudi Arabia at times appears to pose difficult conflicts for the Saudis, who have shown an eagerness to reach out to the Western world through its media but remain fearful of offending powerful conservative elements of the society. A clear example of this scenario came during the discussion over whether to stage an immediate trip to the border area. A half-dozen Saudi officials publicly preached the same official line: that there was no abnormal activity at the border. But several privately told reporters there was indeed a rush of Kuwaitis at the border, and they were influential in arranging the quick trip to the border. One official pulled aside an AP reporter just before the reporter headed to the border in a private car. ``We are being told the official line is what you get, to keep you guys from rushing up there,'' the official said. ``But about 1,000 have crossed and more are expected. It's busy up there. But please don't say how you found that out. I would be in big trouble.''

DOC.BYLINE: RTC Cancels Satellite Auction for Million-Dollar S&L Properties. ^By DAVE SKIDMORE
DOC.TEXT: Federal savings and loan bailout officials said Monday they were canceling the much-promoted international satellite auction of million-dollar properties inherited from bankrupt savings and loans. L. William Seidman, chairman of the Resolution Trust Corp., said the auction was canceled after the Auction Company of America, which the agency had hired, did not contribute to a joint fund promoting the event. ``The group we contracted with couldn't fulfill their end of the deal,'' Seidman said in a telephone interview. Jim Gall, chairman of the Miami-based Auction Company of America, disputed Seidman and accused the bailout agency of bungling the auction. He said his firm has spent nearly $2 million over four months to prepare for the event, about what it was obligated to spend. The auction was to be held Nov. 15 in Dallas, Texas, with satellite hookups to bidders in nine other U.S. cities as well as Tokyo and London. The RTC had hoped to sell 71 properties valued at $300 million. The auction was a centerpiece for what the agency had billed as its ``great fall inventory clearance sale'' aimed at drastically slimming its ballooning inventory of S&L assets. ``We hope to start over. ... It's going to slow us up a little but, but I don't think it's a major blow,'' Seidman said. Gall faulted the RTC for failing to set minimum prices for the properties and for withdrawing three properties from the auction list and selling them using other methods. Gall said potential buyers must have some assurance the properties will remain on the auction list or they will be unwilling to spend thousands of dollars on the environmental, engineering and appraisal reports needed to offer an intelligent bid. ``We've lost investor after investor,'' Gall said in a telephone interview. He said a low or no minimum auction price also is needed to stimulate interest in an auction by holding out the prospect for a bargain, he said. ``To this day, the agency hasn't put out reserve prices,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Meets with Czech Leader Havel
DOC.TEXT: Britain's Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and President Vaclav Havel agreed Monday on the need for tougher measures against Iraq, and Havel indicated Czechoslovakia may expel Iraqi diplomats. Mrs. Thatcher, making the first visit by a British leader to Czechoslovakia since World War II, also said the European Community should extend membership to the new democracies of Eastern Europe once they implement economic reforms. But she was adamant that Britain would give no large-scale financial aid, and that major investment was unlikely in Czechslovakia until Prague has established a private enterprise economy. The visit has been billed by British and Czechoslovak officials as ending decades of icy relations between Prague and London after Czechoslovakia's peaceful revolution ousted ruling Communists in November. Mrs. Thatcher and Havel addressed a joint news conference at Prague Castle after 2{ hours of talks. She said the expulsion by the European Community of Iraqi military attaches Monday reflected shared anger at Iraq's invasion last week of official residences or compounds of France and three other countries. ``We naturally wished to act together over the outrage by Iraqi troops,'' said Mrs. Thatcher, whose government expelled 31 Iraqi embassy personnel and students. Asked if Czechoslovakia planned to join the West European action against Iraqi diplomats, Havel said: ``It does not depend only on me, but it seems the situation is evolving in that direction.'' ``The only difference between England and Czechoslovakia is that we can't send our navy ... because we haven't got one,'' said Havel. ``But we are looking at a number of other possibilities on how to face this evil, which is embodied by the aggressive regime of President Hussein.'' He referred to Iraq's President Saddam Hussein, whose troops overran Kuwait on Aug. 2 and subsequently annexed the oil-wealthy emirate. Havel said he had no major differences with Mrs. Thatcher over her policy of restricting aid now largely to sending advisors to help along economic restructuring. ``If you are going to get investment in, we have got to be certain the old bureaucracy - industry run by government - has gone,'' Mrs. Thatcher said in an interview published Monday in a Prague newspaper, Lidove Noviny. Mrs. Thatcher, who arrived Sunday with her husband, Denis, at the start of the three-nation European tour that will also take her to Hungary and Switzerland, was greeted at the ornate Hradcany Castle by a guard of honor. Havel - playwright and one-time dissident - and the British Conservative Party leader stood side by side in the autumn sunshine as a military band played the national anthems and a jaunty welcoming march. Earlier, Mrs. Thatcher warned Czechs and Slovaks not to allow ethnic differences mar the democracy they have won after decades of Communist rule. ``It would be a great tragedy if people merely used freedom to emphasize differences,'' a British official quoted Mrs. Thatcher as telling leaders of the Czech republic. The new federal government and the country's Czech and Slovak republics are trying to draw up new constitutions that will satisfy calls for less centralized power. Before meeting Havel, Mrs. Thatcher, swept through this historic capital in an armored-plated Jaguar to visit the city's Jewish cemetery and a museum commemorating the victims of Nazi concentration camps in World War II. She is to address the Czechoslovak Parliament Tuesday before flying to Bratislava in the Slovak republic.

DOC.HEAD: Angola Rejects U.S. and Soviet Observers At Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: Angola's Marxist government does not want United States or Soviet observers at the next round of peace talks with UNITA rebels, the official Angolan news agency said Monday. The Portuguese government, acting as unofficial mediator in the conflict, had asked Moscow and Washington to send observers to the talks, slated for Sept. 24 in Portugal. The move was to pressure the Angolan foes into a compromise to end the 15-year-old civil war, Portuguese officials said. The United States is believed to channel more than $50 million in aid to UNITA yearly. The Soviet Union backs Angola's government. The last round of talks in Lisbon last month stumbled over a UNITA demand that the government recognize the group as a legitimate political party before a cease-fire. Both the United States and the Soviet Union have indicated they would send observers if both government and rebels wished. But Venancio de Moura, Angolan vice-minister for foreign relations, said Saturday in Namibia that such participation would not be useful, Angola's ANGOP news agency reported. ``On the contrary, we consider it premature,'' de Moura was quoted as saying. He said a truce could be reached this month if UNITA dropped its demands for explicit political recognition. UNITA spokesmen said recently the rebels had rejected a government proposal offering UNITA ``special status'' but falling short of full political recognition. He said, however, the rebels would make it easier for the government to recognize them during the next round of talks. Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos also said recently the rebels have intensified their attacks, ``making it difficult to build a climate favorable to national reconciliation,'' ANGOP reported. UNITA fighters said last week they would scale back attacks in response to a plea from the Organization of African Unity. UNITA - the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola - has been fighting the government since Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf pvs, bgng `In 1971...' to CORRECT date of Dag Hammarskjold's death to 1961 sted 1971. Moves info 1 graf higher to place in correct chronological sequence. Pickup 15th graf pvs, `In 1975...' This item moved in advance as b0174 of Sept. 10.
DOC.TEXT: Today is Tuesday, Sept. 18, the 261st day of 1990. There are 104 days left in the year. On Sept. 18, 1793, President George Washington laid the cornerstone of the U.S. Capitol, using a silver trowel and marble-headed gavel to put the stone in place, in accordance with Masonic ritual. On this date: In 1759, the French formally surrendered Quebec to the British. In 1769, the Boston Gazette reported on the first piano built in the U.S., a spinet with a three-to-four octave range. In 1810, Chile declared its independence from Spain. In 1850, Congress passed the Fugitive Slave Act, which allowed slaveowners to reclaim slaves who had escaped into other states. In 1851, the first issue of The New York Times was published. In 1873, a panic caused by the failure of the brokerage firm of Jay Cooke and Company resulted in a five-year depression. In 1927, the Columbia Phonograph Broadcasting System, later CBS, made its debut with a basic network of 16 radio stations. In 1940, 50 years ago, Harper and Brothers published ``You Can't Go Home Again'' by Thomas Wolfe. In 1947, the United States Air Force was established as a separate branch of the military. In 1961, United Nations Secretary-General Dag Hammarskjold died in a plane crash in northern Rhodesia. In 1970, 20 years ago, rock star Jimi Hendrix died in London at age 27. In 1975, newspaper heiress Patricia Hearst was captured by the FBI in San Francisco, 19 months after she was kidnapped by the Symbionese Liberation Army. In 1987, President Reagan announced that he and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev would meet later in the year to sign a treaty banning medium- and shorter-range nuclear missiles. Ten years ago: President Jimmy Carter told a news conference the United States was ``not going to apologize'' for past actions in Iran. Pulitzer Prize-winning author Katherine Anne Porter died in Silver Spring, Md., at age 90. Five years ago: President Reagan publicly confirmed the release of the Rev. Benjamin Weir, an American held hostage in Lebanon for 14 months. U.S. officials had kept Weir's release a secret in hopes that other hostages would also be freed. One year ago: Hurricane Hugo reached Puerto Rico, causing extensive damage as it continued to barrel toward the U.S. mainland. Today's birthdays: Actor Rossano Brazzi is 74. Actor Jack Warden is 70. Singer Frankie Avalon is 50. Baseball player Ryne Sandberg is 31. Thought for today: ``Loneliness ... is and always has been the central and inevitable experience of every man.'' - From ``You Can't Go Home Again,'' by Thomas Wolfe, American author (1900-1938).

DOC.HEAD: California Businessman Pleads Guilty to Bribery for Navy Contracts
DOC.TEXT: A California businessman pleaded guilty Monday to conspiring to bribe two Navy procurement officials by paying them more than $26,000 to help his company obtain lucrative electronics contracts. Manuel R. Caldera, 59, former chairman of Amex Systems, Inc., of Los Angeles, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to pay bribes and making an illegal payment to a public official. Together, the charges carry a maximum sentence of seven years imprisonment and fines of $500,000. The guilty plea before U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton in Alexandria, Va., marked the latest conviction in the government's investigation of Pentagon procurement fraud. Thirty-nine defense consultants, procurement officials and contractors plus several companies have been convicted since the investigation known as ``Operation Ill Wind'' became public more than two years ago. Caldera, a Mexican-American who was honored in 1983 by President Reagan as a minority businessman, admitted paying bribes to former Navy procurement officials Stuart E. Berlin and James D. Sampson between 1978 and 1985. The two former officials, who worked for the Naval Electronics System Command in Arlington, Va., agreed to approve additional contract work for Amex in return for the money, according to court papers. Sampson, who has not been charged, and Berlin, who is serving a 26-month prison term for his guilty plea to unrelated charges, are cooperating with the investigation. The conspiracy charge to which Caldera pleaded guilty listed payments of $26,000 between 1982 and 1985. A statement of facts filed by prosecutors indicated payments totalled $34,000 between 1978 and 1985. Until 1984, Amex was eligible to obtain government contracts without competing with other firms because it was a minority-owned business, prosecutors said. The minority-business preference ended shortly before Amex was sold to Allied Corp. for $45 million. Hilton scheduled sentencing for Nov. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Derailment Forces Residents From Homes; Evacuation May Last Three Days
DOC.TEXT: Residents of this town southwest of Little Rock won't be able to return home for two or three days while a toxic acid spill caused by a train derailment is cleaned up, authorities said Monday. The town's 345 residents were evacuated when one derailed car began leaking highly corrosive nitric acid, some of which evaporated to form a cloud over the town, said Gary Talley of the state Office of Emergency Services. ``The car is upside down and it looks like the leak is on the underside,'' Talley said. Until the all of the chemical is drained and either evaporates or is neutralized there is little authorities can do but secure the area, he said. ``We're gearing up for two to three days,'' Talley said.
