He said that meant the earliest residents could return home was late Tuesday afternoon. About 10,000 gallons of nitric acid was expected to leak from the 17,386-gallon tank car, Davis said. An earthen dam was built to contain that acid, said Niolan Spain, emergency service coordinator for Ouachia County. He said they didn't plan to do anything with that pool of acid until morning. The 51-car train was on a regular run between Gurdon and El Dorado when eight cars derailed at 4:45 a.m., according to Mark Davis, a spokesman for Union Pacific in Omaha, Neb. The cause of the accident was under investigation. No injuries were reported. Nitric acid can irritate the skin, eyes and mucous membranes, and cause burns, depending on its concentration, said Robert L. Horn, public health laboratory director for the state Health Department. The acid is non-combustible, but will accelerate the burning of combustible materials.

DOC.HEAD: Loggers, Environmentalists Converge On Congress; Dispute Job Loss Cause
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, bgng: Meanwhile some xxx to CORRECT that environmentalists were lobbying against legislation; fixes category code.
DOC.TEXT: Scores of timber industry workers asked congressmen Monday not to destroy jobs by sharply reduced timber cutting, while environmentalists lobbied for legislation to protect the Northwest's ancient forests. ``I'm scared for my family,'' said Judy Marr, who runs a small logging company in northwestern Washington and said she was worried about legislation that would reduce timber harvests. ``For us it's not a weekend hike or a walk every five years. For us, it's an everyday lifestyle.'' Ms. Marr was among about 200 loggers, mill workers and community leaders from Oregon and Washington state who sought out members of Congress to plead that they keep the plight of timber workers in mind when considering legislation that would reduce timber cutting. Legislation that would ban logging on 6.3 million acres including about 2.7 million acres currently open to timber harvests is expected to be considered by the House Interior Committee later this week. The push to protect Northwest forests intensified this summer when the spotted owl was declared protected under the Endangered Species Act. Scientists say the only way to ensure the owl's survival is to restricting logging. A federal task force has been trying to work out ways to protect the owl, but still minimize the economic impact on timber workers. Rep. Denny Smith, R-Ore., said White House Chief of Staff John Sununu has told him that there is little liklihood that environmental and economic considerations could be balanced in the spotted owl deliberations without Congress changing the Endangered Species Act. He said Sununu urged that Congress change the law. But Smith as well as Sen. Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., said they do not believe there are enough votes in Congress to do that. Valerie Johnson, leader of the Oregon Lands Coalition, said the Northwest is the latest region to fall victim to overzealous environmental legislation that is causing ``social havoc and human suffering'' among timber industry workers and related businesses. ``We are all being told that Americans don't need us any more,'' she said. Meanwhile some 500 environmentalists also fanned out among the congressional offices to lobby against legislation they said would further destroy the Northwest's dwindling old-growth forests. Frances Hunt of the National Wildlife Federation said the economic plight of the timber workers was wrongly being blamed on conservationists' attempts to preserve the ancient forests. ``We have already lost 90 percent of the old-growth ecosystem. It is not the last 10 percent that is putting them out of work, it is the 90 percent that was cut before,'' she said. The timber workers gave Smith a petition with 40,000 signatures from families concerned about their future and asked congressmen to ``weigh both the scientific evidence and the social price tag'' when considering such issues as the protection of the threatened spotted owl. ``We didn't come to Washington to ask Congress for a handout. We came to ask for the opportunity to continue working,'' said Doug Robertson, a county commissioner from heavily timber-dependent Roseburg, Ore. contested bid for re-election, said the Northwest residents face an uphill battle.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Asks New Yorkers Lobby for Crime Bill
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday that New Yorkers alarmed about crime should lean on Congress to enact an administration bill to stiffen penalties against criminals and build more jail cells. At a news conference, Bush said that ``soft treatment of the criminal ... sends exactly the wrong signal to those embattled citizens.'' ``I'd like to see our crime bill pass,'' he said. ``I think that would send a good message to the policemen on the streets of New York that we plan to back them up more.'' Bush's anticrime bill has been stalled in Congress since last year. It's provisions include the death penalty for ``drug kingpins.'' On that point, Bush said, ``We've got a difference with some in New York on that one.'' He did not cite any opponents by name. New York has been stunned by random shootings whose victims have included innocent children and other bystanders. Last month, a 22-year-old visitor from Utah, Brian Watkins, was stabbed to death when he tried to protect his parents during a subway mugging. On another subject, Bush criticized the tactics of some AIDS activists, singling out protestors who disrupted a recent speech by Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan at an AIDs conference in San Francisco. ``I must say, some of the excesses of those groups does not help the cause,'' the president said. ``I had a lot of mail saying people were quite embarrassed by that.'' Speaking about the economy, Bush said, ``I don't think there's a financial crisis. I think the economy's growth is slow. I do not think that nationally we're in a recession.'' He acknowledged that New England states, with heavy unemployment and other economic problems, were undergoing ``a very difficult situation.'' He said, ``Other areas of the country have gone through similar regional downturns ... I think the best thing the federal government can do is to get these interest rates down and to adopt growth incentives so that people will continue to create jobs.''

DOC.HEAD: Congress Approves Free Mail for U.S. Troops In Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: The House by a 368-0 vote gave final approval Monday to legislation that would give free mailing privileges to U.S. troops deployed in the Persian Gulf. The legislation now goes to President Bush. The Senate approved the measure by voice vote last week. Under current law, free mailing privileges are extended to members of the armed forces engaged in hostilities. This legislation would extend free mail to participants in Operation Desert Shield, including those aboard ships. The free postage would apply to cards, letters and audio cassettes. Members of a recent congressional delegation visiting Saudi Arabia heard troops complain they were unable to purchase stamps, and that stamps brought from home were made unusable by the extreme heat. The Congressional Budget Office estimated that the measure would cost between $6 million and $8 million in fiscal 1991, money that the Defense Department would pay to the Postal Service. The Postal Service sought to institute the free mail last week, but the Pentagon refused to begin the program without legislation.

DOC.HEAD: President Nominates Mercanti As Engraver At Philadelphia Mint

DOC.TEXT: President Bush will nominate John M. Mercanti to be engraver of the U.S. Mint in Philadelphia, the White House said Monday. It is a promotion for Mercanti, currently a sculptor and engraver at the mint.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait Accuses Iraq of Torture, `Big 5' Meet to Tighten Sanctions
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq on Monday rejected a proposed visit to Iraq and Kuwait by the secretary-general's envoy for humanitarian aid, and Kuwait's ambassador filed a protest against alleged Iraqi atrocities. Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan of Pakistan had been appointed by Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to oversee U.N. aid in the gulf crisis. Perez de Cuellar appealed last week to Iraq to allow Aga Khan to make a visit to determine food and medicine needs - especially those of foreigners. Emerging from a visit with Perez de Cuellar, Ambassador Abdul Amir Al-Anbari said Iraq rejected the visit, as well as the Security Council's call for aid to be delivered to Iraq and Kuwait through non-Iraqi organizations. ``Iraq is the cradle of civilization and not just another poor country,'' Al-Anbari said, describing the U.N. plan for food deliveries as ``humiliating.'' Meanwhile, the Security Council's sanction commmitte recommended the international community provide aid to Jordan, which is heavily dependent on Iraqi commerce. Jordan is one of 10 nations, including India, Sri Lanka, Bulgaria and the Philippines, which have requested relief from the sweeping U.N. trade embargo intended to compel the withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait. The five permanent Security Council members - the United States, Britain, China, France and the Soviet Union - met Monday to discuss the possible expansion of enforcement measures against Iraq to include an aerial blockade and sanctions against countries that violate the embargo. The existing embargo already covers air traffic, in theory, but the Security Council has only permitted the use of force to halt maritime traffic, to allow ships to be stopped and boarded and their cargoes inspected. The United States, Britain, France support the new restrictions, but China and the Soviet Union were said to be opposed to the aerial blockade. Western diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they expected the Security Council this week to adopt a resolution that would take punitive measures against violators of the embargo. An air blockade is considered risky because halting planes is difficult without the use of deadly force. Numerous international conventions protect civil aviation. Meanwhile, Kuwaiti Ambassador Mohammad Abulhassan said in a letter to Perez de Cuellar that `the entire population of Kuwait, including third country nationals, is being subjected to a reign of terror, systematically planned and relentlessly pursued by the Iraqi occupiers.'' Iraqi ``criminal practices are being stepped up with the sinister objected of making life under occupation so inteolerable that the population is forced out, in order to alter the demographics of Kuwait,'' the letter said. Some Kuwaitis have speculated Saddam Hussein wants to repopulate Kuwait with Iraqis. An estimated 300,000 of Kuwait's native population of 570,000 have fled since Iraq invaded on Aug. 2. Abulhassan also wrote that many Kuwaitis have been arrested for refusing to collaborate with occupation forces, and some of them ``are being subjected to all sorts of intimidation and physical torture.'' In the presence of a large crowd, Iraqi troops shot to death Mubarak Faleh Al Note, the chairman of a cooperative society, Abulhassan said, when he refused to hang a portrait of Saddam and removed one of the Emir of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Bolivian Indians March into La Paz to Protest Deforestation
DOC.TEXT: About 800 Indians marched into the capital Monday, ending a 470-mile trek to draw attention to their anguish over the deforestation of the Amazon rainforest where they reside. The Indians were greeted by tens of thousands of city residents who poured into the streets of La Paz to greet them. The Indians, including women and children, made the 32-day trek from the jungle lowlands to La Paz to demand the return of 750,000 acres of land deeded to lumber companies. La Paz is 13,000 feet above sea level. At a 14,500 foot-high crossing 25 miles outside La Paz, Aymara Indians from the highlands met the marchers and sacrificed a llama to the Aymara earth goddess in a ceremony dating to pre-Colombian times. Aymara leaders gave the marchers a symbolic key to La Paz and accompanied the rainforest Indians on the last stretch of their march. The march, which involves various small Indian tribes, has captured the attention of Bolivians by exposing the misery of the oft-neglected tribes from the isolated lowlands of interior Bolivia. ``The march is not against anybody but a call for Bolivians to pay attention to their plight,'' President Jaime Paz Zamora said during a meeting with the Indians last week as they began their march toward La Paz. Residents along the way have provided marchers with food and lodging. Support groups from La Paz assisted with emergency medical care. Doctors said at least 100 of the Indians were suffering from high-altitude sickness. The Indian groups want the government to overturn contracts that granted the huge tracts of tropical rainforest in the Amazon and La Plata River basins to six lumber companies. The contracts were signed under the conservative administration of Victor Paz Estenssoro, who turned over the presidency to Paz Zamora, his nephew, after elections in May 1989. A coalition of Indian groups say the logging companies are not replanting the mahoganies and other fine woods they cut and are destroying the delicate ecological balance of the area. The government's forestry board, which advocates the interests of logging companies, has taken out adds in local papers saying loggers were not damaging the environment. Loggers also argue that should the government back away from the logging contracts it would harm foreign investment in Bolivia. ``Any effort to deny the contracts legally agreed upon will put faith in the government at stake and would seriously affect the climate of confidence that is being created in the country,'' read one add. The Roman Catholic Church's Episcopal Council, meanwhile, said Sunday: ``Investments are welcome but not at the cost of the depredation of our natural resources and the search for endless profits.'' ``Indigenous people should be respected as people and as citizens,'' the group said in a statement. There are at least 40 isolated Indian communities in the Bolivian forests with a population estimated at 150,000 people. The Indians work as nomadic hunters, fisherman or as hired hands at cattle ranches. Bolivia, a poor landlocked country in South America's midsection, has about 7 million residents. About two-thirds of the nation is made up of tropical lowlands.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Testifies Abortion Reversal Could Hurt Other Rights
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates 2nd graf pvs with Souter ending his testimony; inserts grafs 3-5 with Souter final statement and other witnesses; edits graf 6 for style, picking up 7th graf pvs: The 14-member etc.
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court nominee David H. Souter said Monday at his confirmation hearings that letting states outlaw abortion might cast doubts on other privacy rights. Senators told Souter, testifying on his 51st birthday, that his confirmation was virtually assured. During a third and final day of Senate Judiciary Committee questioning on controversial issues he would face as a justice, Souter said he opposes a judicial ban on the death penalty. In a final statement to the committee, Souter said, ``You have treated me with such consummate fairness that on whatever court I may sit I hope I will do as well.'' Souter was followed to the witness table by an American Bar Association committee which previously announced that it had given him its highest rating - ``well qualified.'' More than two dozen other witnesses, including the woman whose challenge to a Texas abortion law led to the Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion, were scheduled to begin testimony Tuesday. Souter continued to dodge questions concerning his views on abortion but did address the privacy-rights issue and said his personal feelings on abortion would not keep him from taking part in Supreme Court decisions on the subject. ``A lot of people have the feeling that your confirmation process is over,'' Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., told Souter at one point. Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., told the New Hampshire judge, ``I believe you will be confirmed.'' Sens. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, and Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, also voiced confidence about Souter's success. But committee chairman Joseph Biden, D-Del., said some senators, including himself, remain undecided. The 14-member committee will send its recommendation to the full Senate for a confirmation vote Biden indicated might come ``in two or three weeks.'' Asked whether he believes the death penalty violates the Constitution's ban on cruel and unusual punishment, Souter said, ``I think that would be an insupportable constitutional conclusion. That is an opinion I could not join.'' Retired Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan, whom Souter was picked by President Bush to replace, held such a view. The only high court justice remaining who opposes capital punishment under all circumstances is Thurgood Marshall. But the court now is far more closely divided on its 1973 abortion-legalizing decision, Roe vs. Wade, and Souter again Monday turned aside questions about his personal views on that topic. Pressed by Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., Souter did say his personal beliefs would not keep him from participating in abortion decisions on the high court. He also said a successful attack on Roe vs. Wade ``might call into question prior privacy rulings.'' The comment could be significant, suggesting that a concern for other privacy rights might make Souter less willing to vote to overturn the 1973 ruling. In previous testimony, Souter told the committee he believes married women have a fundamental privacy right to use contraceptives. Souter also said overturning Roe vs. Wade would make abortion ``a matter for legislative judgment'' - as individual states would have to decide whether to outlaw or stringently regulate abortions. On another subject, Souter said he made a mistake by not insisting that New Hampshire return $74,000 contributed to the state by the owner of the Seabrook nuclear power plant for law enforcement costs connected with anti-nuclear demonstrations. Questioned by Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, Souter said giving the money back to the Public Service Co. ``would have been an appropriate position to take. I wish I had taken it.'' He said acceptance of the contribution gave rise to the appearance ``that justice can be deflected by this.'' Metzenbaum also brought up the Supreme Court decision earlier this year striking down a federal ban on burning the American flag. The senator asked, Is the court obligated to enforce individual rights ``no matter how unpopular the cause?'' Souter replied: ``If that were not the case, there would be no need to have a Bill or Rights.'' The nominee refused several invitations by Grassley to criticize past Supreme Court rulings that expanded the rights of criminal suspects. About the landmark 1966 ruling in Miranda vs. Arizona that required police to warn suspects of their rights before questioning them, Souter said the ruling did not create a new right but merely set down procedural guidelines for protecting a right. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., reminded Souter of an answer Robert H. Bork gave during the confirmation hearings that preceded the Senate's rejection in 1987 of Bork's Supreme Court nomination. Taking issue with Bork's view that adding to an individual's rights necessarily diminishes the rights of someone else, Simon said he believes adding to one person's rights enhances the rights of all. Souter agreed with Simon, saying, ``I'd rather have a right to do something ... than a right to stop someone else.'' Simon replied: ``I like that answer.'' When Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., asked Souter how he had changed over the past 25 years, the judge said he had ``learned something of the wisdom'' of Benjamin Franklin's advice to ``join with me in doubting for a minute your own infallibility.'' Simpson said, ``I like that.''

DOC.HEAD: President Threatens To Veto Textile Bill
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday he would veto a bill due for a vote in the House to sharply limit imports of textiles, apparel and shoes. ``The bill is a threat to the stability of the world trading system and is completely contrary to the economic, commercial and political interests of the United States,'' Bush said in a letter to congressional leaders. ``This legislation would seriously restrict textile and footwear imports and violate international trade rules,'' the president added. ``It represents the worst form of economic policy for America, one based upon the mistaken belief that less trade throughout the world will somehow save American jobs and enhance our prosperity.'' The House was to vote on the measure Tuesday. The bill would restrict textile imports levels to a 1 percent increase over the previous year. Shoe import quotas would be permanently fixed at 1980 levels and would cover 38 product categories, applying to all countries except Canada and Israel. Meanwhile, a spokesman for 12 major European countries warned that passing a bill to limit U.S. imports could bring failure to more than four years of world-wide talks to increase trade and to cut subsidies to farmers. Andreas van Agt, ambassador of the European Economic Community, called it ``this Draconian provision.'' He wrote House Speaker Thomas S. Foley that he wanted to explain why the 12 governments in the community oppose the bill. ``Indeed, the passage of such legislation would be tantamount to eliminating all prospects of progress in this area and, even worse, will jeopardize negotiations not just in textiles but in all other areas covered by the Round as well,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: South Africa Would Sign Nuclear Treaty, Under Conditions
With AM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: South Africa would sign the nuclear non-proliferation treaty if other nations in the southern African region also agreed to sign such a document, Foreign Affairs Minister Pik Botha said Monday. He said officials have discussed the issue with the United States, Soviet Union and Britain. Botha cited reduced tensions between the superpowers as a reason for the willingness to join the pact. ``The South African government is prepared to accede to the treaty in the context of an equal commitment by other states in the southern African region,'' Botha said in a statement. Discussions on creating a nuclear-free zone in southern Africa had been held with neighboring countries, he said. ``Such a move would further remove suspicions and should strengthen the economic and geographical cohesion of the region,'' Botha said. It was the latest in a series of signals that South Africa has greater cooperation with its neighbors, among the most vocal critics of the apartheid system of racial segregation and white dominance. During the 1980s, South Africa supported rebel movements fighting leftist governments in Mozambique and Angola. However, South Africa has signed peace treaties with both countries and is improving diplomatic and trade contacts with other countries throughout Africa. South Africa has previously refused to sign the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. It has one nuclear power plant, near Cape Town, and is a major uranium exporting country. It has refused to say if it has nuclear weapons, but is widely believed to have the ability to make them. The treaty calls on countries with nuclear weapons to refrain from selling them or the technology to other countries. Those without nuclear weapons agree to refrain from purchasing them or the technology to make them. More than 130 countries have signed the treaty.

DOC.HEAD: 1{ Tons of Colombian Cocaine Seized in Largest Dominican Bust
DOC.TEXT: Police confiscated nearly 1{ tons of Colombian cocaine worth about $33 million in the Dominican Republic's largest-ever drug seizure, officials said Monday. Seventeen suspects - 10 Dominicans and seven Venezuelans - were arrested over weekend, the Drug Control Division said in a statement. The operation began in Colombia after authorities were tipped the cocaine was aboard a Venezuelan-registered ship, Cesma II, the officials said. The statement said authorities confiscated 2,930 pounds of pure cocaine, which arrived Thursday near a beach 11 miles from the capital, Santo Domingo. It said 1,959 pounds of the shipment was seized from fishing boats that picked up the drug after it was thrown overboard in cases. The remainder was confiscated from a house where it was delivered Friday night. The Dominican Republic, which shares the Caribbean island of Hispaniola with Haiti, has become a major transshipment point for Colombian cocaine destined for the U.S. market. The largest previous drug seizure here was in May 1987, when authorities confiscated 2,119 pounds of cocaine aboard a ship.

DOC.HEAD: Guatemala Goes on U.S. Drug Problem List
DOC.TEXT: The State Department has placed Guatemala on a list of major drug trafficking countries, and further U.S. aid will be conditioned on how hard it fights the narcotics problem, a diplomat said Monday. U.S. officials say at least 4,000 acres in Guatemala's rugged western mountains were planted with opium poppies last year. The region yields three or four 16-metric ton harvests a year - said to be enough heroin to supply the annual needs of each addict in the United States. The country is also a major transshipment point for cocaine. Fourteen tons were seized in Guatemala this year, compared to 4 tons last year, U.S. Embassy spokesman James Dickmeyer said in an interview. ``Guatemala has been overwhelmed by drugs. That's why it has been put on the list,'' Dickmeyer said. Any nation that produces more than 5 tons of opium paste automatically goes on the drug watch list, which currently includes 24 nations - 10 in Latin America and the Caribbean and 14 in Asia and the Mideast. Every March, the administration gives Congress a ``scorecard'' on each country's efforts to curb drug production, trafficking or money-laundering. If the administration fails to certify Guatemala is cooperating in the war on drugs, it could lose half its U.S. aid. Dickmeyer said Guatemala is not likely to have problems with certification because it is cooperating with the Drug Enforcement Administration. ``When they pass information to Guatemala that something is coming through, the shipment usually gets busted,'' Dickmeyer said. U.S. aid to Guatemala in the current fiscal year totalled $121.3 million - $118 in economic aid and $3.3 million in military aid. It included more than $1 million earmarked primarily for a U.S. spraying program against opium fields. The military, which has dominated Guatemala for decades, has not been involved in fighting poppy cultivation, officials say. It has left enforcement to the undermanned Treasury Police. Some prominent Guatemalan officials have been linked to drug trafficking in recent years. U.S. officials say drug operations thrive in a climate of corruption that has grown since Christian Democrat Vinicio Cerezo became president in 1986. Polls indicate the Christian Democrats will lose the presidential elections set for November.

DOC.HEAD: Two Million Soviets Could Come to Israel Within Six Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Shamir comment. Pickup 6th, `Dintz suggested...'
DOC.TEXT: Up to 2 million Soviet immigrants could arrive in Israel by the end of 1995 and the government will need hundreds of millions of dollars in extra aid to absorb them, a senior official said Monday. The projection by Simcha Dinitz, chairman of the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency, would mean an increase of nearly 45 percent in Israel's current population of 4.5 million. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir on Monday welcomed a planeload of Soviet immigrants, praising the influx as a boost to the strength of the Jewish state. ``These immigrants are more important than weapons,'' Shamir told reporters at Ben-Gurion International Airport near Tel Aviv. Dinitz's estimate was the highest yet for a massive influx of Soviets that started last year. The flow of immigrants has consistently exceeded expectations and outrun plans for housing and employment for the new arrivals. ``It is a most revolutionary thing,'' Dinitz told a news conference in his office. ``I know of no other society going through such a massive absorption process.'' Earlier this month, Shamir said a million Soviets were expected within the decade. Dinitz suggested Shamir gave a conservative estimate out of concern the flow could be stemmed by the crisis in the Persian Gulf and pressures from Arab countries on the Soviets to halt the immigration. ``All these fears of interference with immigration have proven unfounded. It didn't happen. With each passing month we are seeing an increase,'' Dinitz said. Dinitz said Israel expected the total of Soviet newcomers to reach 1 million by the end of 1992. He said this meant Israel's population would grow by nearly 25 percent. ``We have a potential of another million over six years,'' Dinitz said. He added that the Jewish Agency was already processing applications beyond the 1 million mark. The Jewish Agency oversees immigration and Jewish fund-raising abroad. The pace of immigration has already risen dramatically in the last few months, Dinitz noted. This month's total through Sept. 16 was 9,864 Soviets, Dinitz said. Dinitz said the pressure to handle the arrivals was so great the government was considering receiving 3,500 Soviet immigrants over Rosh Hashanah, the Jewish New Year holiday from Wednesday through Saturday. This is despite rabbis' complaints about allowing travel on holy days. Most Soviet Jews say they are leaving their country because of increasing evidence of anti-Semitism and economic instability in the Soviet Union. The flow of Jews to Israel also has been spurred by more liberal Soviet exit policies and tighter U.S. immigration rules. Dinitz said Israel had to take ``drastic, comprehensive steps'' to absorb the newcomers in an economy already troubled by double-digit inflation and a recession. Officials have estimated at least $30 billion would be needed to take in 1 million immigrants. Israel's gross national product for 1988, the last year available, was $33.5 billion. Israel has so far budgeted only about $2.3 billion over the next three years, and world Jewry has pledged another $740 million. Dinitz indicated Jewish leaders abroad were already increasing their contributions and that a record of $650 million was received this year, but he said more would be needed. Israel is already hard put to handle the immigrants. State TV reported last week that only 8,000 of about 100,000 newcomers this year had found jobs. Unemployment excluding the immigrants has hit 10 percent. Housing Minister Ariel Sharon told the Cabinet on Sunday that construction was under way for only 5,000 of 45,000 housing units approved earlier this year, the Yediot Ahronot daily said.

DOC.HEAD: West European Nations Agree to Expel Iraqi Military Personnel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to UPDATE with West German action. Pickup 4th, `British Prime...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: European Community nations agreed Monday to expel Iraqi military aides and restrict the movement of Iraq's diplomats in retaliation for raids on foreign diplomatic compounds in Kuwait. Britain ousted eight members of the Iraqi Embassy and ordered the deportation of 23 other Iraqi citizens. West Germany gave military aides at the Iraqi Embassy in Bonn 48 hours to leave the country. And Italy announced a previous expulsion order would apply to 11 employees in the Iraqi military attache's office. Belgium told Iraqi diplomats they could travel no farther than 18 miles from Brussels, and Italy restricted them to an area within 18 miles of Rome. West Germany limited their travel to Bonn and the city airport, and the Dutch demanded written requests from Iraqi officials for travel outside The Hague. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, on an official visit to Czechoslovakia, said Britain expelled the Iraqis ``in order to support France and other countries whose residences were attacked by Iraqi troops in Kuwait.'' ``After the exceptionally scandalous behavior against the diplomatic missions, something had to happen,'' Dutch Foreign Minister Hans van den Broek said. ``(Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein has to see he is in a no-win situation,'' he said. Italy's foreign minister, Gianna De Michelis, said he hoped the European reaction would show Saddam an ``escalation (of tensions) will not help ... but will strengthen our solidarity in enforcing the embargo.'' The United Nations imposed an economic embargo on Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. In a final statement, the foreign ministers of the 12 Common Market nations urged Iraq ``to realize the suicidal character of its behavior toward the international community.'' On Sunday, the U.N. Security Council condemned the Iraqi raids on the French, Belgian, Dutch and Canadian embassy compounds in Kuwait. France has since expelled 29 Iraqis. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said there was support among the foreign ministers for an air blockade of Iraq, but he said it was important to get backing from the Security Council for such a move. The officials refused, however, to set a price tag on the amount of aid they will give to the states of Egypt, Turkey and Jordan to help offset the economic impact of the Persian Gulf crisis. At an informal meeting earlier this month, the ministers promised the three countries $2 billion through the end of 1991 to compensate them for lost trade with Iraq. But on Monday, they put off a formal decision on the amount of aid. ``The community is determined to assist these countries in the sacrifices imposed on them by the present international crisis,'' the ministers said. They said they would look ``as a matter of urgency'' at a proposal to channel $2 billion to the countries. But they asked for updated estimates on the amount of help the countries need and the contributions already made by community and other nations. Hurd, taking note of fresh pledges of military and financial support for the U.S.-led operation in the gulf, said Europeans ``are increasingly putting our forces and our money where our mouth is.'' The 12 EC nations are Belgium, Denmark, France, West Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, Spain and Portugal.

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Mission Scrubbed Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 23 grafs to UPDATE with flight delayed until after October flight of Discovery, tanking test planned; ADD planned launch date for Discovery. Pick up 23rd graf pvs, `Veteran astronaut...' ^By MARCIA DUNN
DOC.TEXT: A buildup of flammable hydrogen vapor in the engine compartment Monday forced NASA to cancel a fourth attempt at launching the space shuttle Columbia. NASA postponed Columbia's astronomy mission until after a higher-priority flight of the shuttle Discovery in October. The leak appeared as the shuttle's huge external fuel tank was being filled. It was detected a few minutes after supercooled liquid hydrogen fuel began flowing into the tank at a ``fast fill'' rate of 8,400 gallons per minute - the same point where buildup caused NASA to cancel two previous launches. At one point, the vapor reached levels more than triple NASA's limit. The shuttle was to have been launched at 1:28 a.m. EDT Tuesday. ``The mood is pretty depressing,'' said Keith Hudkins, chief of the orbiter division. ``After all summer trying to chase these leaks down ... I'll tell you this, we've had all the experts working very long hours, and they are experts. It's just a very difficult problem.'' After the launch was called off, engineers scrambled to find the cause of the problem. They monitored sensors in the engine compartment long after the filling operation was stopped. Robert Crippen, director of the shuttle program, said NASA would conduct a tanking test, on Sunday at the earliest, in an attempt to pinpoint the source of the leak. Television cameras will be mounted in the crowded compartment, he said. ``It's obviously a leak we cannot pick up,'' Crippen said. He said the leak appears only when the liquid hydrogen fuel is at its coldest - minus 423 degrees Fahrenheit. As it warms a few degrees while the shuttle sits, the leak stops, Crippen said. Columbia is the oldest ship in the fleet. It has been flying since 1981 and has nine missions on its flight log. At a briefing earlier in the day, William Lenoir, the head of NASA's space flight program, expressed the hope the leaks had been found and fixed. Two leaky components were replaced last week. ``We're going to keep trying until we get it right,'' he said. In past filling operations, NASA said it would stop fueling if there were more than 600 parts of highly flammable hydrogen vapor in a million parts of air. But on Monday, Lenoir said that the bottom line would be raised to 1,000 parts per million. The mission was called off on Monday when concentrations reached 3,300 ppm. On Sept. 5, when the last filling operation also ended in a scrub, sensors recorded 6,500 ppm. On the attempt before that, May 29, hydrogen leaked in two places: from the large pipe that connects the ship with its tank and in the aft compartment where the engines are. The pipe was replaced, and there was no leak in that area on Monday or during the last fueling. Hydrogen vapor could burst into flame if the concentration is too high. Monday afternoon began badly for the launch team. The start of the filling operation was delayed 53 minutes because of lightning within six miles of the launch pad. Columbia was to have carried seven astronauts into space and the $150 million Astro observatory. ``It gets a little harder each time, but the science is there and we want to go after it,'' said mission scientist Ted Gull. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration hasn't launched a shuttle since April, when Discovery carried the flawed Hubble Space Telescope into orbit. Discovery now sits on a launch pad 1{ miles away from Columbia. Discovery is scheduled to launch around Oct. 8, carrying a satellite to study the sun. Atlantis, meanwhile, is in the hangar undergoing repairs for hydrogen leaks that were detected over the summer. The Astro mission originally was scheduled for March 1986, but was delayed indefinitely following the Challenger explosion two months earlier. Veteran astronaut Vance Brand is to command the mission. At 59, he would be the oldest person to fly in space. The crew includes four astronomers who would have operated Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes in non-stop shifts during the nine- to 10-day mission. An X-ray telescope, responsible for Columbia's second failed launch attempt, was to be managed by computer commands sent from the ground.

DOC.HEAD: List of Major Events at The New York Post
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of important event sin the history of the New York Post, the nation's oldest continuously published daily newspaper.

Nov. 16, 1801 - Post founded by, among others, Alexander Hamilton, the nation's first Treasury secretary, and former New York Gov. John Jay, later chief justice of the Supreme Court, as a polite, liberal publication for the city's upper class. 1829 - William Cullen Bryant begins his 48 years as editor. 1881 - Sold to railroad tycoon Henry Villard. 1903 - Passed on to Villard's son, Osward Garrison Villard. 1914 - Sold to banker Thomas Lamont. 1922 - Sold to a syndicate of 34 owners, including Franklin Delano Roosevelt. 1924 - Sold to Cyrus H.K. Curtis, publisher of the Saturday Evening Post. 1935 - Sold to Philadelphia publisher J. David Stern, who was persuaded by Roosevelt to keep the paper going after Curtis' death. 1939 - Bought by City Councilman George Backer and his wife, banking heiress Dorothy Schiff. They divorced in 1942 and Mrs. Schiff assumed sole control and turned the newspaper into a tabloid. 1966 - The Post becomes the only afternoon newspaper in New York City as the number of dailies shrink in the wake of a strike. 1967 - Moved to 210 South St., former plant of the defunct Journal-American, and circulation rises to 700,000. Nov. 1976 - Mrs. Schiff sold the Post for about $31 million to Australian publisher Rupert Murdoch, who was building his media holdings in the United States. 1983 - Circulation reached 962,000. 1986 - Murdoch granted two-year waiver by Federal Communications Commission on rule barring cross-ownership of newspaper and television station in the same city. Sept. 30, 1987 - Post circulation had dropped to 690,915. Dec. 30, 1987 - Congress approved measure preventing the FCC from repealing or modifying its newspaper-television cross-ownership rule. Jan. 14, 1988 - FCC gave Murdoch until March 6 to sell the Post or his TV station. Feb. 7, 1988 - Developer Peter Kalikow agrees to buy paper, contingent upon $24 million in union concessions Murdoch called essential to continued operation. May 10, 1988 - Kalikow names Jane Amsterdam editor to raise paper's ``journalistic standards and practices.'' March 5, 1989 - A Sunday edition is launched and dies nine months and $20 million later. May 31, 1989 - Jerry Nachman is named editor, signaling a return to lively tabloid-style coverage, but circulation continues to slide, falling to just above half a million. Sept. 4, 1990 - Kalikow tells unions the Post cannot survive unless it gets $19 million worth of contract concessions. Sept. 14, 1990 - Ten of 11 unions have agreed to concessions; The Newspaper Guid balks but agrees to submit a wage-cut and job-cut proposal to the membership. Sept. 17, 1990 - The Post survives another brush with extinction as members of the Newspaper Guild vote 242-45 to approve concessions and a buyout offer from Kalikow.

DOC.HEAD: Another Look at `Gypsy' and `Falsettoland'
DOC.TEXT: The test of any great role is in the different ways it can be performed and still be successful. A fine example is now on view at Broadway's St. James Theater where the revival of ``Gypsy'' has a new Rose, that quintessential stage mother, in the person of Linda Lavin, last seen here three years ago in Neil Simon's ``Broadway Bound.'' Lavin plays Rose, the mother of stripper Gypsy Rose Lee, as a twitchy street fighter, tough, uncompromising and more than a tad neurotic. It's a thoroughly original, even dangerous performance, different from the portraits provided by the other formidable women - Ethel Merman, Angela Lansbury and Tyne Daly - who have played the role on Broadway over the last 30 years. And it's an amazing demonstration of what an actress, who has thought out the role from a very specific point of view, can do. Lavin is willing to let the audience dislike this Rose as she forces daughters June and then Louise into the show business careers she never had. It's a credit to Lavin's harsh performance that she refuses to soften the woman. Everything her Rose wants, she wants on her terms only - whether it's the love of that sweet candy salesman turned manager Herbie or a career for her awkward, also-ran daughter Louise. Watch her grim determination as she prepares sweet little Louise for her debut as a burlesque queen. The concentration is awesome as Rose contemplates finally making her daughter a star. Lavin's fierceness extends to her singing. The woman knows how to handle a theater song. Long before she was television's ``Alice,'' she had a steady career in Broadway musicals. Her ``Rose's Turn,'' is a frenzied cry for recognition for what she did. What's amazing is that Lavin manages to evoke a sense of pity for this woman, making the ending moving and a bit teary as mother and daughter come to a sort of uneasy truce at the final curtain. The rest of the cast has improved in the 10 months the show has been playing on Broadway. Jonathan Hadary remains the definitive Herbie, putting a human face on what is often a cipher of a character. Christen Tassin is still hilariously horrific as Baby June, the world's most obnoxious child star. And Crista Moore has grown immeasurably in the title role of the ugly duckling who becomes a very sexy swan. The score by Jule Styne and Stephen Sondheim is as brassy and classy as ever, and Arthur Laurents' book is a model of what musical comedy writing should be. And now there's Lavin. Mama Rose has never been as unappealing - and as fascinating. --- ``Falsettoland,'' William Finn's musical about facing big city life in the Age of AIDS, keeps getting better and better. In its recent transfer to off-Broadway's Lucille Lortel Theater for an open-ended run, the musical remains funny and poignant. On repeated viewings, two things stand out - the melodic inventiveness of Finn's score and the rapid-fire staging of director James Lapine. This is a musical that never stops. For 70 fast minutes, the story of Marvin and how he copes with his son's bar mitzvah and his lover's fatal illness never lets down - musically or emotionally. The cast, headed by the superb Michael Rupert and Stephen Bogardus, is now even more comfortable in the show. It's odd to think of a musical about AIDS as exhilarating and not depressing, but ``Falsettoland'' turns the act of growing up and coming to terms with oneself into an affecting piece of musical theater.

DOC.HEAD: Eritrean Rebels Claim to Kill More Than 1,000 Troops
DOC.TEXT: Eritrean rebels claimed they killed or wounded nearly 3,000 soldiers in four days of fighting that the Ethiopian government said was causing ``enormous sacrifices'' among its troops. The Eritrean People's Liberation Front, which appears this year to have scored a breakthrough in its 29-year-old war against the central government, said the rebels had rebuffed a government offensive that began Sept. 9. The rebels said the government suffered 1,050dead and 1,900 injured in the battle near Asmara, Ethiopia's second largest city. The broadcast, monitored in Nairobi, said the rebels also captured three tanks and a large cache of weapons. It was impossible to independently verify the rebel claims. Egyptian President Mengistu Haile Mariam hinted at the fighting Wednesday in a speech marking the 1974 coup that toppled the late Emperor Haile Selassie and brought Mengistu to power. Mengistu said the Eritreans were intensifying their war and government troops were ``paying enormous sacrifices to uphold the entity of the motherland.'' Mengistu appealed to the rebels to resume the peace talks they held with the government last year. Ethiopia's army is made up largely of forcibly recruited youngsters. They face an experienced guerrilla force considered by many the best in the world. The Soviet Union has halted military aid to Ethiopia after years of support. The Eritreans control most of the countryside in Eritrea province. In February, after their largest offensive ever, they captured the Red Sea port of Massawa and cut all ground routes to Asmara from the capital, Addis Ababa. The government is also fighting a smaller guerrilla group, the Tigre People's Liberation Front, which controls Tigre province, on the southern border with Eritrea. The Tigreans are seeking to oust Mengistu and establish a government patterned after that of Albania, the last of the hard-line Marxist states in Eastern Europe. Although their aims differ, the Tigreans and the Eritreans usually conduct joint offensives.

DOC.HEAD: Indonesian Military Hero Released from Prison
DOC.TEXT: A former leader of the 1965 military coup who later fell out with President Suharto and became an important dissident has been released from prison. More than 1,000 supporters hailed former Lt. Gen. Hartono R. Dharsono at the gates of Cipinang Prison on his release Sunday. Dharsono, 64, commanded troops in Bandung when President Suharto, then a general, took power in the 1965 coup that deposed President Sukarno. Dharsono's troops provided Suharto with essential support. Later he became ambassador to Thailand and secretary-general of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, which groups Thailand, Malaysia, Brunei, Singapore, Indonesia and the Philippines. But Dharsono in the 1980s became associated with ``Petition 50,'' a dissident group of retired military officers, former Cabinet ministers and human rights activists who petition for greater democracy. The group last month demanded Suharto step down and allow more democracy in the world's fifth most-populous country. Dharsono was by far the best-known defendant in one of more than 30 subversion trials in 1985 that grew out of a September 1984 riot in Jakarta that left at least 30 dead. He was charged with signing a report that challenged the official version of the event. Another count said he attended a meeting where Moslem youths planned to retaliate for government brutality during the riot. Dharsono was sentenced in 1986 to seven years behind bars. He got time off for good behavior.

DOC.HEAD: Hinckley Loses Bid to Vote in DC Election
DOC.TEXT: Presidential assailant John W. Hinckley Jr. has been denied permission to vote in the District of Columbia where he has been confined for eight years for the 1981 shooting of President Reagan. Hinckley claimed in a petition to the DC Board of Elections that he had resided and paid taxes in the District for eight years and should be given the right to vote in the upcoming general election. But after a hearing Monday, the board rejected the petition and said a person involuntarily confined cannot change his address to the jurisdiction where he is being held. Hinckley, charged with the attempted assassination of the president, was found innocent by reason of insanity in 1982 and since has been confined at St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Washington D.C. ``He does not have the freedom or the will to adopt the District as his residence,'' said William Lewis, the board's general counsel. Hinckley has the right to vote, but must do so by absentee ballot in his home state, the board said. Hinckley grew up in Colorado, but lived in various states shortly prior to his arrest. It was not clear Monday where his legal residence would be.

Vietnam's Communist Party chief Nguyen Van Linh and two other Vietnamese leaders secretly visited China this month for talks on improving relations, Thai officials and Western diplomats said Monday. It is believed to have been the highest-level Vietnamese delegation to visit Beijing since the two countries fought a border war in 1979. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the delegation that met with Chinese Premier Li Peng included Linh, Vietnamese Prime Minister Do Muoi and Pham Van Dong, a former prime minister who is a senior advisor. In early May, Japanese officials had quoted Linh as saying he was ready to go to China to normalize relations if the Chinese invited him. In Beijing, an official of the Vietnamese Embassy on Monday denied such a visit took place. The Chinese Foreign Ministry refused to comment. A Thai government official said the two sides had met to discuss what positions they would take at the Cambodian peace talks in Jakarta, Indonesia. The talks last week produced a breakthrough agreement in which the Cambodian factions joined to form a Supreme National Council and accepted a U.N. Security Council plan as the basis for a settlement. The first session of the Supreme National Council convened Monday in Bangkok. Vietnam and China have decreased border attacks the past two years. Their deputy foreign ministers have held several rounds of talks on the war between the Vietnamese-installed government and Chinese-backed guerrillas in Cambodia. China has said the Cambodian conflict must be resolved before relations with Vietnam can be normalized. A Western diplomat in Bangkok said Monday the two countries were eager to get past the Cambodia issue so they could increase economic ties and trade, which has boomed since the border was opened two years ago. The Communist neighbors agree that the basis for a settlement should be the comprehensive peace plan, adopted Aug. 28 by the U.N. Security Council. The plan calls for heavy U.N. involvement in Cambodia before elections. They appear to still disagree, however, over how much power the government and the guerrillas should have in this interim period.

DOC.HEAD: Four Ceausescu Aides Freed Because of Failing Health
DOC.TEXT: A military court on Monday freed for health reasons four of 23 former Politburo members on trial for allegedly contributing to hundreds of deaths during last year's anti-Communist revolt. The 165-page indictment attributes the 1,033 deaths and more than 2,000 injuries during the December revolution that toppled dictator Nicolae Ceausescu to decisions taken by the group. The defendants - who face maximum sentences of life in jail in convicted - pleaded innocent to the charges, read out Monday. The five-man panel of military judges then announced that four of the 12 who had requested medical examinations will be released from prison, but will not be allowed to leave Bucharest. The judges said the four would be allowed to remain free for three months, indicating their situation would be reviewed if the trial continued past that time. The four included former Premier Constantin Dascalescu, suffering from diabetes, heart disease and spells of delirium, and former union president Miu Dobrescu, who has nervous system disorders. Th other two are Gheorghe Radulescu and Suzanna Gadea. Their ailments were not disclosed. Former Vice Premier Ion Radu was freed from jail last month for unspecified health reasons. The trial opened July 21, but has been postponed three times by requests to change the makeup of the panel of judges and by medical examinations of the accused.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Opens for Accused Wine Country Slayer

Eds, SUBS grafs 6-11 pvs, `Defense lawyer...the slayings,' with 6 grafs to CORRECT attribution of quote bgng, `Though he...,' to prosecutor sted defense attorney, CLARIFY defense and prosecution descriptions of motive. Pick up 12th graf pvs, `Salcido was...
DOC.TEXT: Two pictures of the winery worker accused in a homicidal rampage emerged in court Monday - one a brutal killer who planned nine slayings and accomplished seven, the other a heartbroken drunk fogged by ``psychotic depression.'' The prosecutor and defense attorney presented the contrasting views in opening statements at the murder trial of Ramon Salicido, who has admitted killing his wife, two of their three children, his mother-in-law, her two young daughters and a co-worker. ``The evidence will show that Ramon Salcido targeted nine people for death,'' Sonoma County Chief Deputy District Attorney Peter Bumerts said. ``He had a reason why each should die and he then set about to kill them, and it was only happenstance that saved two of them.'' Salcido also faces attempted murder charges for the throat slashing of his daughter who survived, and the shooting of a co-worker at the Grand Cru winery in Glen Ellen, in California's wine country 40 miles north of San Francisco. Neatly dressed in a gray suit, the defendant appeared to have tears in his eyes when the slayings were described. Defense attorney Marteen Miller, who concedes his client committed the killings, says Salcido should be acquitted of first-degree murder because he was incapable of planning the crimes. Miller said Salcido had been an alcoholic since the age of 18 and had consumed three grams of cocaine and three bottles of champagne in the hours before the slayings, which he said were committed while Salcido was in a ``psychotic depression.'' That state was triggered by a demand for child support from Salcido's previous wife, the prospect of losing his job and fear that his wife, Angela, would leave him, Miller said. However, Bumerts said Salcido's rage began simmering a year after his 1985 marriage when his wife told him Sofia, the daughter she was carrying at the wedding, was not his. ``Though he remained with her and fathered her two subsequent children, the anger and humiliation ... stayed with him and surfaced later on,'' he said. Bumerts said Salcido wanted to kill his in-laws because they knew he was not Sofia's father, and he wanted to kill his co-workers because he believed they were trying to get him fired. Salcido was arrested near his birthplace in Mexico within a week of the killings and confessed to authorities. His videotaped statement will play a major role in the trial, Bumerts said. Salcido is charged with fatally shooting Angela, 24, at the couple's duplex in Boyes Hot Springs and cutting the throats of their three daughters and leaving them for dead at a county dump. Sofia, 4, and Teresa, 22 months, died. Carmina, then 2, survived to tell detectives, ``Daddy cut me.'' The first witness, Timothy Smith, told of finding the girls near the quarry where he works. He discovered Sofia and Teresa first, then went back and spotted Carmina. ``I went down the embankment after her, set her on her feet and asked where her Mommy was,'' Smith said, adding that he then realized the little girl's throat ``had been cut from ear to ear.'' Salcido also is accused of fatally stabbing his mother-in-law, Marian Richards, 47, and her 12-year-old daughter, Ruth, in their home in Cotati and killing Richards' 8-year-old daughter, Marie, by cutting her throat. Salcido also is charged with fatally shooting Tracey Toovey, 35, a co-worker at the winery. Other charges include attempted murder for the attack on Carmina and for allegedly shooting co-worker Kenneth Butti and allegedly trying to shoot Butti's wife, Terri. The Buttis are among the prosecution's witnesses. Carmina, reportedly living with a Missouri family, won't appear, Bumerts says. The trial was moved from Sonoma County to San Mateo County, near San Francisco, because of extensive publicity.

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Fire Reignites After Being Declared Out
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with vessel engulfed in flames, firefighters to wait for light to renew attack on fire. Pick up 4th graf pvs, `Earlier, firefighters...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BAY2
DOC.TEXT: A gasoline tanker that exploded and burned for more than a day before being doused Monday burst back into flames hours after firefighters declared victory. ``She's engulfed there. It's the same thing as we had yesterday,'' Coast Guard Petty Officer Patrick Higgins said late Monday. He described the M.V. Jupiter as engulfed in flames about nine hours after authorities thought they had doused the fire believed to have killed one crewman. Firefighters weren't able to explain why the blaze reignited aboard the vessel moored in the Saginaw River. They planned to wait for morning to renew the battle because it would be too dangerous at night, Higgins said. Officials had pronounced fire extinguished about 1:30 p.m. Monday. The explosions and fire that broke out Sunday morning killed one of the ship's 18 crew members and left three hospitalized in fair condition. Earlier, firefighters from Boots & Coots, a Houston firm specializing in petroleum blazes, knocked down the flames by dousing them with water and fire-retardant foam from the decks of a Coast Guard ship. Cleanup crews put sponge-like material in the water to prevent gasoline from seeping into the river, said Clay Evans, spokesman for the Spill Control Association of America, an industry spill-response group. Evans said a small amount of gasoline leaked into the river, which was closed to boaters Monday. Dave Usher, president of Marine Pollution Control in Detroit, said Monday that a few thousand feet of absorbent padding and booms about 10 inches thick were at the site. ``It's under control, but there's always a danger,'' Usher said of a potential gasoline spill.. The Michigan Department of Natural Resources conducted water and air contamination tests. Thick smoke blanketed the area until the fire was doused. Hundreds of dead shad, walleye and perch washed ashore as far away as a half-mile from the tanker, said Terry Walkington, a department spokesman. ``There was some fish lost, we don't know if it was the explosion, or if it was from the heat that caused stress on the fish,'' said Mike Moore, department deputy director. Preliminary water tests showed no heavy concentrations of gasoline or oil, said David Hales, director of the natural resources department. ``We won't be able to get a detailed analysis until later this week,'' he said. Spilled gasoline was unlikely to have long-term effects on fish because it evaporates rapidly, Walkington said. The tanker - owned by Cleveland Tankers Inc., a subsidiary of Ashland Oil Inc. - was ripped by an explosion Sunday morning as it unloaded its cargo of unleaded gasoline at Bay City's Total Refinery Dock Facility. The first blast was followed by explosions in each of the ship's remaining five cargo holds. The Jupiter had unloaded about 30,000 barrels of its 54,000-barrel cargo when the blast occurred, said Dan Lacy, spokesman for Ashland, which is based in Ashland, Ky. Investigators were unsure what caused the fire. One possibility was that the wake of a passing ship could have parted some of the Jupiter's mooring lines and its gasoline connection, spilling fuel that ignited and caused the blast, Lacy said. Ashland spokesman Tom Dalesio said a small quantity of gasoline leaked into the river shortly after the explosion, but had evaporated or been burned off by the intense flames. Damage to the Jupiter won't be assessed until the tanker cools enough for investigators to board and inspect, possibly as early as Tuesday, said Tom Dalesio, another Ashland spokesman. The missing crewman, Tom Sexton, 46, of Iowa, was believed to have died while swim toward shore, state police spokesman Robert Nelson said.

DOC.HEAD: New York Teen-Ager Charged With Killing Mom's Mugger
DOC.TEXT:
A teen-ager who stalked a street thug accused of mugging his mother was charged with manslaughter Monday after he allegedly tracked the thief to a drug-plagued park and stabbed him.
Victor Lopez, 18, of the Bronx allegedly stabbed 25-year-old Lazara O'Farrill three times early Saturday, police Lt. Michael Bramble said. Maria Lopez said O'Farrill stole two gold chains and reached into her blouse to see if she was hiding money in her brassiere. ``The young man was trying to avenge his mother's mugging,'' Bramble said. ``Basically, someone took the law into their own hands. Instead of coming to the police, they acted irrationally and emotionally.'' A tourist from Utah was killed earlier this month when he tried to defend his mother from muggers on a Manhattan subway platform. Mrs. Lopez, 37, said she was approached by two men and mugged by O'Farrill as she walked to the subway on her way to work. ``I screamed, I was nervous, I called 911, then I followed one of them,'' she said, adding that she then called home and told her sons Victor and Raymond, 21, what had happened. ``I feel guilty,'' she sobbed. ``If I hadn't called my son, this wouldn't have happened.'' O'Farrill was notorious in the neighborhood for strong-arm robberies, she alleged. ``Mostly everybody had been mugged by him, even people in his own building,'' Mrs. Lopez said, adding that he belonged to a gang known as ``Los Machoteros,'' or the machete-wielders. ``The detectives told me that even his mother said she expected this to happen,'' she said. Mrs. Lopez talked her son into surrendering after two area teen-agers were arrested and charged with the killing. ``I believed it wasn't right,'' she said. ``I told him there's no need to be hiding.'' Lopez was arraigned in Bronx Criminal Court on one manslaughter count and one count of criminal possession of a weapon. His remained in jail with bond set at $5,000. The sons found O'Farrill's alleged accomplice, who told them he only tagged along when O'Farrill mugged their mother for money to buy crack, police said. The sons spent an hour looking for O'Farrill before they found him at drug-plagued St. Mary's Park. As they approached, O'Farrill swore at them and ``tried to pull something from his waist, and that's when my son stabbed him in the arm,'' Mrs. Lopez said. O'Farrill died of loss of blood from stab wounds to the chest, arm and leg, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the medical examiner. ``I never knew a killing would happen, all we wanted to do was to take them to the police,'' Mrs. Lopez said.

DOC.HEAD: US Negotiator Says Days Of Bases Coming To An End
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with talks resuming; Pickup 6th, `The two...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MLA7,8
DOC.TEXT:
U.S. and Philippine officials opened talks Tuesday on the future of U.S. military bases, and the chief American negotiator said the days of a large U.S. military presence here ``are coming to an end.'' ``What remains for us to determine is the rate at which this presence will be reduced and the nature of the relationship our two governments wish to pursue,'' chief U.S. negotiator Richard Armitage told the opening session. U.S. and Philippine panels resumed the talks that began last May on the future of Clark Air Base, the Subic Bay naval base and four smaller installations. The lease on the bases expires in Sept. 1991, and President Corazon Aquino says it is time to discuss the ``orderly withdrawal'' of the 40,000 American troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents stationed here. ``It is clear to me that the days of a very large presence of U.S. sailors and airmen in the Philippines are coming to an end,'' Armitage said in his opening remarks. On Monday, police clashed with hundreds of demonstrators who demanded that the Americans go home. At least 17 people were arrested and seven people were injured in two anti-bases rallies outside the U.S. Embassy. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Monday in Washington the Bush administration hoped any new acccord would ``include provisions for a continuing defense relationship, including U.S. access to Philippine military facilities.''
The two sides agreed during the opening round in May to continue talks on a new U.S.-Philippine security agreement. Opposition to the bases is growing among Filipinos who consider them an infringement on national sovereignty. On the eve of the talks, Mrs. Aquino said in a nationally televised address that the negotiations will redefine relations between the United States and this former American colony. ``It is now necessary for our government to work with the United States for arrangements regarding the orderly withdrawal of their forces from our country,'' she said. Last Friday, The Washington Post reported that U.S. negotiators will offer to close the bases over 10 years. Manila newspapers reported last month that the Philippines will propose that Clark Air Base and other facilities be closed next year in return for allowing the Americans to keep Subic for 10 years. U.S. officials said the 40,000 American troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents will remain as long as they are wanted. The installations are among the largest American bases on foreign soil. ``In a world where the Cold War has ended, and events in Eastern Europe and the Middle East have altered the traditional geopolitical order, the decades-old parameters of the (Philippine-U.S.) relationship no longer hold,'' Mrs. Aquino said. ``The old cannot continue; the new must now be born,'' she added. ``This new relationship shall be the subject of the talks that begin tomorrow.'' Rafael Alunan, the spokesman of the Philippine panel, said Manila wanted the talks ``to restructure our relations to cover a broad range of concerns.'' ``For us, there is more to life than security matters, and that is what we have to impress upon them,'' Alunan said. Mrs. Aquino also noted that a government panel is working on plans to convert the bases into civlian use. The panel is expected to finish its report next month. Any new agreement must be approved by two-thirds of the 23-member Philippine Senate, where opposition to the facilities is strong. U.S. troops have been restricted to their bases to prevent attacks by Communist rebels. In May, two American airmen were killed outside Clark on the eve of the first round of talks. Early Monday, about 350 protesters marched to the U.S. Embassy but were driven away by police after some in the crowd hurled small bombs. A judge and two policemen were injured and three demonstrators were arrested. Later, about 1,000 protesters returned, but police again blocked their march about 200 yards from the embassy. At least 14 more were arrested and at least three demonstrators and a policeman were hospitalized for blast wounds. Col. Ricardo Reyes, Manila police operations chief, said the demonstrators provoked the second clash when they tried to break the police line.

DOC.HEAD: Two Families Produce Winning Tickets in $106 Million Lotto
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, `Her brother...,' to correct name to Scott sted Chuck; INSERTS 1 graf after 18th pvs, `Piasecki and...,' to UPDATE with background on former auto worker, plans to buy house. Pick up 19th graf pvs, `The holders...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto TD1
DOC.TEXT: One lucky player trembled so much when she heard she won a share of a $106.5 million Lotto jackpot that she dropped her ticket. Another ran outside in her bathrobe, screaming ``We're rich! We're rich!'' Two winning ticket holders in the nation's second-richest lottery drawing came forward Monday. Both planned to share the wealth with family members - one group having gone so far as to create a legal partnership in case they won. Six winning tickets were sold for $1 each. Each is now worth $887,500 a year, before taxes, for 20 years. Kathy Smith of Longwood said when she realized Sunday morning she had a ticket with all six numbers, ``I shook so bad I dropped the ticket.'' She said she picked the winning numbers - 5-6-21-34-35-45 - at random. She will get one-fourth of the $17.75 million individual winner's share, with her brother and mother receiving equal cuts and seven others splitting the final 25 percent. Her brother, Scott, a Tampa accountant, came up with the partnership idea and he and the others - mainly relatives - entered into the formal agreement last week. Together the group bought 50 tickets. The other winner to come forward was Richard J. Piasecki, a retired auto worker originally from Kenosha, Wis. ``We told our landlady and then she wanted to feel it and she started rubbing it and I grabbed it out of her hands,'' Piasecki said laughing. ``She said she wanted to rub it for luck.'' He said he's sharing his cut with his two children. His daughter, Mary Jo Bednarski, met her husband with the news by running into the driveway of their Wisconsin home in her bathrobe yelling ``We're rich! We're rich!'' Mrs. Bednarski, who has four children, said she'll quit her job at a Hardee's restaurant. ``This is my notice,'' she said at a news conference, adding the family was considering moving to Florida. The families said they weren't disappointed with the cut of the near-record jackpot. Pennsylvania posted the record in April 1989 with a $115 million jackpot. ``Who needs $106 million?'' asked Pat Landry, Ms. Smith's mother. Mrs. Landry, 54, of Sorrento said she'd quit her job at Seminole Community College, but planned no big spending sprees. ``I don't want my life to change,'' she said. ``I'm quite pleased with my life, very pleased with my life. Don't get me wrong. I wouldn't turn this down but I mean, this is frosting on the cake.'' Ms. Smith, 34, said she wouldn't quit her nursing job because she loved her work, but planned to buy a car and some land for horses. Her 35-year-old brother said he would continue to work, adding he'd ``prudently invest ... maybe buy a few things.'' Piasecki and his wife, Jeanne, of New Smyrna Beach, will divide their money into thirds to share with their two children. Piasecki took early retirement after working 32 years as a body repairman when 5,300 Chrysler employees were laid off by a plant closing in Dec. 1988. The couple, who have lived in a rented mobile home since moving to New Smyrna Beach last year, plan to buy a small home with a little land. The holders of the four other winning tickets have 180 days to claim their prizes. The tickets were sold in Miami, Winter Haven, Coconut Creek and Venice. Piasecki said he ``almost died'' after going through his 30 tickets right after Saturday night's drawing. A few minutes later he called his daughter. ``He yelled `We're millionaires!'' Mrs. Bednarski said. ``And I said `This is sick.' I thought he was playing a joke. My brother got on the phone and started yelling `It's true, it's true!''' Her brother, Richard Piasecki of New Smyrna Beach, also plans to quit his job as a print pressman. The elder Piasecki retired from Chrysler Corp. in 1988 after 32 years as a body repairman. He and his wife, who moved to New Smyrna Beach last year and live in a rented mobile home, plan to buy a small home with a little land. The couple, who own a motor home, also plan to buy a bigger motor home and a boat. Mrs. Piasecki said the couple will travel. Mrs. Piasecki said winning made her eat her words. ``I don't believe in gambling,'' she said, adding that she ``fussed at my husband every time he bought some tickets.''

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of Sept. 10-17:
DOC.HEAD: AP Board Approves 3.9 Percent Rate Increase
DOC.TEXT: The board of directors of The Associated Press has approved a general assessment increase of 3.9 percent for its 1,538 daily and weekly newspaper members and 5,800 broadcast members, effective Jan. 20, 1991. William J. Keating, chairman of the AP board of directors and chairman and publisher of The Cincinnati Enquirer, said the assessment increase, in percentage terms, was the lowest in three years. ``Mindful of the difficult times that confront much of the industry at this stage, the board approved a rate increase that is well below the projected inflation rate for 1990 and 1991,'' Keating said. The 3.9 percent increase will not cover all of the increases and new costs faced by AP. AP will continue to meet the growing demands of the news industry through a vigorous cost control effort and by increasing non-traditional revenue sources, Keating said. Non-traditional sources now make up 24 percent of AP's revenue. Eleven years ago that figure was 7 percent. ``Of the new money that AP needs to fund 1991 operations and continue to improve services, only 31 cents of every dollar will come from the assessment increase,'' Keating said. ``It is vital to all of us that our cooperative remain strong and able to meet the challenges in news coverage and technology,'' Keating said. ``Even as some members reduce their own activity to absorb the impact of a difficult year in the industry, demands on the AP grow as we look to AP to do things that, in a healthier time, we might not have relied on AP to do.'' The general assessment increase will be combined with another step in the phase-in of the circulation-based newspaper formula for those members that have not reached their appropriate assessment level. The 1991 assessment also will reflect any circulation changes at the member newspaper. The assessment increase applies to all basic services for both newspapers and broadcasters and to all supplemental services except for the rates for financial market tables, which are being adjusted downward in two steps in 1990 and 1991 to reflect savings achieved in producing computer-generated stock lists. AP members will receive their new weekly assessment figures by early October, Keating said.
DOC.HEAD: New York Post Faces Live-or-Die Vote
DOC.TEXT: News and advertising employees at the New York Post were to vote the evening of Sept. 17 on whether the nation' oldest daily would live or die. Owner Peter Kalikow said if members of the Newspaper Guild did not agree to a four-day week - meaning a loss of one day's pay - he would close immediately, putting 960 people out of work. The 505,000-circulation paper is losing $27 million a year. On Sept. 14, unions at the paper agreed to $19 million in concessions. Guild negotiators rejected Kalikow's offer 7-3, but the guild president endorsed it and decided to let the members decide. The union's 352 editorial and advertising workers were voting on whether to accept a 20 percent pay cut and the elimination of 43 jobs. Punctuated by a big question mark and a picture of the presses, the front page headline Sept. 17 was possibly the 189-year-old newspaper's last: ``WILL THE POST PRESSES EVER RUN AGAIN?'' In a story inside, Editor Jerry Nachman was asked how he would feel if the Post folded. ``How did the captain of the Titanic feel?'' he asked. ``I think we will get through this tonight because the alternative is unthinkable,'' Nachman said. A 23{-year composing room veteran, who declined to give his name as he arrived at work, said: ``It's more than a job. It's part of your life. It's part of the life of the city.'' If the Post lives, workers will get 20 percent of company stock and a representative on the board of directors, union leaders said. Kalikow bought the money-losing tabloid from Rupert Murdoch two years ago after wringing $24 million in concesssions from the unions.

DOC.HEAD: Reuters Employees Authorize Strike; No Deadline Set
DOC.TEXT: U.S. employees of the Reuters news agency authorized their union leadership to call a strike against the company, the Newspaper Guild of New York said. Guild members voted by a larger than 20-1 margin for the authorization after contract talks that began nearly a year ago failed to result in an agreement. The Guild represents nearly 500 employees, including 150 journalists. In a Sept. 10 news release, the Guild blamed the failing talks on ``Reuters' demands that it substantially raise the cost to employees for their health insurance'' while cutting maternity benefits and severance pay. Andrew Nibley, Reuters' editor responsible for North America and Latin America, refused to discuss details of the negotiations while they are in progress. ``I would say that all major U.S. corporations are dealing with the whole issue of spiraling health care costs and how they can be contained. We think that our salaries are quite competitive and among the best in the industry,'' he said. ``I don't think a strike would be in anyone's interest and I certainly hope it doesn't come to that,'' he added. The Guild represents journalists, technicians, computer operators, sales support staff, customer service and clerical employees. The last contract expired in February. Salaries at Reuters range from $680.75 to $840.75 a week for reporters. Correspondents can make up to $996.32, and salaries for technicians range from $694.51 to $727.51.
DOC.HEAD: UPI Closing Bureaus in Five States
DOC.TEXT: United Press International is closing bureaus in five states as part of a general staff realignment. Spokesman Milt Capps confirmed a report in The Albuquerque (N.M.) Tribune that bureaus in New Mexico, Wyoming and Montana would be closed. He declined to say how many layoffs were involved. Capps also said UPI had given notice to staffers in one-person bureaus in Grand Rapids, Mich., and Bismarck, N.D. He said the news service was expanding its stringer networks in the affected states ``and working on a number of joint ventures with people in the regions for additional coverage.''
