UPI is ``taking quite a few steps this summer and fall to realign our staffing in the wake of our creation of a number of new autonomous editorial units,'' he said. ``The upshot is that virtually every bureau in the system worldwide is affected either by increases or decreases.'' Capps declined to discuss whether any future closures are planned or how many bureaus UPI now operates in the United States. Last month he confirmed a Washington Post report that 31 UPI reporters and editors were being laid off. Capps said there will be net increases in staffing in such areas as sports, business and finance and emphasis on UPI's joint ventures with cable TV's Financial News Network, States News Service and Financial World Magazine. ``We are developing what we think is a new role for UPI after 83 years which entails not only strong general news service but increased emphasis on focused news reports that can command a premium in the marketplace, including media and corporate subscribers,'' he said. ``The bottom line is we can now say we have more people writing for UPI across the board than a year ago,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: Court Approves Distribution of Book on Israeli Spy Operation
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court lifted a ban on publication of a book about Israel's secret service, reversing a judge's order to halt distribution at the request of Israel. Israel's claim that the book endangers its intelligence agents ``has not been sufficiently supported,'' the Appellate Division of New York Supreme Court ruled unanimously Sept. 13. The day before, Judge Michael Dontzin had issued a temporary restraining order barring St. Martin's Press from distributing the book, titled ``By Way of Deception: The Making and Unmaking of a Mossad Officer.'' The Israeli government filed a lawsuit claiming the book could imperil agents of the spy agency, known as Mossad, by blowing their cover. The book was written by Victor Ostrovsky, who says he was a Mossad agent for four years in the 1980s. He said in the book that Israel had detailed information about preparations for the bombing that killed 241 Marines in Lebanon in 1983 but gave the United States only a vague warning so that U.S.-Arab relations would be damaged. The publisher said it would start sending the book to bookstores again. ``We think it's a victory for a free press and we are going to sell the book again,'' said Roy Gainsburg, president of St. Martin's. ``Orders have increased dramatically, which is what always happens when you try to stop a book.''

DOC.HEAD: Florida To Start Collecting Newspaper Sales Tax Dec. 9
DOC.TEXT: Florida will begin collecting sales tax on newspapers Dec. 9 following a state Supreme Court ruling that ended an exemption. The 6 percent state tax plus any local option taxes will be collected on sales and subscriptions and will raise $25.7 million a year, Tom Herndon, director of the Department of Revenue, said Sept. 13. The Supreme Court on May 31 rejected an attempt by magazine publishers to obtain the same exemption that was enjoyed by newspapers. The court then went a step further and voided the exemption entirely. A services tax that was enacted in 1987 included both magazines and newspapers, but when the services tax was repealed the sales tax was extended only to magazines. The justices ruled the imbalance was an encroachment on the First Amendment's freedom of the press protections.
DOC.HEAD: Desert Deployment Spawns Two Newspapers; Radios for the Troops
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. military is handing out radios and more newspapers to GIs hungry for news, but it's not printing or broadcasting anything the strictly Moslem government could deem religious or racy. In the early weeks of the deployment, troops often asked visitors to send copies of local newspapers, saying they knew little about their mission or the situation back home. Operation Desert Shield since has spawned two newspapers, the Desert Defender and the Desert Dragon, as well as several more informal newsletters. The military distributed portable radios by the dozens at base camps last week, so the troops can hear Armed Forces radio and local English-language broadcasts. The radios were distributed after the military made sure that none of the broadcasts include religious programming or gospel music. ``We are being very sensitive to the culture of the host country,'' Army Col. Rick Kiernan said. ``We want to get the troops music, information and sports programming but we also want to be good guests.'' A transmitter was recently installed in Saudi Arabia to relay the radio, and Armed Force television also is available in some areas where U.S. troops are housed in military housing or hotels.
DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards Former Race Promoters $13.6 Million
DOC.TEXT: The Plain Dealer lost a $13.6 million libel suit to former promoters of the Budweiser Cleveland Grand Prix, who said they were defamed by stories in the newspaper in 1984-86. The plaintiffs had asked for $16 million in damages. Publisher Alex Machaskee said the newspaper will appeal the Sept. 14 verdict. C.K. Newcomb and Associates, along with Charles K. Newcomb and James H. Foster, promoted the event starting with the first race, in 1982. A week before the 1984 race the newspaper published a story saying Newcomb and Foster paid themselves nearly $1 million from race proceeds in violation of a lease they had with the city. The articles also said the race did not satisfy rent payments to the city because Newcomb and Foster told the city the race was deeply in debt. Lawyers for The Plain Dealer argued during the eight-week trial that the primary points of the articles were true. The plaintiffs argued that the race in fact lost money its first two years and that the articles were false. Newcomb and Foster sold the rights to the race in March 1985 to businessman and former race car driver Roger Penske, and The Plain Dealer later became co-sponsor of the event.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Trademark Infringement Suit by Pop Group
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge dismissed a trademark infringement action brought by New Kids On The Block, a pop group that sued USA Today and Star magazine for using their name in telephone surveys. U.S. District Judge William J. Rea ruled Sept. 10 that the use of 900 toll numbers to gauge popularity of the group was a news gathering activity and therefore protected by the First Amendment. USA Today asked readers who their favorite New Kid was and Star asked readers who they thought was the sexiest New Kid. Each phone vote had a fee. The New Kids' lawyer, Philip Heller, said he would appeal. ``While we recognize the importance of the First Amendment, we disagree with Judge Rea's application of it in this case,'' Heller said. Heller said 900 numbers are commercial services. ``And the First Amendment does not protect the use of another's trademark and likeness to further commercial ventures, even if a newspaper is involved,'' he said. He said the 900 polls competed with the group's own 900 hotline by using pictures of the singing group and their name.
DOC.HEAD: Judge Lifts No-Notes Rule for Reporters
DOC.TEXT: A judge decided to allow reporters to take notes in his courtroom, prompting Philadelphia's two daily newspapers to drop a legal challenge. Common Pleas Court Judge Eugene E.J. Maier signed an order Sept. 11 lifting the prohibition. He earlier had said he felt note-taking could distract a jury and undercut the official record of a court proceeding. ``After I had given further thought to it, I don't think it offends me, and we shouldn't keep on with it as long as we could control the matter in another way,'' Maier said. He said he might ask reporters to sit in a part of the courtroom where jurors cannot see them. Philadelphia Newspapers Inc., publisher of The Philadelphia Inquirer and the Philadelphia Daily News, dropped its appeal of the ban, which had been pending in state Superior Court. The case arose when Daily News reporter Joseph P. Blake was ordered by a court officer last month to stop taking notes during a murder trial. Two Inquirer reporters on separate days also were prevented from taking notes. ``There has been a gut feeling that note taking should not be permitted,'' the judge told an attorney for the newspapers, according to a transcript of an Aug. 20 meeting in his chambers. ``It may set up a method by which the official transcript can be tested or can be impeached, should we say, or at least contradicted,'' Maier said. A jury could be swayed ``to give greater attention to some testimony rather than other testimony,'' because a person took notes, he said. The newspapers said in their appeal the rule violated federal and state constitutional rights of reporters to cover criminal trials ``as surrogates for the public.'' After lifting his ban, the judge said he would continue to prohibit note-taking by members of the public who are not media representatives and would reserve the right to ban note-taking by reporters. ``A judge is like the captain of a ship,'' he said. ``The judge has to control the courtroom. The worst thing that can happen is that you don't have that control.''
DOC.HEAD: Boston Globe Declines To Endorse Any Candidates
DOC.TEXT: The Boston Globe decided not to endorse any contender for statewide office in the Sept. 18 primary election, announcing in an editorial that ``the resource of leadership is severely depleted.'' The Sept. 13 editorial said that Massachusetts faces political and economic perils and that there had been ``politics-as-usual bombast'' among the candidates. The Globe criticized both Republican gubernatorial candidates for taking ``irresponsible'' positions by supporting a November ballot question that would sharply roll back state taxes and fees. On the Democratic side, the editorial said, ``John Silber seemed on paper to be an ideal profile for voters yearning for a new era.'' ``Campaigns, however, are waged not on paper but on personality,'' the Globe said. ``If voters were judging Silber on a report card, his mark on `Works well with others' would not be high.'' Francis X. Bellotti, a former attorney general, offers associations with the era of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Columbus Dispatch Seeks Ruling on Gag Order
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys for The Columbus Dispatch asked the U.S. Supreme Court to rule on a gag order issued in a juvenile court custody case and upheld by the Ohio Supreme Court. ``Without guidance from this Court, state courts have developed conflicting approaches to the Constitution's role in ensuring public access to juvenile court,'' said the writ filed Sept. 11 on behalf of Dispatch Printing Co., which publishes the Dispatch. The writ said judges should have to consider First Amendment issues along with other evidence when they issue a gag order or close a custody case to the public. Judge Ronald Solove of Franklin County Juvenile Court issued gag and closure orders last year in a three-way custody fight by two would-be adoptive parents and the surrogate mother of Tessa Reams, now 5. An appeals court reversed Solove's order but the Ohio Supreme Court then upheld the order. The high court said juvenile proceedings are not presumed to be open and can be closed whenever a judge determines the psychological harm the publicity might cause the child outweighs the public's interest in the case. The court said First Amendment rights did not have to be considered. Solove has since reversed his decision, but the Ohio Supreme Court ruling still stands. The Dispatch's lawyers argued in court papers that the state Supreme Court's ruling ``missed the mark'' by relying on ``out-of-context snippets from unrelated decisions.'' They also said the state court ``misconceived the nature'' of the First Amendment.
DOC.HEAD: Indiana Appeals Court Rules Records Open to Public
DOC.TEXT: The Indianapolis Convention and Visitors Association must open its financial records because it receives substantial public financing, the Indiana Court of Appeals said. The Sept. 11 decision upheld a county court ruling in favor of The Indianapolis News and its parent company, Indianapolis Newspapers Inc. The convention bureau had argued it wasn't a public agency subject to the state's Public Records Act. It said forcing it to open its records ``will have far-reaching negative consequences'' for similarly situated groups that do business with government. But the appeals panel concluded the public has a right to know how its money is being spent by such organizations. ``ICVA receives approximately 70 percent of its revenue from public funds. Therefore, the Legislature has entitled the public to review the expenditure of those funds,'' Appeals Judge Linda Chezem wrote. ``Clearly, the Legislature intended the public to have the right to investigate whether its tax money was properly spent.'' According to court records, the association is a group of about 600 members interested in promoting and advertising Indianapolis as a site for conventions, cultural and sports events, trade shows and tourist visits.
DOC.HEAD: Alternative Baptist News Agency Formed
DOC.TEXT: Dissident Southern Baptists have formed an alternative to the group's news agency that will be run in part by a Gannett executive, a communications professor and the news editor of People magazine. Leaders of the new Associated Baptist Press began organizing the news agency Sept. 11. The move is in response to the firing this summer of the two top editors of the Baptist Press, the denomination's longtime news agency. The firings came during a closed meeting of the Southern Baptist Convention's Executive Committee and further fueled a debate over freedom of speech and access to information within the nation's largest Protestant denomination. Conservative Baptists accused the fired editors, Al Shackleford and Dan Martin, of being biased toward the moderates in their reporting. Moderate Baptists, on the other hand, believe Baptist Press now will become a closely controlled public relations agency for the conservative-dominated Southern Baptist Convention. ``I think the free flow of information goes to the bedrock belief of the Baptist faith,'' said Charles Overby, president of the Gannett Publishing Foundation in Washington. Overby, a Southern Baptist layman who is a member of the 15-member board of the new agency, said Baptists have a tradition of free speech. ``That is how Baptists came to be, so the ABP is rooted in the history of Baptists, and I believe that the work of this organization will be consistent with the needs of Baptist people to stay informed,'' he said. Shackleford is also a member of the board of the new ABP. Other board members include Carl L. Kell, professor of communication and broadcasting at Western Kentucky University; Hal Wingo, news editor of People magazine; Raymond McDaniel, retired editor of The Shreveport (La.) Times; and Catherine Allen of Samford University in Alabama. Bob Terry, editor of the Missouri state Baptist newspaper, presided over the meeting and warned that the new organization should not be identified as a ``moderate Baptist'' news agency. Rather, he hopes it will be regarded as an uncensored source of information for Southern Baptists. Matters of financing and personnel are yet to be worked out, but leaders hope the new press can start functioning this fall.

DOC.HEAD: PBS To Provide TV Show Listings Through For-Profit Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: A subsidiary of the Public Broadcasting Service and another company said Sept. 11 they would launch a nationwide system to transmit television show listings to viewers' homes to help set videocassette recorders. The system would send the TV listings in the ``vertical blanking interval,'' the empty space in a television signal that is seen as a black bar when a TV picture rolls. The system from PBS National Datacast, a for-profit PBS subsidiary, and InSight Telecast would provide subscribers with detailed on-screen TV show schedule information that could be used to set a VCR through the use of a special device, the companies said. The system is expected to be available in early 1992, the companies said. National Datacast says it has been using the vertical blanking interval to send information, such as stock quotes and credit card verification data, since 1984. InSight is a provider of TV listings.
DOC.HEAD: Police Agree To Apologize in Dispute With Student Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: Police agreed to apologize and reprimand an officer who confiscated a camera from the editor of the Western Michigan University student newspaper. Nik Kalyani of the Western Herald filed a formal complaint against Officer Thomas Miles of the Kalamazoo Township Police Department. Kalyani said he was photographing police officers as they patrolled the city on Sept. 7. When he snapped a shot of an officer writing a ticket, Miles approached him and took the camera. Kalyani says Miles took the camera back to his patrol car and opened it, exposing and ruining the film. Police Chief Richard Butler agreed Sept. 11 to reprimand Miles and order that Kalyani be given a letter of apology.
DOC.HEAD: Fremont County Newspaper Ceases Publication
DOC.TEXT: The weekly Fremont Observer, started three years ago by several people associated with a tax protest group, will close because of lawsuits, Publisher Grover K. Wilkerson said. ``We don't have any choice,'' Wilkerson said. ``It's costing too much money in lawsuits. We can't afford supplies, we can't afford to print and people won't deal with us because of the lawsuits.'' The newspaper targeted public officials in articles penned my nameless writers or those using pseudonyms such as ``Pauline Fearless.'' Wilkerson said the last edition was printed Aug. 28. At one time the paper's circulation reached 1,400 and it employed 12 people. Four people lost jobs when the paper folded. Wilkerson said the paper had been hit with ``four to five lawsuits'' within the last year. Two of those were filed by former District Judge Paul Keohane and former Canon City Administrator Errol Snider. ``They were all public officials,'' said Wilkerson. ``Anytime you challenge government, they put these slap suits on you. . . . We're just a controversial newspaper and they can't stand that.'' Keohane, who says he was voted out of office because of a cartoon and articles printed in the Observer, said the closure of the paper would not affect his lawsuit, set for trial in July 1991. ``I suspected this would happen,'' said Keohane, who now practices law in Canon City. ``I'd say this is probably good for the community. I'm glad to hear it.'' Keohane filed the suit a year ago claiming the Observer printed a cartoon that insinuated he was a drug user. He also said he was defamed by seven articles printed in October and November 1988 involving his ruling in a sexual assault case.
DOC.HEAD: Desert Sun Co. Buys Coachella Valley Weeklies
DOC.TEXT: Desert Sun Publishing Co. has purchased a group of weekly publications serving several Coachella Valley communities from Brehm Communications Inc. The company, which is owned by Gannett Co. Inc. and publishes The Desert Sun in Palm Springs, bought Desert Community Newspaper Group and Sentinel Newspapers. Terms of the sale were not disclosed in the Sept. 10 announcement. Newspapers in the deal include the Post newspapers serving Cathedral City, Palm Desert, Rancho Mirage, Indian Wells, La Quinta and Kind and the Desert Sentinel and Lo-Desert Shopper serving Desert Hot Springs.

DOC.HEAD: New York Officials Respond to Story
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins' aides are attempting to show that a Time magazine story and poll that portrayed the city as a declining metropolis were misleading. Press secretary Albert Scardino said Time had made a ``gross misrepresentation of its own data to let New Yorkers paint a negative view of themselves.'' ``The fact is, the overwhelming majority are proud of their city,'' he said. ``They came here for great opportunities and still have them, despite the problems.'' The magazine reported that 73 percent of 1,009 city residents interviewed Aug. 2-5 said they thought New York was dangerous and that 59 percent said they would move somewhere else if they could. But it did not report that 70 percent thought the city was exciting or that 78 percent of the respondents described their neighbors as friendly. Jennifer Hillings Epstein, a Time spokeswoman, said the article was neither misrepresentative nor unfair. ``We used the news from the poll,'' she said. ``We're a news magazine, and we used the news.'' The poll, conducted for Time and the Cable News Network by Yankelovich Clancy Shulman, had a margin of error of three percentage points.
DOC.HEAD: Gannett Television President Is First Black Augusta Member
DOC.TEXT: Ron Townsend, president of Gannett Television, has become the first black member of the Augusta National Golf Club. Townsend, who oversees six Gannett television stations, said Sept. 11 that his acceptance had nothing to do with the racial controversy that raged at last month's PGA Championship. Racial policies became an issue in golf after news reports that Shoal Creek Country Club near Birmingham, Ala., site of the PGA Championship, had no black members. Townsend said his membership in the Augusta club, site of the annual Masters tournament, came up five or six weeks earlier in a meeting in Washington. ``I had a meeting there with members of Augusta National, which was prompted by the chairman of our company, John Curley, who mentioned my name to some folks,'' he said. ``It was around the same time as Shoal Creek, but they made it clear that it (accepting a black) had been discussed months before,'' said Townsend. ``It's conceivable that the Shoal Creek thing put in on the front burner, but it was not a direct result of that.''
DOC.HEAD: Paper, Citizens Oppose Protective Order
DOC.TEXT: ThermalKem Inc. wants a protective order that would keep environmental groups from releasing any information they get from documents or tours of the company's facilities. ThermalKem attorney Richard Willis said company officials asked for the order to protect trade secrets and employee confidentiality and to prevent a repeat of statements made by citizens after a tour of ThermalKem's facility in 1989. After that tour, members of the group said they became ill at the plant. The environmental groups and The Herald newspaper of Rock Hill are opposing the order. Robert Guild, a lawyer for Citizens for Clean Air and Water of Rock Hill and Environmentalists Inc. of Columbia, said the order would shield broad classes of information from being released from the facility and would reduce public access. The environmental groups are challenging approval of a permit for ThermalKem's existing incinerator by South Carolina's Department of Health and Environmental Control. Ron Stanley, appointed to hear an administrative appeal of ThermalKem's permit, is considering the order, which would prohibit the groups from discussing what they learn from subpoenaed documents obtained as part of the hearing. It also would restrict the groups from discussing what they see during a tour of the company's hazardous waste incinerator in southwestern Rock Hill. Stanley had ordered ThermalKem to schedule the plant visit by the end of September and complete the release of documents to the groups by Oct. 15. James M. Brailsford III, attorney for The Herald, asked Stanley to schedule a special hearing. He said a hearing was necessary to ``determine that the restraint is essential and that less-restrictive alternatives would not be effective.''

DOC.HEAD: New Mexico Court Won't Interfere in Photo Order
DOC.TEXT: The state Supreme Court on Sept. 12 let stand a lower court order that the Albuquerque Journal turn over photographic negatives of a fatal highway accident for use in a lawsuit. A panel of three justices rejected without comment the newspaper's request to nullify the order. The negatives are sought by Ford Motor Co. and John Barton, whose 62-year-old wife was killed in 1985 when her car collided with a truck near Santa Fe. Barton sued the automaker, alleging a defect in the car caused the head-on crash. Ford issued a subpoena for the photographs and negatives in July. The company said they are essential in determining the liability issues in the case. State District Judge Art Encinias ruled Sept. 4 that the Journal's constitutional privilege to protect its news gathering did not outweigh the need for the pictures. He ordered the negatives turned over within 10 days. The Journal argued it had a First Amendment privilege to withhold the unpublished photographs and protect its right to freely gather news. Jim Dines, a lawyer for the Journal, told the justices in a hearing Sept. 12 that the issue was ``a very important constitutional matter that involves the freedom of the press.'' Dines said he had reviewed 10 court cases from various states on similar issues and that in seven of them photographs were found to be ``qualifiedly privileged'' and were not required to be turned over. He also argued that the 46 negatives were not necessary to determine the precise location of the scene of the Nov. 12, 1985, accident, because that information was available elsewhere. Charles Peifer, an attorney for Ford, which teamed with Barton to obtain the photos, said the litigants wanted to determine the position of the vehicles relative to one another and whether debris at the site had come off the vehicles before the accident or as a result of impact. That information cannot be obtained from the picture the Journal published, which the newspaper provided to the litigants, or from any other sources, Peifer said.
DOC.HEAD: Illinois Newspaper Ends `Doe Watch'
DOC.TEXT: Police eliminated the Doe Gang without firing a single shot. For 17 days, the Pekin Daily Times blamed nearly every crime in this Illinois River city on John, Jane and assorted other Does to protest the police department's refusal to identify people arrested. Police agreed to reveal the names and the newspaper's Doe Watch has come to an end. ``The Doe family was a ficticious creation of the police as a way to shield the names of people arrested each day,'' said Kent R. Davy, the Times' managing editor. Police Chief Jack Leuck scrapped the secrecy policy Sept. 4, allowing the Times to print the names of everyone arrested daily after city lawyers advised him the department might be violating state law. Leuck, a retired FBI agent, said he took over a year ago and was told the policy had been in effect at least 15 years. He said the police changed suspects' names to Doe to protect anyone who was not formally charged. ``Sometimes we pick someone up and the victim decides not to press charges,'' he said. ``People change their story or make things up and we end up releasing the individual who was arrested. If that arrest is reported, it can cause an individual irreparable harm.'' Davy, a lawyer and former assistant prosecutor in Guam, sees it differently. He said abuses could occur if police arrest records are kept secret in the city of 34,000 people, near Peoria in central Illinois. ``People ought not be whisked away and jailed without the public knowing,'' Davy said in an editorial. ``People of position and influence ought not to be able to avoid prosecution after an arrest without everyone knowing.''
DOC.HEAD: Harte-Hanks Changing Dallas-area Papers
DOC.TEXT: The Plano Star-Courier will eliminate two editions and the Mesquite News will publish weekly instead of bi-weekly, Harte-Hanks Community Newspapers announced Sept. 14. Beginning Oct. 3, the Star-Courier will publish Wednesday through Sunday mornings, Publisher John Williams said. The newspaper now publishes afternoon editions Monday through Friday and morning editions on Saturday and Sunday. The two newspapers are among eight Dallas-area publications owned by Harte-Hanks.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Censors CNN Report, Rivals Say It Happens to Them, Too
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi officials censored a CNN report Sept. 12 in which a woman who had been trapped in Kuwait said Iraqis killed people simply because they had pictures of the country's deposed emir. As in previous cases, the report was censored by fast-forwarding past the woman's comments during the report's satellite transmission from Baghdad, making her words unintelligible, a Cable News Network spokesman said. However, correspondent Tom Mintier, who filed CNN's report from Baghdad, called a colleague in Jordan with his recollection of the woman's comments, which was relayed to CNN in Atlanta for a later broadcast, CNN said. The woman, whose name was not released, was on a London-bound charter flight filled with foreigners who had been trapped in Kuwait since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of that country, CNN spokesman Steve Haworth said. In an interview during the flight's stopover in Baghdad, she said that ``they (Iraqis) are killing them for having pictures of the emir and paper flags the kids have for school. They are killing them for this. It's getting really bad.'' The woman apparently referred to Kuwaitis and paper Kuwaiti flags. Iraqi censorship of U.S. network reports, occurring even as Iraqi President Saddam Hussein continues to try to portray himself positively on television, is neither unusual nor yet excessive, network officials say. ``It's a common experience among all the networks,'' said Ed Turner, CNN's executive vice president for news gathering. Turner said another network's shot of baking pita bread was censored and yet another ``had a sound bite from Saddam himself, and that was fast-forwarded.'' CNN has been censored about six times, which is ``not so many as to be onerous, but it is annoying,'' Turner said. Each time, including Sept. 12, CNN showed the full report as it was received from Baghdad, but noted which parts were censored. David Miller, foreign editor for NBC News, said three taped NBC reports, all about hostages, had been censored during satellite transmission. The correspondent's words were not altered, but the picture was blurred, he said. Each time, the ``NBC Nightly News,'' aired the full report. Iraqi censors seem most sensitive to reports on hostages, said CBS foreign editor Al Ortiz. But the censorship has not been so severe ``that we haven't been able to . . . still manage to get the story reported,'' he said. Miller said there were no advance warnings from Iraqi officials and they seemed to have no rules. ``I don't think they have guidelines . . . there's no set of rules the way the U.S. military (in Saudi Arabia) does it.''
DOC.HEAD: NAB To Send Radios to Persian Gulf Troops
DOC.TEXT: The National Association of Broadcasters announced a campaign to send radio receivers and batteries to American service men and women serving in the Persian Gulf. The campaign, called ``AIR-LIFT,'' will purchase radios and batteries from industry fund-raising efforts and distribute them to U.S. troops through the Armed Forces Radio and Television Service, the association said Sept 12. Westinghouse Broadcasting Co.'s Group W Radio division will lead the fund-raising campaign and purchase the products, the industry group said. ``Our goal is to get as many radios to as many troops as we possibly can, with a target of 25,000 receivers with batteries,'' said Lynn Christian, a senior vice president for the association. ``We think radio can play a very important role keeping our fighting people in touch with the world.''
DOC.HEAD: Limited Televising of Federal Court Proceedings Approved
DOC.TEXT: Americans, accustomed to watching presidents and members of Congress on television, will get their first televised look at federal judges at work next year. The U.S. Judicial Conference, which sets policy for the federal courts, approved a limited plan Sept. 12 that will permit TV cameras to record civil trials in a handful of federal courtrooms. The three-year experiment will begin in July, limited to two federal appeals courts and six trial courts. Judges who volunteer their courtrooms for the plan will have almost total control over what the public sees. Rep. Robert W. Kastenmeier, D-Wis., who has been urging approval of the experiment, hailed the move as a step toward promoting public understanding of the court system. ``The time for federal courts to permit TV news coverage in courtrooms has come,'' said Kastenmeier, chairman of a House subcommittee on courts. ``Technology that permits us access to world events also compels us to use that access to make our own government available to our citizens.'' Kastenmeier said televised congressional proceedings, which began in the House in 1979 and in the Senate in 1986, have been beneficial to the public. C-Span, the cable network that telecasts public affairs programs, also welcomed the experiment. Forty-five states have approved the use of television cameras in their courts, and supporters say there have been no adverse results. The action does not mean federal criminal trials will be televised. The Judicial Conference left intact a rule banning cameras in criminal cases. Nor will Supreme Court proceedings be televised anytime soon. The Judicial Conference has no control over the high court, and most justices are believed to oppose cameras there.

DOC.HEAD: Market for Business News Radio Seen
DOC.TEXT: Two business-oriented radio stations that began operating in Virginia this spring already are up for sale. But that's not worrying the manager of Richmond's WRBN-AM, a third newcomer to the business radio market. Despite the troubles of his counterparts in Roanoke and Hampton Roads, Jon C. King said there is an increasing appetite for business news in the right area. As vice president and general manager of WRBN, King has overseen operations at the Richmond station since it began broadcasting June 14. ``The diversified marketplace that we have here has confirmed to us since we've been on the air that there is a significant appetite for what we're doing,'' he said. ``We expected that people would find our format interesting at times during the day, but we're finding that people are tuning in longer.'' King said Arbitron surveys show WRBN is increasing its market share. The two other stations in the format have lost listeners. WBNI-AM radio, which billed itself as Roanoke's only business news station, suspended operations last month after less than five months on the air. Another business station, WXIR-FM in Hampton Roads, began operations April 13. Officer manager Lisa Barnes said she was notified in July that the station was being sold. All three Virginia stations carried broadcasting from the Colorado-based Business Radio Network, but WRBN expanded the national and international programming to include local business news. King's station also features travel news, stock market updates and a varity of talk shows. Another business station serving northern Virginia listeners, WPGC-AM in Maryland, has been broadcasting since Oct. 1, 1989. Donna Francavilla, WPGC's program and news director, said location has everything to do with the success her station. ``Given the level of education - the number of `suits' we have in Washington - the level of sophistication and the fact that residents in the Washington area are interested in national, international and local news, we're far more likely to survive than a station in a suburban area,'' she said.
DOC.HEAD: Cable TV Show To Honor Soldiers
DOC.TEXT: Country music stars will send greetings to military personnel in the Middle East on a cable TV show Sept. 18. ``Crook and Chase,'' a 30-minute program on The Nashville Network, will include taped messages to American troops from country performers Waylon Jennings, Eddie Rabbitt, the Kentucky HeadHunters, Reba McEntire and Rodney Crowell. The studio audience will include the families of Air Force personnel from Pope Air Force Base in North Carolina, which has airmen and women in the deployment. A tape of the show, including greetings from relatives, will be made available to the military.
DOC.HEAD: Panelist Bounced on Eve of Gubernatorial Debate
DOC.TEXT: A radio talk show host who was supposed to help moderate a gubernatorial debate Sept. 12 was removed from the program after one of the candidates questioned his objectivity. Republican candidate Dave Frohnmayer's campaign demanded that the League of Women Voters, sponsor of the debate, remove Alan Siporin from the four-member debate panel. ``Siporin has made comments on the air during his radio program that give us very clear reason to question his objectivity when it comes to Dave Frohnmayer,'' campaign spokesman Dave Henderson said. Siporin, of Eugene radio station KLCC, said he was shocked to learn he had been removed. He said he had maintained good relations with Frohnmayer, the state attorney general, over the years. ``If a person who is running for governor is willing to go to these lengths to keep someone off a panel of journalists, you have to wonder what kind of access the people of Oregon, through the media, will have to the governor,'' Siporin said. Frohnmayer's debate with Democrat Barbara Roberts, independent Al Mobley and Libertarian Fred Oerther was sponsored by the League of Women Voters.

DOC.HEAD: CBN Called Only Possible Source of Satellite Interruption
DOC.TEXT: Federal prosecutors said the process of elimination points to a Christian Broadcasting Network technician as the person who interrupted two adult entertainment channels with religious messages. Defense attorneys for Thomas M. Haynie, however, told a jury Sept. 11 that in its process of elimination, the government eliminated the real culprit. James R. Wilson, a Justice Department attorney, said in opening arguments: ``No one will take the witness stand for the government and say that they saw or heard the defendant say or do anything for which he could be charged. But we will show how it was done, from where it was done, and by doing those two we will show who did it.'' Stephen E. Story, Haynie's attorney, told jurors the government will fail to prove its case because its engineering data on which it is basing its case is flawed. ``The government doesn't have the right facility. This episode did not happen at CBN,'' Story said. The Playboy Channel and Home Dish Only Inc.'s Exxxtasy Channel were interrupted on Sept. 6, 1987, with a message flashed on screens: ``Thus sayeth the Lord thy God. Remember the sabbath and keep it holy. Repent for the kingdom of Heaven is at hand.'' Wilson said the government will show CBN's satellite earth station was the only such station operating at the time that could have produced the religious message in the form it was sent and had the power to pirate the two satellite channels. The only person working at the earth station that Sunday night was Haynie, Wilson said. Haynie was indicted in April by a federal grand jury on three counts of interfering with the operations of a satellite and three counts of violating FCC licensing regulations. Story said the defense would challenge the government's technical evidence and show that errors were made in calculations and measurements vital to the prosecution's conclusion that Haynie was guilty. Story said Federal Communications Commission investigators ignored numerous other earth stations in their search for the pirate. Story said the defense would offer several alternate sources of the message. The trial was expected to last two weeks.
DOC.HEAD: Donald Forst Named Newsday Vice President
DOC.TEXT: Donald Forst was named vice president of Newsday and a member of the company's senior management committee Sept. 13. He will remain as editor of New York Newsday, a position he has held for five years. Forst joined Newsday as national editor in 1971 and was later promoted to managing editor. In 1974, he edited the paper's Pulitzer Prize-winning series ``The Heroin Trail.'' In 1978, he left Newsday, and during the next seven years he served as executive editor of The Los Angeles Herald Examiner, editor of the Boston Herald American and editor of Boston magazine. He returned to Newsday in 1985.
DOC.HEAD: Newsday Associate Publisher To Become Times Marketing Chief
DOC.TEXT: Steven L. Isenberg, associate publisher of Newsday, will join the Los Angeles Times as executive vice president for marketing at the beginning of 1991, the Times announced Sept. 12. Times Mirror Co., based in Los Angeles, publishes both newspapers. Isenberg, a lawyer and onetime chief of staff to former New York Mayor John V. Lindsay, will succeed Don Clark. Clark, 64, will continue as an executive vice president during 1991 to ensure an orderly transition, Publisher David Laventhol said. Isenberg will be responsible for advertising, circulation, promotion and market research as well as marketing for the Times' daily regional editions in the competitive Orange County, San Fernando Valley and San Diego areas. Clark, who has been with the Times for 37 years, was named to his current position in 1988. He held several management positions in classified advertising before being named director of that department in 1981. No successor was named to Isenberg at Newsday, where he has special responsibilities for the newspaper's New York edition.
DOC.HEAD: Mann Named Managing Editor in Dalton, Ga.
DOC.TEXT: Michael S. Mann has been named managing editor of The Daily Citizen News. He replaced Terry Smith, who accepted a public relations job with the U.S. Forestry Service in Washington. Mann previously worked as managing editor at The Tifton Gazette and was managing editor at the Jackson County Floridan in Marianna, Fla., and Clay Today in Orange Park, Fla.
DOC.HEAD: Daily Times-Call Names Managing Editor
DOC.TEXT: Keith Briscoe, assistant managing editor of the Odessa (Texas) American, was named managing editor of the Longmont Daily Times-Call on Sept. 10. Briscoe was previously news editor in Odessa, city editor of the Big Spring (Texas) Herald and news editor of the Commerce (Texas) Journal.

DOC.HEAD: Wheeler Named Fargo AP Correspondent
DOC.TEXT: Marilynn Wheeler, a newswoman in the Portland, Ore., bureau of The Associated Press, was named correspondent in Fargo on Sept. 12. She succeeds Jeff Meyer, who transferred to the AP's Los Angeles bureau. Wheeler joined the AP in Seattle in April 1986 and moved to Salem, Ore., for the 1987 legislative session. She moved to Portland later that year and had been broadcast editor and night supervising editor. Wheeler was a reporter and photographer for the Enterprise-Courier in Oregon City before joining the AP.
DOC.HEAD: Coughlin Resigns From Washington, N.C., Paper
DOC.TEXT: Executive Editor William J. Coughlin, who led the Washington Daily News to a Pulitzer Prize this year, has resigned. No replacement will be hired and Managing Editor Michael Adams will take over directing the newsroom, Publisher Ashley B. Futrell Jr. said Sept. 12. No reason for the resignation was given. The 10,700-circulation afternoon daily won the award for distinguished public service for stories on chemicals in the town's water system. Its investigation was prompted by Coughlin seeing a notice on the back of his water bill.
DOC.HEAD: Chronicle Writer Named Kansas Professional in Residence
DOC.TEXT: A staff writer for the San Francisco Chronicle has been named the 1990-91 Gannett Foundation professional in residence at the University of Kansas. J. Michael Robertson will teach beginning, mid-level and advanced reporting classes at the William Allen White School of Journalism and Mass Communications. He is the 15th professional journalist to teach for a year at Kansas under the program, which is sponsored by the Gannett Foundation. Since 1980, Robertson has worked as a reporter and editor for the Chronicle. He has worked as a part-time journalism instructor at San Francisco State University since 1986. He also taught at North Carolina State University from 1970 to 1975.
DOC.HEAD: Couple Selling Weekly After 42 Years in the Business
DOC.TEXT: Jack D. Tarr, editor-publisher of the weekly Banner-Press, has sold the newspaper and will retire after 42 years in the business with his wife. Betty Tarr said she and her husband sold the newspaper to Zean and Marilyn Carney, who operate a Lincoln publishing company. The Banner-Press has a paid circulation of 4,307 and distributes an estimated 175 copies free. The Carneys operate Arbor Printing Co. in Lincoln and also publish The News in Waverly, The Ashland Gazette and the Wahoo Newspaper.
DOC.HEAD: Thomas P. Davis
DOC.TEXT: Thomas P. Davis, former owner and publisher of The Georgetown Times, died Sept. 14 after a long bout with cancer. Davis, who owned the Times from 1955 to 1975, was also executive director of the Chamber of Commerce. At the time of his death, Davis was associate editor of the Marlboro Herald Advocate in Bennettsville. He began his journalism career as a reporter for the Greenwood Index Journal and later was a reporter for the Richmond (Va.) Times. Survivors include his wife, son and daughter.
DOC.HEAD: Paul Durham
DOC.TEXT: Paul Durham, founder of The Free Press and editor for 36 years, died Sept. 9 of a heart attack. He was 57. Durham founded the newspaper in the early 1950s, working in a factory during the day and setting type by night. In 1959, he sold the paper to what is now Temple-Inland Inc., but remained as editor of the 3,500-circulation paper until last January, when he retired. Survivors include his wife, two children and one granddaughter.
DOC.HEAD: LeRoy J. Hansen
DOC.TEXT: LeRoy J. Hansen, retired foreign editor of U.S. News & World Report, died of cancer Sept. 10. He was 68. After combat service as a Marine in World War II, Hansen covered Asia for United Press International for 11 years, including the Korean War. He left UPI after 17 years to join U.S. News in 1965 and served the magazine in several positions before retiring in 1985 as foreign editor. Survivors include his wife and three children.
DOC.HEAD: Laurence D. Johnson
DOC.TEXT: Laurence D. Johnson, metro editor of The Bismarck Tribune, died Sept. 15 of cancer. He was 43. Johnson was hired by the Tribune as a sports writer in 1976. He also worked as a state Capitol reporter, farm writer, editorial writer and regional editor before being named metro editor two years ago. He is survived by his wife and a son.

DOC.HEAD: APME Selects Finalists for Public Service Awards
DOC.TEXT: Twenty newspapers have been selected as finalists in the Associated Press Managing Editors association's 20th annual Public Service Awards competition. The finalists, announced Sept. 13, were chosen from 122 entries - 79 from newspapers with more than 50,000 circulation and 43 from newspapers with less than 50,000 circulation. One winner from each category will be announced in October at the APME convention in Dallas. Finalists in the less-than-50,000 category, listed alphabetically by city, are: The Albuquerque (N.M.) Tribune for its series ``A Price on Their Heads,'' exposing the threat to elk, eagles, bear and other wildlife posed by animal traders, trophy hunters and poachers. The Bismarck (N.D.) Tribune for its investigation into the abuse of children placed in foster homes on the Standing Rock Indian Reservation. The Casper (Wyo.) Star-Tribune for its articles about the state's lax regulation of insurance companies. The reporting prompted the withdrawal of a gubernatorial candidate and the resignation of the state insurance commissioner. The Columbia Missourian for a special report that concluded the public housing authority was not only the city's largest landlord but also the worst. This and other coverage led to the resignation of the authority's executive director and its chairman. The Livingston (Mont.) Enterprise for comprehensive coverage by its five-member news staff of the large and secretive Church Universal and Triumphant and its damaging impact on an area adjacent to Yellowstone National Park. The Sun News of Myrtle Beach, S.C., for providing detailed, helpful, responsible coverage of Hurricane Hugo even though its plant was disabled. The newspaper organized a print and broadcast pool to report from the battered oceanfront. The West County Times of Richmond, Calif., for its series exposing safety and environmental violations at the San Francisco Bay area's six oil refineries. As a result, the state increased minimum fines for pollution from $1,000 to $10,000. The Salina (Kan.) Journal for articles about use of excessive force by city police officers. The report led to a state investigation and the retirement of the police chief. The Valley News Dispatch of Tarentum, Pa., for a series that painstakingly documented the failure of local officials to collect more than $10 million in taxes owed to the area's 13 school districts. The Washington (N.C.) Daily News for revealing that for eight years city officials had known cancer-causing chemicals were in the tap water. The disclosure resulted in a two-month water ban, an improved treatment system and state and federal reviews of water regulations. Finalists among newspapers with more than 50,000 circulation are: The Albuquerque (N.M.) Journal for discovering a link between the dietary supplement L-tryptophan and a rare and sometimes deadly blood disorder. Ten days after the first story was published, the federal government banned the sale of the supplement. The Chicago Tribune for its series ``A Dream in Jeopardy,'' a comprehensive examination of cutbacks in corporate pensions and health benefits and threats to the Social Security trust funds. The Des Moines (Iowa) Register for a series about the rape of an Iowa woman and how she coped with the emotional trauma and legal ordeal that followed. The woman's decision to be identified in the account touched off a national debate over whether to keep secret the names of rape victims. The Detroit News for uncovering the financial ties of the mayor and police chief to a former deputy chief at the center of a federal investigation into a secret police fund. Questionable practices by the officials were documented in spite of the city government's ``no comment'' policy when questioned by reporters. The Lexington (Ky.) Herald-Leader for its series ``Cheating Our Children,'' on political interference in the state's public schools and the failure of local officials to collect property taxes owed to financially strapped school districts. The Courier-Journal of Louisville, Ky., for a broad examination of the state's public-school crisis. Articles published over six months included four in-depth series on flaws in the tax system, the special problems in Appalachia, the need for preschool programs and ways to improve teaching. The Philadelphia Inquirer for its series ``The Blood Brokers,'' which lifted the veil from the unregulated, multibillion-dollar business of buying and selling blood. Dog kennels in Pennsylvania were inspected more often than blood banks, the series revealed. The San Jose (Calif.) Mercury News for its comprehensive coverage of the Oct. 17 earthquake that devastated parts of Northern California. The day after the disaster and during the months that followed, readers received exhaustive reporting, vivid writing, compelling photos and graphics, and public service information. The Seattle Post-Intelligencer for its report ``Chemicals Ride the Food Chain,'' which revealed that truckers haul orange juice, baby food and other cargo destined for human consumption after carrying toxic chemicals in the same tanks. The disclosure resulted in a new state law prohibiting such practices and support for similar legislation in Congress. The Blade of Toledo, Ohio, for its series ``The Secret Files of Internal Affairs,'' based on a review of 200,000 police disciplinary documents never before made public. The seven-month project revealed that the department failed to prosecute officers for assault, drunken driving and other crimes and that 98 percent of citizens' complaints of police brutality were dismissed. Four newspapers were selected as finalists in the Freedom of Information Award competition, according to David Hawpe, editor of The Courier-Journal of Louisville and chairman of the APME Freedom of Information Committee. The winner also will be announced at the APME convention. The finalists are: The Detroit News, for an investigation tracing payments from a secret Detroit police fund, through which more than $1 million in taxpayer money was said to be laundered. The complex story touched on the activities of a deputy police chief, Mayor Coleman Young and others. The Fort Lauderdale (Fla.) Sun-Sentinel, for a series on the state of Florida's failure to impose adequate controls on care centers, leading to deaths and injuries among such diverse groups as infants, retarded adults and teen-age criminals. The Daily Reflector of Greenville, N.C., for revelations concerning the background of a candidate for Superior Court judge, resulting in legislation changing state law to open the records of the North Carolina Judicial Standards Commission. The Hartford (Conn.) Courant, for an examination of the government's military recruiting system that suggested it promotes corruption, undermines quality of the armed forces, and costs taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars annually.

DOC.HEAD: Philadelphia Inquirer Columnist Wins Mencken Award
DOC.TEXT: Steve Lopez, columnist and writer for The Philadelphia Inquirer, has won the 1990 H.L. Mencken Writing Award. Lopez received the award and a $2,500 cash prize in a ceremony Sept. 12. ``Mr. Lopez in his columns confronts public officials head on, reflects the irritations and anxieties of people at all levels, and arouses Philadelphians. He does this in a style that is as pungent as it is lucid,'' contest judges said. The Sun awards the prize annually to a newspaper writer whose opinion column most approximates the quality of Mencken's commentary.
DOC.HEAD: Cornell Honored for Religion Writing
DOC.TEXT: George Cornell, national religion writer for The Associated Press, was honored for 40 years of service in the field by the National Council of Churches. Cornell received a Bible and an engraved silver tray at a luncheon Sept. 12 during the group's annual Communications Meetings Week. ``In the 40 years I've been covering religion, press attention to the subject has increased enormously, both in quantity and quality,'' Cornell said. ``There's a growing new corps of excellent religion reporters, sophisticated in the field, convinced of its importance and thoroughly professional in their approach.'' Cornell joined the AP as a general assignment reporter in 1947 after working on the Cleveland County Times in Norman, Okla., the Daily Oklahoman in Oklahoma City and an Army newspaper in the Pacific theater during World War II.
DOC.HEAD: Lewis Wins Korn-Ferry Award
DOC.TEXT: Paul Lewis, the United Nations correspondent for The New York Times, has been named the first recipient of the Korn-Ferry International Journalism Award for excellence in United Nations reporting. The award recognizes the American journalist who contributes most significantly to the understanding of the United Nations. The award was established last year by Korn-Ferry International, a leading executive search firm, in cooperation with the Business Council for the United Nations. The council, comprised of nearly 100 corporations, was founded more than 30 years ago to provide a better understanding of the United Nations throughout the business community. Lewis will be honored at the BCUN Ambassadors Dinner on Sept. 18 in New York, where he will receive the first-place prize of $5,000. The runners-up were Ethan Schwartz of The Washington Post, Josh Friedman of New York Newsday and Moses Schonfeld of Fairchild Broadcast News. The judges for the award were William E. Ahearn, vice president and executive editor, The Associated Press; Dennis A. Britton, editor, Chicago Sun-Times; Roy Bode, editor, Dallas Times Herald; Shelby Coffey, editor, Los Angeles Times; William German, executive editor, San Francisco Chronicle; John H. Lyst, editor, The Indianapolis Star; Ronald Martin, editor, The Atlanta Journal-Constitution; Peter Prichard, editor, USA Today; Al Rossiter Jr., executive editor, United Press International; Joseph Sterne, editor, The (Baltimore) Sun; Ed Turner, vice president-newsgathering, CNN; and William F. Woo, editor, St. Louis Post-Dispatch.
DOC.HEAD: CBS and PBS Win 10 News Emmys Each
DOC.TEXT: CBS and PBS won 10 awards each and TBS's ``National Geographic Explorer'' picked up four - more than any other program - when the 1989 Emmys for news and documentary programming were handed out Sept. 12. ABC won six awards and NBC five. CNN, Fox Broadcasting, HBO and MTV each received one Emmy, and an independently produced program that was syndicated won another. All of TBS's awards were for ``National Geographic Explorer.'' The 40 winners were chosen from more than 900 entries in TV news, analysis, investigative reporting, interviews and programming on history and culture. For general coverage of a breaking news story, CBS's ``48 Hours'' won the program award for ``Hurricane Watch'' and the ``NBC Nightly News with Tom Brokaw'' won the segment award for coverage of turmoil in Romania. In the category of outstanding instant coverage of a breaking news story, NBC News won an Emmy for its special ``China in Crisis'' and CNN won for its coverage of China. For outstanding background and analysis of a current story, ABC's ``The Koppel Report'' won the program award for ``Tragedy at Tiananmen: The Untold Story.'' ``Tragedy at Pine Ridge,'' which appeared on the ``NBC Nightly News with Tom Brokaw,'' and ``The Education of Admiral Watkins,'' which appeared on PBS's ``The AIDS Quarterly,'' won the segment award. In the category of outstanding investigative journalism, ABC won the program and segment awards for ``Pan Am: Flight 103'' and ``Prisoners of Care,'' respectively. ``The Living Language'' on PBS's ``The Power of the Word with Bill Moyers'' and NBC News' ``Ronald Reagan . . . An American Success Story'' were honored with program awards for outstanding interviews and interviewers. Segment awards for outstanding interviews and interviewers went to CBS News' ``Face the Nation'' for an interview with John Tower, to ``Saturday Night with Connie Chung'' for an interview with Marlon Brando and to ABC's ``20-20'' for an interview with Patty Duke. For outstanding coverage of a continuing news story, CBS's ``48 Hours'' won the program award for ``Women Doing Time'' and the ``CBS Evening News with Dan Rather'' won the segment award for ``China: The Ancient, The New.'' For outstanding informational, cultural or historical programming, TBS's ``National Geographic Explorer'' won the program award for ``Search for Battleship Bismarck.'' A syndicated show, ``Hitler (Remembering World War II),'' and ``Free To Be Wild'' on ABC's ``20-20'' won the segment awards. ``Illusions of News'' on PBS's ``The Public Mind with Bill Moyers'' won the program award for outstanding news and documentary. Individuals honored for outstanding news and documentary work were Chris Beaver, Judy Irving and Ruth Landy, producers of ``Dark Circle'' on PBS's ``P.O.V.'' and Perry Wolff, producer of CBS's ``The Moon Above, the Earth Below.'' Wolff also was honored for the same show in the category of outstanding individual achievement in writing, as were Charles Kuralt and Peter Freundlich for their writing on ``Milepost - Student Stopping Tank in Beijing'' on ``CBS News Sunday Morning with Charles Kuralt.''

Mitsubishi Electric Corp. is marketing a videocassette recorder in Japan that automatically cuts out commercials. Sales have been good, though the product has raised the ire of television networks. The special feature works only on Japanese shows produced with two audio channels for presenting bilingual programming, and the company says nothing similar is currently planned for the U.S. market . . . Walter Cronkite will film an educational documentary about dinosaur tracks discovered recently at the Culpeper Stone quarry in Virginia . . . Like the schoolteacher she once was, 95-year-old Audrey Stubbart still pounces on errors and drills others on grammar. Mrs. Stubbart is the last proofreader at The Independence (Mo.) Examiner, a job fast disappearing from journalism as editors rely more on computers. ``This is such a fascinating job that I don't see how anyone gets old enough to want to quit,'' Mrs. Stubbart said in a recent interview.
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists and loggers are conducting rival lobbying campaigns on Capitol Hill this week in a high-stakes political battle over the Northwest's oldest forests and the northern spotted owl. The two sides scheduled meetings with members of Congress as two House panels prepared to move forward with legislation addressing forest protection and timber harvest levels. About 500 environmentalists rallied at the Capitol on Sunday to protest a series of bills they say would further reduce the shrinking supply of the nation's old-growth forests. ``The timer industry lobby has a national agenda as they grab the wealth of public lands, operating from a national power base in Congress,'' said Mark Winstein of Save America's Forests, a grassroots organization that sponsored the demonstration. ---= UNITED NATIONS (AP) - Angered by Iraqi raids on the French and other diplomatic compounds in Kuwait, U.N. representatives say they're considering extending to air corridors the international embargo on trade with Iraq. On Sunday, the Security Council unanimously passed a resolution condemning Iraq for violating diplomatic territory with Friday's raids and warning that further sanctions were likely if Baghdad continued to ignore U.N. resolutions. The U.S. ambassador, Thomas R. Pickering, said another resolution would be drafted to impose an air embargo, a step the United Nations has never taken against a nation. An air blockade would involve the interception of planes approaching Iraq and would pose a far greater danger of triggering hostilities than the boarding ships in the Persian Gulf, which has been done under the U.N. naval embargo. ---= DENVER (AP) - A toddler who was trapped for 14 hours in a 12-foot shaft at his parents' new home popped out ``like Superman'' after a firefighter crawling on his belly through a rescue tunnel grasped the boy's hand. Twenty-month-old Kevin Davis was released from a hospital with little more than a scraped elbow Sunday after being treated for dehydration. Kevin listened to his mother sing nursery songs and busied himself rolling mud balls as rescuers dug a parallel hole to the shaft and then tunneled over to the boy, who had fallen in on Saturday afternoon. ``I could hear him crying, but I couldn't touch him and I couldn't help him,'' said his mother, Lisa Davis, fighting back tears at a news conference at Denver General Hospital. ``It was really difficult.'' ---= BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) - The leaders of Cambodia's government and its three-party guerrilla opposition today convened a U.N.-supported council formed in an effort to end 11 years of war and create a neutral democratic nation. The Supreme National Council was formed at talks in Jakarta, Indonesia last week after the groups agreed to a U.N.-drafted peace plan. It was held at the Cambodian Embassy in Bangkok, which had been abandoned since 1975. Over the weekend, 100 Thai workers cleared the embassy of overgrown foliage and repainted it. The council has six seats for the Vietnam-installed Phnom Penh government and two spots for each of the rebel factions. The plan also allows for a 13th seat for a chairman, but the post remains in dispute. ---= JERUSALEM (AP) - Israel has appointed Yoram Aridor, a former finance minister who has never held a diplomatic post, as its ambassador to the United Nations. Aridor, 57, a member of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc, received the necessary Cabinet approval on Sunday, a spokesman for Shamir's office said. The Foreign Ministry said Aridor will assume his post later this month after the opening of the General Assembly in New York. He will replace acting Ambassador Yochanan Bein, who will remain part of Israel's U.N. delegation. The Israeli-born Aridor was named finance minister in 1981 during triple-digit inflation. He was forced to resign in 1983 after he backed an unpopular plan to tie the Israeli shekel to the dollar.

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Sunday, Sept. 23, the 266th day of 1990. There are 99 days left in the year. This is the first day of autumn, which arrived at 2:55 a.m. EDT.

Today's Highlight in History: On Sept. 23, 1779, during the Revolutionary War, the American warship Bon Homme Richard, commanded by John Paul Jones, defeated the HMS Serapis after Jones reportedly declared: ``I have not yet begun to fight!'' On this date: In 63 B.C., Caesar Augustus was born in Rome. In 1642, Harvard College in Cambridge, Mass., held its first commencement. In 1780, British spy John Andre was captured along with papers revealing Benedict Arnold's plot to surrender West Point to the British. In 1806, the Lewis and Clark expedition returned to St. Louis from the Pacific Northwest. In 1846, the planet Neptune was discovered by German astronomer Johann Gottfried Galle. In 1912, Mack Sennett's first Keystone short subject, a ``split-reel'' of two comedies starring Mabel Normand and Ford Sterling, was released. In 1926, Gene Tunney scored a 10-round decision over Jack Dempsey to win the world heavyweight boxing title in Philadelphia. In 1938, a time capsule, to be opened in the year 6939, was buried on the grounds of the World's Fair in New York City. In 1939, Sigmund Freud, the founder of psychoanalysis, died in London. In 1952, Republican vice-presidential candidate Richard M. Nixon delivered what came to be known as the ``Checkers'' speech as he refuted allegations of improper campaign financing. In 1957, nine black students who had entered Little Rock Central High School in Arkansas were forced to withdraw because of a white mob that had formed outside. In 1962, New York's Philharmonic Hall (since renamed Avery Fisher Hall) formally opened as the first unit of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. In 1973, former Argentine president Juan Peron was returned to power. In 1982, Amin Gemayel was sworn in as president of Lebanon, pledging to end the country's ``vicious cycle of bloody violence.'' Ten years ago: As the Persian Gulf war between Iraq and Iran intensified, the United Nations Security Council appealed for an immediate halt to the fighting. Five years ago: In an address to the 40th UN General Assembly, Secretary of State George P. Shultz called on the Soviet Union to ``get down to real business'' on arms control negotiations. One year ago: President Bush, saying he was ``very pleased'' with talks between Secretary of State James Baker and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze in Jackson Hole, Wyo., told reporters in Kennebunkport, Maine, there would be a superpower summit later in the year. Today's Birthdays: Actor Mickey Rooney is 70. Singer Ray Charles is 60. Singer Julio Iglesias is 47. Actress-singer Mary Kay Place is 43. Singer Bruce Springsteen is 41. Thought for Today: ``I saw old Autumn in the misty morn Stand shadowless like silence, listening To silence.'' - Thomas Hood, English author (1799-1845).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Monday, Sept. 24, the 267th day of 1990. There are 98 days left in the year.

Today's Highlight in History: On Sept. 24, 1789, Congress passed the First Judiciary Act, which provided for an Attorney General and a Supreme Court. On this date: In 1869, thousands of businessmen were ruined in a Wall Street panic after financiers Jay Gould and James Fisk attempted to corner the gold market. In 1896, author F. Scott Fitzgerald was born in St. Paul, Minn. In 1929, Lt. James H. Doolittle guided a Consolidated NY2 Biplane over Mitchell Field in New York in the first all-instrument flight. In 1934, Babe Ruth made his farewell appearance as a regular baseball player with the New York Yankees in a game against the Boston Red Sox. (The Sox won 5-0) In 1948, Mildred Gillars, accused of being Nazi wartime radio propagandist ``Axis Sally,'' pleaded innocent in a Washington D.C. courtroom to charges of treason. (Gillars ended up serving 12 years in prison.) In 1955, President Eisenhower suffered a heart attack while on vacation in Denver. In 1957, the Brooklyn Dodgers played their last game at Ebbets Field, defeating the Pittsburgh Pirates 2-0. In 1960, the USS ``Enterprise,'' the first nuclear-powered aircraft carrier, was launched at Newport News, Va. In 1963, the US Senate ratified a treaty with Britain and the Soviet Union limiting nuclear testing. In 1968, the CBS television magazine ``60 Minutes'' premiered. In 1969, the trial of the ``Chicago Eight'' (later reduced to seven) began. (Five defendants were convicted of crossing state lines to incite riots at the 1968 Democratic national convention, but the convictions were ultimately overturned.) In 1976, newspaper heiress Patricia Hearst was sentenced to seven years in prison for her part in a 1974 bank robbery. (She was released after 22 months under an executive clemency order from President Carter.) In 1988, members of the eastern Massachusetts Episcopal diocese elected Barbara C. Harris to be the first woman bishop in the church's history. Ten years ago: Cheered by hundreds of well-wishers, Polish labor leader Lech Walesa formally applied to have the Solidarity independent trade movement certified by officials in Warsaw. Five years ago: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, addressing the UN General Assembly, warned that the Reagan administration's ``Star Wars'' proposal threatened a ``nuclear catastrophe.'' One year ago: Residents of Charleston, S.C., attended church services as they faced a third day of recovering from the devastation of Hurricane Hugo. Today's Birthdays: ABC sportscaster Jim McKay is 69. Actress Sheila MacRae is 66. Actor-singer Anthony Newley is 59. Thought for Today: ``Ninety-nine percent of the failures come from people wo have the habit of making excuses.'' - George Washington Carver, American botanist (1864-1943).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Tuesday, Sept. 25, the 268th day of 1990. There are 97 days left in the year.

Today's Highlight in History: One hundred years ago, on Sept. 25, 1890, President Benjamin Harrison signed a measure establishing Sequoia National Park, while that same day, Congress completed legislative action on creating Yosemite National Park. On this date: In 1513, Spanish explorer Vasco Nunez de Balboa crossed the Isthmus of Panama to discover the Pacific Ocean. In 1690, 300 years ago, one of the earliest American newspapers, ``Publick Occurrences,'' published its first - and last - edition in Boston. In 1775, American Revolutionary War hero Ethan Allen was captured by the British as he led an attack on Montreal. In 1789, the first United States Congress, meeting in New York, adopted 12 amendments to the Constitution and sent them to the states for ratification. (Ten of the amendments became the Bill of Rights.) In 1890, 100 years ago, Mormon president Wilford Woodruff issued a Manifesto formally renouncing the practice of polygamy. In 1904, a New York City police officer ordered Lillian Orr, an automobile passenger on Fifth Avenue, to stop smoking a cigarette. (A male companion was arrested and later fined two dollars for ``abusing'' the officer.) In 1919, President Wilson became seriously ill and collapsed after a speech in Pueblo, Colo., during a national speaking tour in support of the Treaty of Versailles. In 1957, with 300 US Army troops standing guard, nine black children who had been forced to withdraw from Central High School in Little Rock, Ark., because of unruly white crowds were escorted to their classes. In 1962, Sonny Liston knocked out Floyd Patterson in Round 1 to win the world heavyweight title at Comiskey Park in Chicago. In 1973, the three-man crew of the US space laboratory ``Skylab Two'' made a safe splashdown in the Pacific after spending 59 days in orbit. In 1978, 144 people were killed when a Pacific Southwest Airlines Boeing 727 and a Cessna private plane collided in the air over San Diego and crashed. In 1979, the musical ``Evita'' opened on Broadway. In 1981, Sandra Day O'Connor was sworn in as the first woman justice on the US Supreme Court. Ten years ago: The Freedom sailed to victory to retain the America's Cup, defeating the Australia in the best-of-7 series off Newport, R.I. Five years ago: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze met for more than four hours at the Soviet UN Mission, but did not reach agreement on any of the issues they discussed. One year ago: President Bush, addressing the UN General Assembly, offered to slash American stocks of chemical weapons more than 80 percent, provided the Soviets did the same. Today's Birthdays: New York Yankee broadcaster Phil Rizzuto is 72. ABC news correspondent Barbara Walters is 59. Dancer-actress Juliet Prowse is 54. Actor Robert Walden is 47. Actor-producer Michael Douglas is 46. Actor Mark Hamill is 38. Actor Christopher Reeve is 38. Actress Heather Locklear is 29. Thought for Today: ``The richer your friends, the more they will cost you.'' - Elisabeth Marbury, American writer (1856-1933).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Wednesday, Sept. 26, the 269th day of 1990. There are 96 days left in the year.

Today's Highlight in History: On Sept. 26, 1789, Thomas Jefferson was appointed America's first Secretary of State; John Jay was named the first chief justice of the United States; Samuel Osgood began service as the first Postmaster-General; and Edmund Jennings Randolph was named the first Attorney General. On this date: In 1777, British troops occupied Philadelphia in the American Revolution. In 1820, pioneer Daniel Boone died in Missouri at the age of 85. In 1888, poet T.S. Eliot was born in St. Louis. In 1892, John Philip Sousa and his band performed in public for the first time, in Plainfield, New Jersey. In 1898, composer George Gershwin was born in Brooklyn, N.Y. In 1914, the Federal Trade Commission was established. In 1918, the Meuse-Argonne offensive against the Germans began during World War I. In 1950, United Nations troops in the Korean War recaptured the South Korean capital of Seoul from the North Koreans. In 1955, following word that President Eisenhower had suffered a heart attack, the New York Stock Exchange suffered its worst price decline since 1929. In 1957, the musical ``West Side Story'' opened on Broadway. In 1960, the first of four televised debates between presidential candidates Richard M. Nixon and John F. Kennedy took place in Chicago. In 1962, the television comedy ``The Beverly Hillbillies'' premiered on CBS. In 1977, Sir Freddie Laker began his cut-rate ``Skytrain'' service from London to New York. (However, the carrier went out of business in 1982.) In 1984, Britain and China initialed a draft agreement on the future of Hong Kong once the British colony reverted to Chinese rule in 1997. Ten years ago: The Cuban government abruptly closed Mariel Harbor, ending the ``freedom flotilla'' boatlift that resulted in 125,000 Cuban refugees entering the United States since the previous April. Five years ago: Hurricane Gloria approached the North Carolina shore, prompting more than 150,000 Atlantic Coast residents to flee. American officials confirmed the defection of Soviet KGB official Vitaly Yurchenko. (Yurchenko later ``re-defected'' back to the Soviet Union, claiming he'd been kidnapped.) One year ago: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze accepted President Bush's call for deep cuts in US and Soviet chemical weapon stockpiles in a speech to the UN General Assembly. Former housing secretary Samuel R. Pierce Junior refused to answer questions from a House panel investigating scandals involving HUD. Today's Birthdays: Actress Julie London is 64. Actor Patrick O'Neal is 63. Actor Kent McCord is 48. Singer Lynn Anderson is 43. Singer Olivia Newton-John is 42. Actress Melissa Sue Anderson is 28. Thought for Today: ``To be wildly enthusiastic, or deadly serious - both are wrong. Both pass. One must keep ever present a sense of humour.'' - Katherine Mansfield, New Zealand-born author (1888-1923).

DOC.HEAD: Today In History
DOC.TEXT: Today is Thursday, Sept. 27, the 270th day of 1990. There are 95 days left in the year.

Today's Highlight in History: On Sept. 27, 1964, the Warren Commission issued a report concluding that Lee Harvey Oswald had acted alone in assassinating President Kennedy in November 1963. On this date: In 1779, John Adams was named to negotiate the Revolutionary War's peace terms with Britain. In 1825, the first locomotive to haul a passenger train was operated by George Stephenson in England. In 1854, the first great disaster involving an Atlantic Ocean liner occurred when the steamship Arctic sank with 300 people aboard. In 1928, the United States said it was recognizing the Nationalist Chinese government. In 1939, Warsaw, Poland, surrendered after weeks of resistance to invading forces from Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union during World War II. In 1954, ``Tonight!'' hosted by Steve Allen, made its debut on NBC television. In 1959, a typhoon battered the main Japanese island of Honshu, killing nearly 5,000 people. In 1959, Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev concluded his visit to the United States. In 1979, Congress gave final approval to forming the Department of Education, the 13th Cabinet agency in US history. In 1988, three days after he had seemingly won the men's 100-meter dash at the Seoul Olympics, Canadian sprinter Ben Johnson went home in disgrace, stripped of his gold medal for using anabolic steroids. Ten years ago: Iraq claimed to have captured Ahwaz, a key oil city inside Iran, but Iran denied the claim, calling it ``a great lie.'' Five years ago: Hurricane Gloria, packing winds of 130 mph, stormed ashore and proceeded to head up the Atlantic Coast. (By evening, Gloria was over New England, its maximum winds down to 75 mph, minimal hurricane strength.) One year ago: Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. agreed to a $3.4 billion-dollar cash buyout by Sony Corporation. Today's Birthdays: Former Illinois senator Charles Percy is 71. Actor William Conrad is 70. Movie director Arthur Penn is 68. Actress Sada Thompson is 61. Actress Kathleen Nolan is 57. Author Barbara Howar is 56. Sportscaster Dick Schaap is 56. Actor Greg Morris is 56. Singer Meat Loaf is 43. Baseball player Mike Schmidt is 41. Singer Shaun Cassidy is 32. Thought for Today: ``Any man should be happy who is allowed the patience of his wife, the tolerance of his children and the affection of waiters.'' - Michael Arlen, English novelist (1895-1956).
