DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press reported erroneously on Sept. 13 that out-of-court settlements had been reached in almost all of 265 asbestos disease claims by workers at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard. Most of the 20 defendants in those cases have settled with plaintiffs, but cases are proceeding against the rest. About 200 claims are being tried together in a New York state court in Manhattan and the remainder are on trial in U.S. District Court in Brooklyn. The defendants include companies that made asbestos or products containing the material used at the shipyard.

DOC.HEAD: Retailer Spurs Revolt by Shoppers In Snub of Planned Parenthood
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of longtime customers of Dayton Hudson Corp. are tearing up their credit cards and threatening a Christmas season boycott in a revolt over the retailer's snub of Planned Parenthood. The credit card shreds began arriving by mail at Dayton's downtown headquarters after the company confirmed on Labor Day weekend that it was ending 22 years of financial support for educational programs at Planned Parenthood of Minnesota. The response prompted trustees of the Dayton Hudson Foundation to reconsider their decision in talks with Planned Parenthood set to continue this week. ``I don't think they expected any big outcry,'' said Toni Tschann of the Minnesota Women's Political Caucus. ``And frankly, I never thought I'd hear from this many. But people aren't standing for it.'' Dayton Hudson spokeswoman Ann Barkelew said several hundred customers have returned their credit cards. On Saturday, about 500 people rallied outside a Dayton's store in suburban Edina where they repeated their vow to boycott all Dayton Hudson stores beginning the day after Thanksgiving unless funding is restored. Dayton Hudson, with 1989 sales of $13.6 billion, owns Dayton's, Target, Marshall Field's, Hudson's and Mervyn's department stores in 33 states. ``Dayton's has always stood with women,'' said Gloria Griffin of the Minnesota Women's Consortium. ``Women are their customers. I strongly feel this is only a momentary mistake.'' Weighing in behind the irate shoppers is at least one big investor and Bryn Mawr College President Mary Patterson McPherson, who sits on the Dayton Hudson board of directors but is not a trustee of the foundation. ``I am pleased they are reconsidering,'' said McPherson, who declined to elaborate. She is an adviser at Women's Way, a Philadelphia group that funds organizations that work in concert with Planned Parenthood. ``The majority just feel that helping low-income teen-agers is something that nobody should be afraid to do - especially Dayton's,'' Tschann said. In 1946 Dayton Hudson began giving 5 percent of profits to charities. In 1989 the company gave away $22 million and received the America's Corporate Conscience Award from the Council on Economic Priorities. ``When a company of the prestige and importance in the philanthropic community says `no' to Planned Parenthood of Minnesota, that is a devastating message to corporate America,'' Thomas Webber, executive director of Planned Parenthood of Minnesota said. Webber said the proposed $20,000 grant is financially insignificant compared to its symbolic importance. Many shoppers believe Dayton's withdrew financial support from Planned Parenthood because the Christian Action Council of Falls Church, Va., threatened to boycot Dayton's and other corporations that fund Planned Parenthood. Barkelew said foundation trustees for years had considered ending financial support to Planned Parenthood because many people misconstrue the aid as support for abortion. But Barkelew said the company was having increasing difficulty convincing people that the money was not used to fund abortions. She said the foundation will continue to support other groups with teen pregnancy prevention programs. Instead of freeing Dayton Hudson from the abortion debate, the decision has had the opposite effect. The possibility of a boycott from either side looms ust as the company enters the holiday shopping season, which generates more than 50 percent of annual sales. ``Our worst fears have been realized,'' said New York City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, a trustee of city pension funds holding $31.9 million of Dayton Hudson stock. ``We're long-term investors and it's quite clear that when people get angry with a company that can affect the bottom line.'' Holtzman and Carol O'Cleireacain, the city's finance commissioner, urged Dayton Hudson Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Kenneth Macke to continue funding for Planned Parenthood. Denying the funding places Dayton Hudson ``squarely in the camp of the anti-choice forces and in opposition to the overwhelming majority of Americans who support accessible birth control,'' the investors said in an Aug. 7 letter. Reatha Clark King, a spokeswoman for the General Mills Foundation, said corporate gift giving decisions should be made soley on the merits of published guidelines describing the goals of a foundation. ``If you start evaluating your requests against special interests, then you might sway from your purpose,'' said King, whose organization gave $18,000 to Planned Parenthood this year. Barkelew said the company is ``confident a solution will be reached,'' but she declined to say what steps are being considered.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Cosby, Michael Jackson Top Magazine's List
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Richest Entertainers-List
DOC.TEXT: Bill Cosby may face a television challenge from the Simpsons cartoon family this fall, but he leads all entertainers in the money-making ratings, according to Forbes magazine. Cosby topped the business magazine's list of the world's 40 richest entertainers with $115 million in estimated gross earnings for 1989 and 1990. The magazine said Cosby made $60 million last year and projected he would earn $55 million this year. In its Oct. 1 issue, released Monday, Forbes said the 53-year-old Cosby is making an estimated $4 million a month on syndicated reruns of ``The Cosby Show.'' Pop singer Michael Jackson, who hasn't released an album or gone on tour this year, fell to second place after holding the top spot for two years. Forbes said Jackson had two-year earnings of $100 million, $35 million of that in 1990. Jackson's singing sister, Janet, was a newcomer to the list, ranked 26th with estimated two-year earnings of $30 million. The rock group The Rolling Stones - with $88 million - rose to third place from eighth last year thanks largely to a big concert tour. Movie producer-director Steven Spielberg, whose ``Arachnophobia'' was a box-office success this summer, made $87 million to slip to fourth place from second. New entrants on the list were the teeny-bopper sensation New Kids on the Block in fifth place. Forbes said the group would make $78 million in the two years, $61 million of it in 1990. Forbes said the estimated gross incomes were based on talks with industry executives, lawyers, agents and managers. It said earnings figures for recording artists are based on royalty payments from record and video sales and estimated pretax gross for concert tours. Rounding out the top 10 were television personality Oprah Winfrey, $68 million; actor-producer Sylvestor Stallone, $63 million; pop singer Madonna, $62 million; bodybuilder and movie star Arnold Schwarzenegger, $55 million; and Peanuts artist Charles M. Schulz, $54 million. Newcomers to the list included former Beatle Paul McCartney, with an estimated income of $45 million, thanks to a year-long concert tour; actor Bruce Willis, star of the two ``Die Hard'' movies and of the December-release ``Bonfire of the Vanities,'' based on the Tom Wolfe novel, at $36 million; and actor Sean Connery, who starred in the film ``The Hunt for Red October,'' at $35 million.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Bargainers Hung Up Over Capital Gains Tax, Spending Cuts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Bargaining resumes 10 a.m. EDT, pre-noon top planned. Version moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Budget Talks-Glance
DOC.TEXT: New gaps are opening between congressional and administration bargainers at their budget negotiations as Democrats back away from about $35 billion in proposed cuts to benefits programs such as Medicare. The two sides planned a tenth day of meetings today at Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland after a Sunday evening session ended on a fractious note. ``Some of our members are wondering if they want an agreement,'' said a Republican official familiar with the talks. ``It doesn't look good right now.'' For the last several days, Democrats have expressed a willingness to pare benefit programs by $125 billion from the amount needed over the next five years to keep pace with inflation. Differences over spending cuts have been considered one of the bargainers' minor squabbles. But Sunday, Democrats told GOP bargainers that they could accept a lesser cut of about $90 billion in Medicare, agriculture and other benefit programs, said two officials who demanded anonymity. Among the proposed reductions they rejected was a Republican plan to save $27 billion over the next five years by boosting the monthly premium Medicare participants pay for doctors' coverage. Under the GOP proposal, people with higher incomes would pay more than the current $28.60 monthly fee. Reductions in benefit programs would be a crucial part of a deal bargainers are trying to shape to shrink the federal deficit by $50 billion next year and $500 billion through 1995. These programs are among the fastest growing parts of the federal budget and are one of the prime targets on the GOP hit-list for savings. Major problems remain over taxes. Democrats and Republicans agree that the package should include about $25 billion in new levies and fees for next year. Republicans, saying they want to spur the weakening economy, insist that a cut in the capital gains tax rate be part of that package. They say cutting the tax - paid on profitable sales of property - would encourage more people to sell their holdings and would increase government revenues. But Democrats say the proposal would simply help the wealthy lower their tax burden, and they want some other tax boost for the rich as a tradeoff. The two sides tried working out a deal on taxes Sunday but got nowhere. Administration budget director Richard Darman proposed several alternatives he said Republicans would accept in exchange for dropping the capital gains tax rate, said one official. Among them was a plan eliminating certain deductions for people with adjusted gross annual incomes above $200,000. ``There was no meeting of the minds at all,'' the official said. Both sides agree taxes should be increased on alcoholic beverages, luxury items such as fancy cars and electronics equipment, energy and perhaps on cigarettes. Final details have yet to be worked out.

DOC.HEAD: Common Market Unemployment Holds Steady at 8.6 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Unemployment in the 12-nation European Community held steady at 8.6 percent in July, the EC's statistical office said Monday. The rate has not changed since March. But, the figures conceal ``contrasting trends at national level,'' the statistics office Eurostat said. Unemployment fell 0.4 percent in Spain and 0.1 percent in Portugal, whereas it rose 0.2 percent in both Belgium and Britain. For comparsion, the unemployment rate in the United States rose to 5.6 percent in August from 5.5 percent in July.

DOC.HEAD: US Firm Vows to Oppose Contract Award to Japanese Company
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. company that lost the bidding to build a people-mover system for a new Japanese airport said Monday there were irregularities in the decision that awarded the contract to Japanese bidders. The dispute involves the $7 billion Kansai International Airport being built in Osaka in western Japan. The airport project earlier had been at the center of American complaints that U.S. firms did not have fair access to the Japanese construction market. Kansai International Airport Co. conducted a briefing Monday for the 13 bidders on why it chose Niigata Engineering Co. and Sumitomo Corp. to build the system to carry passengers to remote gates at the airport, scheduled to open in 1993. ``With the information provided to us in the meeting today, it is clear that there were irregularities in the procurement process of the people-mover contract for KIA,'' said John Tucker, president of AEG Westinghouse Transportation Systems, headquartered in Pittsburgh. In a statement, Tucker added that ``this latest information provided only fuels the fire of our efforts to block the award of the project to Niigata Engineering and to pursue any avenues to make the truth known.'' Efforts to reach Westinghouse officials here for elaboration on the alleged irregularities or what the company specifically planned to do to block the contract award were unsuccessful. The briefing was called after Westinghouse charged that there were violations of the U.S.-Japan construction agreement in the evaluation and selection procedures. The airport company announced in July that the contract for an automated guide-way transport system in the passenger terminal building had been awarded to Niigata Engineering and Sumitomo. It did not state the value of the contract. Company officials said Monday they had explained at the briefing that the procedure had been fair. They added that while Westinghouse had experience in such systems, Niigata Engineering also was experienced in city transportation systems. Japan and the United States reached an agreement in 1988 on procedures to allow American builders to bid on construction projects in Japan, including the Kansai airport. U.S. officials said later Japan was making significant progress in allowing American companies to compete for construction projects.

DOC.HEAD: Repeating to fix cycle designator
Common Market Unemployment Holds Steady at 8.6 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Unemployment in the 12-nation European Community held steady at 8.6 percent in July, the EC's statistical office said Monday. The rate has not changed since March. But, the figures conceal ``contrasting trends at national level,'' the statistics office Eurostat said. Unemployment fell 0.4 percent in Spain and 0.1 percent in Portugal, whereas it rose 0.2 percent in both Belgium and Britain. For comparsion, the unemployment rate in the United States rose to 5.6 percent in August from 5.5 percent in July.

DOC.HEAD: KCPL Extends Offer for KG&E Stock
DOC.TEXT: Kansas City Power & Light Co. extended on Monday its $857 million cash tender offer for Kansas Gas and Electric of Wichita stock until Oct. 19. Kansas City Power & Light said Kansas G&E shareholders have tendered more than 13.5 million shares, about 44 percent of the company's common stock. When the Kansas City utility extended the deadline from Aug. 21 until Sept. 14, it said about 43 percent of the common shares had been offered. Kansas City Power & Light launched its offer on July 23 at $27 per share, a premium of 37 percent over the market price of Kansas G&E common stock. Kansas G&E officials say the offer is inadequate and recently began negotiations with an unidentified company that might be interested in acquiring it.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Rises Above $33 Per Barrel, Sets New Record on Merc
DOC.TEXT: Oil futures soared above $33 a barrel today to record levels on the New York Mercantile Exchange today, as traders responded to bullish prices in Europe and continued Mideast tensions. Light sweet crude opened on the Merc at a record $32.80 per barrel for October delivery, surpassing the old opening high of $32.35 that was set Aug. 2, 1983, and matched once during the latest Persian Gulf crisis, on Aug. 23. The exchange's records for crude date to March 30, 1983, when it began trading the oil futures. In late morning trading, crude rose as high as $33.10 before dipping back under $33 but stayed well above the old record. The October crude contract closed at $31.76 a barrel on Friday. Other contract months for crude were all higher as traders responded to bullish prices of Brent Blend, a European oil that moved up in the wake of a pipeline cutback in the North Sea and rumors of an unscheduled pipeline repair in the Soviet Union. Oil markets have been swinging so wildly since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 that traders took it in stride as oil leaped to a new record price. ``I think the move was `There goes that, so let's shoot for the next target,''' said trader Ed Kevelson, with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``$32.35, which seemed like a pretty tough level to get to, just evaporates this morning.'' Kevelson said traders were also reacting to news that Iran and Iraq had stopped exchanging prisoners, despite their recent conciliatory moves that have included the re-establishment of diplomatic ties. Traders were also following reports that pro-Iraqi groups might try to move food and medicine into Iraq, despite the blockade of Iraq that was imposed after its troops occupied Kuwait. ``I think any test of the blockade is very bullish at the moment,'' Kevelson said. The price of crude opened so high on the Merc in response to prices of Brent, which was trading up about $1.30 per barrel today, said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Brent prices were higher in part because of a North Sea pipeline problem that was keeping about 70,000 barrels per day off the market. European oil prices were also higher because of a rumor that unscheduled repairs would be held on a Soviet pipeline from the Ural Mountains to the Caspian Sea, although traders said the Soviets issued a statement this morning that was construed as a denial of the rumor. ``That kind of took a little bit of wind out of the market,'' Hittle said. When Brent is trading at a premium, supplies that normally would go to the United States are often kept in Europe, which can help push up prices of the light sweet crude futures traded on the Merc, Hittle said. Rising oil prices were accompanied by higher prices for petroleum products futures. Unleaded gasoline was up 2.94 cents to 93.30 cents per gallon on October contracts, while home heating oil was up 2.91 cents to 85.70 per gallon on October contracts in late morning trading. Distant months were all higher for the products. Natural gas stayed the same at $1.52 per 1,000 cubic feet for October delivery, although later months were slightly higher.

DOC.HEAD: UMW Convention Begins With Union Facing Legal Troubles, Membership Loss
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to update with Trumka and Kirkland speeches, deleting reference to meeting, which lasts nine days, being a week long. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `The convention... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A national energy policy promoting the use of coal could have helped prevent the Persian Gulf crisis, the United Mine Workers' president said today at the convention marking the union's 100th anniversary. ``The only reason characters like Saddam Hussein have any power at all is because of the oil they have - oil we could have replaced years ago with coal mined in the United States and Canada,'' UMW president Richard Trumka said. AFL-CIO President Lane Kirkland told the more than 1,000 delegates from the United States and Canada that unions are on the verge of a breakthrough following the 1980s, which he called a period of illusion, excess and frustration. Kirkland urged support of a bill before Congress that would bar employers from permanently replacing striking workers. ``That's a basic right recognized in all but the most backward or repressive nations,'' he said. The UMW rejoined the AFL-CIO last year, four decades after the famed UMW President John L. Lewis pulled his union out. Other speakers scheduled to address the delegates include the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole. The celebration of the once-powerful union's centennial is mixed with financial and legal concerns. During the nine-day meeting, delegates will be asked to give the International Executive Board, the UMW's governing body, authority to close or merge the 21 local districts to help the union save money. Several of the largely autonomous districts are insolvent because of layoffs. They also will decide whether to allow the governing body use of interest earnings from the $60 million strike fund to pay legal expenses and other costs associated with strikes. Currently, the fund can be used only to pay benefits to strikers. And the delegates will be asked to approve changes UMW leaders say they need to deal with multinational corporations in the world coal market. Trumka and other union officials say the proposals will give the union the latitude to deal with coal companies that increasingly are owned by conglomerates such as Exxon and Du Pont. The convention at the opulent Fontainebleau Hotel comes as the UMW struggles to overturn $52 million in fines levied by a Virginia judge because of the 10-month Pittston strike in 1989. The union also faces more than $1 billion in lawsuits filed by companies idled by a five-week wildcat strike that began in sympathy with the Pittston strikers. The union declared victory in the bitter Pittston strike, but it was a costly win. A financial disclosure form shows the union's net worth fell by $45 million in 1989, down to $126 million. The UMW, formed in 1890 by the merger of two rival mine unions, once held a firm grip on the nation's energy needs. As late as the 1940s, its 400,000 members controlled 80 percent of the country's coal production. But the union's influence has declined in recent years. Beset by increased mechanization in the nation's mines and a jump in the number of non-union coal operations, the UMW has seen its working membership dip to about 70,000.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Drop On Weather, Weak Exports
DOC.TEXT: Grain nd soybean futures prices turned lower after a mixed opening this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade amid weak export demand and forecasts for mild temperatures in the Midwest. Soybean futures opened higher after some private meteorologists predicted cold temperatures early next week in the Midwest. But the market's focus quickly turned to nearer-term factors, including predictions for beneficial rain in the region later this week. Joel Karlin, grains analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago, said the markets also were responding to weak export demand across the board. ``Export business for all these markets is abysmal,'' he said. ``It's been really hurting the wheat and corn and it's starting to afflict the soybeans also.'' The impending corn and soybean harvest is likely to increase selling interest, Karlin said. In early trading, wheat futures were 1 cent to 2 cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.56 a bushel; corn was \ cent to } cents lower with September at $2.32 a bushel; oats were unchanged to { cent higher with December at $1.14} a bushel; soybeans were 7 cents lower to 1} cents higher with September at $6.18 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Some pork belly futures leaped the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound in reaction to gains in the cash hog market and strong demand for pork. Live cattle were .43 cent to .70 cent higher with October at 79.15 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent to .78 cent higher with September at 89 cents a pound; live hogs were .15 cent to 1.28 cents higher with October at 53.15 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.7 cents to 2 cents higher with February at 56.65 cents a pound. Cattle futures ended mixed on Friday; pork futures advanced.

DOC.HEAD: Tentative UAW-GM Agreement Reached
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with bargaining council meeting rescheduled for Tuesday, add quotes from two of its members. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `The UAW's... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. and the United Auto Workers reached tentative agreement early today on a new three-year contract covering 300,000 workers in 29 states. ``I'm just delighted we got this contract settled without a disruption,'' UAW President Owen Bieber said in announcing the agreement, reached after a 41-hour bargaining session between the union and the world's No. 1 automaker. Details of the agreement were to be outlined at a meeting this morning in suburban Detroit of the union's 300-member GM bargaining council, made up of local union presidents and bargaining committee chairmen. But that meeting broke up after only 15 minutes and was rescheduled for Tuesday because the printing of the proposed contract had not been completed. Bieber said at a news conference before dawn that he was ``very, very satisfied'' with the agreement on pensions, and GM vice president Alfred Warren said the contract gives the company latitude to reduce its work force. The Detroit News reported today that the contract includes a 3 percent raise the first year, 3 percent lump sum payments the next two and retention of a requirement that GM hire one worker for every two who quit, retire or die. There had been speculation that GM would push hard to remove or alter the 1-for-2 policy and that the automaker wants to cut tens of thousands of hourly jobs and close up to four assembly plants to better compete with the Japanese. The Big Three automakers lost about 6 percentage points in U.S. market share during the 1980s, while the Japanese gained the same amount. If approved by the UAW council, the contract would be sent to the rank and file for ratification, a process expected to be completed by the end of the month. As he arrived for this morning's meeting, Tom Robinson, president of Local 549 in Mansfield, Ohio, who helped negotiate the settlement, said only that it ``met all the goals we came down here to meet.'' Earl Perry of Local 2188 in Fitzgerald, Ga., was more cautious. ``We still have to get through this one,'' he said, referring to the since-rescheduled bargaining council meeting The UAW's old three-year contract with GM expired at midnight Friday, but both sides agreed to extend its terms while talks continued. UAW contracts with Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. also ran out at the same time, but the union put talks with Ford and Chrysler on hold so that it could concentrate on GM and use that pact as a model for the other automakers. Bieber and Warren said the new agreement could be tailored to Ford and Chrysler. The union's contracts with the Big Three automakers cover more than 450,000 active workers. This year was the first time in 11 years that UAW contracts with each of the Big Three ran out at the same time. The last time the UAW struck GM was in 1984. That strike lasted a week and ultimately involved about 25 GM facilities nationwide. Meanwhile, talks continued in Toronto between the Canadian Auto Workers union and Ford of Canada. The CAW's 12,800 members at Ford of Canada struck early Saturday after talks broke off. Negotiations were held later Saturday and resumed Sunday. No plants involved operate on weekends so any strike impact won't be felt until today; if the strike continued, U.S. Ford plants that use parts made in Canada would be affected. Bieber, whose union's 1.5-million membership dropped by a third largely because of the shrinking U.S. auto industry, said he expected the tentative agreement would get a warm reception by the bargaining council. ``Suffice it to say at this point they will be pleased with what we have to say,'' he said. Warren said the talks were ``some of the most difficult bargaining'' ever between GM and the union. But Warren and Bieber were upbeat about the prospects for changing labor relations between the company and union. ``We feel that the spirit we developed during the negotiations, the relationship we built with the new leadership of the United Automobile Workers bodes well for General Motors, for the customer, the marketplace and the United Automobile Workers,'' Warren said. The average hourly wage with cost of living adjustments for GM workers is about $15.75 under the 1987 agreement. Fringe benefits, particularly health care costs, boost that to nearly $30 per hour, the company has said. At Ford, the figure is about $31 per hour, and Chrysler's was just more than $33. Some of the fringe benefits include pension matters, which was a hot topic going into the talks. There was a strong movement within the UAW to include cost-of-living adjustments keyed to the inflation rate.

DOC.HEAD: American Stock Exchange Plans Trading Facility in Hawaii
DOC.TEXT: The American Stock Exchange announced Monday it was planning a trading facility in Hawaii in an attempt to link U.S. and Pacific stock and options markets during the Tokyo business day. The exchange set an 18-month timetable to develop a business plan and negotiate with American and Far East financial institutions for joint ventures that would be necessary to open a trading facility in Hawaii. ``As global financial markets evolve in the 1990s there will be the increasing demand for foreign securities by investors in both the U.S. and Pacific rim countries,'' American Stock Exchange Chairman James R. Jones said. The business day in Hawaii overlaps trading in New York and Tokyo, the world's two key financial markets. The Amex is the second-largest U.S. exchange behind the New York Stock Exchange. It recently has sought to expand into new products and technologies that tie into the gloablization of world markets. The Hawaii venture is being planned with the Economic Development Corp. of Honolulu, a nonprofit organization under contract to the state. It represents the Honolulu Financial Center Task Force, which is lobbying for a financial center in Hawaii. The Amex said in a statement that a variety of financial products could be offered in a Hawaii trading facility, including some not currently sold in Asian markets. It said the success of a Honolulu facility would depend on attracting investment order flow from Japan and other Asian countries. The statement said Hawaii is a hub for a new trans-Pacific fiber optic cable system and has proximity to more than a dozen satellites for data transmission.

DOC.HEAD: Westcott Communications To Buy Detroit TV Production Firm
DOC.TEXT: Westcott Communications, the nation's largest business television firm, said Monday it has agreed to purchase a Detroit-based television production company serving the automotive industry. In the deal, Westcott will assume the operating liability of G &J Marketing Inc., Westcott spokesman Ron Coppock said. The acquisition will expand Westcott's business television capabilities, particularly in the auto industry. Westcott provides business television services such as broadcast training and news programming to more than 5,000 car dealerships in North America. G & J produces business television programming for General Motors Acceptance Corp. and other Detroit-based companies.

DOC.HEAD: Gains in New Mexico and California Push Up Number of Working Rigs by 21
DOC.TEXT: With strong gains in California and New Mexico, the number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States rose again this week, climbing by 21 to 1,060, Baker Hughes Inc. reported Monday. This week's tally reflected a smaller increase than the 26 rigs added a week ago despite gains of 17 rigs in New Mexico and 13 in California. I.C. Kerridge, a vice president and economist at Baker Hughes, which has been making the survey ince 1940, said the Middle East situation appeared not to be affecting the count much this week. A week ago, industry watchers credited the 26-rig jump to rising oil prices triggered by the Middle East crisis. The count a year ago was 965, Baker Hughes said. In Canada, the rig count of 117 represented a jump of 20. A year ago, the Canadian tally was 100. Kerridge speculated the New Mexico increase was due to drillers working coal seam wells in the northwest part of the state. The wells produce methane gas from coal deposits and a federal subsidy for such wells expires at the end of the year, he said. The California increase followed a previous decline and reflected an adjustment in the market, Kerridge said. Among other major oil-producing states, Colorado added four rigs, while Oklahoma was up two. Kansas, North Dakota and Pennsylvania each declined by three, while Ohio lost two and Michigan one. Louisiana, Texas and Wyoming were unchanged. The Houston-based oil toolmaker's rig count, a widely watched index of drilling activity, represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil, not those producing oil. At the height of the oil boom in December 1981, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But the rig count plunged to a low of 663 after oil prices collapsed in the summer of 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Closes Geneva Unit, Bowing To Swiss Competitors
DOC.TEXT: Chemical Banking Corp. said Monday it is closing its bond trading, foreign exchange and money market operations in Geneva because of insufficient profitability. Chemical was one of the most active participants in Swiss franc bond trading but high local interest rates and the collapse of the Tokyo stock market in recent months have hurt the bank's activitites in the Swiss market. At the same time, Chemical said it was closing Chemical Securities Co. in Tokyo, which concentrated on marketing and brokering Japanese equities and equity-linked bonds under the direction of the Geneva office. The moves were part of the American banking group's strategy to ``focus only on activities where maximum profitability can be achieved,'' said Francois Larsen, director of the Geneva unit, called Chemical N.Y. Capital Market Corp. He said the capital markets unit found it increasingly difficult to market its service after selling its Geneva private banking subsidiary in November 1988 to the French financial firm Dumenil-Leble SA. Chemical also is closing its foreign exchange and money market operation in Geneva, leaving a seven-person cash management branch office of the New York-based bank in Zurich as its only Swiss presence. Patrick Voegeli, the bank's head trader, said two factors hurt profitability in the past year. High short-term Swiss interest rates made it expensive to finance bond positions, and sharp drops on the Tokyo stock exchange made Swiss investors reluctant to trade Japanese equity-linked instruments. Chemical Bank joined Citicorp in founding the Swiss new-issues market in the mid-1980s. Trading on the market comes before the end of public subscription, and levels quoted there allow investors to judge the price they are offered by potential salesmen. But Switzerland's three big banks increasingly dominated the market since they began trading there in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Tire Maker Seeks Control of West German Company
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf `Pirelli officials. . . to UPDATE with spokesman saying no public tender offer planned; PICKS UP 6th graf, `Financial terms. . .
DOC.TEXT: Pirelli SpA, the Italian tire maker, said Monday it is seeking majority control of Continental AG of West Germany in an apparent bid for a strong partner to face international competition. A Pirelli spokesman said a merger of the worldwide tire operations of Pirelli and Continental was considered under the plan. The spokesman said Pirelli had proposed transferring its tire operations to Continental and then taking control of the company, creating the world's fourth-largest tire maker. The Italian company is controlled by the Pirelli family, which founded it. The company also makes cables. Pirelli officials said the company owns a 5 percent stake in Continental, but a spokesman said that no public tender offer for more Continental shares would be made. Financial terms and other details of the offer were not disclosed. Continental aknowledged it had received a proposal to merge with Pirelli's tire business but did not clarify its position on Pirelli's bid for control of the operations. The concern would double Pirelli's market share to 16 percent from about 8 percent, with $9 billion in sales. The new group would rank fourth in the world tire market behind France's Michelin & Co. with 24 percent, Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co. of Akron, Ohio, with 19 percent and Japan's Bridgestone Tire Corp. at 17 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Chief Admits Goofs, Blames Self For Automaker's Problems
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, `By some. . . to CORRECT `vehicles' to `cars'; PICKS UP 7th graf, `During a. . .
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca blames himself for the No. 3 U.S. automaker's deterioration in recent years, particularly a botched effort to diversify and a failure to create more popular cars. ``I'm confessing my sins here,'' Iacocca was quoted as telling The Wall Street Journal in an interview published Monday. Iacocca, who turns 66 next month, is famous for salvaging Chrysler from near-bankruptcy at the end of the 1970s in what became a now-legendary comeback. But under Iacocca, Chrysler has weakened again, hurt by vigorous competition particularly from imports. Chrysler's sales have dropped nearly 17 percent this year vs. an industrywide decline of 5 percent. By some estimates, Chrysler will conclude 1990 as the fifth biggest seller of cars in the United States, behind Japan's Honda Motor Co. and Toyota Motor Corp., as well as its historical U.S. rivals, General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. During a two-hour interview in his Highland Park, Mich., headquarters, Iacocca said he was determined to lead Chrysler through a second comeback. His major failing, he was quoted as saying, was trying to diversify Chrysler by expanding into the aerospace and defense businesses, a strategy that GM and Ford also undertook. He said Chrysler's effort led to the formation of a holding company that added a layer of bureaucracy and diverted the company from its main business of producing new vehicles. Chrysler is now shedding its non-auto businesses in an attempt to refocus on cars, but its current models are still largely derived from the 10-year-old K-car. ``If I made a mistake it was following other companies, and maybe those were grandiose schemes, Iacocca said. ``We didn't need a holding company. That's what made us top-heavy.'' To shore up its finances, Chrysler has undertaken a large-scale cost reduction program, including the closing of one third of its assembly plants in the past three years. Iacocca has ordered $2.5 billion in reductions to be made by the middle of next year.
