DOC.HEAD: First-Quarter Earnings Up 12.7 Percent
DOC.TEXT: General Mills Inc. said Monday that profits in its first-quarter rose 12.7 percent as the food and restaurant company showed growth in sales of baking goods, cereals and snacks. Net income for the quarter ended Aug. 26 were $129.5 million, or $1.58 a share, up from $114.9 million, or $1.39 a share, in the 1989 same period. Sales grew 16 percent to $1.74 billion from $1.50 billion a year earlier. The results included a $5.7 million gain from discontinued operations. In last year's first quarter, General Mills gained $7.7 million from discontinued operations. General Mills Chairman Bruce Atwater told shareholders at the company's annual meeting that he wants sales to triple by the year 2000 to more than $19 billion a year. Last year's sales were $6.4 billion. Separately, the company's board of directors approved a two-for-one stock split effective Oct. 10. Atwater said the company's consumer foods division reported first-quarter gains in sales and operating profits of 15 percent and 18 percent, respectively. The performance was led by Betty Crocker products, Big G cereals and international food operations. Betty Crocker benefited from volume gains of 11 percent for desserts, 14 percent for Hamburger Helper and other main meal mixes and more than 50 percent for various snack food categories, Atwater said. General Mills' share of the $7 billion retail ready-to-eat cereal market increased to more than 28 percent, he said. Restaurants reported first-quarter gains in sales and operating profits of 18 percent and 15 percent, respectively. Average unit sales increased 4 percent at Red Lobster and 6 percent at The Olive Garden, Atwater said.

DOC.HEAD: Tisch Brothers Increase Stake in Another Bank
DOC.TEXT: CBS Inc. chief Laurence A. Tisch and his brother, Loews Corp. executive Preston R. Tisch, said Monday they have acquired 9.9 percent in the parent company of Bank of Boston. The brothers, along with other Tisch family members, said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing they have paid a total of $6.96 million for 772,400 Bank of Boston Corp. shares since Aug. 3 at prices between $8 and $10 per share. The filing also said that either of the brothers or an entity they control may seek Federal Reserve Board approval to acquire more shares, raising the total under their control to 14.9 percent. Last month the Tisch brothers disclosed they had acquired sizeable stakes in three other bank holding companies: 9.5 percent of Baybanks Inc., of Boston; 6.8 percent of Equimark Corp., of Pittsburgh; and 5.6 percent of Chicago-based Continental Bank Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Fraud Trail of 10 Soybean Traders Begins
DOC.TEXT: Greed motivated 10 Chicago Board of Trade soybean traders to cheat their customers, a federal prosecutor said Monday at the third fraud and racketeering trial stemming from an FBI probe. ``The conduct of these traders is regulated to ensure that their customers from around the world are treated honestly,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Tom Durkin said in opening arguments. ``Before you is a group of people who decided to play by their own rules.'' The trial follows the indictment of a clerk and 18 soybean traders after a 1988 FBI investigation that also covered the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The clerk and other eight traders have pleaded guilty. At least five defendants who have admitted guilt are scheduled to testify in the trial along with an undercover agent who taped conversations in the trading pit while posing as a trader, Durkin said in court. ``They were confident they wouldn't get caught,'' Durkin told the jury before U.S. District Judge George Marovich. ``They broke the rules to make money that they are not honestly entitled to.'' Prosecutors used large placards to explain to the jury where the alleged crimes occurred. Visual aids also were used to describe how soybean futures are traded. The soybean traders are among 48 people indicted last fall at the world's two largest futures exchanges. Twenty avoided trial by pleading guilty and one by pleading no contest. Fourteen Japanese yen traders from the Chicago Mercantile Exchange are being tried before U.S. District Judge William T. Hart. That trial opened last week. In the first trial resulting from the investigation, a jury in July convicted two Swiss franc traders from the Merc of relatively minor trading violations and acquitted a third. The jury could not reach verdicts on scores of more serious charges, including a racketeering count against one of the three defendants. The men are to be tried again on those charges next year.

DOC.HEAD: Interest Rates Fall
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities fell in Monday's auction to their lowest level in six weeks. The Treasury Department sold $9.2 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.39 percent, down from 7.41 percent last week. Another $9.2 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.30 percent, down from 7.34 percent last week. The rates were the lowest since Aug. 6, when three-month bills sold for 7.23 percent and six-month bills averaged 7.19 percent. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors - 7.64 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,813.20 and 7.69 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,630.90. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, inched up to 7.75 percent last week from 7.74 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Media Groups Join To Acquire East German Publisher
DOC.TEXT: West Germany's Bertelsmann media group has teamed up with British publisher Robert Maxwell to take over East Germany's largest newspaper and magazine publishing group. Gruener and Jahr publishers, of which Bertelsmann owns 75 percent, and Maxwell's Mirror Group signed an agreement Friday to acquire Berliner Verlag. The deal must be approved by an East German government commission. The commission is responsible for sales of assets formerly owned by East Germany's Communist party, Gruener and Jahr spokesman Kristoph Keese said. The acquisition was first discussed in June after Maxwell announced interest in acquiring the East German publisher and said he wanted a West German partner. East Germany and West Germany are to unite on Oct. 3. The agreement calls for Gruener and Jahr and Maxwell each to pay 50 percent of the costs of the takeover. The spokesman said the price was between $160 million and $180 million. The West German company is to be the managing partner in the joint venture, with Maxwell or one of his representatives serving as chairman of supervisory board. Gruener and Jahr is a major West German publisher of newspapers and magazines. A Maxwell spokesman said in London that the stake in Berliner Verlag is being acquired by Maxwell's family-owned Mirror Group. Among the group's publications are Britain's Daily Mirror newspaper. Bertelsmann is West Germany's largest media group, second in the world only to Time Warner Inc. of the United States. The two newspapers and six magazines published by Berliner Verlag are some of the most important publications in East Germany, Keese said. They include the Berliner Zeitung morning newspaper, with a circulation of 420,000; its evening edition, Berliner Zeitung am Abend, circulation 135,000; and the weekly newspaper Die Wochenpost, circulation 52,000. Circulation of its six magazines, which include a women's journal, a weekly illustrated, and travel and culture publications, exceeds 630,000. Separately, Munich-based Burda GmbH said it is considering launching a newspaper in East Germany. Burda said it plans to form a joint-venture with News International, the media group operated by Australian publisher Rupert Murdoch.

DOC.HEAD: Strike Paralyzes Romanian Shipping
DOC.TEXT: About 25,000 shipping industry workers went on strike Monday in the Black Sea port of Constanta, bringing most of Romania's sea shipping to a halt. The strike included ship workers, navigators, dock workers and drivers employed by area transport services. Strikers claim a government program announced in June promising higher wages, better working conditions and speedy decentralization of industry was being impeded by government bureaucrats and local officials. Adrian Tanase, an attorney and union leader of the port workers, said the strike would continue indefinitely. He said the navigators' union sent a telegram Monday telling all Romanian ships worldwide to stop loading or unloading cargo. The Transport Ministry said the walkout was unjustified because most of the demands have been discussed with the government and are being studied by authorities. The ministry said that among the original demands made by the unions in talks with government last week were relaxed import rights for seamen to bring in cars, video equipment and other luxury goods tax free into Romania. President Ion Iliescu met with several union leaders Monday. The main unions involved in the strike demanded the dismissal and punishment of administrators who have not been able to carry out the government's promises to workers. Port workers demanded that the port be turned over to private hands, that safety standards be adhered to and that customs laws be changed to make it easier to import goods. The unions also demanded a share of an estimated $215 million worth of property formerly belonging to the pre-revolutionary trade union confederation in Romania, which was reorganized shortly after the revolution. The striking unions, which have sprung up since and are not represented in the national council, are demanding $50 million worth of the property. The navigators' union also ordered strikes in other port towns of Galati, Braila, Tulcea and Sulina, Tanase said.

DOC.HEAD: Kansas City Utility Extends Hostile Takeover Bid
DOC.TEXT: Kansas City Power & Light Co. on Monday extended its $857 million cash takeover offer for Kansas Gas and Electric for one month. The utility said Kansas Gas & Electric shareholders had tendered about 13.55 million shares, or 44 percent of the company's common stock, by last Friday's deadline. The new deadline is Oct. 19. Spokeswoman Joele Frank said the number of shares tendered was smaller than a month earlier. But she said the number of outstanding shares also had declined. Kansas City Power & Light made its offer July 23 at $27 per share for a total cost of $857 million. The utility said the offer was a premium of 37 percent over the market price of Kansas Gas & Electric common stock. Kansas Gas & Electric recently began negotiations with an unidentified company that might be interested in acquiring it.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Information Service Planned
DOC.TEXT: Farmland Industries Inc. said Monday it planned to offer a national satellite network for farmers to get the latest agricultural news and statistics. Farmland will join the Illinois Farm Bureau and Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc. in the venture, expected to be available by early next year. Subscribing farmers would get a satellite dish and a monitor to carry information on commodity prices, market news, weather, agronomic updates, and crop and livestock reports. The 30-inch dish and monitor will not be capable of carrying other commercial channels. Kansas City-based Farmland is one of the nation's largest farm supply and marketing cooperatives.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market made little progress Monday, restrained by rising oil prices and other inflation worries. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which had fallen 55.44 points last week, rose 3.22 to 2,567.33. But declining issues outnumbered advances by about 9 to 8 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 681 up, 768 down and 508 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 110.60 million shares, against 133.39 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 136.06 million shares. Crude-oil futures for October delivery climbed $1.87 a barrel to $33.63 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, reaching new highs for their summer-long upsurge. Analysts said that intensified investors' worries about inflation and the showdown in the Persian Gulf since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. More evidence of the inflationary consequences of rising oil prices is expected on Tuesday, when the government reports on the consumer price index for August. Analysts estimate that the CPI will post an increase of 0.8 percent to 1 percent, for its biggest monthly increase since January. With energy costs continuing to advance, there isn't much hope at present for any better news on inflation over at least the next month or two. Energy stocks were broadly higher. Atlantic Richfield gained 1} to 141|; Amoco 1[ to 58]; Chevron 1} to 77|; Exxon \ to 51|; Phillips Petroleum { to 29\, and Texaco ~ to 65]. Among oil service and drilling issues, Halliburton rose 1\ to 55~; Schlumberger \ to 66{; Parker Drilling } to 8}, and Baker Hughes { to 33. Depressed bank stocks, by contrast, continued to struggle. Chemical Banking fell } to 19{; Chase Manhattan } to 15~; Banc One 1[ to 22, Barnett Banks 1\ to 21, and Manufacturers Hanover [ to 25|. In the blue-chip industrial sector, International Business Machines rose } to 105[ and Philip Morris edged up [ to 44~, but Boeing dropped { to 45|; General Electric slipped { to 59, and General Motors was down ] at 37[. Barden Corp. jumped 30{ to 63 in the over-the-counter market. The company said it agreed to be acquired by FAG Bearings for $66.50 a share. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $6.25 billion, or 0.21 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained .47 to 174.62. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 1.23 to 375.83, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 0.94 at 317.77. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market dipped .31 to 374.11. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 321.71, up .26.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Gold Rises
DOC.TEXT: The dollar continued to slide Monday as traders anticipated a move by the the Federal Reserve to push U.S. interest rates lower. Gold prices advanced. The market expected the Fed, facing growing evidence of a slowing economy, to nudge down interest rates when negotiators reach agreement on $50 billion in federal budget cuts, said Ronald H. Holzer, vice president and chief dealer with Harris Trust & Co. Little progress was reported from the budget talks in Washington on Monday, but the market anticipated an eventual agreement. The dollar - like all other currencies - is supported by higher interest rates. When traders sense that rates are likely to fall in the United States, they sell dollars. The U.S. currency has fallen sharply in recent few months amid continuing signs of economic weakness. The Persian Gulf crisis has also taken a heavy toll on the dollar. Holzer said the dollar also fell on expectations of a widening in the U.S. trade deficit. The Commerce Department was releasing the July trade figures Tuesday, while the Labor Department was announcing consumer price figures for August. The dollar did manage a slight gain against the Japanese yen, rising to 136.55 yen in New York from late Friday's 136.45. In Tokyo earlier, the dollar rose to a closing 137.00 Japanese yen from 136.55 yen at Friday's close. Later, in London, it was quoted at 136.47 yen. But the dollar skidded against the British pound, which has been boosted in part by higher interest rates. Sterling rose to $1.9140 in New York from $1.8930 late Friday. In London, the pound rose to $1.9025 from $1.8980 late Friday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.54865 German marks, down from 1.5695; 1.2768 Swiss francs, down from 1.2990; 5.1870 French francs, down from 5.2565; 1,160.00 Italian lire, down from 1,171.75; and 1.15725 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16505. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday's levels were: 1.5575 German marks, down from 1.5625; 1.2865 Swiss francs, down from 1.2910; 5.2160 French francs, down from 5.2305; 1.7550 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7605; 1,165.00 Italian lire, down from 1,166.00; and 1.1593 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1648. Gold rose in New York, climbing $4.30 on the Commodity Exchange to close at $389.40 a troy ounce. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $390.50, up $4.75. Gold rose in London to a late bid of $389.75 a troy ounce from $385.25 late Friday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $389 from $385 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.41 to close at a bid of $387.37. Although prices rose, gold dealers in Zurich said the market's mood remained depressed, particularly because gold appears unable to move higher despite higher oil prices, a weaker dollar and little excitement on major equities markets. At the same time, a belief that gold could surge if hostilities begin in the Middle East is keeping the metal from dropping sharply, traders said. Silver rose in New York, gaining 1.6 cents to close at $4.766 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange. But earlier in London, silver fell to a late bid of $4.78 a troy ounce from $4.79 late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Posts Strong Gain as Crude Oil Futures Hit Record High
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices rose strongly Monday on New York's Commodity Exchange as fears of tightening oil supplies pushed crude oil futures to record highs, spurring some investors to buy gold as an inflation hedge. But precious metal analysts said gold's gains were relatively small compared with the advance in energy prices, suggesting the historical relationship between the two markets has changed. On other commodity markets, livestock and meat futures rose sharply, soybeans fell and grain futures advanced. Gold futures settled $4.20 to $4.30 higher in New York with the spot September contract at $389.40 a troy ounce and the more actively traded contract for delivery in October at $390.60 a troy ounce. Silver futures ended 1.6 cents to 1.9 cents higher with September at $4.766 a troy ounce. The rally extended to five days a runup in gold prices following a $10.90 plunge in the September contract on Sept. 10. The contract now has regained all but 10 cents of that amount. John Jonat, a precious metals trader with Deak International Inc., said traders are focuing more on a perception that higher oil prices and the military buildup in Saudi Arabia will send the U.S. economy into a recession than the inflationary implications of higher oil prices. ``I don't think the old relationships ... are really in effect any more,'' ``I don't see huge investment demand for gold right now coming to the rescue. I don't think people are rushing in to buy it again.'' In the absence of significant developments in the Persian Gulf standoff, talk of a possible shortfall in Soviet crude exports supported crude oil futures on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Crude also was supported by President Bush's statement that he saw no need to draw supplies from America's strategic oil reserves, said Jim Ritterbusch, an energy analyst with PaineWebber Inc. Light, sweet crude oil futures settled 32 cents to $1.87 higher with the October contract at $33.63 a barrel, eclipsing the previous closing high of $32.35 on Aug. 2, 1983. Cash crude prices reached nearly $40 a barrel in 1980. Wholesale heating oil futures settled .90 cent to 2.67 cents higher with October at 85.31 cents a gallon; wholesale unleaded gasoline was 1.31 cents to 1.94 cents higher with October at 91.67 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures rose sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, led by limit gains of 2 cents a pound in the pork belly market amid reports of higher cash hog prices and strong demand for pork products. Trading volume in the cattle pits is expected to drop during the next two days ahead of a monthly Agriculture Department on Wednesday. The report is expected to show about a 4 percent increase over a year ago in the number of cattle on feedlots in the seven largest producing states. Live cattle settled .30 cent to .75 cent higher with October at 79.37 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .25 cent to .80 cent higher with September at 89.17 cents a pound; live hogs were .33 cent to 1.13 cents higher with October at 53 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 2 cents higher across the board with February at 56.65 cents a pound. Soybean futures prices fell on the Chicago Board of Trade in a move that some analysts attributed to weather forecasts and slow export demand and others to a technical correction after last week's gains. Corn and wheat futures rose moderately, reversing the trend of the three previous sessions. After the close, a weekly USDA report showed 5 percent of the U.S. corn crop and 1 percent of the soybean crop harvested as of Sunday, which is slightly behind the normal pace. Wheat futures settled 1} cents to 4 cents higher with September at $2.61 a bushel; corn was 1\ cents to 3 cents higher with September at $2.35} a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 2{ cents higher with September at $1.09\ a soybeans were } cent to 9 cents lower with September at $6.15{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Shares Rise From Lows To End Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Share prices closed mixed Monday after erasing early losses on the back of a good opening on Wall Street and a late buying spurt in London. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed up 0.5 point, or 0.002 percent, at 2,094.3. Volume was 286.6 million shares, well below Friday's 418 million shares.

DOC.HEAD: Top $33 Per Barrel for New Record
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Heightened uncertainty in the Mideast propelled oil futures prices up almost $2 a barrel Monday to nearly $34, shattering the previous record and leaving traders wondering where the market was headed next. ``Obviously, you've got a lot of tension building up again,'' said trader Ed Kevelson with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Speculators in the influential oil-futures market said they believed tensions were higher because of anti-American demonstrations in Baghdad and concerns that pro-Iraqi terrorists might try to sneak through Kuwait into Saudi Arabia, where the United States and allies have amassed a large military force. Light sweet crude, the benchmark grade of oil on the New York Mercantile Exchange, hit an all-time high of $33.75 a barrel for October-delivery contracts before settling at $33.63 a barrel, $1.87 higher than Friday's close. The Monday price broke the previous record of $32.35 set Aug. 2, 1983, which was matched one time during the current oil crisis on Aug. 23. Other contract months were all higher. Oil's rise to the futures record was greeted calmly by traders who have grown accustomed to wild price swings since Iraq invaded Kuwait last month, provoking world anxiety over the availability of oil. With October crude futures closing above $30 per barrel every day last week, some had been predicting that the old record was about to fall. ``I think the mood was `There goes that, so let's shoot for the next target,''' Kevelson said. ``If this lasts longer and longer, $40 is certainly not out of the question.'' William Byers, an analyst with Bear Stearns & Co. said oil's surge above $33 could spur confusion among investors, who may have to resort to trading on headlines. ``We're in uncharted territory,'' Byers said. ``You have no context to look at the market in.'' The cash price of oil traded at about $40 per barrel on international markets during 1979, the last world oil jolt, but the Mercantile Exchange's records for crude date only to March 30, 1983, when the exchange first began offering oil futures contracts. Cash prices represent money paid for actual oil, while the futures prices represent a bet by traders on what oil will do based on future supply and demand. Soaring oil prices had a restraining effect on other financial markets Monday, putting a damper on stock prices and declines in bond prices. The dollar also continued its recent slide. Oil's strength helped bring up the futures prices of petroleum products, although they lagged crude. Home heating oil rose 2.52 cents to 85.31 cents per gallon on October contracts. Unleaded gasoline rose 1.31 cents to 91.67 cents per gallon on October contracts. Other delivery months were higher for both products. ``Heating oil was a little stronger, I think based on seasonal considerations,'' Byers said. Natural gas went up to $1.537 per 1,000 cubic feet on October contracts, compared with Friday's close of $1.520. Near months were higher, while later months were lower or the same. Analysts attributed some of crude oil's strength to higher prices for Brent Blend, a European oil that has been pushed up by a cutback of 70,000 barrels per day at a North Sea pipeline. The high price in Europe and strong opening in New York was also attributed to rumors of an unscheduled repair at a Soviet pipeline, but the rumors were denied by the Kremlin.

DOC.HEAD: Financial Printer Files for Chapter 11
DOC.TEXT: Pandick Inc., a printer of prospectuses, proxy materials and other financial documents, filed for bankruptcy court reorganization on Monday, becoming another casualty of a business slowdown on Wall Street. Pandick President James Alexis attributed the Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing to the ``steady deterioration'' of the financial markets since the October 1987 stock market crash. Alexis said in a statement that Pandick's business has dropped more than 50 percent over the past two years. During that time, the mergers and acquisition business has slowed dramatically and Wall Street firms have cut back sharply. The turmoil in the financial markets since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait further curtailed the company's business and worsened its problems, Alexis said. Pandick said it dismissed 725 of its 750 employees on Friday. It filed for protection from its creditors in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in New York. Asked whether the company would try to resume its business at some point, Pandick spokesman Fred Spar said: ``It's really impossible to speculate what will happen at this point.'' Pandick joined the ranks of other big financial printers that have foundered in recent years, including Charles P. Young Co. and Sorg Inc. Alexis said the company was unable to stay afloat although ``we took significant steps over the past two years to adjust to our changing environment, including the sale of non-core businesses, work-force reductions at all levels of the company and an infusion of additional equity from our ownership group.''

DOC.HEAD: Disney Dumps One-Hour TV Shows as Too Expensive
DOC.TEXT: The Walt Disney Co. is dissolving its department that makes one-hour television dramas, concluding that even popular shows will lose money at current production costs of $1.2 million per episode. Disney, which only recently became a significant producer of TV programming, will continue to make half-hour comedies, which can be sold as reruns more easily. The studio has spent heavily on writers of such comedies, giving several contracts of more than $1 million a year. But executives for dramatic development are being reassigned, although Disney will continue to produce one-hour ``Hull High'' and ``The Magical World of Disney'' segments for NBC. One or two other projects from the department also may survive, Disney executives said. Word of the decision leaked out after Disney officials began informing agents on Friday. Disney executives, speaking on condition of anonymity, confirmed the move Monday. Almost every television program is made at a deficit, as networks are unwilling to pay the full production price. The studios or independent producers absorb the deficit, hoping to recoup their losses through television reruns, foreign sales and occasional videocassettes. The market for one-hour shows both on the networks and in syndication has slowed in recent years, owing to the growing popularity of the situation comedy. A few one-hour programs - ``Hunter,'' for example - are money-makers. Disney's projections for the shows are so gloomy that the studio is giving up on them despite the prestige and leverage with the networks they can bring. ``The studios have been complaining about this for a long time,'' one Disney executive said. ``Certainly the unions and the guilds didn't believe it. Well, Disney is now saying: `Believe it.' '' A turning point was a show titled ``N.Y.P.D. Mounted,'' which CBS had ordered. After looking at projected revenue figures, Disney decided against producing the program, which is being taken over by Orion Pictures Corp. The decision to abandon hour-long TV shows was a difficult one for Disney chief Michael Eisner, whose background is in television. Disney spent heavily over the past two years to establish itself as a force in network programming for the first time. But a review of predicted revenues turned up bad news for one-hour dramas, which cost $1.2 million or more per episode because they are produced on film, with several cameras and location settings. Networks generally pay only $800,000 to $900,000 for the rights to broadcast each episode, and often less. TV stations have found that viewers prefer comedy reruns during the key 4 p.m.-8 p.m. time slots, so foreign sales must make up the difference. And even for a successful show, those bring in only $250 million to $300 million. ``Disney just simply couldn't make financial sense of it,'' the executive said. ``The numbers even in the half-hour area aren't great. But an hour show . . . even if it's a hit for five years, we can't make a profit.'' Disney made six one-hour pilots last year, of which two initially were picked up by the networks: ``Hull High,'' a high school musical, and ``Tag Team,'' about pro wrestlers-turned-cops, which ABC ordered and then dropped three months later. Disney has encountered similar difficulty with its local television station, KCAL-TV. Broadcasting a three-hour block of primetime news, KCAL has attracted sparse viewership and negative reviews.

DOC.HEAD: Turner Broadcasting Vet Named to Top Post at Whittle Communications
DOC.TEXT: A longtime top executive with Turner Broadcasting System Inc., Gerry F. Hogan, has resigned to become a vice chairman at Whittle Communications, Chairman Christopher Whittle announced Monday. Hogan, 44, has been associated with Turner Broadcasting founder Ted Turner for 19 years during which he helped Turner build one of the nation's most formidable cable television operations. Hogan has been president of Turner Entertainment Networks since November 1987, presiding over the 1988 launch of Turner Network Television, the largest startup network in the history of cable television. TNT started with 17 million subscribers and has since grown to 49.6 million subscribers, making it cable TV's fastest growing network as well. Hogan also was responsible for the operation of TBS SuperStation, the Atlanta-based television outlet that is the cornerstone for Turner's cable TV empire which also includes Cable News Network and CNN Headline News. Whittle described Hogan in the announcement as ``one of the most important influences in the development of cable television as a significant medium in the 1980s.'' Hogan worked his way up in Turner's organization, signing up in 1971 as an ad salesman for WTCG, the Atlanta station that became TBS SuperStation. In the past few years, he has been one of Turner's closest aides. ``Gerry has played an important role in the success of our company,'' Ted Turner said in a statement. ``We wish him well in his new endeavor.'' A spokesman for Turner Broadcasting said no decision has yet been made on Hogan's successor. Hogan's departure is the third major executive defection from Turner Broadcasting in the past 13 months. In August 1989, Robert J. Wussler, a senior executive vice president who had been with Turner for 10 years, resigned to head Comsat Video Enterprises, a Washington-based company investigating the use of Direct Broadcast Satellite technology to transmit programs directly to receivers in the home. Hogan joins another Turner executive, Farrell Reynolds, who joined Whittle in May as head of its educational division, which handles media properties designed for school use. Reynolds had been president of Turner Broadcasting Sales Inc. Whittle Communications is much smaller than Turner - its revenues amount to about $230 million compared with Turner's $1.2 billion. But Whittle is viewed as one of industry's innovators. Based in Knoxville, Tenn., and 50 percent owned by Time Warner Inc., Whittle specializes in creating out-of-home media that enable advertisers to reach precisely defined audiences. Whittle has developed, for instance, the commercially sponsored Channel One news show designed for use in high school classrooms, magazines developed specifically for doctor's waiting rooms, ad-sponsored posters that hang in school lobbies and medical waiting rooms and books with ads placed inside. At Whittle, Hogan will oversee five business areas: Whittle Private Media, Hispanic Media, American Style magazine for beauty parlors, Whittle Regional and Whittle International. In addition, he will head three confidential development projects. Hogan will be one of three vice chairman at Whittle, each reporting to founder Chris Whittle. The others are Alan Greenberg and Laura Eshbaugh. In a telephone interview, Hogan said felt he had ``taken it as far as I could take it'' with TBS and felt Whittle offered new challenges. ``You can't build new and exciting bsuinesses every day in a maturing industry,'' he said. At the same time, he said he felt he had assembled a strong management team at Turner Broadcasting that could continue its growth. In addition to his posts at the two Turner entertainment networks, Hogan had been responsible for the company's public relations, advertising and promotion and research departments, an in-house film production uinit and a publishing division. He had previously been vice president for advertising sales at TBS and was president of Turner Broadcasting Sales Inc., a wholly owned TBS susbidiary in charge of nationwide ad sales efforts for TBS, CNN and Headline News. Although Whittle Communications has attracted increasing attention in recent years, the company actually will celebrate its 20th anniversary later this year. It employs 1,000 people.

DOC.HEAD: Europeans Warn Vote in Congress Threatens World Trade Talks
DOC.TEXT: A spokesman for 12 major European countries warned Congress on Monday that passing a bill to limit U.S. imports could threaten world talks aimed at increasing trade and cutting subsidies to farmers. A House vote was scheduled for Tuesday. The bill would limit the increase of imports of shoes, clothes and other textiles to 1 percent a year. Supporters said it would halt a loss of jobs and business in this country. Opponents maintained it would show the United States to be unwilling to join a freer world trade system. Andreas van Agt, ambassador of the European Comunity, said passage of the legislation ``would be tantamount to eliminating all prospects of progress in this area and, even worse, will jeopardize negotiations not just in textiles but in all other areas.'' Over 100 countries are taking part in trade negotiations that began in 1986 in Uruguay. The United States and the Europeans are considered the most important negotiators, though a deal will not be possible without Japan and Third World countries. A year-end deadline has been set for agreement, though Congress has given the Bush administration power to negotiate until March 1991. Negotiators for the first time since world trade talks began after World War II are dealing with farm subsidies, services such as banking and air travel and ``intellectual property'' such as books, patents and computer programs. These industries now provide many more jobs in the United States and other industrial countries than the production of traded goods addressed in previous trade talks. The hope is to increase the current $4 trillion worth of international trade every year and to reduce the $250 billion that subsidies to farmers are estimated to cost taxpayers and consumers annually. President Bush has promised to veto the bill, as President Reagan vetoed two like it. But the Senate has enough votes to overturn a veto, though some senators could change sides after a veto vote is issued. ``Passage of this bill would disrupt negotiations on rules necessary to protect all U.S. industries from unfair trade practices,'' Michael J. Boskin, chairman of Bush's Council of Economic Advisers wrote in a letter to Congress. Secretary of State James A. Baker III added in a letter of his own that the bill would violate agreements of the United States with countries supporting it in the Gulf crisis.

DOC.HEAD: General Motors Plans $1 Billion for Car Parts Division
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. said it plans to spend $1 billion in Europe over the next five years to expand industrial capacity and research and development for its car parts division. The investment by the U.S. carmaker's Automotive Components Group will include building several new production facilities in Europe, said Mark McCabe, the group's European president. The money also will be used to modernize the division's 49 existing plants in Europe, McCabe said. GM expects the European market for car parts to grow from around $60 billion at present to $100 billion by the year 2000, he said. The forecast assumes that new car sales in Western Europe will rise by 700,00 from 1990 levels to 14.2 million cars a year by 1995. Eastern European demand could add another 3.5 million cars. Europeans are demanding extras like power steering and air conditioning presently sold on only a small proportion of cars in Europe, he said. Manufacturers, meanwhile, tend to rely more on components made by outside suppliers. New European Community emission standards taking effect in 1991 will boost demand for fuel injection systems, catalytic converters and other emission control, McCabe said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Issues Injunction Against Voit Sports for Patent Infringement
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge barred Voit Sports Inc. from selling its Grass Hopper golf bag, saying it is too similar to the Eclipse bag sold by Sun Mountain Sports Inc. ``The great similarity between these two bags as well as (Voit's) own advertisement . . . strongly suggests the possibility of deliberate copying of plaintiff's product,'' U.S. District Judge Bruce Thompson said the injunction issued late Friday. Aside from blocking Voit from making or distributing the Grass Hopper bag, the judge ordered the company to deliver all unsold bags for destruction. Executives with New York-based Voit would not comment on the ruling when contacted Monday. Sun Mountain Sports, based in Missoula, Mont., began marketing its Eclipse golf bag in July 1986. The bag is characterized by its tilted stance and inside dividers designed to keep golf clubs separate and easily accessible. ``We've made golf bags for a long time, and our company really began to take off with the introduction of our Eclipse bag,'' said Eric Reimers, founder and president of Sun Mountain Sports, said Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Nike Reports Record Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Nike Inc. Monday reported a 31 percent increase in earnings on a 38 percent rise in revenues in the three months ended Aug. 31, despite Operation Push's call for a boycott. The Chicago-based civil rights group alleges Nike is not doing enough to help blacks. The Rev. Tyrone Crider, executive director of Operation Push and about 30 demonstrators interrupted the company's annual meeting Monday. The protesters recited a prayer that criticized the company's dealings with blacks. The group of almost 700 shareholders responded by chanting ``Nike, Nike, Nike . . . .'' After a few minutes, the group left the room, shouting, ``Say no to Nike.'' Net income for the first quarter ended Aug. 31 was $99.6 million or $2.62 a share, an increase of 31 percent from the $75.8 million, or $2.01 per share, earned during the same period last year. Revenues for the three months jumped 38 percent to $833.6 million, compared to $602.6 million the previous year. International revenues were up 89 percent. Revenues from domestic athletic footwear were up 31 percent, domestic apparel revenues 21 percent and non-athletic footwear revenues 20 percent. Knight said orders for athletic footwear and apparel exceed $1 billion for the first time. The orders, scheduled for delivery between September and January, are 42 percent higher than those taken during the same period last year. ``The 89 percent increase in international revenues solidly indicates that we are beginning to capitalize on the enormous opportunities in overseas markets,'' Knight said at the meeting. ``We see further worldwide growth ahead as evidenced by the 42 percent increase in futures orders for the next five months.''

DOC.HEAD: Kodak Introduces Photographs On Compact Discs
DOC.TEXT: Eastman Kodak Co. unveiled a product that allows snapshots to be stored on compact discs and played back on televisions. The Kodak Photo CD system digitally stores images from negatives or slides on compact discs. The pictures can then be shown on ordinary television or computer screens with a Photo CD player that also plays audio CDs. ``This is the answer for consumers who have wanted both the astonishing quality of 35 millimeter photography and the convenience of digital storage, display and manipulation. Users can enjoy traditional photographic quality, and view their pictures on TV,'' Kodak chairman and chief executive Kay Whitmore said in a statement. The system will not be available until 1992. Kodak said it made the announcement to give other manufacturers time to develop licensed products and software. Kodak introduced the Photo CD at a news conference in Tokyo Tuesday morning. The company planned news conferences later in the day in London, New York and Rochester. To use the system, film is first processed conventionally into negatives or slides. Each picture is then scanned and transferred into digital form, and the compressed digital image is written to a compact disc. Photo customers bringing film in to a photofinisher will have the option of ordering a photo CD along with their prints and negatives or slides, Kodak said. Unfilled discs can be returned to have more images added, creating ``electronic albums'' of up to 100 pictures. The digital pictures have the same resolution and color quality as a film image, according to Kodak officials. Because that resolution is 16 times greater than a regular television and four times greater than High Definition Television formats, the technology will not become obsolete for a long time, spokesman Paul Allen said. ``We believe this will set the standard for many years to come,'' Allen said. The CD player allows viewers to manipulate the picture on the television screen by zooming in, cropping a picture or shuffling the order. The company anticipates the Photo CD player will take the place of the slide projector for group viewing of photographs, Allen said. The system was developed jointly with Dutch consumer electronics company N.V. Philips, which owns most CD patents. The Photo CD players will be manufactured by Philips and will play either photographic or audio CDs. Kodak will manufacture the gold-colored photographic CDs, each capable of holding up to 100 images. The Photo CD player is expected to cost less than $500, and a Photo CD less than $20. The photofinishing system consists of a high-resolution film scanner made by Kodak, a computer work station and image processing software, a Philips-made discwriter and Kodak thermal printer. The processing system is expected to cost less than $100,000, and will be targeted at photofinishers and possibly even mini-labs, Allen said. The discs, which will be manufactured in Rochester, are compatible with computer CD-1 and CD ROM XA readers. Kodak officials said they expect software to be developed that will make the system compatible with most computers. The company expects other uses for the system to emerge in desktop publishing and other fields, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Paper to Continue Publishing After Guild Approves Offer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to ADD quote, deadline for employees to resign and get severance benefits, union official declining to estimate how many might resign, background on paper's financial troubles. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY32
DOC.TEXT: The scrappy New York Post, colorful chronicler of a troubled city, survived its own brush with extinction Monday after its biggest union agreed to concessions to save the publisher money. Members of the Newspaper Guild, representing 350 editorial, advertising and clerical employees, voted 242-45 to approve concessions including eliminating dozens of jobs and cutting the workweek to four days with a 20 percent pay cut. A last-minute sweetener offered by Publisher Peter S. Kalikow would boost severence pay for those who agree to resign. Kalikow had said he would close the nation's oldest continuously published daily and put nearly 1,000 people out of work if the Guild rejected the offer. ``Let's go to press,'' Kalikow said after the vote. ``This is not a management victory,'' he added. ``It is not a labor victory. It is a victory for all New Yorkers who deserve the honesty and diversity offered in the pages of the New York Post.'' The Guild was the last of the paper's 11 unions to reach agreement with Kalikow on a total package of $27 million in cost cuts. The vote followed a 90-minute meeting punctuated by boos, applause, and speeches. ``You feel like the executioner has loosened the noose,'' said Jill Brooke, who reports on TV and radio issues. ``But we still have a life sentence: a 20 percent pay cut.'' ``We accepted a package that none of us liked, we accepted a package that made no sense to any of us and we accepted a package that makes us less than middle class,'' said reporter Peter Moses, who nonetheless voted for approval. ``We went from the outhouse to the tree.'' Editor Jerry Nachman said he was overwhelmed by gratitude. ``They have taken a great sacrifice in order to preserve their careers in New York journalism, their colleagues' careers and an important New York institution,'' Nachman said. Union members said sentiment swung in favor of the plan Monday afternoon when Kalikow offered to ``buy out'' those who agreed to resign. The publisher said employees could approve the plan, then resign by Wednesday night and receive the same termination and severance pay as if the paper were shut down. Some employees had argued earlier that they might be better off voting against the deal and taking the severance and termination money that would come with the newspaper folding. ``That takes away the principal reason for a no vote,'' metropolitan editor John Cotter said of the sweetened offer before Monday night's meeting. Theodore Kheel, an adviser to the unions, also said the Post would not stick to its requirement that 43 jobs be severed, but would settle for whatever number of resignations were forthcoming. At a news conference after the vote, Guild president Barry Lipton said he didn't know how many would resign. Kalikow also has promised the unions 20 percent of the company's stock and a representative on the board of directors. Kalikow said he had to have the union concessions to cut back on losses now running at about $27 million on an annual basis. He is believed to have lost more than $100 million personally on the paper. By Friday night, negotiators for the Post's 10 other unions had reached agreement with the company. The Guild's negotiating committee rejected Kalikow's offer 7-3, but local president Barry Lipton endorsed it and had it put up to a vote of the members. The package includes about $19 million in union concessions and $8 million in other cost reductions, including management wage cuts. Monday's front page asked: ``WILL THE POST PRESSES EVER RUN AGAIN?'' On the street before the vote, New Yorkers thought about life without the city's feistiest tabloid. ``I love the Post. I don't like to see it go,'' said Joseph Yedid. But he sympathized with Kalikow: ``This is New York. You always look out for your own interests.'' The Post was founded in 1801 by Alexander Hamilton and a group of merchants. The paper had money troubles from the start, but its fortunes seemed to have dimmed for good in the 1970's as much of its audience moved to the suburbs. Australian media baron Rupert Murdoch took over in 1976 and transformed the Post from a liberal into a politically conservative tabloid, albeit one that featured sexy pictures, racy headlines - like the famous ``HEADLESS BODY IN TOPLESS BAR'' - and lots of crime stories. Murdoch said the paper lost $150 million before he sold it in 1988 for $37 million to Kalikow, a real estate developer who also acquired the paper's valuable waterfront land on South Street in lower Manhattan. Under Kalikow, the paper has never made money and suffered heavy lossess on an ill-fated Sunday edition launched for a brief period in 1989. Recently, the slump has deepened as an economic decline in the New York City further cut advertising revenues.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Keating, Other Former Top Lincoln S&L Officials, Indicted
DOC.TEXT: Charles Keating Jr., former head of Lincoln Savings and Loan, has been indicted in connection with the sale of junk bonds issued by the failed Irvine-based thrift, according to a report broadcast Monday. Keating, former head of Lincoln and its parent company, American Continental Corp. of Phoenix, was to be arraigned Tuesday morning in Superior Court on charges of criminal fraud, KCBS-TV reported, citing unidentified sources. The businessman was indicted in connection with Lincoln's sale of more than $200 million in now virtually worthless junk bonds to 22,000 investors, many of whom were elderly, according to the report. The indictment would represent the first criminal charges in the Lincoln case. Numerous civil lawsuits have been filed. District Attorney Ira Reiner declined to confirm the report, but issued a statement saying his office had completed its presentation to a special grand jury investigating the matter. ``Since grand jury proceedings are confidential, the district attorney's office will not comment until such time the court lifts the seal of confidentiality,'' the statement from Reiner's office said. The grand jury began investigating in February whether Lincoln officials misled bond buyers into believing the high-risk bonds were federally insured. The district attorney had been presenting evidence since April. The government seized control of Lincoln in April 1989. Regulators estimate the bailout could cost taxpayers as much as $2 billion. Federal and state prosecutors also were not in their offices. Last month, a federal judge in Washington upheld the government takeover of Lincoln, saying the operation of the thrift by Keating and others ``amounted to looting.'' On Monday night, Shirley Lampel, one of the disaffected bondholders, responded to the report of the indictment, saying: ``I don't know how many bondholders are out there . . . but they're dancing in the street tonight. ``We'd like to get our money back,'' she added. U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin dismissed Keating's suit to recover the collapsed thrift and said it was ``abundantly clear'' Keating and other officials abused their positions. Keating could not immediately be reached for comment. The Los Angeles-and Chicago-based attorneys representing Keating were not in their offices after business hours. Under a recent agreement announced by the Justice Department, Keating must tell the Office of Thrift Supervision 48 hours in advance of any transactions exceeding $5,000. Keating already has provided financial statements, which have not been disclosed. Those terms had previously been imposed on Keating by a preliminary injunction issued by the U.S. District Court in Los Angeles. The announcement indicated he had agreed to them.

DOC.HEAD: More Air Fares Rise to Pay for Higher Fuel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CORRECT total increase to 9.72 percent
DOC.TEXT: Trans World, Northwest and United joined other major airlines Monday in imposing an additional 4.2 percent fare increase that will raise domestic tickets by a total of 9.72 percent since Iraq invaded Kuwait. The higher rates go into effect on Oct. 1 as airlines try to recoup some of the extra money spent on jet fuel, which has risen by about 50 percent since the Aug. 2 invasion. Last month, airlines boosted domestic fares by 5.3 percent to partially offset the higher fuel costs. The latest round of increases bring the industry's major players to the same levels of higher fares. TWA spokesman Jim Faulkner said airlines will not be able to recover all of the costs they have absorbed recently, as passengers have used up old, cheaper tickets while flying on planes that used the more expensive jet fuel. Airlines were unsure whether they will be catching up with the higher costs once the higher rates go into effect. ``That's beyond our speculative abilities, because it requires seeing into the brain of Saddam Hussein and we don't have that capability,'' Northwest spokesman Bob Gibbons said. The second wave of fare increases was begun by Pan Am, which announced a 4.4 percent increase on top of its earlier increase. Airlines that responded last week with announcements of additional 4.2 percent fare increases included American, America West, USAir, Delta and Eastern.
